I really recommend this game !
Only downside is that there is only one "way" of 3 bosses but this is early access, there will be more in the future and this isn't a big deal as each bosses are challenging even after a lot of hours !

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn is a wonderful FPS rogue-lite, with a satisfying game play loop that makes every run feel impactful thanks to its upgrade system. Each world is broken into 5 levels, 4 where you fight both normal and elite enemies, and 1 boss level. The levels themselves are procedurally generated, but the boss fights are always the same. At the end of each level, including after killing the boss, you get an upgrade that will allow you to put a point in one of 3 randomly selected character talents, which improve your abilities or add new properties to your abilities.

Pros:
-Gun play feels great, and mostly all feel unique. There are the obvious archetypes here (like a rocket launcher or a 3 burst assault rifle), but there are some unique guns too (like an automatic rifle that stores crits as energy for an alt fire that shoots rockets, or a weapon that looks like Zarya's gravity gun and shoots a gravity well like her ult, if you are familiar with Over Watch).
-Deaths don't feel cheap. While you can die very quickly in this game, I've yet to experience a death that felt like I had no control. Every death felt like I made a mistake.
-Killing enemies sometimes, and bosses always, drop soul essence, which allows you to upgrade both a general talent tree, as well as a smaller character specific talent line. Eventually, you can get a talent that allows you to bank a number of essence, meaning even a run where you get killed in the first level can have an impact on your progression.
-3 difficult modes, with rewards scaling to meet the increased challenge.
-Currently, 3 characters that each have a very different skill set, and a few different play styles based on how you upgrade after each level. The cat has abilities that lock down enemies, the dog dual wields and throws grenades, and the bird uses close range physical abilities to deal high damage and heal himself.

Cons:
-Early access, so there are some bugs. The majority I've come across are enemies having issues with path finding, though I have had some times where an enemy has just stopped doing anything.
-Controller settings are way too sensitive, and you can't bind to either stick click (R3/L3), so you have to take your thumb off the right stick in order to jump/dash/reload/change weapon. Obviously, M+K users won't have to worry about this.
-There are only 3 worlds, you always fight them in the same order, and the boss fights don't change as the difficulty increases other than they have more health. If you don't like repetition, you won't like the game in its current state.
-Due to the language barrier of the devs being from Hong Kong (and some times the formatting of the text box), there are some confusing translations on scroll and ability explanations.
-Game does not do a very good job of explaining some of the more high level ways of play, like how combining 2 of the 3 status effects (shock, fire, decay) can produce a more powerful effect (example: mixing shock and fire causes the afflicted enemy to be mind controlled for a short period, where they will attack and pull aggro from other enemies)
-Enemy AI isn't exactly great, and certain enemies can be kited in such a way that they can never hurt you while you kill them.
-Some elite enemies that appear in vaults can be a bit tanky, taking a lot of ammo to kill.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Good game. The mix of Risk of Rain 2 and Borderlands 2 I never knew I wanted. There's not much yet, but what has been presented is great and can only get better. Plus it has CO-OP.

The Cat plays like the Siren; all elemental stuff and AOE control.
The Dog is the Gunzerker if the Gunzerker could also spec into explosions.  
The Bird plays like the Doom Slayer (and is my favorite); kicking and cleaving to restore armor while in the midst of a firefight.

review:
Thanks but i don't get it. I suck at rogue games, I'm at 6 hours playing and still can't defeat the first big boss. I hardly find anything in this game that helps to win.  I know it ain't supposed to be easy, but i do hope they make changes to the game. No tutorial,Movement is too slow, dash, not a big help, scrolls and whatever else seem to be useless, you lose all money and essence that you don't or just can't spend, 1 essence less than enough to upgrade, well you lose it, no carry over or saving what you earn in money or essence. So the game is fun but you try hard to win just to lose what you earn { not a great incentive } to keep playing to try and win. I know it's early access but a lot of changes/improvements are needed for me to recommend or continue playing. I'm sure i'll get laughed at and picked on for 6 hours and can't beat the first big boss, so go ahead get it out but i am reading help guides since there's no kind of tutorial, just found out you can save and heal yourself in between stages, if that's true, the game has no help at all in tutorials. If you're good at rogue games get this you just might enjoy it, me, i'm learning.

Now 15 hours level 21 and still can't beat the first boss, i must be a fool. 
PLEASE ADD A DETAILED TUTORIAL TO HELP PEOPLE LIKE ME THAT MAY NOT UNDERSTAND HOW TO ACTUALLY GET THROUGH THIS GAME. I'm new at these rogue games but this game looked really fun and it is. I've played over 15 hours and made it to the first boss 3 times and died quick. I know I'm  not good yet but is the first boss supposed to be this hard ? We should not have to lean on the forums or youtube to learn how to use certain  weapons on certain characters or what all the pickups are or why i get the same power ups 3 times and they're still level 1, PLEASE EXPLAIN ALL THIS IN THE GAME, HOW HARD IS IT TO DO THAT ? You do want this game to succeed right ? Don't just throw it out there with no help included. Over 15 hours on the same what ? First 4 or 5 levels , please tell me ,is it just me ?

The game is still in early access, yet is already highly replayable with a large array of weapons and "occult scrolls", which are ability and perk generating items. title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Great feeling FPS that scratches the Borderlands loot-itch and also gives you the rogue-like feeling of progression when you're able to surpass your previous attempts. I almost gave up after the first few hours, especially when I kept dying at the first boss and was losing hard-won Souls (progression currency). However, after getting the perk that allows you to "Bank" them it allows you to feel like you are progressing even if you aren't getting any further. Perhaps we should start with that.

After a certain point, the game just "clicks" and you become powerful enough to breeze through the early stages. For me, it was getting the Bird character. I never liked the other two but once I got the Bird (short range, melee focused) it became incredibly fun. Also knowing the guns and perks helps.

Met a couple of hacked characters (max rank but didn't know gameplay basics). That's not the game's fault. Overall, a fantastic roguelike FPS and I can't wait for content patches and new characters.

Fun guns and nice pacing.  Difficult but fair. 

I have no negative comments with the glaring exception of the platform "puzzles".  I'm not sure why this is in here.  It completely disrupts the flow of gameplay, they aren't in any way fun or interesting, and the engine and look of the game is incredibly poorly suited to this type of activity you can't reliably tell what you can jump on and what you can't.  Maybe somewhere there is someone who would enjoy this but seriously they should just be playing portal or a game actually designed for this sort of thing.  If the developers for some bizarre reason insist on keeping this in the game why not just make it so you can toggle the platform parts on or off when you start a game?

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Played my 2 hours and refunded. I dont see the hype. The guns feel good Ill admit that and hitting headshots with the "ping" sound is satisfying but thats about it. The levels are tiny ...and I mean TINY, theres barely any room to maneuver, and since the game is kinda "hard", youll die a lot which is normal. The thing is though, that because you die so much, youll ALWAYS have to redo the same first tiny level, with barely any variety in its design and kill the same mobs over and over again with the same first default gun...rinse and repeat. 

The power difference between the first biome and the second is just overwhelming. I beat the first boss at level 5 or something, appeared in the desert biome and couldnt even kill the first mob there because they overpowered me so much. So I died, used my soulstones I had to barely upgrade one trait that I could afford, a whopping +x normal ammo or special ammo ...I dont remember.

I dont feel my character is getting more powerful fast enough, especially seeing how easily I got killed at the 2nd biome. Some guns are weak, others are way overpowered, I never really missed ammo so I dont see why there is such an emphasise on upgrading the amount available as character upgrade. 

Oh and you lose any unspent Soulstones after you go back to the inn so ...in practice, if all your potential new trait costs 50 and you only ended up with 49 during your run, you lose them all. -That- is a big "nono" for me.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is an amazing experience for the price.  Mix Borderlands with Slay the Spire, and you have some idea of what you're looking at.  

The gunplay feels really good already.  Borderlands is a really good point of comparison in this department.  There are a wide variety of guns that have their own mechanics, and then those come with different tiers of modifiers so different versions of the same gun can behave very differently.  And you'll see quite a variety of these guns, because you don't get to keep any of it- when the run ends, you start from the beginning, and don't keep your gear.

The gameplay is highly addictive- when you die, you do get to spend the points you earned into a persistent talent tree that will make the next run a little easier.  So then you're like, "one more run."  Next time, maybe you'll get the guns and gear to be even more badass and push a little further.

The options truly open up for you as you level, and you can feel yourself progressing with every death.  And you will die a lot, at first.  But then you unlock a wide array of guns and scrolls (bonuses that can completely change your style of play).  The talent tree unlocks whole dimensions to gear and the shop that aren't available at first. And you the player will get smarter, faster, wiser in the character skills you choose and the guns you keep and the scrolls you combine.

You're locked in as the versatile mage-cat for a good while, but rest assured that eventually you'll unlock other characters, and they play completely differently.  The dog is a dual-wielding but initially squishy dps powerhouse who can make the most of explosives and rapid fire weapons.  The bird is a close-range, mobile, survivable martial artist who typically favors shotguns.

The game is still in development, but I can say for certain that it is worth the $12 price tag if you enjoy cooperative fps games with a rogue-lite twist.  An amazing experience with friends, since you can share any gun or scroll you come across to help each other build your characters.  But I've had really good experiences with the match-making system and internet randoms, even though I play at very odd times.

I really look forward to seeing how this game develops!  The game already has a lot of polish, can't wait for more.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I play this game a lot.  I have two friends who I play this with all of the time - there are three character to choose from currently and they have multiple builds.  Each run is very unique and the perks and scrolls you get as you progress will define your character's build.  Each run feels different, and even if it didn't feel different, I love seeing hundreds of thousands of damage on the screen at once from my explosion build, or instantly killing an elite with a "no reload" shotgun build.  It's really endless.  

If you want to chill, just play the cat and use your grenades and freeze ability to help your friends out while they dish all of the damage.

Want to feel like a god?  Go the explosion build with the dog and dual wield 'rocket launchers' (tiger cannons) with your no-reload scroll you just found.

I'm just breaching the surface on what you can do and they are always adding more content.

OK after another 20 hrs of this game i stand by the fact the game is awesome for the ¬£10 price. A seriously fun shooter with a lot going for it, great gun play, fun progression system its just a solid early access game. Only issue is the dash and character movement is so slow, yes there are buffs but your not always guaranteed to find them, which for those of us that enjoy a solo sessions really spoils the game as many enemies off the bat move faster then you, especially certain attacks where they move even fast then before, or start to spam attacks to an extent you cant move out the way it just becomes a trap you cant escape and i don't really understand why they haven't sorted this? Obviously this isn't as much of an issue as i'm making out as when in multiplayer teamwork becomes your work around and becomes a challenge rather then a game over. Its just the only lil issue i have. But yeah otherwise awesome game!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
[h1] Absolutely In Love!!! [/h1]

Got this game after feeling a little burnt out on other rogue-like shooters. Saw gameplay online and was pleasantly surprised when I jumped in, at how easily I acclimated to the game when I finally jumped in myself. 

There's a little something for all of my interests here : Guns, Powerups, God like synergies, Skill trees that carry over, smooth  progression (so far), character options, randomized inscriptions on weapons that can also roll really good buffs, and loads of other loot you unlock while playing by completing certain tasks. 

My one gripe is the xp that carries over. once you are done with a run you use the 'spirits' to unlock skills on the skill tree. Now while I have yet to have had a run where I couldn't at least increase one thing, I find myself being bummed out at the left over xp that is essentially lost when you exit the skill tree . I see the skill that increases it but have not had a run good enough to actually get the skill to save the limited amount of spirits I can carry over. 

Other than that one small problem I've run into, I think this is a stellar game and can't wait to see it be developed further, even though I genuinely feel like they have an incredibly solid starting place. I'm really excited for more levels and enemies. I really enjoy the random gun functions they've added and am really looking forward to more innovation like what I've seen, not only with the guns themselves, but the affixes that can randomly spawn with them and make a pretty okay gun GREAT.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn is an absolute gem. I'm partial to rogue-likes/lites, and this game has that "something special" that just begs you to do one more run.

The gameplay is what really sets it apart from other rogue-lite FPS games like Ziggurat and Immortal Redneck. It plays smooth and the elemental effects will be familiar to Borderlands players, but there lies a deeper element of status effects by combining elements that you have to find out about yourself. The weapons, while seeming like there aren't enough to allow true variety, actually have a huge distribution of effectiveness based on their "inscriptions" - stat bonuses and effects that are randomized on the item card when it's generated.

Man, I could go on and on about how great this game is, and I haven't even touched on things like your Ascension buffs or Talents yet. At $11.99 USD FULL PRICE, this game is a steal. [i]don't tell the devs, but this is easily a $30 game[/i]

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Dev team is active and respond great. This game has potential, and is priced fairly for what you get.  At this time though, I can't recommend the game, until they make several changes. 

Pros:
   Cute aesthetic. 
   Bullet registration seems incredibly accurate. 
   Looks great, lots of graphics options. 
Cons :   
   Also your weapons reset every play through, so you only get to start with the one initial weapon. So if you are expecting like destiny or borderlands 3 where you get to keep your gun and upgrade that permanently this is not like that at all. 
   Talent tree skill caps - For example, HP talent you can only put 5 points in it, the point of rogue like games is to feel rewarded for the grind, a direct correlation between time spent in game and your power level(with a little luck of course ;)). 
   Repetitive, You run the same mission over and over, and souls don't carry over so it makes it even worse if you aren't skilled enough to beat the mission. 
   I would love to see a run mechanic, and slide mechanic, would make the game feel much more fluid
   Can't play multiplayer until level 10 
   Souls don't stack ( You use souls to put skills into your talent tree, you permenantly get to keep the skills but the souls reset to 0 after every mission(Why??)).
developer_response: Thanks for your feedback. A feature of roguelite game is to reset after the death so you will have different experience in each run. Players can match with other players after reaching level 10 so they can be familiar with the game and have better performance. In the end, the talent "Dimension¬†Pouch" allows you to carry certain amount of Soul Essences out of each run.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Its heart is in the right place, it really is, but it's flawed. Deeply flawed.

Gunfire Reborn is a SOLID FPS, but It is a not a good Roguelite.

First, the positives.
The frame rate is fantastic and the movement is beautiful, save for some weird choppiness in a single player game one time that didn't affect me all that much,  (It was effectively the same speed but the pace was inconsistent.) unless you're in multiplayer, in which case there may be issues, which is a problem in a movement based shooter like this one.

 Accuracy is mostly based on your own aim  (For balancing purposes, thankfully) and the dodging and dashing away from enemy fire is very effective, rewarding navigating through all the projectiles enemies throw at you, but not too much to where it's OP. The encounter design is fantastic and despite being chunk based (At least it seems that way) it mostly makes good use of the room composition and enemy design to create pretty good fights.The weapons range from conservative to experimental with an equally varied range of effectiveness, but it's analyzing these weapons and their stats, their traits and how they interact with you and the rest of the game that it really begins to show the aforementioned deep flaws of this game. 

The translation job for this game is not great and it can hurt the gameplay by providing unclear descriptions, and although i complained about this in an earlier iteration of this review, it is worth noting that the issue is now drastically reduced and is now just a matter of less than optimal sentence structure rather than entirely misleading descriptions.

Determining the effectiveness of weapons and elemental damage early in your tenure, both ingame and in concept is very iffy, which is an issue when you only have two spare weapon slots. (You cannot drop the starting one.) In the first zone, the health bars of enemies with shields (Not armor though, oddly) aren't really treated all that differently compared to base health, but then ramps up extensively in the second zone, especially if the enemy has modifiers applied to them to make them tougher. Compound this with damage numbers being used to denote damage values to enemies whose health is shown via a bar with no numbers (Though bosses are an exception, oddly) and it becomes less effective at denoting how effective a weapon is, save for a comparative frame of reference between the weapons you use yourself, and with the limitations on your arsenal, you're not really going to get many opportunities to check that out, especially since the meta devolves into requiring you to cover your elemental weaknesses by the second or third zone (Though this is now due to deliberately tanky enemies in general compared to every enemy with an extra shield in the zone) lest you should throw away the run due to how long fights can take without them.

Character progression when you die is also concerning (One extremely so) based on its design. It's built and balanced around innate traits tied to you, the player, in both ascension and overall player level.
Ascension is fine but can screw you over sometimes. These levels are tied to the run and apply modifiers to you or your abilities, and when you are presented with the opportunity to get one, you are presented with one of three options that may or may not synergize with your build. I get that if left entirely to choice the game would have to be balanced around minmaxed offensive builds and that's kinda dumb to be honest, especially in a rogue-esque game in general, but it becomes a pain when you have to rely on good builds that RNG could screw you out of after the second zone. 
Player level is what picks up the slack, though in my opinion it really, REALLY shouldn't. The game is balanced in part around permanent upgrades, and this is evident through straight stat increases and features being unlocked, such as unlocking the ability to find ultra-powerful weapons, buffing their spawn chances, ability buffs that stay permanently, and worst of all, getting direct HP, shield and overall damage reduction buffs.
I get that there needs to be some overall progression to keep the game interesting, but the game already does that by giving out new weapons and abilities as milestone rewards, and that works wonderfully already. Leaning on that sort of progression and balancing the game around not having this levelling system will make the game more skill based and more player friendly, since there should be absolutely no reason to grind out a game like this and the player won't be cheaped out by bosses balanced around inherent damage reductions they have to grind lower area tiered runs to achieve. It makes the game longer, and not in the fun way.

The first boss, Wu Lu, is designed and balanced to be basically a QTE that literally requires you to dash out of their attacks if and when you can dodge them to begin with. A couple times he'll just charge you and there's hardly anything you can do to avoid his attacks. It's not fun to fight against, it's just bad. The amount of damage he deals can kill you pretty easily, too, and you can't really build yourself up defensively to deal with it, ironically making a decent chunk of your starting/early arsenal unviable against him (As some weapons have movement reductions when they're out) because if you use them at the wrong time during the fight, you're basically dead since he usually twoshots you. Given he's literally the first boss, this is not a good impression to make for people picking up the game, as it's not hard to reach him. The first time  i beat him i had to cheese him using stuns that i had to build my entire character around.

Your reward for defeating him is to actually move onto the further zones which are actually way better than the first in terms of roguelite gameplay. Arcadey enemy modifiers and slightly ramped up difficulty that factors in elemental weapon balancing in a genuine way, unlike the starting area, where weapon elements basically meant what flavor you wanted to kill things with some buffs attached if you build into that element. The second zone's boss is also semi-representative of what a boss should be but its damage values on one of its attacks effectively ensures your death if you do not get out of it in time.

I will say this though, these devs have a good history with a decent amount of accolades under their belt and they've got a built in feedback feature, and with the community engagement they have, it's clear they're genuinely trying to improve the game, and they have the potential to do it. Though i'll admit i'm unfamiliar with this particular company, I believe they will work to improve this game and i look forward to seeing this improved upon and completed.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is really, really fun.
I will start off by saying that it's sorta like a first person nuclear throne or enter the gungeon. It has a lot of differences with those games, but they share a lot of similarities. It's very addicting and easy to get into, the gameplay is fun, though it does get a tad repetitive. In it's current state, the game is a bit lacking in terms of content. It is however still in early access and is being regularly updated.
I haven't tested the multiplayer out yet, no one I know has interest in this game so I can't comment on that aspect of it. However the single player mode is just fine and is still worth your time.
It's a very enjoyable game that is certainly worth the price, and I'd highly recommend you try it out.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I'm going through my library and letting you know why I stopped playing this:

This game is receiving such high praise for no reason whatsoever. This is a cheap game, it feels like a cheap game, it looks like a cheap game. With MANY other quality titles that are this type of game but better, there is ZERO reason to buy it. I feel ripped off. Try ULTRAKILL or Mothergunship if you want just a few of the examples of better titles. 

- Guns feel like GARBAGE. EVERY gun feels like a peashooter. The animations feel unfinished, the sounds are mediocre. This is F2P mobile game quality. In this kind of game, that's just not acceptable.
- Levels are drab, uninteresting. Environments in this game are just BORING to look at. Art-style is one thing, but this game is just BORING all around. Look at the cherry picked screenshots, do you see anything that says "Wow!"? No. 
- I had a friend to play co-op with, this is the ONLY reason I played so long, without them it would have been a 3hr play at MAX.
- DON'T WASTE YOUR MONEY.
developer_response: Sorry for your unpleasant experience, we will add more content and randomnessÔºåand we will optimize the game difficulty and game balance in the future update, stay tuned.

title: Gunfire Reborn

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I can't believe I haven't already recomended this game.

Certainly it has a few issues but it is consistantly updated, has amazing mecahnics and whatever you hear, no it is not purely reliant on meta progression. While that does massively help make runs easier, a level 0 character can beat the final boss on hard mode, it takes a lot of luck, and tons of skill, but it is possible.

Learning the game is a bit tough since its constantly evolving and many things are bugged or nerfed or even buffed over time, but if you are on the fence about getting this game I highly recomend trying it out. If its not your thing so be it, not everything was made for everyone but I love almost every thing about this game.

Overall points:

Gunplay: Fluid, responsive, skill heavy, 10/10

Movement: A bit hard to get used to, but great once you have learned it, 9/10

Gun variance: Its no BL3, but it has a multitude of options, 7/10 (with every major update there are a few more guns added so this will likely go out of date quickly)

Build variance: There are a few good ways to build each of the 3 characters, but almost always one extremely powerful build and about 2 other minor ones, 8/10

Meta Progression: This is a bit of a major make or break point of these games, and I believe that it has been handled extremely well by the developers, the high end skills may seemingly cost enormous ammounts of essence, but after you unlock them, you should be completing runs consistantly. 9/10

Overall 8.5/10 (no thats not mathimatically accurate but its how I feel.) Would recomend.

review:
This game is similar to Immortal Redneck but with online co op matchmaking.

It's a Roguelike FPS with funny weaponery and scrolls that affects your build with passive effects in your current run.

You can also enhance your character after each run with "souls" collected during your previous one.

The gunfight is really good, weapons and enemies are pretty diverse and have different mechanics. There are also elites mobs like in Borderland.

The game may sometimes seems unbalanced but in fact it's the way Roguelike games work.
If you have good weapons and good scrolls (passive buffs and skills enhancements), you'll roll over enemies and levels but if you have bad ones, than you'll die fast. Classical Roguelike.

The game currently have 3 levels divided into several areas and one boss per level. They can hide secret areas that you will need to complete in order to win a rewardl. These secret areas feature platforming, combat or action challenges and can be very tricky. If you die in one of them, then your run ends... 

It's a really addictive Roguelike FPS and for ‚Ç¨10 it's a pretty good deal.

review: This is by far the best fps roguelite that I have played (others being tower of guns, and Immortal redneck) the game has solid gunplay and a good feeling of progression. The only big issue is that a lot of times it does just seem that if you get hit once it's game over (the bosses show this often) however between the gunplay and the wide variety of pickups it seems like this game has a good amount of room to grow and the potential for hundreds of hours down the drain. Well worth the money even in it's early stage.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
These Devs are something different. You can clearly see it by the recent updates. Even though playing on Linux isn't officially supported and the latest update made it impossible to play due to the update to steamSDK that wasn't supported by Proton yet they've gone out of their way to fix it and now You can play the game without issues again.

As for the game itself it's a very fun roguelite FPS with some meta-progression in form of a "talent tree" that you upgrade using the souls that you collect from the monsters. For now the game features the following: 

- 3 bosses and 3 stages one for each boss
- 100+ occult scrolls which are basically upgrades (or downgrades) that you find during the run
- Fair amount of weapons
- Co-op mode with pings system
- Dynamic combat based on skill rather than luck unlike many other roguelites. The game doesn't kill you in unfair ways and many attacks are telegraphed so you have enough time to react.
- 3 playable characters

The devs are incredibly active and push out an update roughly every week. Sometimes it's something small like minor balance changes to a few things and sometimes they're major like a new characters, stages or bosses.

TL;DR

Buy the game. It's great and the devs actually listen to the community. Frequent updates and no dodgy microtransactions or DLCs that block game content. Overall a steal for this price.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Roguelikes have quickly infiltrated many other genres recently and now they've come to fps'. The closest thing I have for comparison is maybe Borderlands? Though without the cringe humor and terrible CEO.

For those uninitiated, you pick a character(out of 3 as of this writing), each with their own abilities and get as far as you can while getting powerups and randomized loot along the way. There are some abilities that are clearly way better than others and the first character seems much stronger than the others, but that's something that can always be balanced later. The gameplay has a good feeling though I'm very terrible at the jump puzzles. A ton of weapon and enemy variety with some nice bosses that don't feel unfair. 

It's still in early access and thus there's still work to be done but it's in a decent shape right now. I do hope there'll be more upgrades and characters to unlock in the future. The game's made by a Hong Kong company I think and there's some Chinese cultural specific references I caught. It's a great co-op experience.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I've seen several people call this game a [b]Borderlands Binding of Isaac[/b] and while the art style might reseble BL slightly and it does somewhat fall under the same category as TBoI, I'd heavily suggest not to forcefully give Gunfire Reborn a lable just so it has one. For now, here's a quick Pros & Cons list. For those who are interested in a more in depth review, feel free to continue reading :)

[b] [u] Pros:[/u] [/b]
+ Great gunplay 
+ Fluent movement
+ Several playable characters to choose from
+ Expanding arsenal of unique weapons and skills
+ Several dificulties with well done learning curve
+ Detailed enviroments, great enemy design and unique artstyle
+ Well done Coop Mode
+ Constant updates and support by developers

[b] [u] Cons:[/u] [/b]
- Balancing of weapons, skills and characters varies from update to update
- Lacking choice making resulting in less skill/weapon management and brainless playstyles
- Limited amount of skills results in most runs having about the same bunch of skills
- With only 3 Areas and bosses rather short
- In general lacking content 

[i]Gunfire Reborn is a [b]First Person Shooter Rogue-Like[/b] which is currently in [b]early access[/b] and is being updated frequently. Right now you can choose one of three different "Heroes", each with their own abilities and specialization to enter a somewhat procedurally generated dungeon with up to 3 other players in  Co-Op or on your own, fighting either from one room to another or agains waves of enemies. A single playthrough currently features 3 different Worlds, each with several stages and a boss stage at the end of each of them. During all this you unluck different abilities by finishing stages, can collect new weapons from enemies (or unlock new ones once certain requirements have been met) and earn money and "Soul Essence", a currency used to upgrade the gear you carry or buff your character permanenty after each run.[/i]

Now that that's out of the way, [b]would I reccomend Gunfire Reborn? Short answer yes.[/b]
The game shines with its charming stage and enemy designes, interesting characters, weapons and abilities along with the differnt playstyles you can chose from, [b]fluent movement and just generally great controls[/b] as well as a devoted developer updating the game regularly. Most of the weapons are rather unique but all of them play pretty well, same goes for the different characters and their unique traits. A single game can take as little as [b]20 but also up to 40mins[/b] depending on you playstyle, experience and progress in the game. DIfferent enemies and especially bosses that might seem difficult in the beginning will probably not be a problem anymore if you give it enough tries and finally beating them feels [b]satisfying without seeming too tedious[/b]. The Co-Op mode, while buggy in the beginning is now in a rather good state with relatively good connection while giving the players more options than before like the sharing of loot among each other.

That said, [b]is the game perfect? Short answer, no...[/b]
Gunfire Reborn is as mentioned before an [b]early access[/b] title which, while being updated frequently, is still [b]far from perfectly polished or finished[/b]. [b]Weapons or skill might seem under- or overpowered[/b] at times making [b]some playstyles or characters far superior[/b] of a choice. Skills that were previously balanced by having strong effects with a bit of a drawback are now simple boosts and less thought has to go into skill/weapon management. Overall, the game lacks balance at times and doesn't present the player with proper choice making as most skills are simply buffs (with some but few exceptions) and can be taken blindly. [b]Another issue is (and I know this might seem a bit obvious) the lenght of the game and it's total content[/b]. Yes, the game is great and takes some time to get into/master but once you've defeated the third and currently last boss it's just over. After getting the hang of the game you spend about half an hour on average, trying to do the same stages over and over again or farm for Soul Essence to max out skills. After all skills have been maxed there really isn't much to do right now. It is of course only natural for an early access title to not have the same amount of content as a polished AAA title. I get that and never would I expect that but it should be mentioned that there simply are the same problems with about every other early access game there is. That said, the constant updates show that the developer is still very much invested in this project and tries to improve it with every update.

review:
I could talk about things this game might do better or gush about the parts it does well, but I don't think that's the best argument.

I grew up on COD zombies and halo firefight and when roguelike games became mainstream it was my newest addiction. Risk of Rain, Binding of Isaac, Hades, Dead Cells; I loved them all. 

This is the BEST fps roguelike game that exists right now, and while the content is light, the dev's communication and update frequency is fantastic. In its current state it is worth playing and will provide a ton of fun and addicting gameplay for a great price. 

If you're like me that's all you need to know.

Rating: 89/100

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: This game has potential but is too early in development to recommend. Movement is sluggish and incomplete (no ads, no crouch), you can only switch 2 out of 3 guns, there is no real way to regain health, and bosses cheap shot you to force you to replay (it's fairly random as to whether a dodge from a boss attack will save you or not). Core gameplay loop is fun the first few times but replaying every level every run gets old real quick. A suggestion would be to let people start from each hub world instead of the very beginning.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
4/5. Many great parts of an FPS, in a budget, roguelike form.

+Gunplay almost as satisfying as Doom Eternal (with realistic expectations, for the price of course)
+Rogue-lite version of Borderlands
+Good variety of skills and weapons 
+VERY satisfying gunplay
+Skill based - even tho RNG is a factor
+Kills and deaths feel fair
+Seems simple at first, but gets way harder and complex as it goes on
+Really great setting, theme, style and music

+Enemy types and variety are standard, but in a good way. It mixes things up and the enemy types compliment each other better than I've seen in other PvE's. This is probably due to the smaller spaces that you fight in. Which is a bit of a con.
+3 pretty unique characters with their own skills
+Lots of charm
+Cute, yet somehow still badass character designs. Main character is just a way cooler version of Puss in Boots

-Maps aren't too varied
-Maps are pretty plain looking. But if Risk of Rain 2 can get away with it, surely this can? It's down to taste.
-Movement/arenas feel a bit cramped. Although it might be by design, I would still love to see more things done with the maps. Such as jump pads or teleporters.
-Somewhat slow gameplay for an FPS. Although still pretty satisfying, the cramped hallways and movement can make it feel dull sometimes

As with any rogue, can get repetitive, so play in short bursts or space out your sessions as to not get burnt out

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: Great Roguelite FPS. Gameplay is pretty smooth. For $12 this game is totally worth it. The game is still in early dev, but I can't wait until they add more levels and even harder difficulties. Many different types of guns and occult/cursed scrolls makes every run new/challenging/fun.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
[h1]For their first FPS game, this rocks[/h1]

[i]I'm choosing to make this review in response to a handful of recent negative reviews the game has received, almost all of which they don't deserve.[/i]

And because the game is awesome.

Gunfire: Reborn is a superb model for an EA game. The [b]weapons[/b] are super fun and have great mechanics behind them. There is large number of weapons and the random element plays into what modifier and stat changes they get, two guns wont ever exactly be alike. 

The [b]characters[/b] are little but have the neccessary and strong abilities you'd find in a rouge game, dashes, AoEs and stuns. Each character doesn't have that much unique progression, but rather share a greater skill tree that your goal is to eventually fill. 

The [b]bosses[/b] are dope, there are only 3 major stages and 3 major bosses (excluding elites for now) but they each match their area and have respective defenses. You will see the same areas over and over, but each one has different entrances and routes through them. Hasn't been too repetitive so far. 

The [b]combat[/b] kicks ass, the gun play and movement lets you always have control, the guns don't feel slow or weighed down and the game has Warframe-like element combinations you can create for stronger combos again defenses or for status effects, even more so in co-op. 

The [b]co-op[/b] is great, the loot is all client side so there isn't stealing or trolling, you get your own unique loot and no one can stop you. They could just not revive you, but thats just how public co-op works. 

The [b]matchmaking[/b] is peer-to-peer so if there aren't many players online, expect to get players from farther away and with worse ping, but with the game rising in popularity, this wont be a problem for long. Even without friends I was able to get players who chatted and worked together!

I'll leave the rest for you to decide about the game, its super fun and with a 10~ dollar price tag this was an instant buy for me. I greatly recommend this.

This game is fantastic, especially considering its price. Can't recommend it enough. I'm very excited to see where it goes from here.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I bought this to be a one time event to spend a good evening with a friend. We played for a bit, but some technical issues stopped us from really enjoying it at time, and we put it aside. However, after a few updates we decided to give it another chance and damn I love it since then! The developer really cares about the game, fixing and fine-tuning stuff all the time.

However, I was quite disappointed to find out there are persistent upgrades to your character, aside from gameplay changing (like getting access to challenge side areas, more affixes on weapons, or getting a weapon at the start of the game), which I like a lot, there are also simple stat boosting (+hp, +damage). It feels like the game rewards grinding rather than improving skill. I'd really appreciate to have some "challenge mode" where all the stat boosts from talents are disabled or set to some fixed values.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: I really recommend this game if you love shoot em up level based grinding, its very enjoyable both solo and coop with friends, the fights will feel abit slowpaced at first but gains momentum as you go on with more equipments. Movement feels pretty smooth, enemy AI is more A than I, just like your average shoot em up rogue games, it feels really satisfying to see big numbers on your screen. The content may seems small, but you could easily get 20-30 hour with the grinds and trying out new combos of inscriptions and weapons. For the price of this game, it's a must buy!

Is it cheap? Yes. Is quality equally low? No!

Best spending in my life, which is best described as rogulite borderlands. You can freely share weapons and items, but the loot is individual so the coop is just so satisfying. If you have doubts, just look at the price, you certainly wasted much more money on some other game which sits in your baclog for years.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: The gunplay is very satisfying. There are a ton of random elements in each run: you get weapons with inscriptions, which will change their power dramatically. You will get occult scrolls, which are basically passive effects for your run which can lead to insane synergies. Then you also get to put points into character specific skilltrees during a run. All of the things you collect have a huge impact on your run and you can clearly feel the effects of your choices.  This makes every run very unique and interesting. What I love the most about the game is how punishing it is. If you make one or two mistakes you are dead, no matter how much damage you are dealing. You can really feel yourself getting better while playing and it is very rewarding to get further and further. Every week an update is released to make the game better and to fix bugs, they are adding more and more conten over time. Definitely buy this if you enjoy FPS or Rogue-likes

review:
This game is brilliant!!! 
The gameplay mechanics are fenomenal. It just makes you wanna play again and again......and again :P 
These last two weeks since i got the game,I've been racking up 74 hours played, and i still love it. 
It just so addicting, with all the upgrades and weapons, no run is gonna be the same, and you really need to stay on your toes while playing, because even if i unlocked all upgrades and weapons on all three classes, and i feel really powerful, a moment of loss of focus is enough to kill you or severely damage you , and that's one of the things I love about this game.

To unlock weapons and scrolls ( scrolls are all kinds of upgrades for abilities, weapons HP and more) you need to kill enemies in a variety of ways, with different elemental damage, melee, groups and more.

And don't even get me started on co-op, with personal loot and ability to share stuff you don't want, it is a blast to play both singleplayer and co-op.

I cannot recommend this game enough, it is simply fantastic!!!!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
The best game I've played under $20 in a very long time. A good combination of a loot shooter and a roguelite. 

Pros:
-Gunplay feels solid, not much at all bullet sponge, which is always my biggest complaint about any FPS with RPG elements
-Just the right amount of weapons: few enough to not be confusing, but enough to keep it fresh and interesting
-Very fun power-ups that can ramp you up to feel godlike
-The three characters are all distinct and no one feels more powerful than another
-The game is updated pretty regularly
-Scales well for co-op. The most fun I've had playing a co-op game with friends in a long time
-Challenging, but fair

Cons:

- There are only 3 stages with 5-6 levels each (not including "Vaults" which are side areas for extra loot/power-ups).
- Very little procedural generation map-wise. There are only a few layouts. Sometimes you do them backwards, but it feels same-y after a few playthroughs.
- Translation/word usage can be bad/weak on a lot of the items/power-ups, making it not immediately clear what they do. There are a few items that I'm still not sure *exactly* what they do or how they work, and I have more than 100 hours in the game
- The difficulty curve in terms of the roguelite playthrough-to-playthrough progression is a little out of whack. I felt like during my first playthrough I was COMPLETELY underpowered and now that I'm max level and have every upgrade, I'm only slightly overpowered. Some of it was me being new to the game and just getting better, but not most of it. I think certain upgrades are must-haves to make the difficulty doable early on.
-Runs are pretty short, which is good and bad. At the end of some runs, I'm sad I can't keep going because there are only 3 levels!


Conclusion:
Overall, the game is very fun. I bought it on a whim and was very pleasantly surprised by it, especially from an unheard of developer out of Hong Kong. For me, this absolutely trumps a Triple A shooter like Borderlands in terms of gameplay (and you don't have to put up with the cringey jokes either): the guns never feel like peashooters, the power-ups are fun as hell and can make or break a run, and the difficulty never feels unfair. A lot of the cons I listed above are nitpicky, but my only real complaint is that there's not enough game yet! I want more levels to play, more bosses, and different environments! I think this game is already such a breath of fresh air, and I want more replayability because I already genuinely love the unfinished product.

Other than that, it's a really fun game so far. Very well done!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game took me by surprise. I did read the positive reviews surrounding it, but most simply relativized it to its price with phrasing such as "it's a steal for only 10 bucks!". Having played it first hand at long last I can see why "Gunfire reborn" gets all the praise. Not merely from a value perspective, but as an excellent indie title and roguelite.

First and foremost: I went into this game having seen only a little gameplay and the store front. The latter doesn't really sell it particularly well if...well, you're not chinese. The game is littered throughout with poor denglish, spelling mistakes, poor grammar and generally embarrassing dialogue. It is in fact so bad some weapon effects are completely obscured by, presumably, Google translate. This was something I expected seeing the game's description and it turned out to be arguably even worse than I anticipated.

Secondly the game looks very "generic" from the screenshots. Even though not necessarily untrue this did not bother me in the slightest when playing. Granted a lot of the enemies are recycled in the currently three biomes, but due to the game's excellent pacing you'll be distracted from the fact you're pretty much shooting at the same few baddies(especially the first biome, the tombs, are a big offender as there's very little visual variation in the mobs).

The low poly graphics work. The animations are good. The pacing is really good. I would even go as far as to say the pacing in this game is one of the best I've ever seen in a roguelite. The game is definitely challenging, but so far I've yet to encounter a "oh come on that's just unfair"-moment. The loot is exciting to obtain and there are plenty of viable builds. The sound design, and this came as a surprise to me, is very good albeit minimal. The weapons really do have oomph. The game does require aim, but it's definitely not a twitch shooter. Overall it's more akin to games like Doom where skill is expressed through timely reactions. Combine the great pacing, great feel of the weapons, exciting loot with a game that is neither too hard nor too easy and you have an excellent indie title on your hands.

I must also praise the developers for the bold move of selling it for 10$. I think this worked wonders in retrospect as it's one of those games you get to pick up with spare wallet cash. And, like everyone else already stated, it's a steal for the price. It's an excellent well refined indie title.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
As a FPS, this game is a treat. Lots of guns, tough enemies and a little bit of rpg elements to spice it up.

As a roguelike, it's a trainwreck. Only game mechanics to master are "Shoot  stuff" and "pray to rng daemon", almost everything else is random. Weapons are random, skills are random, game mutators (aka scrolls) are random, sideroom portals are random. As far as I can tell, chances to get pass first bossfight are random too.

ED: few more notes after spending some quality time with the game.

There are even more weapons to unlock then I thought, and I am thoroughly impressed by this. Some may be questionable (i.e. I am not fond of sniper rifle whose projectiles are so slow enemies sidestep them without really trying) but there is still plenty enough to pick from.

I also like number and variety of enemies. And the fact that they don't go for quantity, but quality, so to speak. Although there are some "ankle biters" this game is not about smacking endless hordes of powerless grunts. You have to know them,  learn their attack modes and sequences by heart. Unfortunately, this is process of knowing your enemy usualy begins with getting instakilled by‚Ä¶ something. This is not exactly helped by several major flaws that I hope will be fixed before game is out of EA. One is that enemies can shoot right through each other, Come on devs, it's 21st century, you can do collision physics. Other one is that enemies can track through obstacles. Wallhacking bastards. This one is particulary enjoyed by lifestealing monks in one of those "game just randomly decided to kill you" moments.

As for the bosses ‚Äì I stand by what I written about first boss being essentialy random encounter. It's not that he is too hard, he is easy compared to second one. It's that second one is far enough ingame that you have good changes of getting somewhat working gear combination. First one, not so much. End result is that I get through harder one about half the time, while score for the easy one is about one in five (although it gets better with grinding souls). Sad  thing about this is that random skill build is otherwise a grand idea.

Boasting about random levels is a bit premature. Right now, it's just a bunch or premade corridors, of which there is so few you will see them all in a two or three runs. Portals with trap minigames are a nice change of style. I would very much like to praise simple and clear art style of combat arenas, but I just can't. Because fast paced combat with lot of running and dodging does not go well with invisible walls, no matter how good it looks. In a game where a single mistake can kill you, this is literally showstopper. Third episode is especially guilty here, and while I can ignore that it looks like it was crudely upscaled, maybe even inept use of cover, but constant bumping into invisible walls is unforgivable.

What I can and will praise are those few cases when game froze upon death. Not that I like game bugs that much, but I was pleasantly surprised that upon restart I was able to recover those hard earned soul points. I wonder why it only ever had problems with death, never during fights, but it's not like I mind :-) Anyway, kudos to devs.

In the end, game have a solid and enjoyable core, lots of small bugs that will be easily ironed out during EA and with something like forty hours I can't honestly call it bad. But I can't recomend it until some improvements.
developer_response: Sorry for your unpleasant experience, we will add more content and randomness in the future update, stay tuned.

review:
Pros:-

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Price is fair for what it is, and in my opinion- worth it - even if it's not on sale.

This is a simple little rouge-lite shooter from a small developer in Hong Kong. There's only 3 levels (with multiple stages per level) right now- and 3 different characters. If you're ok with that though- this is a fun little shooter with some varying tactics and synergies. It's ok solo but more enjoyable as a coop game. Randomized drops often make it beneficial to trade/give your drops to teammates that could make better use of them. Coop is actually encouraged by some of the mechanics and that is a good thing.

The genre isn't usually my cup of tea- but i've found myself enjoying this game.

The devs are fairly active and seem to respond to player feedback. lobby screen ambient sounds were a bit annoying and character voices can get obnoxious- giving feedback about this resulted in the addition of features to lower the volume or silence them entirely. In general- bugs get fixed, desired features get added. As it's still in active development and things are still being added, fixed, and optimized- I really can't complain.

For a simple little casual game it's good- and to spite being short- variety manages to keep it interesting.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn is the perfect balance between the 3 different genres of RPG, FPS, and roguelikes. This is well worth more than the $12 that they're asking for and the game isn't even done yet. There's new updates and content almost every week which the devs are very vocal and transparent with the community about.

Okay, so about the game... think Risk Of Rain 2 meets Borderlands (graphics and weapon types), with a little bit of a Binding Of Isaac exploration.It's a perfect blend of different genres that mash up very well. I think this game is a perfect example of how Early Access games should aspire to look like, and for only $12, I would suggest not sleeping on this if you're a fan of dungeon crawlers, roguelikes, or just like a wide variety of quirky weapons to shoot weird looking enemies with. You shoot things, build up your character to be stronger, kill the stage boss, then onto the next and harder stage with a hard and stronger boss. There's also a little bit of lore, if you care about that stuff and don't mind doing a bit of reading, but I just like getting my character a bunch of buffs and shooting things. I'm sure they'll add more lore and content as the game develops. If you're a fan of the genre then you'll know that no run is ever the same, and this game is definitely showing a lot of promise in the genre of roguelikes. 

Oh, and I finally beat Yoruhime-Maru. GG, bitch!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: Avoids the Destiny syndrome of having hundreds of guns, of which only several are actually usable, by randomly generating which guns (and perks) you get on each run. Cool idea, although it's a little frustrating when you get trash rolls on everything and are at a major disadvantage for that run. Co-op is far more fun than singleplayer, especially with friends instead of matchmade randoms. Game could use some balancing between multiplayer and singleplayer though; playing with 3 or 4 players is FAR easier to level than playing solo. Still, pretty fun, and easily worth the ~10 bucks.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
INSANE game for being early access! Virtually bug free, and the gameplay is crispy and engaging. If you even REMOTELY like games like Risk of Rain, I think this is a must buy for $12.

Its a roguelite, so there is a skill tree that you upgrade between runs, but they're mostly just small incremental upgrades (+5% weapon damage), and then unlocking a few nice quality of life features (like starting the game with a gun in addition to the default pistol). But even with that, the main positive feedback loop is unlocking new cool scrolls and learning the enemy patterns to be able to get further and further in the game. The first 10 hours, this game destroyed me, but now (at max level) I can regularly beat the game with a group of friends on the highest difficulty.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
-> Gunfire Reborn is a good game. I payed full price and played a lot. I found this smooth, intense FPS co-op lobby shooter game to be free of un-fun busywork and free of micro-transactions. There is no story arc and only a couple of drone NPCs. The difficulty spikes are excessive as of the date of this review. The cartoon graphics won't appeal to everyone, similar to Borderlands. Overall, this is a good game with a likelihood of getting even better, since the game is technically still in development as of September 2020.

 -> At its heart, this game is an old-school 3D first-person shooter. You will be looking at the world from the center of your own hitbox, with your weapon or weapons visible in the lower corners and a reticle (aimpoint) in the center of the screen. You enter the game world from a bare-bones lobby, which saves you the time you might otherwise waste hiking to where the action is. The lobby does not need to be much, because there is one series of maps as of the date of this review. Luckily, the maps are randomly re-generated for each successive play-through. 

 -> The game is the good kind of rogue-like. Survive as long as you can, and you will harvest soul coins that you trade for permanent power-ups when you die. Your survival will be heavily influenced by your skill, obviously, but also by synergies that you create by selecting which weapons to carry and which temporary power-ups you select from loot boxes found at fixed intervals. The gameplay loop consists of building temporary synergies that persist until you die, then upon demise cashing in the harvested soul coins for permanent, persistent improvements. It's compelling, and it's fun. 

 -> Once you start to get good, play sessions will start getting longer than is comfortable for an intense shooter. Half an hour or 45 minutes is about my comfort level. You can save and quit at the transition between maps, which is generally at around the 45 minute mark. Then, when you return later, you can pick up where you left off. There are also rare scrolls that give extra lives, and once each play-through you can trade half your soul coins for an extra life (not usually a  good idea). Finally, since monsters do not repopulate, you can simply stop playing and leave your avatar in the game doing nothing while you take care of real world necessities. Other than that, I did not see any way to save a game in progress.

 -> Gunfire Reborn has no story that I can discern. Something along the lines of Borderlands' Handsome Jack taunting you would add a lot to the game. 

 -> Part of the game's progression requires that you die every so often, so it shouldn't be surprising that there are heavy difficulty spikes in this game. Bosses at the end of each zone or environment are one such difficulty spike; that's to be expected. Random minibosses can be much more difficult than end-level bosses, however. You might walk into a small room, hear the door crash shut behind you, and be faced with a bullet sponge miniboss with a terrific short-range attack that you can't get away from. Time to cash in those soul chips. Also certain randomly-placed rooms can be swarming with a dangerous blend of short and long range attackers while any available cover is effectively nullified by grenade spam. These uncommon death rooms are highly challenging, with survival rare.

 -> The graphics are cartoonish, with heavy outlines and cell shading added in video post-processing. I found it to be clean and approachable. If you liked Borderlands, you will feel right at home. 

 -> Gunfire Reborn is worth the money and, more importantly, worth your time. It's a lobby-based FPS rogue-like with temporary and permanent RPG elements. I looks and plays a lot like Borderlands, without story elements, a persistent universe, and NPCs with personalities. Gunfire Reborn is well done, and a blast.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: [h1]8 / 10[/h1]A very fun base game, especially with co-op. There are minor hinderances but is overall enjoyable, and each run feels fresh.[hr][/hr][b]Pros:[/b][list][*]Very well optimized. 140 FPS on max settings on a $199 gpu[*]Each hero is a perfect blend of unique, while also keeping with the flow of general combat.[*]The upgrades you get along the run give you a very noticable difference in an aspect of play; instead of many small 5% increases to certain stats, you can get 50% or 200% increase to certain stats, or bonuses when you do certain actions. This [i]really[/i] helps with keeping each run feeling fresh.[*]Many ways to play based on your character and what you get in runs, and they're almost all fun to play.[*]Constant updates[*]a [i]VERY[/i] unique and diverse arsenal[*]Dash dodging, enemies with special attacks, and AOE attacks incentivize skillful movement and target prioritization.[*]Low price[/list][hr][/hr][b]Cons:[/b][list][*]Some upgrades are very lackluster, while others are complete game-changers, which can lead to lobsided or weak builds in runs[*]Random placements of vaults that contain upgrades sometimes leads to runs with bullet-spongey enemies[*]Some areas feel same-y, and theres not a ton of variation with elite enemies and bosses in the current state of the game.[/list]The negatives I have of this game are minor, and the game is in early access, yet is a much more competent product than a lot of other early access titles. If you love rougue-likes, classic FPS like doom, or looter-shooters like Borderlands, you should give Gunfire Reborn a shot.

Another thing that I think it can improve would be the main and secondary abilities, for example if you are using the smoke bomb ability and you want to use 2 or 3 bombs in rapid succession, it won't let you sometimes, it feels like there's is a dead time I'm between trying to use another bomb which results in you pressing the key and having to press it again to throw the second or third bomb, that could definitely improve.The game it's fun and challenging, definitely worth its price.

I played the first 10 hours single player but I highly suggest you try multiplayer ASAP. you get better rewards and from my experience they community is very helpful and fun to play with. This is an early access that is better than most fully released games. This game is worth more than the price tag listed and the updates are constant with devs that are very conscientious of the feedback given. The only complaint I have is the translations to English dont make sense sometimes when it comes to item tooltips....but with a little logic it is easy to figure out the intended message. imo 9.5/10, regardless of your preferences this is a game you should have in your library

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: Let me start off with prefacing that I am not a big rogue-like nor rogue-lite fan. I've only really enjoyed Risk of Rain 2, and Noita, both of which are rogue-likes. The play-hours I have as of this review - 16h-ish according to Steam, yet my steam overlay told me I had about 24hrs - are all within the first 24-ish hours of even owning this game. The first thing that grabbed me was the gunplay. My [i]god[/b] is it smooth! All the guns feel great to use, even better, most of them feel extremely viable and with tight and fun designs. The same proficiency in design is highlighted like the birth of christ in the characters. All three, while being relatively few for a character-based rogue-lite like this, feel extremely fun and viable to use. It's clear a lot of thought went into the designs of the characters, not only in their abilities and ascention trees (skill trees), but also in their character designs. The game also has a low-poly art style, with some of the weapons having more details. This works extremely well, not only for the, in my opinion, gorgeus aesthetics, but also for visibility and playability. The game runs like butter on max settings on a GTX 1060 3GB and a Ryzen 5 1600x and 8 gigs of ram. All three "worlds" are visually pleasing and interesting in their own ways, with the latter two being incredibly good looking in my opinion. I played this for most of my hours alone, yet I managed to convince some friends to buy the game after screensharing with them on Discord, and thanks to the low price it was an easy sell. From the moment 3 of them bought the game, up until the writing of this review, I've been playing it with them. It's currently 4:23 AM and as I checked my Steam Overlay in-game, I had been in-game for approximately 5-6 hours in just that single session of playing with them. It's incredibly addicting and fun, and the talent tree feels incredibly rewarding to slowly chip away at and very impactful. I hope the game recieves even more updates and gets the love it deserves, because it's fucking glorious.

There's not much to say that's new. The game is actually difficult, which is great; skill improves this a lot. Each run is different enough to be fresh. Unlocking new weapons and certain talent options vastly increase your power (If you want to get farther, you'll need to max out all the exclusive stuff; gemini won't matter until the third stage, which you won't reach anytime soon as a newbie). The devs are active and responsive. Best of all, it's very cheap for very high quality.

Not often I play a game I have nothing really bad to say about. If I had to nitpick, the translations into english can make some interactions unclear, but google fixes that very quick.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: I'm 60 hours in and not planning to stop until all the content releases. For 12 dollars this is an amazing value. Even though this game is in Early Access it is insanely polished and has very tight gameplay with a large skill tree and many modifiers (scrolls, characters, acensions) that keep it fresh. I would have happily paid 40 bucks or more for what I got in this game. You might be able to run through the game in 45 minutes after you have mastered it and leveled up alot, but that won't happen for quite awhile. It took about 58 hours to get to level 100 though I do take my time. If you like to max out your characters and unlock all the items and weapons this game will keep you busy for a very long time, and it's not even done yet. I can't wait to see what else comes out in the future. This is my favorite indie game of the year. Its also my second favorite of the year in general ( Doom Eternal being first). There is no reason not to buy this game. It is insanely cheap for how much playtime it offers. 100% hugely recommended

review: One of the best early access titles out there. Guns are fun and inventive, the wide range of skills and upgrades to skills and stats are valuable and quite varied so many builds are possible. Theres a global progression system that persists after each run allowing you to feel like youre always gaining something no matter how far you get. The game runs very well for what it is as well. There are currently only 3 worlds to go through but its early access so thats understandable, even then, it took me quite long to actually "beat" the game once and still my global stats are only about half maxed out and theres a whole other hard mode to run through which seems to bring some new mechanics to the table to test your mastery. This game is very fun if you love borderlands or FPSs with RPG elements. 100% recommend at the price point and quality

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
One of my favorite Roguelites to date! I find the graphics style incredibly pleasing and easy on the eyes. It's very easy to distinguish what's going on in game visually.

I'll try a pro/con list for this review:

Pros:

*Visually pleasing
*Good in game sound track
*Super responsive controls(everything feels nice and tight)
*Interesting weapon choices and combinations
*3 characters to choose from each focusing on a different playstyle
*Tons of replayability
*Very difficult(feels fair, but RNG can be against you and cause your run to end early)
*Online Coop up to 4 people. It's P2P(peer 2 peer) connection, not dedicated servers just so you're aware. Largely online games go smoothly but you might experience minor lag randomly. As of 9/14/20 there is a bug that when typing in online coop, my game freezes and crashes Steam. As long as I don't type, I have no issue. (I'm sure this will be addressed at some point, I'm also sure that I'll not remember to update this review when it is)


Cons:

*English Translations are still a little rough, but you can largely understand what the descriptions are getting at.

*Very grindy. There is a meta progression that you level up after each run that make subsequent runs easier. Some skills increase damage, ammo capacity, health/shields/armor, or reduce damage taken. After becoming more comfortable with the mechanics of the game, I haven't gone back and tried playing on a fresh save. It feels, especially when you're first starting out, like you NEED the damage reduction and increased shields/health just to stay alive. The game almost seems impossible without those boosts.
------I will add that I do enjoy the grind, the further down the tree you go, the more smoothly your runs will go and it gives you something else to look forward to, besides just gameplay.

*Some guns are just plain better than others. After playing the game for about 5-10 hours it becomes pretty clear which guns you should avoid after the first level because they just aren't as good compared with others. The Kunai weapons are just too strong when compared with the other weapons, in my opinion. Or rather, the other weapons are too weak. I think the kunai are in a good place and that the other weapons(like the hippo) just need to be brought up to that same place.



Things I'm hoping are added in the future:
It would be nice to have additional characters in the future.
A more coherent story line
More guns added, with some of the weaker guns being buffed so they're useable.
I would also like to see stage/boss variants, I think that would be a great addition. Or to have separate missions to play through similar to the one mission we currently have.
Having a separate game mode that loops, similar to Risk of Rain2, would also be a really fun addition imo.




All in all, I highly recommend this game. It's already worth the price tag, and I'm sure it will only get better as they continue to update and improve this game throughout early access! It's a great little FPS with some borderlands/RoR2 style game play!
