title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
So I know I don't have many hours into this game (only 11 at the time of review) but I feel like it's enough since I've gotten all the way to the current "Final Boss"
Let me also say I'm not a roguelite player, this is technically my first ever dive into the series type in terms of playing one so I'm not an expert on this, just a casual player. With that being said, it's fun for what it is. If that's what you wanna know there you go no more reading for you, if you wanna know a bit more, well I got you. 
So first off, gameplay, it's an FPS with roguelite elements, what it says on the tin. You randomly find different guns and scrolls as you play and that helps you progress. Most guns seem to be unique in some form so they all have a clear advantage or disadvantage with various stats and extra modifiers. You may pick up a gun that boosts your crit chance, then you may find the exact same model of gun but it boosts your damage instead. Some guns may also come with an element while others are guaranteed to have one. 
As you kill enemies you get copper, that's your currency for the game. Randomly you can find the Peddler, who will sell you health, ammo, guns, and even some scrolls. Though you can only purchase said item once per stage so no infinite health. You could also run into the Craftsman, he'll boost your guns damage or later on reforge it to have some better modifiers. He too, like the Peddler, has a limit on how many times he can upgrade your weapon. He gives you two enhances per stage, though I'm not sure on reforges. They are guaranteed to be in the boss level so you can count on them to be there. 
Scrolls can sometimes be dropped by an enemy but mostly you'll find them in treasure rooms that require you to complete some sort of challenge, be it kill all enemies or an obstacle course. Scrolls are your boosts, from giving you ammo randomly, to boosting your crit damage, even giving a huge damage reduction at the caveat of taking more damage depending on the range the enemy is at. 
Next up is when you complete a stage you'll get a golden goblet that can give boosts to your character's abilities. Though I've only played as the cat and not the dog so I'm not sure what dog can get but cat can get element damage boosts, upgrades for his grenades, and make his ability have an AoE effect and increase its duration, just name a few. There's 18 total that you can pick and some have multiple levels, to make them better. 
Lastly is the talent tree. When you die, cause you will, you'll get the game over screen. The next screen is the talent tree which you spend souls to boost your character permanently. So each time you dive in, you dive in a bit stronger than before and it's a nice feeling. You'll get souls as you kill enemies and can even revive yourself at the cost of souls but it only works once per level so save it for when you absolutely need it if you can. Also whatever souls you don't use until you get a certain skill in the talent tree will be lost each new run so it's best to try and use every soul that you can each time.

Now onto Art Style. It's a unique style, for the 3D models go back to old school days of the 6th maybe even 5th generation of gaming (PS1/PS2) with the overall polygonal models. However, they are very polished and smooth so nothing looks super jarring or hard on the eyes. Everything from the guns to enemies to even the levels look very nice and I don't think I'll get tired of how it looks anytime soon. Also if you couldn't tell, the designs are very Asian/Eastern oriented. A lot of the weapons are designed with this Chinese aesthetic, and the first world is the same, even the boss. The second world is a bit more desert themed but I don't see a clear distinct style with it, maybe Egyptian but I could be very wrong. The third world is Japanese oriented, from enemies to level design, it just screams "JAPAN!" in a good way.

Multiplayer is essentially all of before, except enemies will be scaled based on how many players you have, and bosses will have more health. Get a good group that communicates and you can easily get all the things you want, be it your preferred gun or preferred scrolls. Yeah you can drop most scrolls so you can give your team mates the scrolls you don't want/need that may be very beneficial for them, which helps the group in the long run. Also if someone dies you can buy them back once from the peddler, though the further you go the more it'll cost to revive. 

Story... Bad guys showed up, you fight them, that's it. I mean that's it in a nutshell, you don't really get much more than that when starting, though there's plenty of lore that you can access from the logbook about some of the enemies. 
Anyway that's the good things, now onto some negatives. Though take some of these with a grain of salt and keep in mind that they may very well be nitpicks.

The game can go from 0-100 really quick if you don't know what you're doing or just get unlucky. Some enemies can be very annoying and can be encountered early on (Looking at you longbowman with bullets that can home in on you) though overall again this can mitigated by just playing the game and learning about the mechanics just a little. 

Multiplayer is a good thing for this game but the way it currently is, well it's not super bugged or anything but there's some slight annoyances to it. To start of, multiplayer is locked till you reach level 10, levels are defined by your talent tree, so it's better trying to use every soul you possibly can so that way you get most bang for your buck. I'm not sure if things are client based or not and if they are which ones that applies to. Had someone say the buns (aka health items) are client based so if you see one, that's yours. Though it sometimes seems like certain guns are client based too, until someone picks one up then drops it. So at times you're not sure what's client based or what's group based so you might be taking the gun someone else wanted to use. Then the multiplayer itself, there are no servers, it's all player to player. Meaning if you have a host with a bad connection or get paired with a group where you have high ping, expect a lot of issues. If there were some sort of setting to say "Don't connect me to groups where my ping exceeds X amount" it'd make groups a lot better. 
Now remember when I said obstacle courses for the treasure rooms? Yeah those things can give you a lot of trouble. Not the first ones, those are mostly timing based. No in the second world you can get these little parkour challenges and this game was not meant for platforming. Many times I swear I should've made the jump but the game said nope. On top of it there are moments where you have to essentially do a 180 around a wall for a jump. Even then those, while frustrating aren't as bad as the one you find in world 3. There's the one where you essentially cannot jump. They placed a ceiling above your head and there's no room to jump, forcing you to run forward and dash, which most likely will end up with you falling off. Now mind you these parkour challenges are optional in the treasure rooms but they give a Jade Chest. Jade Chests will give you 3 scrolls and you can pick which one you want instead of just being stuck with only one. But this parkour challenge is timed, take too long and no jade chest for you, which is very easily done if you don't spend a lot of time practicing the required jumps. 
Then my biggest issue with this game, is actually the best praise I can give it. There's just not enough to it. Though to be fair a 12 dollar game in early access that has given me 11 hours SO FAR is really great. So here's hoping we'll get more than 3 worlds and some more guns soon. 
So maybe pick it up yourself and play it. (Removed an issue that got fixed. Also they improved the jumping but still a bit tricky)

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
A neat little roguelite FPS. Reminiscent of Ziggurat for those who've played. Review based on 2 hours of solo play.

As with other Early Access FPS roguelites, it has some common issues related to balancing and RNG. There's randomized weapon and effect pickups, and sometimes the RNG does weird things and you get ridiculously overpowered items or total garbage. This is part of the fun of these kind of games, but I feel like I pickup too many borderline useless weapons/items. In my first couple of hours, I often found myself preferring the default weapon over pickups with undesirable stats, and I didn't care enough to adjust my play to conditional buffs from items (e.g., after you kill an enemy under some condition you gain X% damage for X seconds). But you can somewhat make up for bad items with FPS/twitch skills and the shooting with just basic guns feels solid.

Difficulty - game so far is surprisingly hard; I don't mind it but I feel like I take damage that I can't see/avoid. I'm not sure if it's an issue with visual representation of incoming damage or a hit detection thing. Either I shrug off damage that the self-replenishing shield heals with no problem, or I suddenly drop dead on my face with no idea of what killed me. No in-between of "uh-oh, I'm in trouble, better hide." I find myself hiding behind walls and peeking through the run. Maybe I'm just getting old.

Visual style - initially I hesitated to buy because I thought the visual style was too "cute," but in-game it feels OK. It's definitely more whimsical than serious, and that helps to keep a difficult (so far) game fun and enjoyable.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
From my first impressions, decent for its genre with definite room to grow. Can be enjoyed by most FPS fans, as long as they don't have a problem with the rogue genre niche. I concurr that the pricetag is more than fair for what you get as of right now.

PROS
- Gunplay feels good overall with some interesting weapon mechanics. "Casually serious", as if Destiny 2, Borderlands and Overwatch (and perhaps Valorant) had a baby.
- Lovely simple art style. Cartoony with distinct polygons, which allows generally clear visuals.
- Loadout mechanics are clear enough from the first runs.
- The relative difference in movement between player (slow-ish but with burst with the cat's dash, for instance) and common enemies (multitude of enemies that can even move even faster than you) works fine and adds a slight strategic element.

CONS
- The levels of each stage, as mentioned by others too, are samey. At the very least, some more visual differentiation in the rooms in the spirit of the already easy to look upon art - style could work wonders. For instance, Immortal Redneck is a great example on how to keep rooms visually interesting with a vague insinuation that there is an interesting unspoken lore behind, even if they are semi - procedurally generated.
- The default weapon is nice and it is interesting that it scales, but it hinders the elemental combination mechanics. Personally I would like the ability to replace it, with the ability to re- acquire in the beginning of the next stage or buying it from a peddler, for instance. I realize that might require lots of re - balancing, but I think it can affect positively how good the game feels overall and play a bit more on the elemental mechanics that a good chunk of the gunplay is already based upon.
- Navigation around props / cover, as well as jumping on them could use some refinement. Especially the jump feels kind of weak. Also, additional props and slight map geometry changes can help with the verticality to make player navigation feel more engaging and reward a bit more active pursuing of enemies when the situation calls for it.
- Cat and 1st boss - specific nag time: the dash feels to me underpowered for the combination of the boss being both a jumper and a caster of a strong AOE. As a result, I feel forced to always keep a distance and save the dash mainly for the AOE or the leap, instead of getting rewarded for outmaneuvering in any other way apart from momentarily using the pillars. I am ok with the timing for avoiding attacks being tight, but a bit more movement for the player or smaller AOE on his attacks would feel better, even if the boss had more health to counter-balance that.
- Devs please allow for some crosshair refinement options, especially size and inaccuracy bloom!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn is criminally underrated and deserves to get more attention. Their are 3 worlds but each play through is slightly different to the one before, weapons drop randomly along with fun gun play and a massive catalogue of guns along with a very nice art style which is nicely done. 

At the moment their is only 3 characters you can play with each with their own play style and abilities. However what i do disagree with is that you have to be level 30 and level 40 to unlock these characters so the player is required to grind to unlock them. 

Not played co-op yet but you have to be level 10 to use the matchmaking feature which i think is a good idea because the game forces you to play solo for the first 10 levels of your character progression getting use to the game play, how abilities and scrolls and elemental powers work, but on the other hand it stops friends from playing together straight away.

Gunfire Reborn needs more characters and a few more levels but the game is still in early access and for ¬£9.29 you bag yourself a very fun game to play at a bargain price. 

I highly recommend buying.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
this is a really boring rouge like, and i dont feel the path the dev team is heading down will  fix what i dont like about it.
in rouge like's/lites you do a run, you die, you start over. every time you restart you will be doing the same level first then the same level second, and what even more boring then that is each level has the same boss's and each level always has the same enemies. i dont know how people have put so many hrs into this game, but then again i do, modern gamer loves leveling up for the sake of leveling up. for me its just gotten really boring and repetitive, and there has been no sign that the devs plan on mixing up the levels and adding more boss's
more then the repetitiveness of this game, 
there are like 15 guns but depending on the character your playing you only ever want 2-3 of them and the rest are useless. you cant run, only walk and dash. and there is platforming in this game.
i recommend getting ziggaraut and risk of rain before buying this, when you start each run it wont be the same every time.
reading test- developer, dont bother leaving the canned response you leave in every negative review.
developer_response: Hi, thanks for your helpful suggestion. Current system is not perfect enough and we will optimize it, please give us more time.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: A fantastic roguelike with beautiful art and 3 fun classes. Imagine a first person Gungeon and Borderlands mixed, but without the joke weapons from Gungeon and a short, satisfying gameplay loop that fixes the loot slog created by Borderlands' core gameplay using roguelike mechanics. Games are relatively short and fun, with great feeling weapons mixed with the specialized power granted by Occult Scrolls, giving each game and level a different approach that is very unique to Gunfire's character building style. And it supports multiplayer to boot. Highly recommended, especially for the criminally cheap $12 price tag.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game shows a lot of potential, but there is already enough in the game to make it worth your money. The rogue-like elements combined with FPS action make this game exciting and replayable. Each of the three characters pushes you into a different game-play style, and there are a variety of weapons and scrolls to collect. The scrolls give you buffs that typically last for the run. Many are random drops, but some drops give you a choice of 3, so they allow you to build yourself in your own way. There are also permanent upgrades you can get, allowing even the worst runs to give you some progress. There are also random inscriptions weapons can have, giving them different stat buffs each time. Despite there being only 3 locations, runs still approach 40min - 1hr. However after completing each location, you can save your progress and resume later. One of the perhaps best aspects of the game is its co-op. While drops are local for each player, they can choose to "share" it, making it available for anyone to grab. The game also has multiple difficulties, if you put in enough time to beat the final boss. Speaking of, the bosses will absolutely wreak you the first time you encounter them. They hit like trucks, but once you get their patterns, they aren't so bad. The permanent upgrades also let you dispatch them quicker.

Rambling aside, even in its current state, this game is worth it. Playing with friends is best, but solo play is just fine. The core gameplay is already solid. IMO, the best thing the devs can do right now is inject more variety into the game. Some more weapon options might be nice in particular.

title: Gunfire Reborn

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
At the time of writing this I have a sizeable amount of playtime, max level (125), have beaten the game countless amounts of times and experienced it both solo and with friends. The game is genuinely great.

Gunfire Reborn (GFR from here on out) is a diamond in the rough when it comes to the sheer amount of games that try to do what it does, and it does it in spades. Now this is not without complaint, of course. The game can feel stagnate with continuous runs feeling more-or-less the same, the same stages, going for the same builds that you as a player naturally tend to prefer as you unlock new guns, scrolls, and characters.

More often than not I felt like a new gun would just pale in comparison to a previously unlocked weapon (Prism, Glimmering, Talisman) that does what a new gun does, but better / more reliably. I definitely feel like guns with scopes are obsolete by time you get your hands on them, and never feel as powerful as the previously mentioned guns due to the nature of how they are used. However, this complaint just reinforces what the game tells you, that the game is all about finding your play style, not what is the best.

GFR while in Early Access at the time of writing this is a more complete game than most games that are released. While a bold statement, I say that with confidence. The team from what I can see are active, they listen to the community, and they care about the product they want to deliver. GFR and their team have changed how I see Early Access titles in that regard, and that alone is worth supporting.

I can't wait to see this game's release, and the future of this developer. GFR is absolutely worth your time.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: Unique, creative gun-play around every corner. For about $10 there's probably around 80 hours of pure exploratory combat and platforming gameplay available here. Some may find this repetitive; not myself but I can see why some might. I think it'd be so cool if they added some form of PvP! Maybe you and another player could complete runs and collect guns until you battle each other instead of the boss at the end of each stage! After playing for 40 more hours I definitely have to comment on the choppy/ laggy online gameplay. Whenever I host a game online or with friends I have NO lag. But if a friend hosts or I join someone else's online lobby I lag hard. It feels like an optimization issue.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Do you remember when Blizzard made great games? I know it's been a while. What Blizzard would do is take already established ideas in gaming and polish them until they shined. 
Well, I think the developers of this game could very well be the new Blizzard. This is without a doubt one of the best games I have played in years. It's that good. 
It's really fun. The price is fantastic. The game is very hard to start with but after a while I got into the swing of things. It's a game I keep coming back to.

Edit: Ok, now that I have played 80+ hours let me say that I love this game. The combat is fast and very fun. The weapons are great, the arenas are a thing of beauty as far as the gunplay goes (And as far as art style goes) Gunfire Reborn has become one of my favorite games. Best of all it works great solo and is even more fun with friends. 

If you think this even looks like a game you would like...BUY IT!

Now I just want them to make the "RETURN" key bindable.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Really enjoying this so far. It's one of those games that I'm going to be very interested to see how it progresses. Feels like ETG, but FPS.
Guns are satisfying to shoot, the hit markers are well thought out and provide nice feedback and a pleasing feeling when you get that critical.  So far levels seem to be well laid out, although at times feel cramped, especially with the mechanic of enemies spawning behind you. With more than one player, some will be too small. 

I can't say too much more, as I've only played an hour and a bit, but so far, really liking what I see. This is a game that you can hop into and play quickly, like a ten minute stint, without having to be re-immersed etc.

Some will dislike the passive/background advancement/skill tree of characters I'm sure, but I personally enjoy it. It's done in a what feels like balanced manner.

Just my thoughts so far, but very excited to see what's coming down the pipe.

Edit: after more than a few run throughs on this, it's a great game so far. love the content and heros being added, as well as weapons and perks.

Couple this with the fact that every run you find different scrolls and weapons, and you have a gaming experience that feels fresh every run. I am 100 hours in, maxed out in levels and finished the game in elite mode a number of times, and I do not think I am about to stop.

If you like games like Borderlands and Destiny, buy it. Highly recommended... You will not be disappointed.

To be honest... The game is WAY better than it looks at first glance. I bought it to play with a friend, expecting to sink a couple hours before moving on. The gun modifiers and occult scroll combinations make the game ultra fun to tinker with all the possibilities. 
Not to mention two complaints I had for the game were patched out the following day, as apparently the community had the same gripes and the devs listened. 

Main thing i'd like to see from the Devs in regards to development on the Elite Mode... Add at least one new mechanic to each boss. Also consider having mini bosses spawn in random rooms, as an added layer of difficulty.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
TLDR: buy it. 10 bucks is 1000% worth the buy here. 

Early access tho??. Never crashed, never had problems connecting to my friends. Didn't even have a clipping bug. The game doesn't feel empty like I was expecting. 40 hours in, I'm still in my addicted phase and I haven't finished the game on normal yet. 

There are 3 maps. In each map there are around 5 stages, with the last one being the boss. You start on the first map, go through all the stages until the boss, where you go to the next map. When you die, you upgrade your character with the soul essence enemies dropped and then start from scratch. Nothing but those upgrades and your trusty default pistol. 

Weapons will have random traits on them when they're dropped, at random, by enemies. You'll find abilities at the end of stages or around the map. Some are unique to your character, some are not. This means that each character will play very differently. Some weapons are hot garbage on one character and s+ tier on another. These abilities and traits MATTER. 

Do not be alarmed, however. The game gives you plenty of choices and opportunity. Although a lot of this game is random, the player's choices outweigh luck a vast majority of the time in this game. You'll find a vendor around that offers different guns if the ones you have aren't working for you. 

Gunplay is definitely praise-worthy here. Guns feel great, and even just the simple default weapon is enjoyable to use. The weapons are unique and have their own style. I can tell what weapon I'm picking up when it's on the ground, and I remember exactly what every single one does. 

Character control is a little wonky, I have to admit. You can turn in the air and shift directions at constant speed. It won't feel realistic. 
That said, the parkour levels they add into this game are oddly satisfying. You'll find them in portals around the map occasionally as a replacement to the normal enemy levels, but you won't have to do so much of it that it feels invasive. Some will hate it, some will love it. I really love it.

There are many types of enemies. Some will snipe at you from a distance while others will run into your face with a flamethrower. Some of the enemy design is so well that they almost give away what they are the first time you see them. The kamikaze boxes run straight at you with a dangerous glow. The hulking tanks slowly inch forward with a shield in front of them. The fragile looking snipers hide in the back, looking for a shot at you. I'm never trying to figure out which enemy I'm looking at, it's obvious. 

Although there's a lot to love about this game, there are still some minor complaints.

1. Gun balance. There are a few guns that seriously suck, no matter what I tried. Some guns are completely overpowered. I find myself looking for a few weapons, and then just using them the whole level. It's not that they're inherently bad, but buffs are probably in order. 
2. Wonky hitboxes. Especially on the 2nd boss, I can barely tell when something is going to hit me. At the same time, I can't tell where the weakspot for the boss is either. Sometimes it is the mouth, sometimes the chin. 


Overall, this game is amazing. AMAZING I tell you. You can feel the hard work the devs put into this game, and I applaud them for it. 
It's fun, it's addicting, it challenges the player in fair ways, and it most definitely is worth it's asking price.

in light of the response from the dev... i will now just call this a bad game. i wasnt going to origonally but now they just made me dislike them as a whole and responded with a generic ass response that only partly accurate. 0 effort in the response, 0 effort in their communication. dear devs... dont give half ass responses like that, if you wanna say something, take the god damn time to type it. and i will mention, just because i gave this a negative review i have still been playing it to continue giving it a fare review and to get everything unlocked to see what its like at its more complete state after the grind... but that response made me even lose interest in that now. please never reply to my review again dev's unless you are actually saying something impactful.

also they need to add actual selection on for matchmaking... make it easier for people to just make lobbys and wait for people, and see ping before you join so you dont have people joining then leaving

Only $12 and I've already put more time into than most of my $60 purchases. If you like a challenging rogue-lite with good co-op scaling, large variety of items/weapons, and a "little bit" of grinding; this is something you should play.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is so much better than any $12 game has any right to be. It's downright criminal how much fun it is.

Gunfire Reborn is your standard roguelike gameplay loop of kill, learn, die, repeat, but with stellar gunplay and really fun heroes. Gunfire features some truly unique weapons, each one feeling different from the other. The best part? No single weapon feels like "the best." Every single weapon has some kind of use and can fit a different playstyle.

The graphics aren't quite on the level of Borderlands 3, but they're really pleasant to look at and have a ton of charm. This is a good thing, as the game runs really, really well even when the screen's crowded with enemies.

This is easily my favorite game of 2020 so far, especially when playing with a buddy. The roguelike loop is addictive, the gunplay is far better than Borderlands, and the team has already added a new hero and a ton of weapons. I can't wait to see how this game grows from here on out. And even if it didn't get another update, I'd still say it was a steal at that ridiculous, ridiculous price of $12.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
A sleeper hit! Lovely art style and solid mechanics. Production values are high and well above your typical early access game. I don't know whether it's realistic to expect this to become as deep and polished as Deep Rock Galactic, but for 12 bucks this is a definite buy. Very playable in solo, and a blast in coop!

Update September 2020: The patches added lots of new enemies, weapons and another playable character, as well as ingame voice chat. The difficulty is a lot more even now too, though you will still need to level up a bit to get further in. If I had one criticism it's the lack of ability to join games that are already in progress, though that would require some balancing.

If you like fast paced FPS, this is a definite buy.

review:
The game while still in development has provided me a fair bit of hours of fun. I thoroughly enjoy this combination of Borderlands FPS/Loot-em-up gameplay with the Rogue-Like genre. It's definitely a battle starting out, but even after dying the game just plays solidly with tight gunplay. When RNG gives you builds that allow you to mop the floor you truly feel powerful. 

Cannot recommend this game enough for the price, this is one of the few Early-Access type games that I truly feel is worth getting while it's still in the program instead of waiting.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Game in Early Access at time of purchase.

I paid ten quid for this game, and have gotten 55 hours at time of writing. 
After Gearbox mugged me off for ¬£60 by removing a setting from BL3 8 MONTHS after the games release, rendering it unplayable to me, I was recommended this game from someone on the GBX forum.
 
I have several EA games from Humble monthly, but have never knowingly purchased one. Considering the price (¬£10) when I got it, and after watching a few gameplay videos, I decided to give it a try. 

A wise decision.

Pros:
3 Characters (so far) - With skill trees / Special abilities
3 Levels (so far) - Broken into several (4-5ish) mini-maps.
Several 'Vaults' within each Level.
Main Bosses - Sub Bosses - Unique Bosses
Many different enemies.
Shedload of weapons with unique abilities.
Another shedload of Scrolls.
Great gameplay (if maybe a little basic), with lots of variety.
Each run is different. 
Graphics fine.
Sound fine.
Controls fine(ish)
Re-playability - Through the roof.
Dev's constantly updating (and while not all updates / buffs / nerfs etc will please everyone, that's the EA purpose. 

Cons.

Key mapping needs a serious look at, especially for left handers.
Some additional sound sliders required for certain sounds. 
A couple of bugs (only two in 55 hours), that I have noticed.

That's about is for the cons. 

As a newcomer to this game type, I was initially a little frustrated at the beginning of playing this. I was not aware of the mechanics of a 'Rogue-lite' game. And progress initially seemed slow an arduous. Thankfully, the issue was BNIF (Big Nut In Front) ie, me!
And the main advice give on various forums, really is the only sound advice... Keep Playing. Build Your Souls. Level the character.
Do not expect to steamroller the first level immediately. Accept that failure is inevitable.

So that's my review. For an Early Access game. This thing is top-notch. The devs are active and responsive. The game runs smooth, gun-play is great.

It is very More-ish!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
really fun and nice to play when you have nothing else to do or just listen to a podcast when solo and could easily be a lot more fun with a full 4 player party. Few annoying things here and there but nothing to keep away from a fun gun and run game. If you have friends that enjoy playing through a run and gun hallway style game i suggest getting this game. Though i wish they added some randomness such as playing the other levels first (like the desert levels first instead of the castle) and have the enemies being brought down to an easier level. That and having the other playable characters be played at the start so not everyone is a cat and can find how you want to play the game with your friends or even allow.

Pros: 
-Guns are nicely designed
-Skill progression is fun and always different 
-A lot of replay in a good way

Cons:
-Level designs are simple and don't allow for a lot of discovery
-Enemies can feel basic in early levels and take a few stage clears to get more interseting ones.
-The other playable characters are locked behind a level system that makes you play to unlock them which makes unlocking them taxing and wish they weren't locked away so you can actually play around and figure out your playstyle 
-A lot of replay in a bad way

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: This game is honestly, hands down, one of the best games ive played. To start, there are so many different weapons, scrolls, advancements as well as talents to choose from. Along with that brings so many different combos you can use for each run, giving you the potential of a different playthrough each time. There are so many different rooms per stage you can almost go forever and never follow the same path twice. ive played 120 at the time of this and i have yet to run the same course twice. The devs are great at what they do and they actually care about their game and their players. They always accept recomendations and ask you to give your input on things that need work or things youd like to see in the game. They update the game frequently enough to feel like you arent running out of things to do and it never gets boring. I seriously recommend that you give this game a try. It is the best rouge-like i have ever played

review: This game is great, even in early access. the game play is smooth, and the shooting mechanics are good. the animation is amazing, even though it is still not finished. This game is really fun for anyone who liked risk of rain 2, or most people who play shooters. Its a great game for its price, and even after beating the game, there is lots of more things to do and is still fun to play again even if you feel like you have completed everything. You can play online or alone, and can join someones party if you want to play with them. the elite and nightmare modes are really good and are much harder. Overall, between its playability, challenge, fun, and replayabbillity, I would rate this game a 10/10. Also, its much funner to play with friends.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn is a roguelite first person shooter that borrows the best elements of borderlands (various unique weapons, action + skill tree mechanics, elemental affinities minus the infamous Slag) while completely forgoing the grind and instead lets you in on the action immediately. No quests, no map travel, and no inventory hassle; it's all grab, go, and shoot. You can also play with up to three friends/randoms or just play solo.

The mechanics are tight and the gunplay is satisfying. Most of the weapons are uniquely fun and the current selection of characters are great to play, each offering multiple different playstyles depending on build. This is also the only roguelite in recent years that have me still hooked and playing long after a first win.

Perhaps my only gripe is the balancing.

The first 2 bosses are great, albeit on the easy side, with clear tells and enough leeway to dodge/react while on the other hand, the 3rd boss has instakills that gives you a much smaller time to react all the while throwing mechanics at you at a pace that felt disproportionate to the overall experience. 

Having finished a couple of runs in elite and trying for nightmare clear, not all weapons/ascensions are viable and some are just straight up bad, at least in my experience playing only on solo. Though I do think this is just the side effect of ARPGs/looter shooters with multiple difficulties in general.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
A very fun game for coop.
I am a mostly casual gamer these days and prefer coop games. This scratches the same itch for me as Borderlands, but is a simpler rogue-like FPS.
The combat feel is great (though simple) and, at least so far, every playthrough has been fun. My friend and I struggle with the bosses, but your character gradually gets stronger over time (you get points to spend after a playthrough to permanently increase HPs, etc.), so you can eventually get through even if you're not so skilled at FPSs anymore like me :-)
The synchronicity between the various different weapons/scrolls/bonuses is great. You wind up playing very different styles depending on which you get (which is random, so if you only want to play a certain style that probably won't work so well).
Though it is early access it's pretty polished and I haven't encountered too many bugs yet.
Highly recommended!

and even after finishing the entire early access content a few times on all characters i still played it after my internet came back.

the thing that makes this game great is how unique the scrolls are (and weapons to some degree,specifically the prefixes)
the synergies are fantastic the combination between weapon,weapon prefix,character,character talent and scrolls makes this game into a great game.

the RNG rooms are good not great but good.

the bosses feel good.

the things that this game needs is variation in bosses+scenes(also make it RNG)
and maybe add a 4th stage with more items(weapons/scrolls) as DLC or something like that

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I am really enjoying this game. It feel very Borderlands-esque and doesn't seem to be another game following in on Binding of Isaac's coattails.

It does have it's power ups but it also has guns providing two aspects of randomization that and be independent of each other while also pairing rather well. I've had runs with great guns but not the best of power up and even terrible guns and excellent power up.

You also have an RPG passive skill tree that can assist you in basic powering up you baseline for each run so within every failure you can allow yourself to permanently get a better foot forward next time.

I definitely recommend this game 100%.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is super good and super content rich rn, even in its super early access state. But I'mma list the pros and cons anyways just so this is more concise. 
Pros
1.) Guns feel nice and solid, chunky hit and reload sound effects and super creative designs
2.) Enemies feel good to fight and have very unique reasons for existing, like the sniper exist so that you don't just run in and fuck everything up immediately and the knight horse guys exist to keep you on your toes, you have to ignore them but keep them in the back of your head while fighting grunt enemies so you can dodge their sword laser and kill them in time. 
3.) Characters are nice and diverse, we have a raw damage guy, a utility guy, and a melee guy, they all play super differently. 
4.) ART IS SO FUCKING GOOD
5.) Bosses are the most creative and fun parts of the game, they really truly feel like they challenge everything the gameplay teaches you up to the point to when you fight them. 
Cons
1.) Music fits the setting but is kinda meh
2.) The dash. This is my biggest gripe, the dash fills a super important role in allowing you to dodge homing enemy attacks or big telegraphed ones and plays a big part in the platforming. However, it doesnt feel snappy at all. You can see your character stuttering forward every time you dash, it doesn't feel like an instant dodge move because of that weird buggy stuttering. If this was fixed the game would feel a hell of a lot more smooth. 
3.) The amount of levels is a bit lacking but it's safe to assume this will be changed as more content gets added
4.) Amount of characters, but again, this will be changed as more stuff comes to the game. 
5.) We need more enemies with more unique weakpoints, I love the inspiration this game obviously takes from DOOM Eternal, by adding that dash, and allowing enemies to have attacks that aren't dodgeable without the dash, and focusing on enemy weakpoints so heavily, but I feel that we need more enemies that have weird weakpoints, like the huge black lizard dudes with the scar on their backs, or like the sand worm boss and how hes only weak to damage when his mouth is open. Maybe they could add like samurai enemies that have armor plates that you could shoot off to expose their weakpoint or something, I just love the idea of an enemy having that leeway of being basically invincible before you shoot its weak points off, like revenants or mancubus from DOOM Eternal. It allows the game to be more challenging while also staying fair. 
Overall, this game is a nice 7 right now, super fun to play, just really waiting for more content to be added, the biggest make or break for this game will probably be how unique they get with their enemy design later down the line, I'm a bit worried about it at the current moment because through all 3 of the "worlds" you go through in this game, there's a couple repeat enemies that share AI. But, in it's current state, it's a pretty good challenging roguelike. I would definitely pick it up before the price increases at full release.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Time of review: 2:40 AM.

Time me and my friends started playing this game: exactly 4.6 hours ago.

Get this game before they (probably) raise the price.

It's truly Risk of Rain + Borderlands, and it's as fun as it sounds. It's hard at the beginning, but you definitely get stronger with the permanent upgrades. Highly, highly recommend.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
If it's this fun as Early Access, it's gonna be awesome as an official release.

I got this Early Access for a low price. Highly recommend doing the same. The game is way fun already and with each update things get better. The devs seem to be truly invested in continuing improvement and delivering a great product. KUDOS!

I love playing this while listening to a philosophy lecture or watching a goofy sitcom on a second monitor. Great way to decompress. I like that it rewards different play styles. If you want to power game and crush the win super hard, you can; there's a good combination of luck and tactics and skill. If you wanna enjoy a beer and a toke and just mellow out while killing baddies, well, you'll maybe die a lot but souls carry over for incremental progress, so dying isn't necessarily a bad thing..

TBF, I haven't tried  multi-player, which undoubtedly makes the game more complicated and interesting. Soloing all day, every day. ;P Even so, I  keep coming back to play more and even though I've maxed out the talent tree for all the dudes, I'm still not bored. 

To reiterate, things keep getting better with each update. Hopefully the trend will continue after official launch.

At the moment, it's definitely worth the price. BUY IT NOW!!!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Haven't played much of this game, but I can already tell its heading in the right direction. The movement and moment to moment combat feels good. However I do have a few things I would like to see implemented:
-Movement speed boost/Upgrades. I would like to be able to increase my speed or have abilities upgrades that allow me to jump higher, run on walls, or jump off of things, ect.. After a while the simple strafe and dash feels slow and clunky. 
-More enemy weak points. Some of the enemies have massive health pools with a shield, and hitting them in the head is super difficult, since most of their hit-boxes are tall and slender; I would recommend putting 1 or 2 crit-points on tougher enemies to add variety to the gun play.
-Traps. I love the secret rooms that have traps. Please add more of those with maybe some puzzle solving thrown in. However, I would like to see more traps during the main dungeon crawl as well to add to combat. The traps would work on player and enemy alike.

Other than all of that, this game is a great time. I recommend it to anybody who wants a game that's easy to jump into and start kicking serious butt.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Actually a really fun game!

Here's the idea behind how it works:

You'll start off playing as a cat (The Crown Prince) and progress through different stages battling enemies and gathering scrolls that offer semi-random buffs. There are 3 themed locations and 3 bosses to separate them. Should you die, you are offered the chance to revive (at a cost) or end the run. You only get one revive.  Then you power up your character, and do the run again. Growing more powerful with each run. 

Its fun solo, and its fun with friends. I would definitely recommend.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Poggers game it's basically what would happen if Borderlands and Risk Of Rain had a baby. Devs constantly update the game and you can tell they really care about the game instead of making a quick cashgrab game. Lots of variations every run as you find synergies in different guns with their "inscriptions" (special effects like rate of fire increase, reload speeds, etc).

I'd rate it a 9/10. The game could use more guns, scrolls, bosses, etc but I'm sure more content will come as devs continue to update this game.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Would recommend if you like shooter/looter games like Borderlands or roguelikes like Dead Cells. The game provides a good challenge without being overly difficult or annoying, meanwhile providing you with a slew of unique weapons that always keep the gameplay interesting and enjoyable. 

At the time of writing this review, some enemies/rooms/bosses seem a little bit unfair, but if you play well and get good items you usually won't have a problem.

The game's still in Early Access so there isn't too much content yet, but what's there is very well-designed and will keep you entertained until more content is eventually added.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: I feel that this game has a lot of potential and, while I haven't played much yet, I plan to play this game a lot more. When I play it alone, it is still really good, just harder. When I play it with others, it gets much easier since we can revive each other and others can draw fire so it isn't all focused on you. The only thing I have to complain about is the low character choices, but that is increasing as the continue with updates. I believe this game has a lot of potential and as soon as it is out of early access, I think this game will be 10/10.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Great game so far! It was recommended by a couple friends and I ended up trying it out. 10/10 don't regret my purchase. Make cosmetic skins and allow us to get them either through achievements/challenges or through purchases! 

Also, very important, if it's possible to add client-sided latency prediction, so we don't have lag issues because of generic real-time p2p latency in game when playing with friends overseas, that'd be amazing. Right now it's a bit hard to dodge some boss attacks when playing with friends on 160-230 latency. This issue would be resolved entirely by adding client-sided prediction.

Other than that, fun experience!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Really polished game, highly addictive, and versatility in the different characters.

I also found that either playing with friends, strangers, or single player this game still was entertaining.

Graphics: 8.5/10. Charming low-poly characters, monsters, atmosphere. Great effects and playable on lower end PC's.

Sound: 9/10. Great intense boss music fights, guns sound great, effects sound great, each stage has unique tone.

Gameplay: 10/10. Undoubtedly, the combination of skills, talent, occult scrolls and weapons along with all the inscriptions encourage a varied style which makes this game highly addicting. I found myself constantly playing this over Triple AAA title games. 

This game overall gets a 9.2/10. Can't beat this level of quality for the price.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn is another rouge-like shooter that has done a fantastic job of making the game as addictive as possible.

For most games, how I define the greatness for the most part is based on how re-playable the experience can be. And Gunfire knocks it right out of the park with that one.

Although Gunfire is still in Early Access with many changes and additions planned to make their way in, it already is super solid for how it is currently. It's enough for me to say that if it didn't have (EA) attached to it at the moment, I would definitely believe that it was a ready game.

Gunfire Reborn is just like Risk of Rain and Binding of Isaac and all other rogue likes in which when you die you start fresh, but it does a good job by still making you feel like you're progressing even though it's a restart for every session.

The game implements a very thorough Talent tree in which the profits you make in your runs can be easily converted to the skills you wish to enhance, to better off your upcoming runs in the future. With this, each skill you upgrade is also represented as your player level. The more skills you unlock, the higher level your account becomes. And when it doesn't come to replay ability, Leveling system is immediately the right hand man for what gets me hooked on a game.

The weapons in Gunfire are pretty self explanatory, they're guns. But for those who wish to use other means of attacking they put that into account too and also added cool gadgets and gizmos to use instead. Such as, a laser glove, a fire dragon, a whole lizard, and even primary skills that each unique character has catered to them.

Thankfully if one character doesn't suit your taste with their play style, they also have 2 additional ones currently that spice things up a little.

The list of characters and their specialties:

The Crown Prince (Cat): Elemental damage, Smoke Bomb usage/buffs, Energy Orb Primary skill.

Ao Bai (Dog): Gun improvements, overall sustainability perks, grenade buffs, Akimbo Gun Primary Skill

Qing Yan (Bird): Overall sustainability perks, winged attacks, Claw Leap Primary skill.

Although there may seem very few in character numbers, their uniqueness makes the game play experience completely different from each other.

The game also uses a very subtle elemental system of three elements: Corrosion, Fire, and Lightning. With these three elements, based on who you're fighting they may have an element that consists of their being. By figuring out which element counters which, you can choose the appropriate weapon to gain bonus damage on said enemy. As well as dealing less damage if the enemy element is countering your current weapon.

A complete run of a Gunfire session takes about an average of forty minutes minimum, and up to an hour or longer afterwards. Don't expect to win a session on your first try, but with the help of unlocking items and learning each enemy's combat styles, you'll be soaring through the rooms in no time.

I've had my eye on this game for quite some time and finally got the urge to complete the purchase and i'm shocked as to how much time it has already sucked from my day to day life. The matches are played so differently every time that once i'm finished I hop right back in and see what new situations I am put against to squeeze my way out of this time.

If you are a fan of Risk of Rain and Binding of Isaac's play style, as well as most rouge genre games, Gunfire Reborn is surely up your alley.

review:
*It's a FPS action roguelike with different heroes with different abilities. You can try different builds with scrolls you get in-game as well as relics that you get at the end of every level. 
*It also has online co-op if you want to play with friends and the difficulty increases accordingly.
*There are currently 3 main bosses, mini bosses, secret rooms, platformer levels, a variety of weapons, different types of enemies, upgradeable weapons etc. 
*It's replayable and pretty fun. 
*It took me 36 hours to kill the final boss solo for the first time and then, I decided to write this review because I consider this game pretty underrated and It's still a work in progress. For this price tag, it's a steal. Just buy it.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This is legitimately one of the best shooters I have played in recent memory. The gunplay is excellent (I would say it feels similar to the Destiny, which I think has fantastic gunplay), the levels are well designed, and the enemies are interesting enough to not get bored. 
Though the most outstanding aspects of the game, in my opinion, are the progression and the gun variety. The pace the game progresses (unlocking new guns, new abilities, earning money and upgrades, discovering secrets and game mechanics) is perfect. It's fast enough so that there is [u] always [/u] something new to unlock or play around with, but it's slow enough so that you never get overwhelmed and always have something you're looking forward to. The gun variety is also something that I find incredibly well done. There are all sorts of interesting, fun, and crazy guns- from your standard assault rifles, to crossbows, lasers, rocket launchers, miniguns, dragons, geckos, shirukens, and much more, this game has it all. Furthermore, all guns have their own interesting perks and progression and you unlock many guns by progressing in ways you didn't even know you were, giving you a surprise new, interesting, and upgraded gun as a reward in one of your runs, which feels good every time. I could go on for many more paragraphs about how much I enjoy this game, but I think I've made my point. 
I will say, however, that I am personally not a big fan of the visuals, though I certainly don't think they should be a reason to not get this game. I have also not tried out co-op mode so far, so I cannot say how (well) co-op works and if there are any problems there that I have missed. 
Overall, I think this game is a nearly 10/10 game for almost anyone that enjoys shooters and I highly recommend it to anyone wanting to try something new.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
"Wow, a roguelike with multiplayer FPS gameplay, what a good idea !" That's what you might think. But you should be careful. The idea is good, the execution is frustrating and near to bad.

- Not enough variety in enemies and rooms patterns
- Items synergizing negatively (yes, you can have no more shield and 1 max hp)
- Not finding movement speed upgrades means that you will die, no matter how good you are. There are plenty of enemies able to one shot you, run faster than you, dash at you more often than you are able to dash.
- You finally have a good combo of items ? Let the game bring you the tankiest mob you will ever see. It will run faster than you and will slow you down
- The game is not made for solo players. Multiplier is mendatory since your mates can resurect you. So the one shot from ennemies is less punishing.
- You feel like you have no damages against bosses, elites and enemies with some weird modifiers. why the first boss has 200k damages when my pistol doesn't do more than 200 damages ? I don't know. Does the boss need to regen his shield several times during the fight ? Oh no, he doesn't

After 18 hours in the game, I am finally able to unlock skills at the end of the skill tree. Too bad that 1 run only allows me to upgrade 1 skill at a time because the currency is so rare or just because the costs are stupid.

Good point of this game : 3 playable characters (but once you have the third one, you have to stick with him because he has an extra dash and it's by far the best thing in the game), the multiplayer FPS is a good idea, if you find the good upgrades the game becomes funny until you get take a one shot


I can not recommand this game

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
It's great to see an Indie game get traction, especially a coop roguelite, however this game is lacking diversity for me. 
- Gameplay loop is not satisfying for me, making it feel very repetitive
- Early-metagame complexity is disappointing for beginners
- Combat mechanics are only okay (not a big problem if level design is good)
- Classes do not offer enough differentiation
- Classes are locked too far behind a wall of GRIND (not skill or rng)
- Movement is bland and unexciting
- Lack of innately creative tools for players to express their playstyles (other than through RNG drops)
- Randomized level design is repetitive

The biggest problem I find is lack of available differentiation between player playstyles for a beginner like me. I do not want to grind 5 - 10 hours just to hope to unlock another class, which at first glance doesn't seem that much different from the starter class anyway.

Another big issue is the lack of tools that can accentuate a player's creativity or personality in their playstyle. Deep Rock Galactic does this excellently as all its classes have truly unique and impactful/gamechanging movement tools that can be used in any number of ways. Risk of Rain 2 is another game I've been playing that has really great tools that encourage player creativity and inspires a feeling of freedom.

Gunfire Reborn feels like a Proof-Of-Concept at this point. The core idea of roguelite Borderlands is exciting, but the ancillary gameplay aspects are unrefined and not interesting to me at all.
developer_response: Sorry for your unpleasant experience, we will add more content and randomnessÔºåand we will optimize the game difficulty and game balance in the future update, stay tuned.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
One of the past updates or something in Nightmare mode has made this game go from great to fucking unbearable. It's like it constantly falls out of sync and nothing matches what actually happens. On top of that the hit boxes and collision boxes are terrible. You'll constantly get stuck on ledges while enemies will phase on different levels or take pathing that doesn't make sense in order to reach you. You can regularly see enemy attacks and sniper shots go past you either to your sides or above you and still get 1-shot by them.

If they get these issues fixed it'll be back to being great but until then don't bother if you're planning on playing on higher difficulties. Yes, I know Nightmare is in beta mode but no other mode suffers from the desync and it is insufferable. The other modes are also tolerable with the other issues mentioned since you can usually survive a hit or two.

I will continue to play this game but it's pretty rough to enjoy right now.
developer_response: Sorry for your unpleasant experience. We will check and fix this issue asap. Please give us more time.

review:
Definitely one of the best rouge-lite games I‚Äôve ever played.  The only element I don‚Äôt like is that the ‚Äúrandom‚Äù levels don‚Äôt vary much at all, and not much is left to surprise after a few hours of gameplay.

The English translations are sometimes poor on item descriptions, and make you scratch your head about what whatever you‚Äôre reading means in terms of affecting your gameplay.  This isn‚Äôt a large concern as I‚Äôm sure they will eventually clean this up.  Anything I‚Äôve been confused or curious about, I‚Äôve been able to research on their wiki for more clarification.

Overall, as it stands right now, good game with lots of room for improvement and growth.  7/10 but could easily become 10/10.

review:
Brilliant early access fps with fun co-op option. I would say this game has huge potential and it has very fun mechanics with different types of builds you can build with characters and their talents, guns + ascensions and scrolls. Minor downside in my honest opinion is the dullness of which comes from playing three same zones again and again despite the fact that event portals etc. bring a nice little touch of making zones different on every run.

I am very eager to see where this game will be going in the future, but at the current state considering it is just an early access game I highly recommend it!

Or they could go the ROR2 route with artifacts like command that lets you choose your scrolls or ascentions, glass where you do way more damage but have way less health etc. 

 In short,
graphics 10/10
Gameplay loop 8/10
Servers 7/10 occasional crashes and dips
weapons 9/10

As for as unlocking things most things are easy, however some (especially Demonlore) is extremely grindy and time consuming and require some good RNG

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game has been one of the most pleasant surprises on Steam. The gameplay is skill based, the gunplay is fun, with the critical damage system meaning you have more reasons to learn the enemies, the guns are varied in themselves on top of randomized bonuses, the characters play uniquely and have different skill trees.
And on top of all that, the updates are regular and adress exactly what the players want. So far, it's been three times that I mentioned something would be an improvement and it got added literally a week later.
One of the best developers I've seen.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Fun Roguelite FPS. Uses a similar element system to Borderlands, but there's also a combination effect if you stack multiple. The guns are satisfying, and it's fun to try and shape a build. Extra fun when all your modifiers just click and support each other. Better with other people as you can drop modifiers to help shape each others builds in a run. There's a bit of long-term progression through unlocks and perks, at 30 hours I am only missing a couple guns and am almost max level.

Biggest criticism is just how lite the content is. There is replay value, but there's only the three stages with no option to keep your run going once you clear the final boss. Actively being updated, which helps.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
So, do you like borderlands 2 style of gunplay? Do you enjoy rogue likes? Are you the type of guy who is willing to endure getting their rear handed to them while you are still in the learning process? Do you like GUNS, and do you like chinese inspirations?

Then this game is probably for you! While the game doesn't have much content right now in terms of levels, it makes it up a lot through replayability! With a ton of weapons you can play around with and unlock, 3 characters who can find their playstyle and perks varying from run to run via unique upgrades each one can get via golden goblets. Various scrolls to further add to your abilities, and a somewhat addicting permanent upgrade tree between runs.

What Gunfire reborn does is simple, yet effective. Throwing you into linear levels, and giving you a hoard of enemies to shoot your way through.

That being said, there are some things you should be aware of. 

This is a ROGUE LIKE, ya know, like games such as Binding of Isaac, Risk of Rain, or Gungeon. That means if you die, you go straight back to the very start. You have been warned people who aren't already invested in the genre.

The other thing about this game you must be wary of, is the rather steep learning curve at the start. Not helped by how the skill tree limits your power early on, meaning death can come really swiftly, and unexpectedly to those who aren't at their A game, especially at the very first boss who has an attack pattern that can be easily dodged, but is brutally punishing to those who haven't got a hang of it yet.

BUT if you manage to break through the games punishing early learning curve, you have yourself a VERY fun, (and cheap) first person shooter on your hands! Even made better if you have a friend or two you can play with.

(Note, you can only play multiplayer at lvl 10. If you wanna level up fast to unlock new characters and other things quickly. just buy lots of cheap upgrades, as each upgrade is a level)

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
So, after around 50 hours or so sank in, I think I can give a decent review.

Pros:
-Fluid combat.
-Well worth the money spent based on potential playtime
-Good progression system in terms of skills/unlockables
-Challenging.
-Multiplayer works flawlessly
-Very few bugs/glitches
-Devs add new content and updates regularly.
-Nearly endless ways to build your character and loadout each time.

Cons:
-Obviously, being the same 3 stages, things get repetitive occasionally.
-At this point, I wish there was a bit more content
-RNG based, heavily, when it comes to drops for anything

Overall, I think if you give gunfire the good o'l college try, and play through more than just a round or two, you will find it's enjoyable, and progressively challenging as you continue on. The three available characters are all quite unique, and have their own playstyles which freshens things up. I recommend it, mostly if you have 1-2 people you can play with. Playing solo would certainly be a little stale, in my opinion.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I'll start by admitting that there is something about these more random rogue type games that doesn't really click with me. Starting game after game going through the same starting levels hoping that maybe, just maybe... THIS time the right items will drop and I can progress slightly further than last time is a bit too much like sitting for hours in front of a slot machine, albeit a bit more interactive (but without the free booze). Making run after run through the same bland levels doing your best ATF impression as you shoot all manner of gun-wielding dogs and other critters is fun at first, but by your fourth or fifth slog through the same levels (no, randomly changing where the doors are doesn't inject new life into each run) only to find out that you're simply too ill-equipped to progress is just not fun. I could complain about difficulty spikes and some enemies with ridiculous homing ranged attacks, but I imagine these will be ironed out in later versions of the game.

The game has its charms: each run DOES give you a chance to give small permanent buffs to your character, and sometimes you can get some really wonky combos going. The quality is fantastic for an early-access game, as well. But when each pull on the handle of the slot machine robs you of 45 min to an hour of your life only for you to find out that you didn't get the three cherries this time, the little bits of fun here and there simply aren't a good return on your investment of time. And the time it takes to unlock the second and third characters means your runs are going to be very very similar to one another for quite some time.

I'll revisit this game and likely play it after a few updates, and perhaps I'll end up changing my review. As things stand, the game falls just short of a recommendation.

Cute animals though.
developer_response: Sorry for your unpleasant experience, we will add more content and randomnessÔºåand we will optimize the game difficulty and game balance in the future update, stay tuned.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Rewriting my review from original 1 hour of playtime.
This game has serious potential. It's one of my favorite games to play at this time. Think Borderlands meets The Binding of Isaac and you have Gunfire Reborn. The gunplay is very fun, there is some strategy involved in becoming powerful, every run is slightly different, and each Hero has a different playstyle that is worth playing no matter your progress in the game. 

The only thing the game lacks is good English translation (this seems to be improving) and end-game content. You can likely max your level completely/unlock everything within 40 hours of gameplay. Which is a solid amount of time but it can start to lose replay value once you're maxed out. We need more reason to play outside of the game being fun and a good time passer, some kind of progression for late game content could give reason to dump a thousand of hours into this game. It has that much potential and I really want to see it get to that point.

For an Early Access game this is a steal for the price. Yes it's Early Access, yes it's not done, yes there is occasional bugs, but in the end of the day you can have so much fun with this game. If you like roguelites and shooters you need to pick this game up.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn is a solid game even though its still in early access. The gameplay is really fun and replayable, the guns are all relatively unique and viable in their own ways, lots of choices when creating your build on a run, fairly challenging, and most important of all: it's a great game to play while listening to podcasts! 

Some things that the game needs to work on include the text issues where some of the english is kinda broken (understandable) thus creating possible miscommunications on what a skill does or how a scroll will affect the character. Each level also lack variety as even though they're procedurally generated; it is really easy to get familiarized with the level design and so the game gets tedious a lot more easily. Though these are only minor inconveniences and don't really detract the fact that Gunfire Reborn is a really solid game.

In the current patch, you can unlock all the characters and get to the final boss in about 15-20 hours. I'd say that's a massive value for a game this fun and cheap! All in all Gunfire Reborn is a great relaxing game to play with tons of update to look forward to in the future!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I read/watched a lot of good reviews about this game, seemed like it would be right up my alley. I was wrong.

Played a few rounds solo and I can say I didn't enjoyed it too much. 

TL;DR; Good gunplay (not amazing), cool weapons (didn't get that far to unlock more of them, and I won't. At least for a while). Clunky, forgettable maps/rooms. Graphics overall are ok, not great, even though it's cartoony. Hard to read text? (I don't have issues on any other games). Has potential, will wait for more updates before I jump in again.

As far as I have played and am concerned:

- The good -

- Cool Character(s)
- Some cool weapons
- A lot of different passive buffs

- The bad -

- Dash is way too short
- Maps/rooms are way too small/cramped (to my liking)
- Enemies attacks that track you (they curve as hell)
- Enemies with huge AOEs
- Lots of enemies on some areas
- All of the above combined
- Platforming sections (they're optional though)
- Initial character grunts are way too annoying, had to turn off the voice volume

As someone who enjoys Borderlands and Risk of Rain a lot, I was stoked about this game. It isn't what I expected it to be (yet). I'll check it out again after a couple of updates.

Do not recommend this right now.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Early Access Roguelite FPS for 1-4 players, P2P-based!

Pros/Features:
- Devs read the forums and update regularly!
- 38 different weapons. Feel very different too - some have special abilities or passives (e.g. you can use one of the weapons to shoot, or to throw it to make a large explosion)
- Leveling system to give you better starting stats or unlock playable characters. You level up when you lose a run, more if you got further (remember, it's a Roguelite)
- 100+ different upgrades you can get during a run. Those can improve damage, status effects, defense, movement etc.
- Currently 3 playable characters with very different strengths, like favoring elemental, explosive or close range weapons
- weapons appear with 1-6 random upgrades depending on how far you are in the run. These can be anything from "+Fire Rate" to "Only 2 shots in magazine but the second does x3 damage" to "create a hovering lightning ball whenever you headshot"
- All enemy shots can be dodged by "dashing", enemies do NOT have hitscan

Cons/Still needs work, it's EA:
- Three difficulty modes, but they're mostly about ++HP and ++Dmg
- Don't have a native English translator, so the descriptions of upgrades can sound weird (but 95% of them are still correct)
- Since no enemies are hitscan, they get to deal a lot of damage in return - if you don't move a lot and dodge regularly, you'll die early. It's a roguelite, expect to die often before you get better
- Weapons and Upgrades balance, I rate it about 5/10. A few weapons are very reliable, a few weapons are very unreliable. Some upgrades barely do anything, some upgrades can carry you

TL;DR It's VERY cheap for its quality, I totally recommend it :)

(I played for about 150 hours, the rest is sitting in the menu or restarting for testing)

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is a ton of fun solo and even more with friends.

Replayability is high. When you lose a run, you instantly want to hop back into another. You could argue that only three levels and bosses aren't enough but every run is truly different based on the weapons and scrolls you pick up. 

Worth all $10.00 I paid for it. I would even argue its worth more right now. The game is only in alpha and I can't wait for new guns, scrolls, characters and most importantly, new levels and bosses.

Good community and LFG section in the official Discord server. Also, I'm fairly certain there is a matchmaking feature in game though I have never used it.

Super excited for the future of the game!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Quite a fun game, if not slightly repetitive.  If you like Risk of Rain 2 but wanted some progression with leveling up your characters between runs, this is probably the game for you.

There's room for improvement.  As this is a foreign-made game, a lot of the English translations are off and it can be difficult to tell exactly what a weapon modifier is supposed to actually be doing.  They're not terribly off though, and can usually be figured out.  Some of the modifiers are somewhat boring +damage/+crit damage etc instead of making the weapons more unique to use.  There are modifiers like that to make the weapons more interesting, but in my playthroughs those have been rare.  More variety there would be better.  The levels are pseudo-randomized, with different paths to take open to you each run, but they do all feel the same quite quickly the more you play.  Lastly, once you fully level up your character (which I haven't gotten close to yet, that will probably take ~80ish hours maybe?), I'm not sure what else there would be to do in this game.  So it does have an end (unless they add some sort of endgame for maxed characters), but it will take a long time for you to get there.

I haven't played this with friends, but I think this would be a blast.  Only played solo.  Overall, I'd give this an 8/10.  Good game

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Right now, the game is barely playable.

It's a good concept, it's pretty -- but it's also a slog that doesn't do anything to entertain. It needs a serious rebalance.

1. The hero is SLOW. He moves at a leisurely stroll that barely enables you to avoid enemy projectiles -- and nothing more. There is no run in the game, only an instant, short range dash on recharge. 
2. The "Time to kill" is far, far too long. It takes two headshots -- about 15 seconds in total -- to kill the basic mook, with even the second-least-threatening mook taking 30+ seconds. 
3. The weapons are either slow to fire (and don't deal much damage) or spray bullets that deal no damage at all. Even the "rocket launcher" equivalent can't kill a basic mook in one hit!
4. The game's difficulty curve is all over the place. Some areas are insultingly easy, some areas are clearly designed for a large party and clearly had never been scaled down.
5. You can self-revive once. It's usually a bad deal, since the enemies will gather up to mob you the instant you revive. Since the game does not offer things like temporary invulnerability or pushback on revive, they *will* bring you back down in seconds.
6. There is no way to alter starting gear, so you are forever stuck with one slow firing weak gun. Its only saving grace is that it's fairly accurate and useful for breaking the pots scattered through the level.
7. The "powerups" in this game fall exclusively into "why would I care" or "totally overpowered" categories, with essentially no in-between. Probably my favourite worst example is "burning enthusiast" which grants life-steal on burning enemies... except I've yet to see a weapon capable of setting enemies on fire.
8. Upgrading your weapons doesn't make any sense. You are likely to find a better gun very soon. 
9. There's only one weapon worth holding on to, a plasma rifle like "lightning gun". 
10. Health pickups are extremely rare in the game and usually show up when you don't need them anyway.

And finally:
The game gets extremely same-y very, very quickly. I know what the level is themed, but some more variety beyond "more blue walls" or "less blue walls" would be welcome.

For a game this good to be in early access gives me hope, cuz there's so much more to come, and I honestly cannot wait. If you're considering buying this game, I would strongly recommend it.
