title: Gunfire Reborn
review: It's fun. Not a big community, some nights you just cant' find a team to play with. Game is pretty radically imbalanced, especially for groups enemies scale at an incredible rate, bosses are even worse. Still if you find a group with some 100+ level players, you tend to make it through ok. But a full group of level 20's can't handle the first boss without some luck. While the game kinda of has random weapon drops there appear to only be roughly 15 or 20 weapons available in the game in total and a handful of them are useless, so you're pretty much always looking for the same 5 or 6 guns and if you don't find them you know you won't win right off. Enhancements are critical, even if you get one of those previously mentioned guns, if they don't have great flavor text to enhance them further, same thing, you know you're only gonna make it so far. There are semi "hidden" levels within the primary levels called vaults, which you basically have to do to keep up with the scaling at all. They're mostly fun, but there are a couple which are infuriatingly difficult. Beyond that there are only maybe 4 or 6 of them and the game just randomly switches between which ones appear. Overall the game is fun, especially in a group. However it lacks content on a intense level. It needs a lot more guns and more "vaults" to vary the experience and it needs to focus more on the amount of enemies you're fighting over how long you're fighting them. in some instances a single enemy can take 30~40 seconds to put down because they're just damage sponges.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is one of the top rogue-like FPS I have played (the other memorable one being Immortal Redneck). 

Despite still being in early access, it's quite complete, with the main quest consisting of 3 worlds with 6 stages in each world. You will face against different types of enemies and the end boss in each world. A decent run will last around 1-2 hours. The levels are randomly generated, you will find many weapons and scrolls (good or bad, which you can choose to take or not) that will make each run different and enjoyable. There are also 2 merchants selling upgrades in-game. When the game ends (win or lose) you earn some points which you can use to upgrade your talents to make your character permanently stronger. Currently there are 3 characters to choose from, although you start with cat and will need to hit talent level 30 and 40 to unlock the other 2. The game can be played as single-player or multiplayer with up to 3 other friends or randoms. Matchmaking is simple and fast, and I find myself enjoying my first win in a team of 3. After the first win, the elite difficulty will unlock to challenge you further.

Highly recommended, for single and multiplayer both! I hope they will expand on the story and lore, that will complement the game perfectly.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: This game is absolutely amazing. Its a combination of Risk Of Rain's and Borderlands BEST aspects. It has Borderlands Health/Shield/Armour mechanics, where fire damage does more damage to red health bars, shocks to shields, and corrosive to armour. It has randomly generated gun perks, and unlockable guns like Deadcells unlockable weapon mechanics. It has an out of game upgrade system which give you more health, shields, armour, weapon damage, and a whole VARIETY of other mechanics that make your gameplay more enjoyable. It has well balanced characters, including a dual wielding dog, a cat that is basically a wizard, and a bird that slices its enemies. It has great gameplay, althought the levels stay the same, the order in which you play them is randomized. The enemies are fun, killing them is fun, and the bosses are even fun to fight and do take quite a bit of skill, as there is a dodging mechanic involved. You wouldn't think an FPS Rogue-Like would work, but this one makes it work so very well.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
A game with a simple cycle.

-You enter the dungeon
-You kill everything in the dungeon
-you upgrade you power in the dungeon
-You get achievements for killing those enemies
-You die or live again to kill everything in the dungeon
-you die for good this time
-you might get achievements for dying
-You use your dead enemies soul to upgrade your skills
-you enter the dungeon again but with the stuff you upgraded and stuff you got from achievements

I recommend this game that's all.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: A rouge like fps with Borderlands like elemental mechanics and gameplay. It's really fun and surprisingly challenging. Currently there is 37 regular enemies, 10 elites(minibosses), 3 bosses and 37 weapons(7 different types) + the starting weapon. There is also 3 different characters with their 2 unique abilities to play with. There's a skill tree for each character and every power up you pick through out the game changes your stats and gameplay drastically and most of the time they are power ups with no down sides. It has similar boss fights to Borderlands but it executes every aspect of it much better even when compared to borderlands 3. Every new stage also has very cool and unique themes.This game has a lot of potential to be very popular and even in its early stages of development, its decently polished, offers various good content and is a steal for how little it costs.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
It's been a pleasure watching Gunfire Reborn evolve and refine its approach. There are a few sharp edges but, unlike other roguelikes, every build feels viable. The talent system has a handful of game-changing upgrades - I'd recommend focusing on the Survival tree - but generally provides just enough of a push after each run to make the next run smoother.

Multiplayer is much more fun than single player and, thanks to non-shared loot pools (your loot is only shared if you drop it), online matching without voice chat is a reasonable option.

[/list]

My older Xeon system originally would not boot the version I downloaded, when I emailed the developers with this and my error logs they fixed it ASAP with an update the very next day.

If you're looking for an early access game to support through development, I couldn't recommend Gunfire more. Their team clearly cares about finishing the game and has the resources to do so.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Super fun, crazy addicting. Class balance needs work so there is a reason to play something other than the cat doing 80k dps with the laser glove, but it's a $10 game in early access so... great job!

Some recommendations: 

Secondary skills don't scale well at all, grenades do less than 1% of a mobs health in higher difficulties in the final stages. With them being so lackluster, ascensions for secondaries are pointless and sad to see or get forced to take. Consider improving scaling or adding more utility to the abilities. 

Elemental damage is too scalable. This forces a lack of diversity in builds and weapon choices, and only encourages playing the cat. You can get the laser gloves ticking for 22k damage every .2 seconds with infinite magazines by the end  of act 3 on elite. No other build or class can even do 1/3rd the damage the cat can do. Consider buffing explosive/normal damage, or buffing the dog/bird in other ways, such as the hero talents or improving ascensions. OR nerf the cat, but no one likes nerfs.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
A hidden gem amongst the early access games that contains enough content to give it a try. The game is a quick and tight rogue-like game with a very appealing almost cartoon-like art style. The game can be played on your own but is most interesting when playing together with friends or strangers online. 

A few more remarks:

‚Ä¢	The game has 3 playable characters, each with their own play style that you can unlock within 10 hours of playtime. It is not (yet) possible to buy these characters and the game is not pay to win.

‚Ä¢	The game has three different chapters with their own theme. Each chapter contains multiple levels and finishes with a boss level. Each play through, the level design will be randomly generated from a large set of predefined level designs. So each time the level is different but it will still look familiar.

‚Ä¢	There are plenty of weapons that you can obtain and each weapon has something unique that puts it apart from all the other weapons. Weapons are randomly dropped as loot and by completing challenges it is possible to obtain new weapons for the first time. 

‚Ä¢	The game gets regular updates and the developers listen to the feedback of the community.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Just to clarify, this isn't a review on actual gameplay, there are many other great reviews here commenting about the different mechanics and experience of the game. This is more to defend the game from the negative feedback.

For an early access game that was released in May, it shows its potential of how great of a game this will become. Reading the reviews, I was happy that many people shared the same point of view that I had. Yet I still come across these negative reviews saying it got boring fast and doesn't have much to offer. Keep in mind this game is early access for a reason. I went through the updates and change logs and saw how much they added in only a few months, and I am sure there is so much yet to come.

If you're looking for a game that you can grind for days and never get bored of, yes, this isn't it, YET. But, I say again, it's early access for a reason. For 9 euro, you're investing in a game that will grow to become better than some triple A games I've played recently.

With that being said, if you're looking for a game to grind right now, this isn't the game for you. However, if you see the potential of this game and how good it can become, get it.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is more annoying than fun.  Also, this game is NOT like the BL series, Warframe or D2.  Those comparisons are WRONG.

When the game is tagged 'Roguelite,' pay attention.  The tag means that this game is artificially difficult and gives you almost no health buffs to compensate for the mobs of annoyingly powerful adds often with shields that lob bombs at you.  

Also, having picked up multiple weapons and mods, you DON'T KEEP ANY of them in your inventory when you leave the level.  What you do keep is a small bump in a simple skill tree.  You start every mission with no mods and a single pea shooter.  You rely on RNG to get decent weapons, which doesn't always work.


I played for 45 minutes, got through one level and the side missions, got killed by the boss ( no health drops or second wind, btw, and the boss had huge health and shield pools that recharged 5 times ).  So after all that, ii was able to level up one of five levels on a shield buff ( +5% ) in the simple skill tree.  

OK, i'm not into games that are hard for the sake of being hard, but really...for an average casual gamer, this game sucks.   This is NOT Borderlands or Destiny2 or WarFrame.  Not anywhere close.
developer_response: Sorry for your unpleasant experience, we will add more content and randomnessÔºåand we will optimize the game difficulty and game balance in the future update, stay tuned.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
So far my experience with this game has been fantastic. The developers are actively developing, fixing, and updating the game with new content/patches and its always fun to come back and realize something has changed, even if only slightly.

I haven't played many first person rogue-likes, but if this is any standard the bar is set pretty high imo. It's a fun time playing with friends, or alone. A full run at the time of writing this normally takes me about an hour, but it's a great hour spent in my book.

The default mode might feel a little easy once you figure out the basic mechanics, but the advanced-and currently in alpha (i think?), nighmare-mode ramp it up and bring more challenging gameplay for those who are looking for a challenge. It plays incredibly well for a rogue like; some combination of items are just an absolute BLAST to use. Yes I'm looking at you Advanced Depot and Wild Hunt.

I'm excited to see what else the developers release, and couldn't recommend the game enough to someone looking for twist on classic rogue like gameplay.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn is an interesting game that mixes FPS, rogue-lite, and a bit of RPG elements to create what I find is a pretty fun shooter experience. 

The first thing you'll probably notice are the aesthetics of the game. The characters and the environments use this low poly 3D style with a bit of Chinese influence thrown in. Some people might find this simple and maybe even a bit dull, but I personally think it works very well for this game. Because the graphics are so simple, it makes it pretty easy to see and know what is going on at the moment and as a plus, I also find it is quite easy to keep a high frame rate at all times during each run. Same thing can be said about the UI, being simple, but also giving you information you need without being obstructive. I think there should be some options to change or remove stuff such as the damage numbers, but it gets the job done.

I'll briefly go over the other aspects of the game here as they don't play nearly as big a factor as the gameplay. 
Story is... basically nonexistent. You'll get some brief dialogue when you first start the game and when you first complete a run, but that's about it. Next, the music in the game is good, but somewhat limited. There's the main menu theme, music for each stage, and music for each boss. One thing I found neat is how the stage music is mostly atmospheric at first, but when you get into battle with enemies, it ramps up into something more energetic and fitting for battle until it's over. Lastly, I found the sound design to be pretty great. The weapons sounding exactly how you would imagine them to, the feedback when you land a critical hit on an enemy, and the different sounds that each enemy makes adds a lot to the enjoyment of the game.

Finally we get to the gameplay, which has a lot to go over. Seeing how this is an FPS game, the weapons are pretty important and thankfully they do not disappoint. There are a total of 38 different weapons to use as of right now and they range from the humble assault rifle to more absurd things like a fire breathing dragon or laser gloves that make you feel like you're playing as Iron Man. All the weapon archetypes you would expect such as snipers, shotguns, and rocket launchers, to name a few are here so finding something you end up loving to use is pretty likely. There's a critical hit system for hitting enemies in their weak points and a lucky shot system that gives you a percentage based chance to deal bonus damage to an enemy depending on how high your chance is.

Elements are also in the game and there are three different ones that can apply status effects. Fire which deals extra damage against flesh and can deal damage over time, Lightning which does extra damage against shields and can cause that enemy to take extra damage from everything, and Corrosion which does extra damage against armor and slows enemies down drastically. It is also possible to fuse these status effects together to cause an extremely powerful effect depending on what combination is fused.

There are three different characters you can play as as of this review and they all play differently from each other. You have the cat which uses an orb that's capable of stopping enemies in place for several seconds and corrosive grenades, then there is the dog who can dual wield weapons and use explosive grenades, and finally the bird who has a leaping attack that can restore his armor and a cleave attack in the place of grenades that can hit enemies all around him. All of these characters share a universal dash ability that can be used for dodging or just getting around a bit more quickly. This may make them seem a bit underwhelming, but that is where the ascensions and scrolls systems come into play.

Ascensions are obtained at the end of each level through goblets and they give you the choice of upgrading one of three randomly chosen ascensions. The majority of ascensions in the game give some powerful boosts for doing specific things or power up your characters unique moves. Each character gets their own unique ascensions that allow you to fine tune them to a specific play style. You can obtain the same ascension up to three times in a run to power up their effects, with the third level  being much more powerful than the previous ones. If that doesn't sound good enough for you, there are also scrolls to further power yourself up. Scrolls are items you can randomly obtain in vaults or purchased from a merchant if one is in their inventory. They're typically a lot more specific in their usage than the ascensions, but because of the sheer number of different scrolls there are (there are 100+ you can find), you are bound to find just the right scrolls you need to end up having a run where you just melt everything.

There is something important I should go over that may be a bit controversial, and that is the talents system. Talents are permanent upgrades that you unlock at the end of a run, whether you die or make it to the end. You purchase these upgrades with soul essence that you earn by killing enemies. For the most part these upgrades let you access things that you couldn't before like the vaults or the weapon chest at the start of a run or boosting the amount of soul essence and copper (which is used to buy stuff from merchant and upgrade the level of your weapons) you can earn in a run. Permanent upgrades are nothing new in these rogue-lite style games, but the thing I have a problem with is just how much easier the game gets when you unlock a bunch of these.

When I first started playing the game, it was pretty challenging. You start out with only the cat and a vast number of the weapons and scrolls need to be unlocked by doing certain things before they'll stop dropping in runs. I had to be constantly on my toes against even the weakest enemies as a couple of hits from anything would spell the end of a run. As I kept playing and learning the patterns of the enemies, I unlocked a fair amount of stuff that made the runs significantly easier. This resulted in a snowball effect where because I knew what to expect and the power gained from my talents and new items, the game became so much easier than the start. It got to the point where I was winning much more than I lost even on the harder difficulty.

Even though it's super fun to destroy everything, it gets very boring if I'm able to do that consistently each run. I think this game could benefit from a more challenging difficulty and changing some of the stuff on the talent tree that just raise your stats. Getting stuff like taking 15% less damage from enemies or dealing 25% more damage to enemies, while effective, are just boring in a game like this that rewards you for smart builds and contribute to the lack of challenge that higher level players experience.

Despite these issues, this game is still a blast to play whether you play it solo or in coop. This has been one of my favorite FPS games to play this year and with the attention to feedback that the developers are giving to the community, it can only go up from here. If you get annoyed at having to play the same parts to learn how to combat each enemy or the talents system bothers you, this probably isn't the game for you. For everyone else, I can't recommend it enough. It's so refreshing to play an early access game this year that isn't a cash grab or just a bare-bones proof of concept that doesn't go anywhere. At only 12 USD, I've got more hours out of this game than the vast majority of triple AAA titles I've played and I still want to keep putting hours into this game.

Pretty good but some toxic idiots that like to scream and cuss in voice chat. Y'all know a lot of kids play this right? If your goal isn't to simply communicate with teammates then beat it. Awww some people accidentally skipped a vault? Here's your binky. Not a reason to lose your mind over.

Some bothersome things that could afford to change like the boulders in the vault that are almost impossible to avoid. Some boss moves are also hard to avoid. Controller support is terrible. Sensitivity is so high you'll spin your head off and is too sensitive to adjust the sensitivity. Not too concerned because keyboard and mouse feel fine. 

One thing that pisses me off is getting pretty far, having a lot of soul essence, and then everyone dies and you lose it all. That's bogus. C'mon now.

Good game overall. Would not compare it to Risk of Rain at all. Grasping at straws there. Oooooh you get random items sometimes. Not enough to be compared to Risk lol. Even Doom it was compared to. What? Lots of games with a lot of enemies coming out at once, are they all like Doom too? Goofy.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This is a very solid game--any negatives I can think of really only emerge from the game being in early access (balancing/scaling, interactions between the talent system and certain scrolls and the inability to keep a run going after stage 3). 

The gameplay is amazing, there is a variety of weapons that cannot be neatly categorized into "good" or "bad" based on their normal stats as there are a variety of affixes assigned to each weapon that you find which encourage you to think about what you're picking up and why, rewarding the player for taking time to experiment and get familiar with the game. Metagame aside, the weapons themselves feel great and reward the player for building skill with critical strikes that occur from hitting weak points. The game is very well suited for multiplayer due to having instanced loot (players receive their own loot that only they can see until it is picked up) however the player has the option to drop and trade their loot with others should they choose to which makes multiplayer sometimes more rewarding than singleplayer.

The game has very unified art design and each stage feels different due to a combination of the art as well as different enemies and challenges.

Overall I'm very satisfied with this game and can't wait for its full release.

You couple this with the slow progress you make in your talent tree, and the combination of this game equals monotony rather than a fun rogue-lite. Possibly if this came out a year or two ago this would have been innovative, and probably fun. But, with the current glut of early access rogue-lite games on steam and every other app store, this game just doesn't entice you to keep playing
developer_response: Using weapons with lightning damage can easily break BOSS's shield, and you can evade its attack behind the pillars. Hope you can beat the first BOSS soon! And we will optimize the game difficulty and game balance in the future update, stay tuned.Thanks for your feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Look, I was very excited to buy and play this game after reading and watching reviews. 
I suddenly lost a lot of interested once I realised - it's very easy to go back to the drawing board. (Situations that can kill you instantly / out of no where / to quickly.)

Besides the fact that this game is a roguelite, So - Dying and starting from the beginning, with this particular design of strong grinding they have implemented into the trait tree to progress further into the game. - To me this is very repetitive and I started to loose interest because you continuously keep powering through the same short lived content to grind up your tree. 
I would have preferred at least the "option" of checkpoints designed and scaled correctly after each boss fight so I can at least experience the full potential of the game.

My Rating dropped from 4.3/5 star to 3.4/5 after realising this is what the game has to offer.
Saying that - For the price - It's good entertainment for a round or two a day.

review:
Nuclear Throne in first person. No hit-scan. Balanced and interesting mechanics. Why am I leaving a negative review?

Because a co-op game should never have long periods of down time. You can go several levels without being able revive teammates. 15-20 minutes of not playing. Revives cost money, but you need a merchant to make the purchase. No merchant two levels in a row or more is very bad design for a co-op game.

If/when they allow revives every level is when I leave a positive review.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: It's got some early access crust on it, but almost NONE of that crust shows up in the actual gameplay. The game is extremely solid, and the mechanics are well implemented, and the game is just plain fun. There is so much more content in this game than you would realize, even after a few runs, and it has incredible replayability   even for a roguelike. Can't recommend it enough, honestly.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I would recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of rouge-lites or first person shooters. The game play is tight and feels great and the random aspects of each run contribute to almost endless replayability.
      After completing or losing a run you are returned to the inn where you can spend collected materials from your run to improve your character. It feels very satisfying to start accumulating these upgrades and start feeling really powerful, however there are multiple difficulties to circumvent the problem of becoming to overpowered.
     The multiplayer is also a great feature of this game and the difficulty scales very well with the amount of players. The game features both private squads and online matchmaking.
     Overall this game is a great value for the price and is continuing to receive updates from the developer that add more content and more polish.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I haven't gotten very far into [i]Gunfire Reborn[/i], but so far I really don't see what the hype is about. With so many other great games available, I feel no desire to invest more time into this one when I'm just not enjoying it, so I'll be requesting a refund. There are a few major issues that kept me from enjoying the game:

[list]
[*] I don't like the way the game is balanced. The enemy AI is terrible and their aim is pretty bad too, so normal encounters only become challenging when there are overwhelming numbers present. But then I get to the first boss and the cooldown on my movement ability is just too long to avoid his attacks. I tried hiding behind the pillars, but he just charges me and I'm too slow to get away. Maybe there's some trick I'm missing, or maybe the game is intended to be played multiplayer so that you can switch off kiting duties, but as it is I feel like I'm only ever being hit because the boss can attack faster than my dash cooldown. That does not feel fair or fun to play.
[*] On the subject of movement, the game just feels really slow. I wish it was faster paced, like [i]Doom Eternal[/i], which was one of my favorite games of 2020. That might make the game too easy in its current state, but they could counterbalance it by making the enemies stronger and smarter. I'd also like it if the corridors and rooms were larger and had more verticality to allow for more dynamic gameplay.
[*] I like the low-poly art style, but the environments feel visually flat with narrow color palettes and limited shading. The game is just boring to look at.
[*] The character voices are really annoying, though they can be turned off in the audio menu.
[/list]
developer_response: You can use weapons with lightning damage to quickly break the shield of the first BOSS. You can also avoid some attacks by standing behind the pillars. Hope these tips can help you defeat the BOSS. Because of the background story, the first map is relatively narrow, but the second and third map will give you different experience. Thanks for your feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
For starters the game as a whole is great, it seems like it is 80% finished already - Completely playable tons of Buffs/passives, plenty of weapons; Each with tons of modifiers, 3 Characters, 3 Stages, 3 Bosses (Which aren't just pushovers and take a bit to learn without external input), An interesting elemental mechanic making combining effects more powerful which ends up leading to pretty neat synergy solo and much easier power in multiplayer, Rouge lite elements that are pretty rewarding but feel somewhat pure power creep instead of interesting mechanics (Specifically the talent tree giving things like Weapon damage/CDR/Damage/Health/Damage reduction)
The design and game feel are great, but seems there are more things that have had more attention than others.

(More of a feedback section)
the gunplay, feedback, designs are all amazing. But things like movement - skill usage - feedback for damage (from enemies) can feel quite clunky and frustrating at times.
specifically enemies targeting you behind cover and charging what would normally be easy to dodge; high damaging attacks, Suddenly become un-dodgable with no noise or indication. Very easy to work around once you're familiar with that being possible but could prove to be frustrating early on.
Movement while nothing is inherently wrong with it, it ends up feeling extremely bland at times - The addition of the bird character's ability being a leap makes the game far more enjoyable. I personally would love the movement to be explored more beyond set speed walking, set distance dashing and set height jumping, but it would present a lot of balance issues i would imagine. (Since most enemies attack with projectile like attacks or melee).
Skill usage is one of the things that annoyed me very early on and would be something that would be amazing for game feel. Right off the bat the first character has a Gas grenade and a Ranged AOE stun, Super powerful to be able to set up the nade and stun a group of enemies into it right? The issue is both the stun and the nade have a set animation and a set time, at the end of each there's a small delay where you're unable to act on anything not even shoot your weapon as you rearm it, The game feels like it presents itself as a fast action packed fps but being locked into that huge downtime feels horrible to me. Make it possible to cancel the animation of pulling up the weapon after using a skill - with another skill.
Feedback for damage is a tough one, There is feedback in the sense of, a radar, Enemies make noise when firing - 'Most' of the enemies having a distinct noise associated with them when attacking or nearby, you get a sound when you are hit, screen flashing. All are great but i feel like there could be something more done (This could entirely be a me thing as i have no real suggestions on how to improve it, but better said than not).

Bit of a long one but i really hope they don't just hault development after 1.0 as this game has tons of potential in additional design.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Even in early access, this game has incredibly satisfying gunplay, a great gameplay loop, and TONS of variety. The only thing I would like tweaked is the frequency of "Vault" rooms. Often on a run, I will either see only one, or find them constantly, to the point that they hindered the pacing of my runs. but this is relatively minor, as for an early access game priced at such a reasonable amount, and often on sale, Gunfire Reborn might be the most content-rich roguelite i've played so far. 

If you like FPS games, stylized graphics, wacky weapons and skills, and addictive upgrading (permanent unlocks through trait points and new hero unlocks with much more planned to come) check this out! It is a co-op game, but as a solo player I do not feel under-powered or pressured to play online :) 

overall I'm very happy I gave this a shot, and you should too!

If you hesitate to buy this game, well keep reading--->


This game has early stages like from 1-10, in the beginning its like what is this, its fun but so challenging -->

The further you get to the bosses the better the loot, the harder the enemies, after level 10 you accomplish to queue with random people, it took me a minute or 2 to queue up with other people after the first boss, what is kinda hard to beat in the early stages, we beat him pretty good, the bosses and enemies, do scale based on how many players are fighting against them, normally it would take me 2-3 shots, when queueing with 3 others it takes 4-6 shots, 

if you are seriously in considering to buy the game, trust me and buy it, the game itself is serioiusly great, consistently mini dungeon grinds as we have been playing in mmorpg games..

keep 1 thing in mind, the game is challenging, and dont expect to gain alot of adventages, i have also been playing for years and this game is something different then most of you faced till today,
11/10 i would rebuy it again and again, send multiple copies as well to friends, bought the game for them and now we do have the biggest fun

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Definitely rough around the edges but, at it's core is a really fun shooter compounded with really solid enemy design and weapons. You can absolutely see the spots missing from it like, as of this review a lack of sound effects on the post game currency spending to upgrade your characters, some translation issues, and the lack of an ingame guide to understand mechanics outside of loading screens. You shouldn't have to get lucky to find out shock and fire debuffs simultaneously cause confusion on an enemy, for instance.

As it is if you're a fan of shooters and multiplayer games like risk of rain, I'd definitely recommend it even in it's current state. I've been hooked since I got it playing it nonstop, and I don't hyperfixate on something easily.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I don't know why people hype this game so much.

The balancing is questionable, archers still have homing arrows that are almost undodgeable, there are only a few guns and you always get the same 3-4 weapons in every run and the bosses are just horrible.
  The 1st boss 2 hits you and dodging his attacks is luck based even if you abuse the pillars in the room. Sure, git gud, but it's still bad game design. 
  The player's dodge is on a 3 sec cooldown, which makes the game feel clunky. Movement speed is slow as well.
 
Also, there is not enough room variety. You see the same rooms over and over again after just 3 runs.  

It's a game for the casual roguelike masses and furries, not for fps players.
developer_response: Sorry for your boring experience, we will add more content and randomness in the future update, stay tuned.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is one of the best multiplayer games I've played in a long time.
Fast-paced, action-packed, fun, and always challenging.

It feels very polished. I, personally, experienced very few typical "Early-Access-Problems". No disconnects, no crashes etc. Some issues with slow Connection in multiplayer have been fixed pretty quickly in one of the hotfixes.

The developers seem to listen to their community. New content (weapons, scrolls, difficulty-modes) has been added very frequently since I've been playing.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
The first character you get is a cat with a gun.

Yeah, buy it.

On a serious note, it's a great start to a wave shooter game. I'm having a great time even though it is bare bones for what they'll probably do to it. Running this solo is fun, but it shines with coop gameplay. The gun play feels solid and the perks give you an incentive to keep moving forward. The only thing I would like to see added is the ability to sprint; that extra movement would really help when the enemies are charging in at me for the ez clap.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
-- Positives

- Low poly/Easy on the eyes graphics
- Feedback feature built into the game
- Reactive game updates
- Consistent base game mechanics
- There is enough content to build synergies 
- Fun overall game loop.


-- Negatives

- Needs more content
- There are no secrets in stages
- The challenges in stages are non-optional and sometimes don't provide an additional reward upon completion (also there isn't enough variety in challenges.)
- There's no fast travel between rooms during stages
- Difficulty scaling uses solo stats as base, but as soon as your players in the squad are more than 1 it scaled to 4x (times) the base instead of 1x (+1x for each additional player in the squad.)

!!(These positives and negatives are subject to change over time and with the regular game updates)!!

There are bugs, and I can't speak for every players of this game, but I have not encounter any game breaking bugs. But if there is, there's a feedback option in the game to report it to the developers.

I can't speak for localisation but the English localisation is good to good enough.

There's obvious potential for this game to be amazing if/when it comes out early access.
Overall though, it was worth the purchase.

Couple of complaints, but this is a SOLID buy for the price, even in early access.

Pros? Solid gameplay, variety, and fun with friends! :) Only played for 3 hours, but def will put in more time.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
An instanced shooter that I can just jump in and play with friends anytime with unique builds and a huge variety of weapons is pretty big, and not many other games really fill the need for being an easily accessible FPS game that feels buttery smooth to play.

Its a huge bonus that you don't have to spend a freaking millenia getting to the action or navigating menus to tune the settings to your liking. The game runs smooth, and really emphasizes just how important a buttery smooth experience is for an FPS game, easy to maintain high frames and plays like a responsive shooter should. Built by devs that seemingly understand how an option's menu for an FPS game should look (independent scope sensitivity, easily rebound buttons, no freaking aim acceleration, etc)

Cheap as beans, too. You could easily talk a friend into trying it out with you for under 15 bucks.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Fantastic game for the price. I love the idea behind mashing up random loot generation and randomized levels, with rogue-lite and between-lives power ups. I like the strategy behind insta-rezzing once. Graphics and characters are fun, even cute without seeming juvenile. Sound design is really good. Localizations for text are pretty good.

It's definitely frustrating to have a good build going and then die to things like enemies targeting you through objects (like large boulders three times your characters' height), but you just learn to pay more attention and keep moving I guess. It feels almost nostalgic to 1980's games where save features were rare and boss fights were brutal.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Great co-op shooter, reminds me of Timesplitters 2. Gameplay doesn't feel like an EA title at all either and the graphics are cool kind of ROR2 style. It's good good good good, good good good. 

One gripe: I've noticed some strange increases in fps whenever I die and then revive, for example the game sometimes starts running by being stuck around 30fps then after I die and revive/get revived, it jumps to 60fps and tends to stay there for the rest of the session.

 Other than that it's my kind of perfect.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is really great. I usually consider progression (levels, unlocks etc) to be of little interest in most games I play, but here I find it very enjoyable and it's a key part of the game.

Movement, weapons and enemies are all very well done. The UI is a little clunky in a couple of places, which I would put down to being in early access, but the basic gameplay is very smooth and a lot of fun. The weapons in particular are all very distinctive.

I had seen this game in the past, but had discounted it due to it looking quite cartoonish and being so inexpensive. Now, having bought it on a whim, I think it's easily worth twice the full price at least, from what I have seen so far. If you enjoy games like Deep Rock Galactic, you will like this I reckon. I usually play military-themed FPS games (Hell Let Loose, Verdun, Insurgency etc) and I still like Gunfire Reborn.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
The gameplay in this game is amazing, it puts other FPS to shame even some of the new AAA games availabe now. Fights can be pretty intense specially in the mid levels and above. Also weapons feel very unique and makes the game a lot of fun.

However, the game gets very repetitive rather quickly, since there is only 3 scenarios, and if you are on the lower levels you will not get pass the second level that easily. It will take some hours of grinding before you can finish the second level, and I am not sure how long to even finished the third one. So basically you will spent lot of hours just grinding to the first scenario, and is quite boring since there is little variation to the levels.

Also, playing multiplayer is a double edge sword, since with 4 players in co-op mode makes the enemies very spongy. You need to  have very good teammates. If one or two are just messing around, you wont get pass the first boss.

Still the gameplay is very good, so if you can tolerate the repetitiveness of the game you could have a lot of fun in this game.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
While this game is in early access, it does still have a pretty decent amount of content and unlockables to sink your teeth into.  This game is far from perfect, but is still a good time.

The good:

- This game takes an approach similar to borderlands with its guns.  Very unique, fun, and have random stats so even if you have a duplicate, it will still play a bit differently.

- The characters each have fun abilities and upgrades that change the way you play.  While they have the same speed and jump height, the key to each character are the upgrades you can obtain during a run and creating a build off of them.

- When you unlock something like a weapon or scroll, you get it immediately as a drop in that run so you get to try it right away.  From that run onwards its added to the loot pool.  Love this idea.

- At first I wasn't a fan of the visuals, but over time as I got to see more of the enviroments it really grew on me.  I don't think the first stage does it justice, because everything after the first stage looks incredible.

- very challenging.  If you stand in place for a few seconds, you're dead.  This makes learning enemy and boss' weaknesses and exploiting them even more satisfying.

The Bad:

- The in-between run progression system is, in my opinion, very frustrating.  You gain soul energy by playing the game, and at the end of your run, you can use them at the talent tree to give yourself permanent upgrades.  By itself I think it's cool, but each talent point you get gives you a level.  You unlock very important things, like both of the unlockable characters through your talent level.  Where this bothers me is the fact that a talent point gives you ONE level, no matter how much it actually costed.  So if you want to unlock stuff, you have to prioritize the cheapest upgrades over the good ones.  The soul energy also disappears after a run so you HAVE to spend them, unless you get an upgrade that lets you keep them.  

- The pacing of the gameplay feels way too slow.  There aren't many ways to consistently increase your movement speed.  There are scrolls that will do it but you can't stack them so you have to find many different scrolls that do similar things.  The gameplay feels more like overwatch than a highly mobile shooter.  You have a dash, sure, but it's on a cooldown each time you use it, and doesn't go very far. There's also virtually no verticality to any map, and no movement-based scrolls.  Like why doesn't the bird character have a double jump? Or a glide?  He has wings.  Every character feels like a tank.

- No stacking of items, to make their affects more powerful.  After playing Risk of Rain 2, and seeing how its item system works, I genuinely believe every roguelike in existence should take notes from it.  Stacking of items and getting duplicates makes for way more customizable builds, and allows for people to play the way they like.  

- Doesn't start actually getting fun until you've done a few runs and have more stuff unlocked and have more talent points spent.

- Multiplayer feels harder than singleplayer.  The difficulty scaling is too high.  If you're playing with a 4 player team, every enemy, even the weak ones feel like bullet sponges.  More health isn't the answer to having more players, again, take notes from Risk of Rain 2.  

Overall:  It's a good game, but it's severely outclassed by other games in the genre.  Namely Risk of Rain 2.  But the game is still good on its own and has a lot of potential.  It's in early access so it can't be judged too harshly as of now.  If you're a roguelike enthusiast like myself, this is a game you should play.  But if you don't play these kinds of games usually, this isn't the one to start with.  

6.5/10

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Endless replay value. Even before the addition of the third character and beating the game countless times, every single run you would do would have a different feel and you'd tackle it with a different strategy. You see the same map over and over, but are you going to get your favourite powerups to get through it? Maybe you'll get your favourite weapon, but is it going to have the powerups you need to win or will you have to change at the last minute? Maybe you felt like you've done every possibility with one character, but you probably haven't even come close to mastering how to build the other. 
When the third character was released it felt like everything changed, there was already a randomness to what rooms you'd enter, but now even more rooms are possible to go which makes each run feel that much fresher.
Each run you do powers up your character a little more, you won't get through the whole game on your first try. As you play, you'll make yourself powerful enough to challenge the final boss, and of course the more difficult game modes. The difficulty scales with how many players you're with, solo can be a challenge as you have no backup, but you get more and more monsters that make the game that much more intense when you start playing with a party of 4. Speaking of difficulty, my friends and I were shocked to see how much more challenging Elite mode became in the last update, nevermind the new Nightmare mode. 

For how unbelievably cheap this game is, there's no reason you shouldn't pick this up as a fun simple game to play with your friends, I'm 30 hours in but I know that will get into the hundreds as this game grows.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This might have the EA tag but tbh it feels more complete than most games and it just keeps adding content.

It is exactly what ot looks like, a first person rogue-lite shooter with currently 3 different characters.
All characters have a different play style, defined by the skills and upgrades you get during a run. Also depending on the other items you get there is also quite some diversity in builds. Every run you have to adapt and try to make the most out of the things you get and it is rare that you really feel unlucky and under powered.

The runs itself are perfectly in length imo, You have nice power progression over the course of the run and a complete run will take you around 40min. So it is a really nice game to pick up and play for 1-2h and come back later.

Upgrades you can buy after a run (with currency acquired during a run) feel good and really add up making you feel way more powerful. The normal upgrades are quite general, like more HP, more damage and so on. Every character also has character specific upgrades, which directly improve certain aspects of the character.

It took me 45 hours to get all upgrades but I still have to get all the unlockable items. Around 70% of my runs were singe player, which is totally fine and might be even a bit easier than multiplayer. But multiplayer is a lot more fun. The nice thing is all drops are individual so no competition for loot. The game has automatic matchmaking if you want to play with random people or you can invite your friends. I mostly played with randoms and the community so far was always nice and helpful.

One really important thin in a shooter are ofc the weapons and this game has a lot of them. Most weapons are unqiue and there are only a few weapons which feel the same. Adding to the weapon variety are a huge pool of possible weapon mods. Which modify the weapons heavily They can change the elem tn of the weapon, give you bonus damage, bonus crit and so on, or might even add some unique effects, sometimes unique to the weapon.

All in all this game is perfect in what it does. The difficulty is nice and it never feels unfair. The RNG is fine you never feel like you get screwed and it has all elements one would expect and wish for in a rogue-lite game

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: It's so simple, and that makes it addictive. borderlands meets risk of rain. I haven't made it past the first boss, i feel like it's not that well balanced and there isn't a ton of content. Still i keep playing because it's tons of fun. One thing i would suggest though is randomly generated levels. I don't mind if they use the same assets but it would feel more refreshing to have different/random rooms each time. Also the grind is a bit harsh atm, the reward doesn't scale well with the skill tree requirements. Polish and balance this, keep adding content and add random dungeons. Then it will deserve the reviews it got so far. Right now i have fun, and i see potential, it's still far from where it could be so i hope the devs know that and give us what we want. For it's current price, it is worth it, if you like simple but challenging roguelikes like hades/risk of rain etc and enjoy borderlands. Recommended? YES.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn is an FPS roguelite where you can play as various characters with as goal to survive the Tomb, Desert and the Fjords and defeat the end boss, Yoruhime-Maru.
 
[h1]Full Review[/h1]

Just like many roguelites, every run in Gunfire Reborn is different. Each time you play, different guns, ascensions and scrolls present themselves. Scrolls have varying abilities that can aid a build or work together well with a specific weapon or ability. Many of them can be found but they can also be bought at the Peddler or traded for via treasure chests.

You don‚Äôt have control over what ascensions (character upgrades during a run) you find, but each time you find a goblet containing one, you get a choice in 3, of which most you can upgrade two more times after taking. 

There are a lot of unique guns to choose from (currently 40 different base guns), with a lot of them having a unique function or ability. On top of that, they can all have different statistics and properties to them, such as increased projectiles, magazine or reload speed, a different element or a gun-specific upgrade. This variation allows a lot of guns to be used in many different ways and for many different builds.

You can also upgrade your guns at the Craftsman. He can make your weapon stronger and also reforge any possible Gemini inscriptions. The latter are an inscription that if both your guns have it, they become active and work on both your guns, such as a shared amount of crit damage, or shared magazine, shared damage type (element fusion), etc.

There‚Äôs currently 3 different characters, all with unique abilities, ascension paths and playstyles:

* Crown Prince who can shoot an orb that locks enemies in place and has weakening smoke grenades
* Ao Bai who can dual-wield guns that combines and amplifies their strength and has explosive grenades 
* Qing Yan who is a martial arts character that attacks by using leaps to land on enemies and then cleave them with his wings

There are currently 3 zones: Longling Tomb, Anxi-Desert and Duo-Fjords. Each have unique enemies, elite minibosses and a final boss. They also contain vaults, which are a single area that contain a reward, but to obtain it you first have to survive a challenge, such as a trap parkour or fighting off more enemies.

You can play with up to four players in a single game. Playing with more players makes the enemies stronger but it also allows you to trade scrolls and weapons with your teammates so that everyone can more easily go for the build they are trying to get.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]

In a nutshell, this game is Borderlands mixed with Binding of Isaac in Sea of Thieves graphics. It has great replay value because of the different inscriptions guns can spawn with, as well as the different scrolls and ascensions you get each time.

This game is in early access and while it is a fully-fledged game, it is still worked on when it comes to squashing bugs and adding more content. The devs (only 3!) have shown incredibly potential for this game to become even better and are working hard to add more and more to it. It‚Äôs very addicting and can make you really forget the time. And all that for the ridiculously low price of only 10 bucks, outside of sales. Better get this awesome game before it may have a price increase in the future, because for the amount of content you get, this is a true bargain.

Also, consider joining the Discord: https://discord.com/invite/nFhHmMw where you can find players and chat about the game, as well as suggest and discuss new features.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Weapons and gameplay are very strong, but what you see in the sceeenshots is essentially the entire game.

Levels are overwhelming repetitive and some balance issues are definitely noticeable for enemies, characters, and weapons.

It just feels like it needs more polish. I understand it's an Early Access title, but there are definitely areas needing improvement. For the things it does well, it's incredible. For the things it doesn't, it's pretty lackluster and feels slapped together.

It's a great Borderlands-esque roguelite with some bits of Overwatch and Risk of Rain mechanics. For Early Access the price speaks for the content at the time being.

Definitely has incredible potential. Hopefuy there's more content down the road, but it gets a solid 4/5 at this point in time.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is so fun! It's  even more fun when you have friends to grind with. The game has hours upon hours of grinding despite how early in development it is. And don't think that because it's grinding that it's boring. It's pretty predictable so you can master it's levels, but it has enough unpredictability to keep it from getting boring. All the guns feel satisfying and the characters have good abilities that work well together. You can easily build up specific builds based on your playstyle (I just got done building a super overpowered sniper build on my last run). Along with the fact that this game has a great art style and the gameplay feels one-of-a-kind. I would highly recommend this game for anyone looking for a fresh new pve, fps, and/or roguelike feel.

EDIT: Would LOVE for the creators to make an official discord server for the game. Just a community of people who want to discuss the game, look for groups, etc.

title: Gunfire Reborn

Very challenging, it took my friend and I a few tries to beat the first dungeon, but not so challenging that you want to blow your brains out. A kind of challenging that is very satisfying when you finally win. Good game. Definitely worth the price. Also, I'm pretty sure some of the weapon animations are straight from Overwatch.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Duoyi ought to write a book on satisfying game design after their accomplishments in Gunfire Reborn.

Even still in early access, Gunfire Reborn is a game that [i]feels[/i] good to play in every measure, and its hard to explain why because if you were to compile a list of every satisfying mechanic in the game you would have a list of every mechanic in the entire game. Everything from the tight, faced paced movement that leaves you feeling fully in control of the battle, to the almost lottery-like sound design players are rewarded with for crits and kills.

At the moment, my largest criticism is that the voice acting for the characters can range anywhere from okay, to goofy, to downright difficult to listen to (Crown Prince). Although being in early access, I can only imagine details like this are subject to change anyhow. 

As it stands, the developers are pumping loads of dedication and new content into this game at the moment, and even if development were to halt today for the current asking price of $12 I would still easily recommend the game, but seeing as content is continuing to be added, and at a blistering pace no less, the current price tag is an absolute steal.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn in an amazing entry into not only the FPS genre, but the roguelike genre too. With a vibrant and interesting world and smooth gunplay, each run is bound to feel different as you traverse the 3 worlds and their respective 5 stages each.

Pros:
Interesting cast of characters to choose from all with unique skills.
Incredible assortment of weapons and smooth movement options.
Wide list of enemies to fight across the 3 worlds.
Enjoyable soundtrack.
Adorable artstyle.

Cons:
Can feel pretty grindy at the start.
Less enjoyable solo.

So, if you got a group of friends or are willing to go through matchmaking with randoms, Gunfire Reborn is an excellent choice for anybody with a love for FPS or roguelike games.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Probably the best rogue-like shooter I've played in years, even in the current early-access build. A lot of fun weapons, a lot possible upgrades and quite a few good build for every characters. You also have stuff to unlock for days without feeling very under-powered at the beginning of the game. (Maybe for the first few run but you unlock the first items so fast, it doesn't really matter)

The game also have a coop which is a huge plus. It's not the best coop game out there because it's not specifically made for coop (unlike games like Deep Rock Galactic and Payday) but it's a great game with a good coop experience on top of it.

The only small nitpick I have it on the clarity of some systems. It borrows a lot from Borderlands and Warframe so I guessed some of the mechanics quickly but some of it is not obvious at all. You can't know for sure that there is one element better for every health color. You can't know that "Crit" and "Lucky Shots" are two completely different things. Most of this information is in loading screens but the game loads very quickly for me. I'd love to see all of this things accessible from the main menu.

I'm having a blast alone and with my friends. I'm very much looking forward to new content and quality of life improvements.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
At first, I was very skeptical of Gunfire Reborn. It's a Chinese-made game offered at a very low price point - which is usually synonymous with massive amounts of microtransactions. There's no MTX to be found in this game.. at least not yet, and I'm hoping it stays that way because this is actually a good game. 

At first, this game looked like a mix of Binding of Isaac and Borderlands.. and that's more or less exactly what it is - it's Borderlands in roguelike form. Usually this would be something I'd drop right away, but the game is strangely well-designed with only a couple of flaws: notably the multiplayer is scaled a little strangely and there's some bugs involving enemies spawning on top of you that can lead to deaths that are very hard to prevent.

Gunfire Reborn starts you off with an item pool that has a couple of guns and some skill scrolls in it: scrolls are usually a tradeoff of one stat for another. The basic guns are all kind of bad, though once you unlock better ones (which you do pretty much immediately) you start noticing that the bad guns don't show up nearly as often. Part of the problem is that this game follows Borderlands's design principles of elemental guns that work against different types of HP: enemies can have shields that resist fire and acid but are weak to lightning or armor that's weak to acid but strong against fire and lightning. Non-elemental guns (the majority of what you start with) are kind of meh all around.

That's one thing I wish the developers would improve on. Past the first few stages, you more or less need an elemental gun or two: usually one that does electric and one that does acid. There's not much of a reason to carry anything else unless you're doing multiplayer, in which case fire is also acceptable provided someone else has lightning and acid. There's.. I think one scroll that makes non-elemental guns kind of okay, but it's hard to find and isn't worth hanging onto bad guns for. I feel like there should be some reason to use those and make every item in the pool useful in some way rather than having a bunch of items no one is going to pick up unless they have no better options.

My only other complaint is that the multiplayer is balanced very strangely. Not only does enemy HP scale, but their damage also scales to the point where getting oneshotted isn't all that rare of an occurrence. This becomes particularly egregious in the second stage where you have rapidfire teleporting sniper enemies who can put out ridiculous amounts of damage in MP. In Singleplayer, it's not as bad, but enemy HP scales really fast and can turn some enemies into bullet sponges even if you're using the right damage type and landing headshots. 

There's also a particularly annoying bug where some rooms feature waves of enemies, and on occasion they can spawn right on top of you and either kill you or do lots of damage before you can move. I feel like this is probably an easy fix of either changing the spawn logic so enemies have to spawn X distance away from players or making hidden areas where enemies can spawn that isn't right on top of you.

Other than that though, this is a pretty fun game and worth the pickup at current price, provided the developers do not try to implement MTX.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Initially I suggested waiting to buy this game. After taking a break from this I came back to play it after the devs had released a few updates.

While I still don't think this game is complete, I can say that you will still get your money's worth.

The Good:

Guns: Guns still feel amazing to use. In fact they actually feel better since I first played. They're satisfying and always fun to experiment with.

Combat: There's always a lot going on. You really need to be aware of your surroundings and kill quickly. Previously I had an issue with needing to hide too much. While that still happens on occasion you'll be engaged in high pace action most of the time.

Bosses: Bosses don't seem to have changed much since I first played, but I was already fond of them as they were. Intense battles against unique and interesting enemies. What's not to love?

Characters: Something I didn't touch on before were the characters. With the addition of a third character I feel the need to talk about them. Each character is unique and plays a different way. They won't all stick with every person, but I'm sure you'll find at least one you like. While I would like to see more in the future I can easily live with the 3 the devs gave us.

Loot: Finding loot is always exciting. Whether it be a gun, a scroll or another upgrade point. The best part is that when playing in co-op, loot is client side. That means no loot ninjas, but you have the option to drop loot for teammates if you desire. So it's safe to say the loot system is very player friendly.

Perks: One of my biggest issues was that there didn't feel like there was enough control over what perks you got with each character during a run. This hasn't changed, but they did change the perks themselves to be better. Now it doesn't feel like you're getting screwed over when you don't get what you wanted.

The Bad:

Content: Pretty much my biggest issue right now is that there isn't enough content. You have 3 areas and each area has 1 boss at the end. You may get some secret areas with mini boss like enemies, but I don't really count those being they're always random. Being this is in early access I'm assuming this will change with time. I'd love to see more areas and if possible maybe some branching paths to keep runs unique.


Overall this game is a lot of fun and I now feel like I can say it's worth buying. It may not be done, but with how much progress the devs have made since my initial review of this game I have high hopes for it.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This isn't a negative review, to me its neautral.  It's not "borderlands + rogue-like" like so many  reviews have put it. If anything it is more similar to Immortal Redneck with better skills and arguably better guns; however, compared to Immortal Redneck, the level design is less varied than any of the games discussed in these reviews. It was rare for me to take advantage of the terrain to my advantage.

My biggest problem comes from the lack of damage feedback from both the enemies and yourself. Most of them seem to be unflinching, so its not clear if you have landed a shot. This is mitigated by the damage numerics that float, but it is a visually jarring experience.

All in all, its not a bad game, but to me, it's definitely not a Overwhelmingly Positive game. If you are looking for a fast shooter with rpg progression and rogue-like level randomness, this is a good game. As long as you aren't bothered by the things i mentioned above.
developer_response: Sorry for your bad experience, we will add more content and optimize the gameplay in the future update, stay tuned.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Graphics: Simple, yet refined. (Runs @ locked 120FPS MAX Settings Ryzen 1600X / RX 580)
Story: N/A
Bugs: None @ 8 Hours of gameplay. Will update w/ patch number if quality drops.
Gameplay:
 A great rougelite. Each run feels unique and straightforward with a great balance to the difficulty. Some runs my build is working, othertimes I need to completely change my loadouts and spending habits. Gunplay is satisfying. Exploration is limited, but the vaults add an extra layer of depth to the gameplay. You can use them to dip away from a particularly hard fight or get that one extra scroll that makes your build click. Throwing on my favorite podcast/music and blowing up some terracotta baddies feels great.

Suggestions:
 Progression feels good... most of the time. Sometimes I feel skunked when I have 49 Soul essence at the end of a run and my next minimum upgrade is at 50. Would love to see an "Essence Bank" that takes half of your unused essence at the end of the run and stores it, allowing you to use it at the end of your next run to avoid the exact same situation from happening again. 

 Would love to see a starting roster of 2/3 characters at the start, with a rounded out total of 5 or 6 to pick from. But even this is just for the freedom of choice. The default character feels well balanced and I appreciate that more than a bunch of cliche unbalanced characters thrown in for the sake of inclusion. 

This is a solid rougelite please play it if thats your jam.

review: Gunfire Reborn is one of the best deals you can get on Steam without any doubt. To be 100% honest I don't see quite as much replay-ability as some other rougelites but the gun play in Gunfire Reborn is superb. The feeling of impact with each weapon and the fast movement that becomes second nature within a few games makes this game one of the hardest games to put down. Some of the gameplay systems in G.R. can be a bit confusing at first and not much is explained in very good detail in game but there are plenty of youtube videos or posts online that can help walkthrough how to do things like spend points wisely in the Talent tree or how to stack scrolls to make the best build possible each run etc.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Pretty much everything is fun to use from the occult scrolls, to the hero powers, to the wide slew of unique and exciting weaponry, with synergies on top of synergies where even bad runs are entertaining because of the exquisite gun-play and enemy variety.  On top of that, the developers are very active, updating the game weekly with a variety of bug fixes, optimizations, and item tuning with at least one update each month adding in a few more scrolls, weapons, map tiles, and, most recently, a new hero.  

Don't let the early access tag push you away, this game is 100% worth every penny.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
SUMMARY: A must-buy FPS Roguelike RPG loaded with plenty of features - optional multiplayer, plenty of rewards and unlockables, and it's own fun aesthetic.  There's tough enemies, interesting semi-randomized weapons, and a mix of in-run and carry-over skill advancement.  As you play you unlock even more, so each run is usually rewarding.  Though in Early Access, there's a lot there, and hopefully more to come, and its an absolute bargain at the price.


Note: This game is Early Access, and like most Early Access has its flaws.  In this case the game has a lot of content, but needs some polishing and fleshing out.

Calling Gunfire Reborn an "FPS Roguelike" is technically accurate, but doesn't quite cover just how much is in this game.  The standard stuff is there: shooting things, finding weapons and loot, carry-over character advancement.  But there's also different characters to play, synergies among weapons, temporary boosts, randomized weapon traits, and more.  It goes beyond its premise, so let's get to the game!

STORY: There's not much here, an evil corruption has hit the land of adorable animals armed with heavy mystic weaponry, etc.  I expect there's more story, but on the plus side you start out playing a cat with an awesome hat and alchemic-magic abilities, so that's a plus.  Later you also can play a badass dog who dual-wields weapons and throws bombs, or a Martial Artist Bird with kicks, sweeps, and unique defenses.

LEVELS: Levels are semi-randomized randomized, and you essentially enter an area, battle all enemies, and then the next area opens.  The game levels can range from duller early dungeons to fascinating outdoor areas.  Levels also contain various challenges and hidden vaults where you can uncover Occult Scrolls for bonuses.  Explore everything and find every advantage because you're going to face a lot of . . .

ENEMIES: Enemies are diverse and have decent AI, so they'll shred you if you're not careful. 
 After the first level, you also encounter some enemies with special traits.  They also have their own resistances and vulnerabilities, and that means you rely on . . ..

WEAPONS: The Weapons are wild, from lightning ball launchers to poison dart guns, to giant cannons with tiger faces.  Not only does each weapon function differently, they all have at least one randomized trait (called an inscription), and you can upgrade them.  The farther you go, the more inscriptions a weapon has.  You also can upgrade weapons and alter them.  You can only carry two at a time, and you also get a starter weapon that automatically levels up as you find better equipment.  Choose them carefully as they also work with . . .

SCROLLS AND ASCENTIONS: Each level you can get temporary enhancements for that run called Ascentions.  Scrolls can be found or bought and they add in-run bonuses, but sometimes disadvantages.  Ascentions are are purely positive and follow character-specific skill trees, but you get random choices.  These can have VERY powerful synergies with each other and weapons, so choose wisely.  Of course some things carry over from game to game . . .

PERMANENT BONUSES: As you play (and die) you'll collect "soul essence".  This allows you to get permanent character boosts that carry over between runs.  You'll want to select these carefully and plan accordingly.   Also as you complete tasks like defeating so many enemies or reaching a milestone, more weapons and scrolls unlock and enter the pool of possible equipment.  Playing each time usually has some reward, which affect . . ..

CHARACTERS:  You start with one character, the aforementioned Awesome Cat and can unlock others like the Explosion Dog and Melee Bird.  They also function differently - each has a unique ability and a unique grenade attack.  So there's more ways to play - and ways to team up!  Finally, I'd be remiss if I didnt mention . . .

THE LOOK: Though some levels are dull looking the designs for the heroes and monsters is great.  The heroes (and indeed their allies) have real character - reminicent of designs in Kung Fu Panda..  Early enemies resemble the famous Terracotta Warriors of Qin Shi Huang which is just neat.  Later enemies have different aesthetics of animal-soldiers  Enemies in motion have character.  There's a lot of detail here.

CHALLENGE: The game is challenging, and you'l probably have to grind a few levels before you get far.  The challenge does have some erratic difficulty as the randomized elements can mean one run you're overwhelmed, another you get through it easy.  Careful planning can usually but not always account for being overwhelmed..  One very important note - this is a thoughtful FPS.  Running around without thinking will get you killed!  Instead you want to get into the . . .

GAMEPLAY LOOP: Gunfire Reborn takes a few runs to get into, then the loop kicks in.  Unlocking the Talent tree gives you bonuses and new equipment.  These help you get farther, earning more resources to level up, and finding equipment and Ascentions to possibly prolong your run.  Earlier levels become easier and easier, so you can blaze through them.  The game's tight play and design makes each run fun, relatively short, and rewarding.  Also if you beat the game the first time you get . . .

ELITE MODE:  But it's not over!  Win the game and there's an Elite mode so you can do it all over again with tougher enemies and more rewards!  Elite mode sort of "turns everything up to eleven" - more traps, more dangerous enemies, better loot.

Oh and after that?  NIGHTMARE MODE.


DOWNSIDES: There's only a few downsides, and most are really because this is Early Access.
- The earliest of three levels is dull design-wise.  They get more interesting as they go on.
- Erratic difficulty.  The game's difficulty curve is unpredictable depending on the level, enemies, layout, and if you're facing a boss or not.  You can usually compensate, but there are sudden moments of ease or challenge that can surprise you.
- Runthrough approach.  You can't leap ahead in runs - every time you start over in the first dungeon, though you can save your run between the three areas.  This is not a problem, more of a challenging choice, but it'd be nice to visit other levels.
- Translation.  It's clear the staff tried, but some of the translation has flaws (though the Devs have been working on that).  This is more a warning - it's clear they worked pretty hard on this and they care.

So is it worth your time?  Yes, especially if you want a good FPS Roguelike.  The price is a bargain, there's a lot to the game, it will challenge you, and the devs are responsive.  Gunfire Reborn is an absolute treasure.  "Generous" is how I'd describe the game.

But who's it for?  As long as you don't mind Early Access:
* If the term "FPS Roguelike" tickles your fancy, really this is for you.  Your ship has come in (and it's loaded with monsters).
* If you like FPS games, but haven't done much Roguelike stuff,  you may like it.  The synergies may be appealing, and the replayability is nice.
* Did you like Borderlands?  Would you like the experience in Bite-Sized Chunks while also playing a bipedal dog mowing people down with dual-wielded elemental throwing knives?  Then buy it.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn is insanely fun and incredibly addictive with a lot of replayability in the form of unlocking more weapons and the game's Occult Scrolls. The developers listen to the community and push out regular patches with new content surprisingly quickly and I personally haven't experienced any game breaking bugs only the occasional minor bug that is then fixed in the next update.

Each weapon has a unique feel to them and are all fun to use and have the potential to be powerful depending on how you play the game. The heroes are amazing and I still can't decide on a favourite. This is one of those games that's had me excited for every single upcoming update and has me regularly scanning for any kind of news or hints for when and what the next update is.

10/10 game and I definitely think it should be worth more than it is.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
TL;DR - Rogue Legacy and Borderlands had a love child, and it is glorious. 

All this game lacks is content. It's in alpha, but already we have 3 VERY differently played characters, 3 VERY differently played Acts, 3 VERY differently fought bosses, and a hell of a time in between. I have personal gripes on some of the math for some of the abilites, but that's just one .ini mod away from fixing. 

If you love looter shooters.
If you love random generated levels.
If you love Rogue-like progression.
If you love Hero shooters.
If you love a game that's a blast to play with as many as 3 of your friends. 

Gunfire Reborn is what you want. Full price in Alpha is a whopping 11.99. Been worth it a dozen times over. 


Gunfire Reborn. Support these people. Let's make sure FPS creativity rewarded for ALSO being Reborn.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: Awesome game with rewarding gameplay. You're incentivised to keep playing or restarting no matter what your base skill is, this is important because you also can't just out shoot your way to the end, you need to acquire perks and skills to make you better suited for later levels. This game receives constant updates with meaningful content like weapons and enemies. I love playing this game with friends, and by myself. It taps in to my interest in speedrunning, without being contained to cheese strats and glitches. Theres a ton of fun to be had here. I don't post user reviews often, but this is a hidden gem.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
VERY VERY solid rouge-lite and shooter. 
Pros:
- The mechanics are easy to pickup and feel fun and engaging each run. 
- The constant (and rapid) flow of new content is so refreshing when compared to a lot of other games. 
- Match making is solid and its a great game to play with friends (incedibly popular and contagious in my friend group)
- Gunplay is varied and encourages trying new combinations
- Enemies are well designed and Vaults (siderooms) are solid and add variety in gameplay

Cons:
- The game does (25-30 hours in) become easy, barring the new difficulty above elite that I haven't touched yet.
- The game experience hooks you with difficulty early on, I recommend not starting your first few runs with a level 50 friend who will carry you and jepordize the experience.
