title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Borderlands 2 came out when I was living in an all boys dorm in college. There is literally not a better scenario to have gone in on a 4-pack of keys from a german reseller, we had an amazing time spending hours in Pandora. When Borderlands 3 came  out in 2019 I was forced to accept that I was older, and I'm not willing to put the kind of time in those games ask. I remember how foreign the jokes suddenly seem, how much I wanted to not spend 30 hours looking for a gun I like.

I crave brevity. Borderlands is your drunk uncle talking about his time in the oilfields. I don't care, I don't want it. It was cute when I was younger.

Gunfire Reborn is small, the way book reports are small, and its not quite complete yet either. If I had to describe it, it's like playing a growing monster, something with tons of potential, but you can see all the soft bits still. Some of the menus have not been localized to English, and the unlockables are scant. There are few guns, and while shooting is crisp, your preference will largely be finding a gun that you dislike least. Buffs are small, meaningless things to my lizard brain, but I am stirred to min/max in good runs, few as they are. 

Runs are joyously short, my longest clocked at about an hour, which means you can get to bed on time, and because it's roguelike, friends who are more disposed to grind will still have fun playing with you solving a major problem.

It is still so thin feeling even in its best moments. Paradoxically, playing this makes me miss the bigger bordered lands, I wish to find greater paths of completion, dopamine stills and stagnates when I kill the 1000th clay soldier. Indeed, the whole game reeks of pacing issues, power curves linearly float above weaker enemies unless you've really fucked it, moments rarely feel tense, even in the boss fights. Vaults never feel risky, like I think they're supposed to feel, rooms where enemies are buffed never inspire trepidation. Malaise hangs over everything once you've seen the guns, the rooms, the traps. 

For 10 dollars, and the promise of more, this definitely worth it. Discomfort at the growing thing in the glass can be avoided by not looking too closely at the seams of pre-life, and there's a machine gun that reloads itself to keep occupied. My only hope is that someday I'll play this and not wonder if [i]that other game[/i] has gotten better while I've been away.

This game is very fun, I am glad I popped in onto YouTube last night or else I would have never found this gem. Cannot wait to see what the devs do to this game. Like most people have said, it's a mix between Borderlands and Risk of Rain. There are many items and upgrades to find along single runs, and many skills to pump points into post-run.

There are a few spelling and grammar issues currently, but they're minor enough that it doesn't detract from the gameplay.

Weapons feel really good, really fun to shoot. Enemies feel fair and balanced, although I only just unlocked the second available hero. 

I see myself pumping in many more hours into this game! Do yourself a favor and pick it up, it's relatively cheap. And hey, if you don't find yourself enjoying it, refund it!

EDIT: They just dropped a new character to play as after two months of early access! plus loads of new weapons, balance changes, and enemies. if you're on the fence, this developer is putting in the work to ensure your gameplay experience is as fun as possible! very impressed

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: Okay, so upon purchase of this game I waited to play it and see what the devs update the game with... After 1.8hrs of shooting-dying-repeat I've come to a fairly decent review that I hope is taken into future update consideration even if its already been a forethought.  So the gunplay and elements of the game resemble other games of this genre, which isn't bad however no new game design features which haven't already been used.  The atmosphere and very little story if any aren't the greatest.  My biggest complaint that has me questioning the replay value of this title are the *Hit Boxes* mainly those for the player, its seems the chances of you getting hit by whatever the enemy throws at you are a lot to maybe not.  being that your hit box is freakishly huge compared to the boss fights.  even the various enemies... So it gets rather less enjoyable due to the fact of complete and utter cucked up shite that happens.  So if I would recommend this to others?  Sure, BUT it needs lots of work yet still.
developer_response: Sorry for your bad experience, we keep adjusting the game difficulty and game balance, please give us more time to polish. Thanks for your feedback.

review:
EDIT (20/8/20)
My original review used to be a maybe, because this game felt unfinished.  However I'm changing my review to a firm yes.

The developer has cared about this game immensely and has updated it a ton since I posted my review.  I'm genuinely impressed that they have updated it this much and actually listened to community feedback.  The problems that I listed like menus and certain things not having sound where they should be have been addressed, and things have been toned down in terms of difficulty with more than two players.

This game for it's price is criminally underrated and extremely worth every penny.  I highly recommend you pick it up, and pick up several copies for your friends.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn is a fantastic blend of FPS and Roguelite, bringing a much-needed breath of fresh air to the genre. Even though it is still early access, the game's controls and movement are incredibly tight and fluid, rivalling the feel of even AAA titles. The game is a steal for the price, and being early access means there is only more content to come.

Pros:
- Games feels solid.
- Multiple fun and challenging difficulties.
- Up to 4-player online co-op
- An arsenal of unique, silly, and awesome weapons with an abundance of random perks and traits that keep the game feeling fresh and make each run feel unlike the last.
- (At the time of writing this review) 3 unique characters with their own skill-trees and abilities.
- Bomb-doggo is best doggo.

Cons:
- Some language localisation issues. (improper grammar, etc.)
- (Nit-picking) 2D graphics - such as certain aspects of the HUD and floating text - are very low resolution and quite jarring. (to me)

This game is a fantastic buy for any roguelite fan. The Devs are very vocal with the community and they are releasing new patches and updates almost weekly.
Do yourself a favour and give this game a try.

review:
Gunfire is quickly becoming one of my favorite roguelikes. The amount of variety in the weapons and character builds makes every run feel different from the rest. The gun play is very smooth and fast paced which keeps the action moving from room to room.

My only complaints so far would be the lack of visual variety (you go through the same 3 areas each run) and the somewhat annoying platforming segments for additional items, but those are optional. 

The devs continually update this game with new weapons and items so I have no doubt when this comes out of early access that it will be in my top 10.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
[Edit 20-08-2020 after the update. (changed from negative to postive)]
Guess I got good, but I had over 400HP in the last fight due to the scroll that gives 1max HP if you kill an enemy. And I had 2 revives scrolls, and the ingame revive on the last boss, I used all of it. Remind you I went in blind.
And I got hit back to 30HP with no shields in one shot of the barrage, because I did not knew where it went, but after that I knew. And then the boss went into a second phase. Phew.
I won. Harsh battle but the updates certainly are showing. 

Certainly challenging, but rewarding. Still you need to know the boss or have tons of HP and revives as I had. 
High respect to the developer commenting to my review. The updates do show their improvements

--------------------------
[old review before the updates, negative]
No idea why this game has so many positive reviews, it certainly is a fun game for the dungeoniering, because everything else is nice skills, enemies being different, but the boss fight are terribly balanced, they are either too easy if you have the right weapons, or one or two shot you whilst the normal dungeon areas were very easy. 

Gun play is pretty good since it's about all projectile based. Elemental combos are alright. Enemies very different and great.
The problems with the boss fights are with attacks that instantly spawn on you, giving you barely any time to react. Maybe a second? The bosses do telegraph ''an attack'' but that is not when they are attacking. 
First boss his rock throw, the wind up animation means nothing, and then you get a red circle and 1 second to react or byebye half of your hp. You must save your 3 second dodge to evade this. Why? No idea, but if it's on cooldown, rip you.
Second boss is too easy, laser is pretty much instant, but you can evade out of it.
Third boss... instant barrage from where? Also instant kill with full hp and shields. Yay.

If you want make the game trivial, look up boss videos.
developer_response: Sorry for your bad experience, we keep adjusting the game difficulty and game balance, please give us more time to polish. Thanks for your feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: so far, it's really enjoyable and I am having fun with it, looking forward to new enemies and weapons hopefully soon! Great job!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: This is the best game I have played in years. My best friend and partner play this game with me, it's like raiding with your best friends. Fast paced and the rogue like system gives you all the dopamine hits. New harder level was just on time for us as we were regularly clearing on elite mode. That said, the original character is easier to play than the other 2. I haven't figured out how to build them to work yet and the elemental system is too awesome to stop using in my opinion. I personally think the other characters need a tweak as we can clear on elite with the cat regularly but if any of us go either of the others, even with all their unique talents unlocked, we struggle, big time. Might just be a learning curve for the other characters but I am not so sure. Either way the game is well supported with regular updates and it seems like the developers care about the game and its content. A big key to regularly clearing was trading with your team, you can help them upgrade their weapons, reroll gemini and trade scrolls so you all have a well rounded build come the last dungeon and the last boss. I have some recommendations to make some scrolls that can't be dropped due to how they could be abused to be dropped but only a team member can pick it up, adding to the games current team play focus. This could allow players to pass on triple comeback for instance in order to help not only themselves but their allies. There is definitely room for that sort of mechanic to occur, scrolls intended to be passed through the team in order to clear the dungeon. The best part of this game is how it feels like an entire week of raiding in one run because of the rogue like format. It is satisfying to clear the entire dungeon and exciting every time you get a drop. The RNG component of this game forces you to adapt but more often than not provides a valid build. Our motto is trust in RNGesus. When we trust in RNGesus, we usually end up with everything we need to clear. Nightmare difficulty is a blast. We logged on late last night after the update, cleared it on elite in order to try a run on Nightmare and we got to the second boss before we wiped. It is much harder but so much fun. Love these devs, love this team, keep up the good work! Look forward to what you have in store for us!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Definitely the best game I played this year. I can't believe I got it for 10 bucks, this game has so much to offer, even for an early access. And by the time I write this, the devs just released a new hero and a new difficulty, yet adding more hours of content. I played 31 hours so far and still not bored because the range of weapons and combos is so wide I still have things left to explore.

Now regarding the game itself, the quality is insane. Weapons offer lots of different ways to play and the mechanics are very well made. You can really feel the rogue side of the game in that you don't choose really what you will play, instead you just play along with what you get. Sometimes you'll feel like your setup is garbage but that's ok, just die and upgrade overall stats with what you won so far (yes, you have skills that you can upgrade forever), and sometimes you'll end up with a setup so busted you basically take a crap on the last boss.

Just watch a few videos to really capture the theme of the game and buy it, the hundreds of reviews don't lie this game is amazing.

! Gunfire Reborn 8.20 Update !

New character, new weapons, new enemies, new difficulty and voicelines as a bonus. Massive update, even paying full price for this feels like robbing the devs. They should actually consider increasing the price. Maybe with the next big update? At the very least once it comes out of Early Access.

Looking for Co-Op? Shooter? Crazy builds? Rogue-Lite? Must buy.

___________________________________

Frequent updates and fixes, satisfying gameplay and many things to try.

Fun gunplay, lots of options, interesting synergies, a lot of crazy effects to stack on your character.

Rogue-Lite shooter with persistent progression in the form of passive skills that make you stronger directly or give you more tools during gameplay.

Right now some upgrade and weapon choices feel a bit suboptimal while others are overwhelmingly powerful but you can always experiment and see if you find a good, new build. In any case there is a good variety of weapons and playstyles available.

Feels smooth and doesn't really have any problems functionally. Well worth a buy now, you can definitely get your moneys worth. For longer commitment I am hoping for more substantial content updates in the future, like more weapons, additional characters and levels.

Thank you for your feedback!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Such a simple concept, but so well executed. If you like a straight up shooter that is very linear with some skill progression. Everytime you die (or perhaps finish the run) you get to spend your gathered points you got for that run for skills you get to keep. Skills like reduced cooldown, more damage, etc. etc...

You get to play a dog who can dualwield, a cat who can cast a magic ball similar to the siren in borderlands 2 or a bird/hawk who specializes in melee combat. 

There are regular updates to the game that has more content, weapons, characters and more. 

BTW, this game can be played solo or with others. MAX 4 players.

Have fun, everyone!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
The game was perfectly fine and on a very awesome track. 

I've spent countless hours running through this over and over, enjoying every minute of it.

Until the update that was released today(8/19/20). We've waited so long for the bird.. and now he's here...... and he's .... melee based.

Melee should have never been introduced into this game and seeing as this has been implemented in this format it can only be a matter of time before melee weapons and a basic melee attack for the original characters is put into the game.

This will just cause alot of idiots to be rushing when they shouldn't and getting downed then crying to be picked up.

At which point the game will become just another bland knockoff of the same old stuff that panders to the less than casual audience  and it will stop being the amazing powerhouse that it was.

I am seriously saddened by this because I have seen too many games go downhill because of devs adding things or changing things that 5% of the community keep crying about constantly because they can't figure out how to overcome something or figure out how to deal with something. 

Maybe I'll check back and see if anything has changed in a year or so. Maybe it will have reverted out of this stage and continued on the original badass track that it was on. It was hella fun while it lasted.
developer_response:
Here is the direct message from core developer to your concern, thanks for your feedback: 

Qing Yan is in our plan for a long time, and the dev team also wants to see how a melee-based hero will be like in the game. We will constantly keep an eye on this hero. In addition, currently we don't have plan for melee weapons. Thanks for your support and hope you can understand it. We will keep polishing the game as usual. At least next hero won't be melee-based:)

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
So I had compare to this like Borderlands game mixed with Roguelite and that comes down to the abilities, guns, and difficulty. 

You go through a lot of trial and error (especially when you play by yourself), but because of that trial and error you will improve yourself based on the enemy you come face with, and with knowing which items is best useful, and weather or not you want to risk the chance of going through the purple portal where you can get lucky with scrolls 

Next to that is leveling up your skill power, how much ammo you have, how much damage you do, how much health you have, and how much shield power you have. That's also something to consider when you go through your trial and error.

The game is fun to play, and you will want to get better at knowing which enemy to deal with first and which one to deal with last, what weapon you prefer to use, which abilities you want to upgrade as you go though each level, which gun you want to fully upgrade or just have both upgraded once. You will never know what you'll have to fight at the end of the door nor which types of enemies (unless you been though it so many times you can take a good wild guess at it) I would recommend getting this game and to play it with friends.

review: This game is fun at first, but it becomes stale and repetitive incredibly fast. My favorite games are risk of rain, the binding of isaac and the souls series, so I definitely enjoy challenging games and roguelites, but the difficulty on this game ruins it. Only a select few strategies are viable, and if you don't adopt one of these and prefer to play a different way then you will only get to experience the first stage and maybe the first level of the second stage if you are lucky. I was playing on co-op with one person, I have heard that things are easier in single player, but I specifically got this game for co-op.
developer_response: Sorry for your bad experience, we keep adjusting the game difficulty and game balance, please give us more time to polish. Thanks for your feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
At first this game seems way too simple, but after a play or two it sucks you in. Wonderful game if you like to turn on the game, play a match or two and move on.

Game is engaging, the amount of weapons keeps you going, their various modifications and characters skills allow for great variety in playstyles. 

Difficulty is a problem  - it gets way too difficult way too fast. For example in Stage 4 of the first sequence enemies are capable of annihilating half of your shield with one shot. Getting through first boss alone is a suicide mission.

Because of that it's almost impossible to progress, if you don't play with people online.

More variety in heroes would be nice as well - right now there is only two. Second hero needs to unlocked by leveling up, but by the time you get there you don't want to play as him.

Still, despite its problem, it is still worth it's price

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Fuck those nihilist monks, and the last stage. The monks have little to no delay when they teleport and cast an AoE that has a very fast tick rate and a sizable area that you can't get out in just 1 dash. You die so fast and there aren't a lot of defensive buffs that it just takes seconds to kill you during the last boss. God I regret buying this piece of ÊãâÂ±é.

Edit: I had to look up how to beat the final boss and apparently it needs the character to be at a high level. I wish the game had better conveyance or pacing to tell me that that's what I need to do. Wasted 4 hrs constantly getting frustrated because it's doable to get to the last stage at a lower level but then end up dying so easy at the last boss fight, not knowing that I really should just level up instead. God this is a waste. May play this again with friends but I won't recommend them this so we won't play.
developer_response:
You can easily kill Elite Corrupt Monk by hitting its head, or you can use "shift" to quickly get out of their attack range.
Regarding Youruhime-Maru,you need to dodge his shelling, and the cannon he fired in the second stage can be broken. Hope these tips are useful to you :)
Thank you for your feedback!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I stumbled upon this game by chance about a month ago and was pleasantly surprised! I appreciate it's replay value (primarily because of how your build can influence your strategy). The gunplay is good and the weapons have plenty of variation. The "trick jumping" rooms are fun. Multiplayer works well and is nicely integrated into Steam.

To me, the game is hard - but not too hard. Paradoxically, perhaps, I appreciate how the game can turn on you and end your run in seconds! :) 

I would have liked some more randomness/variation to the dungeons (you will learn them and they'll become quite predictable). I would also appreciate some more movement tech (such as iD-esque bunny hopping or rocket jumping), or at least a higher default movement speed.

Overall, an extremely polished early access release! It took me about 50 hours/80 levels to beat the game on normal mode in single-player. And I am now looking forward to do some more runs in Elite mode.

Update: Elite Mode completed. Akimbo daggers (Prism/Glimmering) for the win! :D

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Better game in early access than a lot of other games at release.  

What I like:  
I like that each character feels very different. The weapons all feel unique too.  The game has good variety for early access.  I don't play a ton of shooters and the difficulty feels fair.

What I don't like:  (honestly this list will probably be taken care of by the time out of early access)
Certain weapons seem to be quite a bit better than others.  The pickups typically give you a buff or passive help, I would like to see the pickups have more unique effects.  Local Co-op would be nice too.  

Overall an amazing game in early access.  Totally worth the cost and most my nitpicks will most likely be fixed by release.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
It's like a shorter Rogue-lite Borderlands.

+ Combat feels more involved.
++ Unless you roll exceptionally good Ascensions (talents for that run) with equally good Scrolls (passive buffs for that run) and guns that cooperate with those Ascensions and Scrolls, you have to prioritize certain mobs or risk instant death.
+ Game feels good, and you feel that when doing the jump vaults
+ Ridiculously cheap asking price - Would have easily paid $30 or so for this game
+ CO-OP is fun, lets you progress easier and sharing drops for crazier builds

- The game is early, and currently only has three levels, each with a handful of stages and a big boss fight at the end.
- Needs some more random things to make the game more difficult
- Some unlocks need a lot of grind
- Lack of dynamic joining games
- More guns, scrolls, stages, bosses, characters, difficulties, randomness, and this game increases in value

title: Gunfire Reborn

I cant put my finger on it, but this game is just fun as hell.. Its great. 
I've submitted some feedback and within 24 hours on all occasions I've received a reply about it. 

If i had to knit-pick, I guess I would ask for more guns? different types.. but really, solid game.

review:
I have unlocked everything, except 2 perks. This game is crazy addicting and I wasn't expecting it to be as good as it was. Roguelite + Borderlands is what I describe it as. Although, the random features that make borderlands loot so fun aren't really here. I have a short attention span, so spending 56 hours is CRAZY too me. My problem at the moment is by the 2nd level you tend to only use the same guns, because they are the most effective. 

So a lot of the guns are just simply there and really serve no purpose. In short, there are some clear balancing issues needed. By the 3rd map you could either just die, or you will just be rolling so overpowered that everything is dying instantly.

The "craftsman" guy is really pointless to me. The upgrade is just to little to have any benefit. I'd like too see the whole craftsman redone and make upgrading or "transcribing" the guns worth it.

 I would also like to see more than 2 classes, because at this point I've seen and done it all. And this is more of what I notice and might not be a fact, but the game doesn't get many decent updates, for sure they fix bugs though which I appreciate it (I haven't ran into any off the top of my head). 

Get this game, it's awesome, especially if you love to unlock things in Roguelites.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn, for being a relatively new game in Early Access, I have to say you get what you pay for.

PROS:
- The kinds of guns you get all feel varied and often unique, from handguns, SMGs and shotguns to laser gauntlets and auto targeting beams.

- The small variety in room layouts means you don't know where you are going but you at least know how to get there.

- The difficulty feels like it scales rather well, the new players may struggle and that can be a bit of a grind but once you're a few hours in you get the hang of dodging and the types of attacks to expect.

CONS:
- The variety of enemies could do with a shake up down the road. Obviously more will always be better and add to the RNG but in its early stage, you know what you're up against and that can take away from the experience.

- The descriptions and localisation could do with a bit of a clean up to make things slightly clearer.

- The current lack of playable characters can often times feel stale considering the option to have 3 other friends tag along. However, this one will probably change once the games been out much longer.

Overall, if you follow the dollar per hour rule, you will get tons of enjoyment from this purchase and I hope to see the true potential over its lifetime.

Edit: As of August 2020, Con 1 and 3 has started to be worked on while Con 2 is much better than the original release.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Although the game is currently in Early Access, it's fairly solid. Being by a HK/Chinese-based studio and featuring some questionable grammar and syntax in the store page, your first reaction might be that it looks like the many shovelware/asset flip type garbage games that are unfortunately cluttering the Steam store; not in this case!

Gunfire Reborn, to describe it better than the Steam Store page, is a rogue-like (or maybe rogue-lite; i honestly am not sure what the distinction is between those two terms) first person shooter, with semi-randomized guns a la Borderlands, that can be played solo or cooperatively (online), and some light RPG elements. You play as one of either two characters (only one of which is unlocked at first), running through rooms and fighting enemies until you reach a boss fight for the level; I would compare it to Risk of Rain 2, The Binding of Isaac, or probably its closest relative would be Immortal Redneck. Upon death, you can invest currency gathered during the run, called "soul essence", into levels in a skill tree, and you can't carry it over to the next run (at least, at first), so you're encouraged to invest as much as possible into whatever skills you can to improve your chances on the next run.

The combat gameplay is surprisingly solid for an Early Access game; there's great variety in weapons, and most if not all the guns I've tried have been fun to use and felt precise and fairly balanced. There are some status effect type things that can stack to broken levels pretty easily, but the game seems to be a "give high damage, take high damage" type affair, at least at the time of writing.

As I mentioned earlier, this game is still in Early Access, so you can expect a little glitchiness here and there, but it seems to mostly come in the form of visual disparities, like your co-op partner's gun looking different to you than to them, or certain effects not properly displaying to the other player. In about 30 hours of play, neither myself nor my friend I've been co-oping with have noticed much in the way of game-breaking bugs. However, the developers are actively soliciting feedback, so in the event that you do encounter any, you can send a report in-game very easily.

Because English is not the developers' native language, you may notice some funky looking grammar or word choice, and if I'm being honest, some of the names of scroll effects or guns read like they're items on a Chinese restaurant's menu, or like they weren't properly translated because maybe the original word doesn't have a good equivalent in English. Here's hoping that these little issues can be corrected before the game truly launches, but for now I'm giving it an 8 on the basis of fun, addictive co-op gameplay and the fact that it's only a $10 game.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Finally, a Rogue-like (or rogue-lite) FPS game that was developed with co-op in mind. 
You can communicate using in-game chat, as well as integrated voip chat. 
You can trade items with your friends and you won't have to compete over an item because everyone gets one. Leveling is based on number of players. Interesting set of items and weapons. Well integrated character progression system where you can use points earned from the adventure to get nice perks that will help you through the future adventures. 

Currently, there are only 2 playable characters and little bugs that are being fixed. 
More contents are being added each week. 
Other than that, this game doesn't feel like an early access at all and feels like a finished product.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Incredibly fun and addictive FPS Roguelite. Nice visual design and satisfying combat. Runs well with stable 60+ FPS @1080p on my GTX 1650 laptop and over 240 FPS @1440p on a GTX 1080 Ti desktop.

My only gripe is that I wish there was more variety in starting levels sort of like Dead Cells. You play the same levels in the same order each time. Despite the lack of level variety, there is a good amount of enemy types, which in different combos keep the gameplay fresh and interesting.

In its current state, it's and 8 to 8.5/10 for me; mainly due to lack of level variety. With more content, this is easily a 9/10 game. I'm having a blast.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I've only played about twenty hours or so, but this game is so fun. It is such a steal for $12. The gameplay and gunplay is so smooth and clean. The hit mark sounds for getting crits/lucky shots feels good. The speed and fluidity feels good. 

The graphics are good as well, it has such a clean artstyle and everything is so visible. The developers also seem to be patching the game fairly consistently, adding a new hero and more guns. The worst thing about this game is convincing my friends to spend $12 on an early access title to play co-op with. More seriously, some of the translations and weapon names are a bit wonky ("Big Hippo") but it's such a minor issue. 

Get this game, it's really fun!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I have been burnt too many times with early access games but when I read some reviews and saw that it was "overwhelmingly positive"..

All I can say is that I have not been disappointed, it is an awesome, fun, addictive game and as you can see my hours of how much I have played and funny thing, I bought it over the weekend so in 4-5 days I have played this much....

The game starts off slow as you cannot make it that far because you gradually unlock new weapons, skills and scrolls as you play which makes you that little bit stronger in which you progress further and further until you finally beat the game!!

That is when Elite mode is unlocked which gives it that little bit of an extra challenge!!

Me and my friend have been enjoying 25 hours of this game and I highly recommend this game to everybody as I can assure you like many others that this is an awesome game and it does not feel like an early access.

The only downside is that the game is short, it only takes around 40-60 minutes to complete but I hope as time goes on there are new levels or something.

EDIT: The devs constantly update, balance, fix and let us know when a major update with new levels, scrolls, weapons, enemies etc are coming out so I recommend this game even more now... Do not listen to the negative reviews as I can assure you that this game is awesome solo or with a few mates!! believe me!!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: Great game, especially for an early access title that just came out recently. The core gameplay is tight and fast paced. The guns feel incredible to use and you are rewarded for aiming well at weakspots by getting increased critical damage. There are tons of unique weapons and enemy variety is already pretty good. Fun progression system that lets you build your character in a new way each run. Huge amount of unlockables through completing in-game challenges (those unlockables being new weapons and passive upgrades alongside new buffs that you find by opening chests throughout a run). There are currently only 3 stages and 3 bosses but it still feels like a lengthy enough package for the low price of $12. I haven't even tried multiplayer yet but as a singleplayer experience I highly recommend Gunfire Reborn.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I want to love this game. I do love this game, but I am SO EFFING FRUSTRATED WITH THIS GAME!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Finding steamed buns when you need 'em is almost impossible (they provide health regen. Delicious, delicious health regen), and I've done literally hundreds of run throughs on the FIRST level without gathering enough soul essence to buy a cup of tea and a steamed bun, let alone up my character's ranking to where e might actually stand a ghost of a chance against Lord Lu Wu The Tiger with a fist of . . . actually I'm not sure . . . Iron? Jade? really corroded bronze? Did I mention he has a shield of 8,000 points and EIGHTY THOUSAND HIT POINTS???? I am NOT joking. Meanwhile my poor Kitty cat has 85 shield points and about the same for hit points. That's all. After SIXTEEN HOURS AND GOD ALONE KNOWS HOW MANY RUN THROUGHS.  To be fair the game IS in Early Access and if the developers have pity on a poor frenzied gamer who just wants to move on to the next level before he dies of old age, I will happily change my review, because the game does have a huge amount of promise. IF ONLY IT WASN'T SO BLOODY FRUSTRATING!!!!!!
(i'm going to stop shouting now and lie down with a cold compress and a cup of tea)
developer_response: Using weapons with lightning damage can easily break BOSS's shield, and you can evade its attack behind the pillars. Hope you can beat the first BOSS soon! Thanks for your feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: So when you start playing, the game's pretty chill, pretty fun but pretty generic. nice cheap B shooter. You turn up the difficulty to where it honestly should be by default, this game is fucking GAS. Every stage becomes a precarious bloodbath with danger and excitement with every step of the way that blends a need for strong decisionmaking with solid mechanical skills, positioning and reflexes. Needs more levels, characters and challenges but it's still in early access at the time of typing this so those are probably on the way right now.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This is a nice little rouge lite shooter with a bit of a learning curve. Once you figure out elemental combination and good scroll interactions it becomes a lot easier. 
It is really enjoyable in smaller bursts but for long sessions there is too little variety at the point of writing. However the dev(s) seem very active and add new things frequently.
All in all for the price it is well worth it if you like shooters and/or rougelites.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I played this game heavily for the first two-three days I had it.

The game has a good amount of replayability, but I want a genuine endless mode. I can't imagine not having it [i]eventually[/i]. For $12 at the time of purchase, it was incredibly well worth it. The history of weekly updates really encouraged my purchase, because at least right now the developer is truly giving it attention.

The game feels like it soft-locks you out of content below a certain account level (looking at you, Lu Wu). The game feels incredibly difficult early on, but once you start getting "up there" in account levels, it's a breeze, even on Elite. If you find yourself having difficulties, elemental combos (Fusion effects) are the way to go.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Quite possibly the best $12 I've spent in years. This game is fun on a bun, it has really solid classic shooter game play (think Serious Sam, no crouch, no sights, just run and gun), it's easy to pick up and play, easy to join your friends, and you can get a satisfying run done in only 15 or so minutes. 

Even if that was all the game had, it'd still be pretty decent, but it layers on some genuinely satisfying roguelike elements (weapon modifiers, and random perks) that make every run feel super unique, and allow for some very interesting and unique play styles (want to be a triple dasher that shoots elemental bullets? totally doable!). The final icing on this cake is that gunfire even has a deep macrogame with persistent upgrades that keep you playing run after run (and many of the upgrades vastly expand the game's content...it's brilliant!). 

Simply put, if you like roguelikes, like classic shooter, or enjoy pick-up-and play coop events, stop reading the review and buy the game already so that you can anxiously await new content updates along with the rest of us!

review:
[h1] Be aware [/h1]
Behind the point and shoot made by this very minimalist approach (graphically).
The wide variety of weapons and items give you a very wide range of possibilities. Even with only 2 characters (at the time of this review).

If you like some mechanics, you can make it good, very good. Though that is up to you finding the proper way to build it.
Beside some meta around (that will probably change over updates) nothing in strong, nothing is weak. Everything has potential.
This is the true skill of Gunfire Reborn, learning how to make a good use of this potential from what ever RNG the game gives you.

Gunfire Reborn have no story background, no character emotions and feelings, no voice acting. And that's a good thing, the game focus on the essential, the gameplay.

Kind of hard to review a game that is barely 3 months old, so if my opinion change I will edit this review

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Picked this game up on a whim after a friend of mine mentioned it to me. It sounded like everything I wanted! Even though I was given the early access disclaimer a few times, I couldn't help but want to try it. I've put some hours into Zigurat and a rogue-lite mod for Legend of Grimrock 2, but neither compare to this game.

It has elements of what I'd call an 'rpg-lite FPS game', though that's a fancy way of saying it's got some mechanics inspired by or lifted from Borderlands. Shields, simple damage types. However, unlike in borderlands, you have the rogue-lite element of incremental upgrades coupled with the finality of death ending your whole run. 

The meat of the game consists of repeatedly playing through the same 3 early-access 'levels', 5 strung together randomly generated rooms or landscapes with a random array of linear map-themed enemy progression, with a few accessible bonus rooms for extra random rogue-lite perks, and trying to successfully beat each level's unique boss.

However, most of your early experience in the game will likely consist of failing to beat the first level, or just getting a little past that and dying. Which is great! Currently, there really isn't too many levels. So replaying the same randomly generated rooms isn't so bad. That said, it is pretty early access. So you will encounter the same tiles and enemies, especially from the first level, quite often. Which can grow a little boring after an odd 8 hours into the game.

That said, the actual guns are quite fun. Unlike Borderlands, which has a long linear campaign to complete and progress through, there progression in Gunfire Reborn is basically set difficulty provided by the enemies you encounter in each level. So, while there are currently some basic weapons that naturally out-progress jankier alternatives, the jank weapons are still pretty usable and fun if you don't mind putting up with them.

The random modifiers on the weapons are quite a lot of fun too. Currently you obtain more modifiers on items by unlocking them in a between-run progression perk tree system. It's not terrible but it feels a little unbalanced. I'd prefer if from the get-go, you have the same amount of types of modifiers (called enhancements in-game), with the bonus chances at getting those modifiers coming from occult scrolls (the run-unique perks you obtain in-game from chests) Additionally, the games' developers do not seem to speak clear English, which is an issue as it hurts the clarity of many enhancements and occult scrolls.

Another criticism I have of the game, is that currently there is a single unique boss enemy for each level. This isn't necessarily a bad thing. It means you must learn how to fight each boss well in order to progress easily through repeat runs. But, the lack of variety means you get bored of fighting the flame tiger after run 6. Plus it makes it especially easy to beat the boss by simply planning ahead and picking up the strongest possible weapon to counter the bosses' defenses to easily surpass it. If the game had some alternative bosses, which may have very similar or the same abilities but with a different flavour or look, it would make replaying a little less disinteresting. Though preferably, the alternative bosses should have some different abilities, at a similar mechanical difficulty as the base bosses.

Beyond that, the game only has two classes playable at the moment. This is due to change soon, apparently the third character is being worked on. The classes are not too different from a siren and a gunzerker from Borderlands. The siren character is the default one you start with. They, like sirens, have a tree dedicated to elemental damage and proc chance, as well as a tree that focuses on improving their force-grasp ability. However the most interesting part of the siren-like character is their smoke grenade. Pretty cool that class-unique grenades are seeing a role here, as it reminds me of classic Team Fortress. I hope that more uniqueness is worked into the trees however, as currently the perks pretty boring passive upgrades, rather than game play changing choices. Arguably that's just their goal anyway, but I like the more situational improvements rather than straight power boosts.

The other character is the dogzerker. Puppo is pretty powerful, mostly due to his strong perks that hugely improve survivability during the guns akimbo ability. He also has a tree focused on improving grenade damage, and grenade damage in general. The third tree focuses on weapon damage and general weapon benefits gained from gunzerking. Honestly, I'd say he needs a nerf.

 At the very least, I think both and/or all classes may need to be nerfed a bit and given more interesting one-of-a-kind game-play changing perks. An example might be replacing the hex smoke perk tree with just a single point talent that makes the gas grenade do no damage, but still apply the effect of max Hex Smoke. A replacement perk for the doggo could be a perk that converts elemental damage on their currently handled weapon into explosive damage bonus for grenades & explosive damage in general. Another could be a perk that reduces fire-rate and damage during dogzerking, but that provides both the damage reduction and health increase that the max level perks of their current tree applies.

I'm not sure how I feel about survivability coming from the between-run perk tree. It feels a little broken, since you naturally make your own runs easier by having many hours sunk into the game. I know this is a common progression style in these kinds of games, but I find it pretty off-putting because of the little depth of game difficulty in it's current state. Right now, getting to around level 45-60 is enough to have both health and shields maxed, along with the first two unique perks of both classes, and a good handful of whatever else you want. By that point, it makes the early game pretty plum easy. Which isn't great, since in this kind of game, you want every level to be challenging.

Ultimately though, for the price it is currently, it's a bargain for the gameplay it offers. Borderlands set the bar but this game really runs with the idea in a very fresh direction. Aside from maybe Remnant, there aren't a ton of good FPS rogue-lite games. Zigurat was the only one I really knew of before this. The game does the concept justice and has pretty surprising replay ability in spite of it's early access circumstance. The game takes the idea of the elemental types from Borderlands but gives them their own spices, mixing two elemental afflictions on the same target gives them a new status effect! This is fantastic as it means using elemental weapons, even as a non-elemental character, has some potent benefit. I hope this concept is explored more in occult scrolls, since the afflict rate for most weapons is pretty meagre. 

I would recommend this if you have been searching for an exciting FPS rogue-lite game.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Holy hell, how has this game maintained this score with as abysmally small content as it contains. I've only played for a short time, yet I seriously feel I've seen every potentially exciting thing this game has to offer, and I've already seen the unexciting things enough to make me not want to play another run. The game has decent fps mechanics, but that's all it really has going for it. Its a sorry excuse for a rogue like, never mind a full fps. Unless you absolutely adore the play pattern created here, you probably won't get more than an hour or 2 out of this. Oh, and those people saying this game is better than BL3 are either off their rocker insane, or bought and paid for.
Edit: I had comments enabled on this, because I was willing to discuss my opinions, given the positive nature of most of the review scores. I  was instead greeted with trolls who attacked me personally over this review. To answer some of their points. No, I did not give up on the game because the boss was hard, I adore hard games. And yes, it is reasonable for me to point out a lack of content in an early access game, because they are still charging money for it. If you want to see a rogue-like in early access done correctly, go look at Hades by SuperGiant games. It is twice the price, but it has a far greater amount of diverse content available within it. I'm sure the dev's are doing everything they can to make this game good, but it currently is not in a state that I in any way would recommend paying money for it.
developer_response: Thanks for your interest, we will add more content and optimize the gameplay in the future update, stay tuned.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This is a pretty good roguelike fps. The game, as it currently stands, is a roguelike though three levels, with each level having 4 sections and a bossfight. The way player gets better in each game that they play is by acquiring "occult scrolls", "ascensions", and new guns in a run, similar to other roguelikes. Ho

[b]Good stuff:[/b]

The shooting: The shooting in the game is very approachable and understandable, without a too much upfront complexity, which stands in contrast to games like counter-strike, where the shooting has a pretty high amount of upfront complexity.

The levels: The levels are well-designed, and fun to run around and shoot in.

The aesthetic: A roguelike with an east asian aesthetic is a refreshing change of pace, the enemies and levels work well together in their design, and the design of the player's characters is pretty appealing.

The movement: The movement feels great, it's very responsive and understandable. It's very much on the floaty side, but that feels appropriate for the game and the playstyle that the game encourages.

The gun design: The design of the guns in this game is for the most part, very good. The knives look very cool, and the animal guns are very interesting. Even many of the "normal" guns have interesting flair to them which makes them satisfying to look at.

[b]Meh stuff:[/b]

The graphics: The graphics are servicable, but nothing really unique or special. Honestly, I think it works to the benefit of the game though, since the simple and uncomplicated graphics mean that this game very easily runs at high framerates, even on weaker machines.

The sound design: The sounds in this game are nothing special. If the volume is turned down while playing, the experience really isn't lessened too much. This is both good and bad. It's good because it's very easy to watch something else while playing this game. It's bad because it means that this game isn't really all that fun to listen to.

[b]Probably should be changed stuff:[/b]

1. Progression: The progression in this game is very slow, and feels very intentionally stunted. There are only two characters that can be played, and the second one can only be unlocked after what is almost always several hours of gameplay. The in-game progression system also takes a very long time to fill out, and goes very slowly.

2. The lack of content: There is really only one thing that can be done in this game, and it's very short, and very repetitive. There are 3 levels in total, and there are 4 sections and a boss fight in each level. These levels are almost always the same, and only have minor variations from run to run. There are also only two characters that can be played, even though there can be up to 4 people in a run.

3. The lack of player agency: The in-game mechanics heavily restrict the player's choices in how the play the runs. The power ups are randomized and the player has little to no choice in , removing the ability for the player to have a lot of choice in how the experience of the game plays.


[b]Recommendations for the stuff to change:[/b]

1: The multi-occult scroll chests need to become the norm, and not the extras. Switching the positions of the multi-occult scroll chests and the single occult scroll chests will allow players to have far more agency in how they create styles during the runs, and I think is likely a very easy way to do so. To maintain the balancing, make the multi-occult scroll chests have a slightly worse drop rate for the higher ranked scrolls, and make the single-scroll chests have a slightly higher drop rate for higher ranked scrolls.

2: Add either 1 or 2 more choices to the ascension chests at the end of each section. Having only three choices really limits the number of ways the player has to build a character, and makes a fully-realized build far less accessible.

3. Get rid of the restriction on carrying over soul essence from run to run. Honestly it's a stupid design decision, and the only way I can think of it making any sense is if the soul essence is planned to become an in-game currency that real money can be spent on. Even so, the restriction on carrying it over from run to run is still stupid, even in the context of it being something that can be paid for, and adds quite literally no value to the player playing the game. Smack whichever manager or game designer thought of the restriction, and remove it from the game.

4. Add more levels to both the standard adventure, and more gamemodes that can be played. I'm sure this is already in progress, but it still needs to be said. Honestly, a combined shooter-platformer mode I think would be a great addition to this, and I think that the beginnings of that idea are present in some of the vault levels. 

Extra recommendations:

1. This one might be hard, and really isn't that necessary, but make the coloring and design of the guns more dynamic or varied. The design of the guns is very good, but perhaps make the coloring or effects of them respond to inscriptions that they have, or perhaps make them have a few predetermined combinations of colors that can be randomly selected from upon generation. I said earlier that I like the design of the guns, and I stand by that. However, I think that they can be better.

2. There should also be multiplayer lobbies. I'm sure that this is also already in development, but being able to play with random other people, instead of just people who are on the steam friends list would be a great addition to this game.

3. Add some character customization options. I think that for multiplayer especially, having some character customization could really help, and also make the characters being played become much more interesting.

If the developers are reading this, I do hope that the recommendations reach the people who can do something about it. I do very much enjoy this game, and I hope to see it improve and become a fully-fleshed out version of itself, rather than what it is currently.

Neat game so far.
I was recommended to try this game because someone mentioned that "it feels like what Borderlands should be", but that's not really an accurate way to explain the game.
It's a Roguelite FPS that's definitely flavored like Borderlands, thanks to the art, character skills and the elemental system, but it's definitely a lot more "Roguelite FPS" than "Borderlands".

Anyway, the game is definitely unfinished, but very playable. I wish there were more characters to pick from than the cat guy and the dog guy, but eh. I hope in the future, they give us two characters to start the game with and have at least four after all unlocks; seems pretty goofy to have a four-player game with only two characters and have the second character only get unlocked after about 8 hours of gameplay.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Worth the early access price.

Gunfire Reborn a first-person rogue shooter. While the game has plenty or work left before it's done, the core game play is solid. You travel through stages with progressively more difficult enemies. After you inevitably die, you upgrade skills with points you earn while playing, making the character more powerful and able to go further on the next run. 

It will take a while before you can beat the first boss. Don't be discouraged, you have to level up a bit but eventually you won't have too much trouble. At first I thought the progression was too slow, but after playing for a while I think it's actually pretty good.

Gun-play is excellent and fairly will balanced. Weapons look good and feel good to use. More weapons are unlocked as you play at a satisfying rate and the variety is really cool. Weapons can have enhancements that increase their damage potential or cause other effects.

There isn't much to dislike other than it's not finished. I'd like more level design variety, better mechanics for jumping and climbing on objects, and the ability to crouch. Otherwise everything is solid and I can't wait to see this game develop further.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
The best FPS roguelite out right now, even in early access. Has a ton of different guns and upgrades you can pick up which have legitimately different playstyles, and which can be combined into some really crazy runs. The shooting mechanics and movement are great as well -- it's definitely faster-paced, though enemies aren't that mobile. The enemy/biome variety could be a bit better --early on if you're dying a lot you might find yourself seeing the first level's enemies quite a bit. There are also only two characters so far. That said, the sheet variety of guns/upgrades really makes up for it, and I think it's definitely worth playing. I'm excited to see it get even better through early access.

PS - On top of all that, it has coop for up to four players, which makes it even better.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Post-Edit: I just beat the game at its highest difficulty- This game is easily worth the price tag.
TL;DR: I've had a 10/10 experience so far, and it's at a more than fair price-point to boot.
I'm a sucker for a good Roguelike, and when I was only 2 hours in, I could already tell it was a good one.
Pros:
- Charming
- Nostalgic references from other popular games (Counter-Strike, Borderlands, Destiny, etc.)
- Plenty of guns and passive skills (Occult Scrolls) that are all diverse- None of them seem completely inferior so far. A lot of it depends on the 'Inscriptions' (rolls) you get on the weapons.
- Very small file size (2.18 GB on disk)
--- Not graphically intensive, so you should be able to run it at high FPS with no issue whatsoever.
   ----- While it is a low-polygon style, it's quite charming.
- I don't feel like any of my deaths were because of some BS, all of them were my mistakes.
- You can drop your 'Occult Scrolls' (Passives) you collect throughout a run if you need to- Great idea. (Except curses ofc)
- You can get some pretty awesome and powerful combinations of rolls on weapons and passives
  --- Weapons can even get completely unique rolls to those weapons: One was a pistol that you can throw and it detonates, (Like a Tediore weapon in Borderlands,) and the more rounds it has in its magazine, the more times it detonates.
  --- Even if you get bad RNG, you can still work your way through content fine, just not as quickly.
- This game seems to have pretty solid online connectivity too- I was able to play with one of my friends that has bad internet, even during times that he normally can't play most other games.
   --- Playing this game together with others makes it feel so much better- Both in that the scaling actually starts to feel like it's where it needs to be, and that you can trade stuff around.
--------------------
Cons:
- There are some grammatical/spelling errors in the English translation
- At this time, the game can be very tedious as you do runs through the same three areas over and over... This will most likely be resolved in the future, seeing as this game is still pretty early into its life cycle.
--------------------
I went over some of the highest up-voted negative reviews, and I'm going to give my own feedback on some of their statements here in an attempt to make this review a more complete perspective into the game.

--- "Movement speed is too slow, especially when using heavy weapons"
For how large the levels are, and the scale of everything considered, the movement speed does feel SLIGHTLY too slow, but not so much as to be a 'Con' of the game.
Also, they're 'heavy' weapons for a reason. You're more than free to switch to your Foundry (Starting pistol) at any given time to have your higher move speed moving around outside of combat. Otherwise, it's just a factor to have to consider when in combat.

--- "Precision platforming feels awful"
There are some Parkour/Kreedz (For you CS players out there) bonus levels in the game, however this game has a complete lack of self-momentum on movement. I understand how that can make platforming difficult or frustrating, but again, I wouldn't say this is a 'Con' of the game. You can change directions mid-air and move at full speed in a different direction if you like, and you can also dodge in mid-air.

--- "Enemies with tracking weapons are too powerful"
Nearly every enemy in the game that has a tracking weapon can be dodged simply by running perpendicular to them. Otherwise, the game even tells you itself in a load screen tip- If you don't have a tanky build, then cover is your next best option.

--- "The difficulty curve is too sharp"
Someone said the only viable strategy at times was to cower behind a rock and pick shots at enemies... That's not true at all. Perhaps if you get bad luck and you're lacking sustain options, sure... But if you have a strong build, you can rain hell on anything that dares to even so much as look at you funny.

--- "The upgrade system feels like artificial padding"
While I admit the game lacks a lot of content to try and be standing on its own two feet, the upgrades are simply there to help you along as you play the game more. This is definitely supposed to be a game that you play for the sake of playing, not to be a completionist.
Another review said this game is 'Grind To Win'... Again, it's really not. The upgrades are there to compliment the game, not being necessary to get far.
First time I ever beat this game on the hard difficulty, I wasn't even half of the max level.

--- "A recent update severely nerfs and punishes solo players"
What??? I think this game is too easy solo! I feel like the scaling with 4 players is the way the game is meant to be played.

--- "Dashes take you a pitiful distance meaning you often can't do anything meaningful about your situation."
They may take you a short distance, but they do it rather quickly. That, and dashes do actually have a short amount of i-frames in them. You can see this to great effect if you make it to the first boss, and try to use your dodges to physically avoid attacks, and to i-frame through attacks.

--- "Obvious skill-grenade combo doesn't work because there's an unnecessary delay after skill use."
The two currently existing characters actually have different grenade-throwing delays on them. I feel like this is an intentional balancing factor, not an arbitrary design decision.

--- "Jump height is low enough to make attempts to climb to high ground annoying."
If you jump while running into a ledge, you'll actually more or less 'step' up the ledge, removing any extra dead time in the air there would have been. Any situation in which you might have tried to jump repeatedly to get to high ground probably wasn't intended to be used as such in the first place.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: I am new to roguelike games, but have always been a fan of looter-shooters, such as the classic Borderlands. When I arrived to the first boss in this game, I got destroyed, and figured this genre was going to take some getting used to. However, the skill tree helped me quickly gain the extra damage and shield I needed, along with some other useful perks. The vaults are fun, I only needed to look up one parkour puzzle, which feels rewarding when finished. The occult scrolls pair well together, such as making yourself 1 HP with one, and then gaining DMG based on % missing health from another. This makes for some extremely fun builds, which get even better from the golden goblets. I personally play Ao Bai, the dog character, but the cat is fun and always useful to have on a team. I normally play with friends, but I have absolutely no problem playing this game solo, it truly doesn't get old. For the price point, this is easily the most entertaining game I have played in years. At 55 hours in the game, I have everything unlocked besides 2 guns and 6 Steam achievements, which only covers the current content. Can't wait to see what's ahead. (First Steam review, I apologize for the lengthy paragraph.)

review:
This is a great Borderlands style game! Easily worth at least $20! I am definitely interested to see where the development of this game goes! If you put just a little more time into creating content for the game, this could easily be a $40 game in no time!

I definitely wish there was a way to make certain types of guns drop more consistently though. Like maybe add perks that add the probability of dropping "heavy" weapons (i.e. gatling gun, rocket launcher, etc.), There is the possibility that if you also add more characters, they could have passive perks that make certain types of guns drop more frequently. 

Most of what this game needs is to add small things that add consistency to the gameplay. There's too many elements of randomness which takes away from making the player feel like they are a part of the world. You could allow the player to start each run with a guarenteed gun of their choice with no perks instead of a guarenteed random gun.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
EDIT: I have since switched the review from negative to positive, however my point still stands. As game is still in early access, hopefully more content will be added in the game. Regardless of that, the core idea of the game is fun.
//
Disclaimer: I'm only posting this as incentive for developers to improve upon the game, and will change the review accordingly as base premise of the game is promising.

The reason why I'm giving a negative review at this point of time is due to little to no incentive to repeat runs apart from farming talent points.

Hear me out - when I think of rouge-like games like Binding of Isaac (where i have 200+ hours), I'm thinking of completely different runs on every replay. I WANT to go for another run because there are lots of power-ups and they change the game dramatically. In some runs you're extremely underpowered, in some you're overpowered, mechanics of your character change etc.

In Gunfire Reborn each run feels EXTREMELY similar as last one. Yes, gunplay is fun however I don't see this game as 'roguelike' because weapon drops, power ups, skills change little of how game is played.

So basically if devs find more ways to diversify gameplay experience and add much more skills/guns/mechanics on how you can go through the game, I can easily see losing myself in the game.
At the moment, however, I'm stuck rerunning same exact stuff with little to no incentive on replaying runs apart from grinding talents.
developer_response: Thanks for your interest, we will add more content and optimize the gameplay in the future update, stay tuned.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
A very fun roguelite shooter in early access.
The graphics are cartoony-ish and have a certain charm to them. 
The gunplay is very satisfying and feels a lot like managing different affixes and modifiers like Dead cells mixed with Borderlands and Doom. 

As of this review the only endgame is to reach max rank of 118 in the skill tree progression that carries over between runs and trying to get a godly run on elite mode. 
The gameplay loop does feel satisfying at first but once you hit max level it just becomes a little bit less brain intensive. I didn't feel there were many times where my skill in an FPS would have allowed me to edge out a bad RNG run.

Devs have been listening and adding new weapons but as of right now the game needs more variety to keep the loop feeling fresh.

title: Gunfire Reborn

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
It is a very fun game that will probably play well on any PC or laptop built in the last 5 years.

Hopefully more people pick it up and the devs keep giving it the love it deserves. It is very difficult, skill based, and I was surprised how effective the co-op is. I would get burned out in a day playing solo. 

The builds are fun and definitely roguelite. 

Wants: More resolution options, host pass-through when the host leaves a game so the run won't end, more characters and a bigger skill tree [these are coming, I'm sure], and character customization. A crouch option could be nice too and would really open up a new strategy of ducking and covering, as most of the low obstacles are just short enough for you to still get hit. 

For $12 clams, it is a steal and probably one of the best FPS co-op shooters I've played in years. It takes the best parts of Borderlands, and borrows a lot of concepts into something really special and original.

And it even runs on Intel integrated graphics with acceptable smooth 60+ fps with low graphics and 720p resolution.

Can't wait for new content. Keep up the good work.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Super fun game! I love it so much. I've dumped 20 hours into it in the first week of playing.
I think that the first couple hours of play may be the most difficult. But once you've unlocked a few items and learned how to deal with some of the enemies, the game clicks and opens up a lot. The more you level up the more interesting the game becomes. Since you unlock new scrolls (abilities) and weapons by leveling and doing challenges, the more you play, the more dynamic the game becomes! This also gives you the time to learn about the scrolls/weapons as you unlock and discover them. Which is great because that means you aren't overloaded with a ton of information at the start. These are just guesses are far as numbers, but there are probably: 100+ different scrolls, 40+ weapons, 30+ character power-ups and 30 persistent character abilities (which are permanent and chosen as you level up). So the fun being how those all work together on different runs. Some runs you get really amazing scrolls that work well with your current weapon. Other times you may not find scrolls you are used to, but the scrolls you do find have you play in a different ways in order to take advantage of their design and fusions together. Endless combinations! and when you have a good run with scrolls and weapons that work well together you can absolutely SLAY and it feels f***ing great!!! I love this game. Buy it and play with a friend or two. It'll be a good time I promise.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Really good, especially for early access; the player characters are really charming, the bosses are cool and different from each other, and the attention to detail, for example on the weapon animations of Fire Dragon and Lizard, is really a testament to the game's potential.  It's also pretty difficult, at least for me, having experience with rogue-likes but not much experience with FPSs; still, with the amount of explosive weapons, for example, there is plenty for a non-experienced player to enjoy and practice with.  

My only complaint is that some of the locations are a little empty, and there are some parts where you're walking around or waiting for enemies to show up, but that also depends on the playthrough as the paths are randomized; the empty hallways and dead-ends is a nice aesthetic touch, that you're visiting the same locales but carving different paths through them each run, but it also doesn't really mesh with the action aspects of the game.  And while the aesthetics are amazing, the music and sound effects are lack-luster.  Plus it could use some translation issues; most of it is passable and charming, but some weapon or upgrade descriptions are vague and easily misunderstood with the rough translation and formatting. 

Other than that, fantastic :)

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I have put in quite a surprising amount of time on this game considering it is considered an Early Access, and surprisingly have only a couple things to pick at. Overall, this game is smooth, fast paced, action filled, and combines strategy with run and gun pretty dang well. If you just start up it does take a bit to finally be able to pass the first boss, but it comes with playing. It only takes 1-2 runs before you know most the enemies and get to the boss reliably. Now, all i have to say negatively about this game is that 
1. There is currently no form of melee in the game either in weapons, or a default punch attack for people that get to close when you run out of ammo
2. The bosses scale WAY too much from playing solo to with a group. The first boss sits at 80k health at single player, but add just one more person they scale 3x health up to 240k. That to me is a bit excessive. I like to play with just me and my friend or my wife, but i feel like we never scale up to match that multiplier. We can barely get past it unless we get a completely broken set up.
Overall: This game is very fun, very action packed, and very entertaining. The few complaints i had are completely bearable, just things i hope will change sometime in the near future. If you love non stop shooting, running, and looting, mixed with having to be smart/strategic. DEFINITELY give this game a shot!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I bought this game after eyeing it for a while and watching the reviews, it seemed like something right up my alley.  A roguelite, FPS, lootfinder with RPG elements.  Tons of guns, sounds cool, right?  

It's VERY EARLY ACCESS.  

I'm going to keep playing it but I cannot recommend it for what it currently is.  This game needs a ton of work still.  

[b]The good[/b]

- Permanent Hero skill tree
- Interesting guns
- Two characters (better than one I guess)
- Good gun hit indicators.  It has a slight arcade like feel to it which is nice.  
- A lot of replay value I guess.

[b]The Not so good[/b]

- The lack of guns.  In the first area you'll have maybe 10 different guns, I think it's less than that until you unlock them.  You'll get used to them very fast and you'll probably be getting bored of them with how often you have to run through the first level.

- The first boss is atrociously over powered for single players.  [spoiler]It has 80k hp and your guns at first do ~100-200 dmg on hit.  Oh and all of his abilities one-shot you.  Also he regens his shield which takes about 30 or so rounds to deplete a few seconds after it depletes.  Unless you get an ability to augment your dash, I think it's either impossible to solo him at first or may as well be.  Your dash has a 3s cd and sometimes the boss will use more than 1 ability in that window.  [/spoiler]

- The upgrades on death are really lackluster and you don't really feel too much stronger. +5max shield, wooo the boss STILL ONE SHOTS ME SO WHAT'S THE POINT.  

- EVERYTHING is randomized.  Okay so at the end of every round you open a chest that has an elemental skill upgrade with 3 choices in it.  Let's say you're on round 2/5 and you want to go poison, you have a poison weapon and you take the poison choice.  Next round, there's no poison choice.  It's now round 5/5 and you haven't gotten a better poison weapon and you haven't seen another elemental poison reward choice.  So basically you're fucked and you get to shoot the last boss in the face like 2500 times and hope you don't mess up once or you're dead.  

I have yet to play with friends.  Maybe it's better.  

I want to like this game but I just don't and it [b]ABSOLUTELY DOES NOT DESERVE 95% APPROVAL[/b].  Far too low of standards.  It's around a 6.7/10.  7/10 just feels too generous.
developer_response: Death reset is one of the features of rogue games. Our talent system is working hard to keep the game results for players. We will release more new content in subsequent versions. Thank you for your feedback. Please stay tuned!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: the devs care VERY much about this game :) so i am changing my review. the only complaint i have with this game, is the death system. i dont think you should be at a huge disadvantage missing out on everything (scrolls, goblets) when you die. on top of missing out on all the upgrades that balance you out with the increasing enemies, the timer for dying also doesnt slow down even after being completely dead. that seems like a bit of an exponential decay type of thing to die, lose out on upgrades, then die faster each time. otherwise fantastic game, cared for heavily by developers, solid price, replay-ability very nice, and guns actually feel unique form one another.
developer_response: Thanks for your feedback. We are constantly working on game balance to make sure every weapon, scroll can be useful in different circumstance. For the BOSS, we will suggest you to read some tips from other players in our Reddit, Discord or Steam forum. BTW, for the first BOSS LuWu, using weapons with lightning damage will be very effective against the shield. You can also hind behind the pillars to avoid some waves of attacks.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: A good dungeon crawler with aspects f both leveling up and rng based gameplay. Yes some areas may appear similar over and over again but each run is not like the last. You may get the best set-up imagineable and still mess up, or have the worst luck but have the best run in your life. From guns you may find, to the scrolls you earn from challenges. The progression is smooth. And Leveling up doesn't feel forced or needed, its implemented pretty well. With each room you clear from either that crazy headshot, or that crazy grenade bounce. You will be left satisfied and even when you lose from something "dumb" or "BS", you have the constant feeling of wanting to go for another run. And as of making this review the game is still in early access, can't wait to see where the game goes from here.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
If you respect your free time, stay away from this game. 
It will consume every living second of your life. You'll start a game, thinking that it only last 20 minutes and then suddenly you have been playing for more than an hour, and you don't want to stop.

The only issue with this game is the lack of dedicated servers and poor optimization of peer to peer connection. Some games with friends can be perfect and others won't last past the first part.

Overall, great game as singleplayer or with friends. Looking forward to the full release.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
TLDR: Love this game it's a steal for the price.

Pros: Runs great, consistent high frame rates on my PC easily hitting 144 frames with an i5 and GTX 1080. Gunplay and weapon variety is excellent. High skill while still having the random nature of roguelite games. Lot's of replay value with tons of unlocks to chase if the core gameplay loop appeals to you. Enemy variety is great in my opinion with lots of different types of choreographed attack patterns and weaknesses to learn and master. The designs of weapons are a joy to play with many standouts and few ones which are not useful. Art design and aesthetic may not appeal to everyone but I think it's quite a gorgeous game personally though the better looking stuff is in the later levels. Co-op is awesome fun as usual.

Cons: Not a ton of content as far as having tons of levels and only 2 characters, however, for the price this makes sense + its early access so more to come. Peer to Peer connections for matchmaking can be unreliable and sometimes downright unplayable with lag. This lag problem has been steadily improving and the devs have said they are aware. It used to often be unplayable for me but now I rarely get lag, still worth noting though (This of course isn't an issue if you like playing solo). If you don't like getting screwed over by random chance bad drops this might not be for you but it's the nature of roguelites so not really a true Con just worth noting.
