title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
The game balance is really rough, hitboxes are just awful they really really are. Many abilities have a far wider hitbox than there particle effect does, resulting in you hitting pillars, walls, etc. when you are clearly aiming to the side of it at an enemy in full view. a lot of enemy projectiles track which can lead to some basically unavoidable deaths depending on the level and the amount that get spawned. Random stuttering throughout the levels which is a disaster for game like this, where one mistake can get you killed. 

Character ripoffs of other games i.e Bao looking near identical to Chen Stormstout with a white wig on. 
Really bad english Translations, most sentences in the game look like they were written by an eight year old.

Honestly a lot of SFX seem like they may have been ripped from Paladins as well now that I think about it.
Just way too many issues and weird things going on here for me to enjoy the game at all.
developer_response: Thanks for your feedback. We have made some optimization over hitboxes in previous update. Also for the English text, many players have helped us improve some sentences, words, etc. We will continue the optimization including bug fixes, game balance and text polish in the future update.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: As of writing this, the game is great at it's core.  I would definitely recommend it for the $12 price point it is at now, but it really has room to grow, there are only 2 options of 'class' character to choose from, and only 3 unique stages, which you play on repeat.  By contrast there are a dizzying number of weapons and scrolls.  Would be great if they would calm down with the weapon additions, and work on new environments and characters.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
A really great start with a ton of potential. Lacks in story, but that's not why we play roguelites now is it? Lots of guns and build-enhancing scrolls. Great progression system. Controls are tight, shooting feels really good.

A few pieces of constructive criticism for the devs:
-Movement can feel sluggish at times. Especially in the first boss encounter.
-Only 2 characters, one of which is locked until you reach talent level 30. I know we are in early access here, but some character and skill variation would be great after 100 runs.

Otherwise, really strong take on the genre.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Wow - having a lot of fun with Gunfire Reborn. 

First up, the games name is appropriate. This is a First Person Shooter with Rogue like/RPG'ish and randomisation elements combined into an enjoyable, yet challenging game with a fresh take on the FPS genre.

The game design is not complicated but it still rewards strategy with pairing skills with weapons or play styles but you never feel like you need to get out a spreadsheet to min/max. Not that kind of game and it's so refreshing because of this.

Also do not expect to be micro managing tonnes of loot every gunfight stressing over which items to hold to carry back to town etc. Again, not that kind of game but you still get choice and randomisation every play through.

The designers have done a great job in making an accessible, easy to get into yet challenging and fun game with out being overly complex or bogging the player down in menus, item management etc.

Graphics, sound, frame rate are all excellent and the glowing reviews are justified. Playing on a 4770k 16 GB 2400mhz Ram and a 2080 RTX Ti 1440p 120 FPS without a frame drop.

One other thing I'd like to mention also is not to let the cartoon style graphics make you think this is another cheaply made and hurriedly pushed out title like so many games that seem to flood the steam marketplace and provide very little entertainment. 

Effort, planning and a lot of play testing has clearly been invested in this game and it honestly plays like a fully developed title.

Seriously, this game is probably the best value game on steam (considering it's quality design,fun and replayability). Usually games go up in price when they come out of Early Access so if you are sitting on the fence my recommendation is snap this up now and enjoy.

Two thumbs up and my respect to the game developers for their excellent efforts.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
It's a great game, for what ever price you should buy it. I bought it for 10‚Ç¨ and it was money well spend. There are a bunch of builds to do in the game but it matters what you like the most. Some people say it reminds them of Borderlands and in way maybe but it definitely is a special game for itself. It was a challenge to learn all the bosses and complete all of the achievements.
Now, when it comes to builds and other things I believe the game has still a lot to work on, there are scrolls that give you a chance to revive after dying and if you have 2 different ones you'd lose both. So in that sense I believe they can still work and tweak the little things. And I'm 100% there are gonna be more stages, bosses, mobs, weapons and scrolls in the game as time goes on! Definitely worth to support the developers and what they do! Have fun playing, you won't regret it.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
It's fun.
You get to the first boss.
You realize that you can't dodge as fast as he attacks.
You die.
Rinse and repeat until you get lucky and win.
It's in Early Access.  It's important to remember that.
This fight absolutely feels like it's an Early Access fight.
A fun game, but also a game that makes you feel like it's a waste of time after this happens for the fifth or sixth time in a day.
Use the pillars, and as long as he doesn't walk through/jump through the pillars, they can take a couple hits.
Outside of this, all I can say is learn to enjoy the first levels pre-boss.  You'll spend enough time there that if you don't fall in love with this game, it's all you'll see.

TL;DR
Fun, but the first boss makes is almost too miserable to recommend.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Such a great game. Very well done. Doesn't feel like Early Access game at all.

Very similar to how Battleborn looked and felt gameplay wise.

Many interesting guns (It has better variety than Borderlands 3).
2 playable characters (3rd is just around the corner).
You can finish a run in 30-60 minutes.
Lots of cool skills and scrolls to make the whole run different each time.

The gameplay is very fluent, fast paced. 

Multiplayer is a bit wonky. Can be a bit frustrating to play with higher ping. 
Solo play is flawless.

I haven't had THIS much fun in ages. For its price it's a steal!

review:
For the current price, this game is totally worth it.  If you're like me you hesitate to buy early access games because you're worried about the game halting development, but even if this game stopped development it would still be worth the current price; it'd be worth a fair bit more and I say this as someone who never buys games at full price!

It's very fun, the gunplay is solid and the gameplay is fairly well balanced.  It could be considered a bit on the easy side admittedly, but for those like me who aren't very good at FPS you can still beat it solo; but of course to me the real draw is playing with friends!

I actually bought this game for a friend because I wanted more friends to play it with.  Also to be clear: yes I am a furry, and yes I was drawn in by the presence of anthropomorphic characters, but this does not affect my judgment on the game itself.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This was a MEGA sleeper hit.  I was recommended this game by a friend as it fit *some* of the things I enjoy - the RNG gunplay of Borderlands, the movement of Destiny, and it has multiplayer without the horrifying plague of PvP.  It fit some of this, but not all of it. It was not trying to be a clone and it wasn't a dead copy.  "Sure, I thought. Lets give it a try!"

I am so glad I did.

I gave it a try.  At first, I died... a lot.  Then I leveled up, and I died less and less.  Then I got good at the game, and I hardly die at all.

All night marathon sessions with friends, clutch revivals in the heat of battle, and a progression and reward system that make me feel like the time and efforts I put into the game are valid and fun.  My friends and I have been rampaging around this game for many hours both solo and as a group and its so far been worth every hour.

I've even gone so far as to get this game as a gift for friends that are saving every penny owing to COVID-19.  Seriously, its stupid amounts of fun for (at time of writing) about $12.

The studio making this are not English as First Language, so expect some typos and expect some translation errors, but the core concept is solid.  Also, most every item does exactly what it says it does, and there is no odd formulas about weapon damage.  If it says "adds damage" that is exactly what it does.

Overall, for $12 you get an insane deal.  This was (at time of writing, 44 hours in!) a smash sleeper hit and I love it for a simple, easy, FUN game I can run with my buddies and put down again for more serious games as needed.  Seriously, we've done pick up group runs while we wait on friends and team mates to get home or sign on after getting their kids to bed.

Get this, and give it a try. :)

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Incredibly fun and a great way to kill some time. 

This game is extremely satisfying to play as you progress. Its gunplay gives a vibe similar to Borderlands, with semi-randomly generated areas. No run goes the same as the last, and it's fun to build off the hand the game deals you. It becomes more fun as you learn what builds to aim for, and you learn how to combat various tricky enemies. 

However, you can certainly tell that it's got some work to do. Currently, the three levels you progress through do not "loop" like you'd expect, and it simply ends there, and elite mode is easier than it sounds. There are also only two characters right now. Despite this, it's well optimized, it has plenty of guns and upgrades, and there's a nice variety of enemies to fight. It's worth more than its price and I can't wait to see what they'll add to the game next.

Also, the bosses at the end of each area actually FEEL like bosses. They're not overly complicated but are also very punishing foes. I'd say rather than reading a guide for them, experience them yourselves and learn their moves. It's really fun to die once or twice to it then annihilate it the next run once you've figured out their workings.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Don't be put off by the early access, this is a solid game already and ENORMOUS fun with friends or solo. It seems very hard in places and you will die a lot, but with the right upgrades and weapons you will progress more each time you play. And the levels/vaults are random enough to make every playthrough a unique experience.

The price is a steal for how much fun you'll have! Highly recommended A+

review: Its like Borderlands mixed with your favorite Rouge-Like. Great price and regular content updates, mixed with good game play and very few bugs makes it a 10/10 for me. Instead of wasting your money on a bullshit skin or loot box I would highly recommend purchasing this amazing game and giving the Devs the support they deserve! You will sink a ton of hours here with your friends or by your self. The replay value is insane and it is very addictive when you start sinking skill points into your character and start to become more and more overpowered. But you will still face challenges, as you play with more of your friends the game becomes very difficult or if you are solo you can try the Elite Mode once you successfully kill the final boss for better loot and increased difficulty. Overall it is one of my favorite games to come out this year!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is essentially "if Borderlands were a rogue-lite" and it works like a charm.  It doesn't seem like much while watching it, but the gunplay is a ton of fun, and there are some interesting interactions to be found between the random weapon traits and passive upgrades that you acquire in a run.  There are also purchasable upgrades that improve your characters across runs, which offer noticeable progression.  You will feel the power you gain from slowly purchasing these upgrades.  

This game can only continue to get better as more enemies, rooms, weapons, and passive abilities are introduced.  I highly recommend picking it up while it's only $12.  It's worth the price by far imo.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Great little game, very reasonable price-tag. 

Regular updates and communication, plays well in co-op (handled latency very well, even up to 300ms).

Lots of progressive unlocks and solid replayability if you don't mind playing through similar levels/enemy types (variety comes from each run's weapons, scrolls and upgrades being different) and they're still adding more.

My only gripe is the boulder traps timing, there's not always a window where you won't get hit on the 3rd room (mostly if you opt for the optional chest).

Would definitely recommend.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Picked this game up due to the recommendation of a youtuber, thought to myself "eh looks ok, will prob return it after an hour..." then i was 3 hours deep in, dying over and over just trying to kill the first boss. I'm hooked. Finally beat the first boss, come to a new area, get killed immediately by a new enemy. Respawn, die, repeat. Beat the second stage and boss. Get to final boss, not even close to standing a chance. Learn the attack patterns, learn weak points and moments to attack. Beat the final boss. Finally after all that time and effort i beat the game and think to myself "that was fun, little sad that its over"
Then the game tells me "Elite mode unlocked"

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Absolutely fantastic roguelike. Multiplayer is quite solid.

Are you tired of games where enemy health scales faster than your weapon damage and their health bars turn into progress bars?

This game lets you blow through that with a well-planned synergy of weapon inscriptions, character ascendancies and a passive tree that allows you to wallow in the awesome might of a completely broken build by end-game!

This game has entered the sacred hall of my frequently-played games. I'm also happy to see that they've been keeping a weekly schedule of updates so the game remains fresh. Worth it.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: I really like this game.  It has the feel of Risk of Rain, but plays like Borderlands. The gun play is fun, and learning to stack the right scrolls together is quite rewarding. The initial grind can be daunting, but after the first few levels, the game opens up a great deal. I hope to see more biomes in the future. It'll be interesting to see how the game evolves.

review:
Its not fun.

same map every time with maybe 1 or 2 rooms changed

same guns that are boring with little to no valuble change between them

same two characters that play nearly the same

same bosses, enemies, spawn points.

A runs viability is entirely on the scrolls you find so by the end of the first map you know if you will win

leveling is the sole thing that can really be counted as progression as it makes your runs easier but not a guaranteed victory, they basically allow you to ram your way through the first area. 

merchants are blatantly overpowered as you can buy health ammo, grenades and weapon level ups.

overall not bad but just bland and unappealing after a while.
developer_response: Sorry for your boring experience, we will add more content and randomness in the future update, stay tuned.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
one of if not THE best game I've ever played.
This game might be too easy for those of you who are hardcore in to shooting games like csgo/valorant etc.
But for more casual gamers this game is extremely fun.
You've got lots of diffferent ways of beating the game. 
likely ull find urself  choosing whether u want hp or shield build when it comes to defence, or maybe even a hybrid of both.
on offence theres so many choices. do u want to be a sniper. do u want to take advantage of the no reload scroll for a big explosion gun that normally has to reload after each shot fired. or do u want to do spread aoe elemental effects, 2 at a time as well with shared damage type gemini.
do u have no dash related scrolls and find the no dash but fast move speed scroll. or do u have lots of scrolls that benefit based on ur dash usage as well as other scrolls that give u more dashes and half the cd on ur dash.
u find a gun that benefits from lucky shot, but weakens ur shots if they're not lucky shots? then u also got lots of scrolls that give u lucky shot chance. to get a bit of a lucky shot build going.

thers lots of choices to be made constantly. 
Scrolls can be dropped and traded amongst team mates, allowing for ur team to work together to achieve powerful builds. 
Also this is a rogue-lite game. meaning every time u die u spend soul essence that u've gathered. u spend it on upgrades in a sort of post game skill tree shop type thing. I really like this system as it makes me want to go back out there every time after a run has ended to try again with the new stuff i just bought.

For anyone considering buying this. Please do, this is not one of those shitty early access fails, this is a full game with a lot of content and a LOT of fun replayability. 
Look for people to play with on gunfire reborn discord if u are ever struggling to find people.
If you in aus just hit me up.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
the combat is fun so the game will be entertaining for a few dozen hours but it's definitely way too much RNG reliant, even for a rogue like. can be especially frustrating because of the wide array of weapons, of which half are outright bad weapons and the fact that it's likely you'll enjoy playing only a few of the weapons, and so you'll only get a decent weapon you like to play once every 4 or 5 runs. i won't even speak of having a good weapon you like and good talents / scrolls, never happened to me in 22 hours ( although non afk time must be something like 17 or 18 hours. )
i wish the roguelite elements were more like risk of rain 2.

though the guns are well designed ( you won't like all of them but everyone will like different weapons and they're all well designed ), the feeling is good when shooting the guns, nice variety of enemies ( which are also well designed, for the most part ) and the fights can be very dynamic depending on what weapon you're playing with. 
so the combat feels great when you finally get a weapon you like with decent perks.

Also be warned the game is hard, you'll get yourself one shot out of nowhere and that's normal, you'll have to keep playing in order to develop a good feel of the game and then you won't be surprised by a rude instakill anymore. well most of the time.

Last thing, as i said the game is imo way too RNG reliant to be interesting in the long term BUT it is in early access and the devs are actively looking for feedback, so maybe they'll change that, it's not guaranteed but it's a maybe.

So in the end i'm recommending the game, even if they never "improve" the roguelite elements by making them less RNG reliant ( especially concerning weapons ), you can still get a few dozen hours out of it for 10 bucks, that's totally worth it.

edit : and here we go, they're already updating the scrolls and perks to make it less reliant on lucky perks/scrolls/weapons combos, the devs are doing a great job, I definitely recommend the game, it's already worth much more than its price and I have got the feeling it's only going to get better.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
For me its very simple: The game is cheap and extremely enjoyable. I find the replay value perfect, with each run wanting more/something different for a certain build. Even with the occasional mega-op build, where you melt bosses in 2 seconds on elite, still make you come back for more. 

Combing scrolls, skills and weapon rolls makes it interesting every time. Especially when you get lucky and manage to "break" the game with certain op combo's. Playing with friends and having a bigger loot pool (drops are per player) allows you to do more swapping and adjusting. 

I'm excited about the prospect of new stages/weapons/scroll/modes. Looking forward to the next big update!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: For the price, this game is very good. In fact, it has no business being as good as it is. It borrows from a lot of other games and combines them into a Rogue-lite experience that is not seen in other FPS's. It takes most of its inspiration from Borderlands, where the core game mechanics lie. Throw in some Dead Cells, and some level up elements, and that's this game. It's a great mix, where you know if you just get that little bit of extra HP, your next run will be the run you beat that boss.

review:
Got recommended to this game by my friend and honestly I love playing it. Both solo and especially with friends. There's so much fun to be had with the game and so few of this "roguelite genre". You honestly need to try it out and if you don't like the game within an hour then just return it. But I loved it instantly.

There's so many different weapons and playstyles in each playthrough. You might not be able to build the same all the time but that's a great thing about the game. You might build just a little different each time. Some runs you are more elemental aka fire poision or electric and other runs you might have more explosions. High ammo or fast fire rate weapons, or low mag weapons. You can even spec into stationary build aka sniper or launcher but I have to admit I haven't tried it yet. I just love running around so much. I love the mobility.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Tl;Dr
Destiny and enter the gungeon had a weird indie baby

Pros:
-Very fun yet simple shooting mechanics.
-Every run you do is randomized. Every time you play you will encounter different guns, rooms, and perks like any other rougelite.
-Every weapon comes with randomly rolled stats so no two weapons feel exactly the same.
-Game is actually challenging
-Variety of enemy types
-Game is $12...that alone was enough for me to buy it.

Cons:
-Game is still in early access. This does not take away the positives of the game because it runs smoothly, however I feel that there definatly needs to be more weapons and characters added to this game soon. (This game is 4 player co op yet there are only 2 characters at time of review.)
-The level up system can feel a bit grindy
-At the start of the game most of the enemies can very easily kill you, however its fine because you can very easily kill them. It becomes a problem when you start progressing through the floors, it adds more enemies, they all have more health bars, yet you are just about as squishy as you were when you started off.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Well worth $12. The games very addicting. Lots of guns to choose from. Inscriptions on guns make them different enough to be interesting. There's only 2 hero and I don't like 1 of them, so that's not great, but it's early access so small gripe. 

The game is quite hard until you get some practice and invest in some talent points. Even with 20 hours in I'm still having trouble with the final boss (there's 3 for now).

My biggest complaint is runs take forever (1.5 hours~ ). I'd like a mode that is very hard but short. I could just play till the first boss, but it's no longer challenging so not a great option. OR just allow us to save run so my friends and I can just hop in and out whenever we have time.

Game has a lot of potential. I really like that even though it is grindy, it doesn't feel like it at all. Just a series of tactical warzones you have to maneuver your way out of while also trying to get the best gun + synergy of ability's and scrolls (scrolls are basically unique power ups, and you can even trade them to teammates).

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
As much as I would love to give this game a positive review and a recommendation of how quite fun and quirky this game is for a roguelite FPS, this game suffers from a lot of flaws in a lot of some unbalanced issues, repetitive stages, bullet sponge enemies, and some things that ticks me off and I'm sure some players do too.

First of all, this game has quite the unique aspects to it although albeit just copying off from other big title games. It's quite fun, yes, but the longer you play the more you start to see the flaws and little itches that kinda annoys you once you start to experience them quite often.

For the positives: this game is kinda unique on its own, can be quite fun, the character models, NPCs, enemies, and level design are nicely done, and this game does deserve the hype it gets until we get to those flaws and issues I will say about this game.

The negatives: Gameplay is quite unbalanced in my opinion, you're left to just praying to RNGesus that you get the best weapons for your style of gunplay and the best scrolls that works with your gunplay/gameplay. Next the movement speed, I feel the movement speed is quite slow and the dodge is not as good or nearly nonexistent, yes you can hide behind things like pillars, stones, columns, etc., but dodging is another story and sometimes you fall flat of dodging some attacks even when you think you've cleared it. In short "The dodge range is just SHORT". Then there's the issue of enemies just being bullet sponges the further you advance into the game even when you think you got the best equipment already, then sometimes you just get thrown into a room with enemies right in front of you and suddenly you're dead (happened to me quite often when going into the next room enemies just suddenly spawns right around you all firing their weapons and BOOM! you're dead), even with upgrading your shield and health I still feel that enemies can kill you quite easily when you're not paying 100% attention to them, but even if you are paying attention to things like where enemies just suddenly spawns next to you when just coming into a room it wouldn't be your fault but the game's fault. And some of my nitpicks on this are like when sniping enemies notice you too quick even when you're far out of their range and some can still manage to shoot you and kill you so you can't snipe enemies from afar, you need to always keep moving. Some weapons can be OP and some can be so weak that you're better off just using your starting weapon. Health pickups are sometimes too sparse especially when you need one in a pinch making you left with getting one from the NPC but even then you can only buy one health recovery from them and still wouldn't be healed to 100% which makes it tough once you get to the bosses.

Overall, this can be quite the fun game, it's quite unique, the design is alright, and I'm sure it can improve once it comes out of early access, but the things this game can offer right now is just a momentary fun experience not something I personally think would be an awesome game to go back to play with over and over, but even then playing it over and over can get quite boring with the state the game is in right now. Hopefully the devs improves this and not just rely on the hype that many people gave this game when it came out.
developer_response: Thanks for your feedback, we will add more content and randomness in the future update, and keep adjusting the game difficulty and game balance. Hope you will be satisfied !

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This is the best new shooter I've played this year by a country mile. In a time when most new shooters suck hairy sweaty monkey balls through a thin straw, this little gem goes back to basics and delivers rock solid FPS action.

+ Most guns feel great to use.
+ Solid movement mechanics.
+ Great cartoony visuals.
+ Good enemy variety.
+ Runs smooth as butter.
+ Meaningfully different runs and good build variety.
+ Very cheap.
+ Bug free.
+ Very good persistent skill tree.

- Somewhat limited content, only three worlds and three big bosses but it's still in Early Access.
- Unlocks can feel a little grindy.
- Can't join coop games in middle of the run, have to team up in lobby before starting a new run.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Would I recommend this game? Yes and No. 

The shooting and weapons feel amazing, the art style is delightful, and I don't have a third thing but you get the picture. Pretty fun time especially for an Early Access title.

Where this game falls short at is the movement. You trudge along at a gentle walk and the "dash" is pitiful. For a game with perfectly appealing shooting and enemy gameplay to hop on the ubiquitous "rogue" bandwagon, I'd expect you to be like a little glass cannon vaulting about in desperate combat to get enemies before they get you. When I am pushed into a small room with 6 enemies who push and 3 enemies who are sniping, the 1 foot dash and waist-high hop does me little good.

The most infuriating part of this experience wasn't the 'git gud' aspect that a lot of souls-like games hide behind, but the fact that I had discovered so many unique weapons that felt so good to use, only to get done in because I was unable to strafe or outmanuever an enemy correctly. 

What it comes down to is just picking a spot with cover and dancing around the obstacle like a game of peek-a-boo. And it's rather boring.

There may very well be a double jump, multi-dash, sprinting, or some grappling hook feature hidden in the upgrade tree  but I can't really see myself sticking with this title that long to find out. The tiny windows of fun aren't worth the feeling of moving through mud.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game, at least in my own opinion, deserves the award of "Making someone who wanted this game to be the next Borderlands-type game instead look up how to refund". 

I had never refunded a game until I came across this gem of a game. It has everything I want in a game.

And to be honest, the dungeon levels play out exactly as I hoped - everything was going great... until the first boss.

A boss that kills you in about 5 seconds. So punishing that I had to go away and look up guides. Guides that told me that a) I had to "gitgud" b) I needed the absolute right weapons to win the fight (remove shields and use fire) c) invest more time to outpower the fight. 

I deliberated a fair bit on this, as I felt Gunfire Reborn was a great game. But the first boss is too punishing. 

So instead I looked up how to get a refund from steam and found that process easier than beating the boss.
developer_response: Using weapons with lightning damage can easily break BOSS's shield, and you can evade its attack behind the pillars. Hope you can beat the first BOSS soon! Thanks for your feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
A true hidden gem on Steam. A beautifully crafted game mixing elements of various games to truly create it's own style. I haven't found a game this replayable and great since Risk of Rain 2. I'm excited to see where the devs take this game, I'd love to see at least 2 more heroes added for even greater coop play. This game really makes you feel like a god after you master even just part of the game, it's an intricate dopamine rush of a game that I cannot recommend more. So much depth in an early access game. Absolutely a must buy for anyone interested in games like Risk of Rain 2, Borderlands, and Binding of Isaac. The best 12 bucks I've spent in the past year.

EDIT: They've done a great job with the updates too, this is one of the few times where a developer actually tries to balance things without making stuff way too over or underpowered for no reason.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Only about 18 hours in as of reviewing this I'll make it short and sweet. For a 12$ game it's fantastic.
Pros:
-Cheap
-Fluid gunplay
-Fun weapon design
-Interesting Upgrade system to keep every run from feeling the exact same

Cons:
-It doesn't guide the player well, IE: a mechanic in the 3rd boss is never shown or hinted at until after the battle starts, you'll probably die guaranteed just because you didn't know there was a mechanic involved.
-Weapon drops are a little rare early
-RNG is rough, sometimes you just aren't going to be effective no matter how hard you try, its still possible but not in a fun way, in more of a bash your head against a wall until it breaks kinda way.

Absolutely going to keep playing.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
An extremely satisfying game loop. As my friend says, "It's Borderlands without the commitment". Personally, I wasn't a fan of Borderlands, but this game is fantastic. It offers a familiar yet dynamic experience each time you start a run. The maps are always the same, but the path you take is often different. The weapons, and scrolls you find along the way are mostly random, and it's extremely easy to pickup without much explanation. 

The core game is fantastic and I can't wait to see what they add next. 

The following is not a statement about any existing features in this game, but what I would be delighted to see implemented in the future:

[spoiler]Personally, I think we've got all of the gameplay components for a really fun and exciting PVP experience. I have never enjoyed any Battle Royale game that I've played before, but between the Occult Scrolls, Ascensions, and Weapon variety we see in the game, there's more than potential for something new and refreshing.[/spoiler]

[spoiler]Obviously, the current net code probably isn't designed to accommodate the scale of a game like PUBG for instance, but it might be worth exploring. Perhaps even a MOBA FPS game type, you could reuse the assets of the NPCs we see in the core game. Granted, this type of game would probably add a lot of overhead cost for servers to adequately[/spoiler]

[spoiler]Even if you just went the Deathmatch route, it could still be fun, even if it's not well balanced (And I wouldn't even suggest trying to balance it). Gungame or other objective based game modes (KotH, CtF, etc) could be interesting too. Just an idea that crossed my mind.[/spoiler]

Even if none of what I mentioned above ever gets implemented into Gunfire, I still think it's a spectacular game that's made me reminisce about my favorite game of all time, the now defunct Gunz: The Duel. I spent over 35,000 hours playing that game, with at least 10,000 of those hours spent doing Quest mode, which is a similar game loop without the dynamic experience of scrolls and random weapons. The bosses in particular remind me of Gunz. 

Thank you so much to the Devs for creating a fun game that captures some of the fun from my favorite game that I can no longer play.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
It's early access. For that, it's ok. It's quite promising, Very promising. But it's just not there yet.
Gameplay is a bit repetetive. Esp. the initial dungeon could do with 2 or 3 more room designs.

There are still technical issues:
* Wonky geometry. I keep getting stuck in tight spaces and at corners for no obvious reasons.
* Wonky input. Sometimes input is not being processed. E.g. try triggering talent and a granade in rapid fashion. 2nd action is not being performed (I am on an NKRO keyboard).
Both usually end with you getting killed while you back out or check the cool downs only to find them ready to go. Frustrating and unnecessary.

Additionally: The user interface gives you non-choices. How would you like to spend those soul essences you can't spend because you don't have enough. WTF? Do you want to return to the in and lose those? Eh, no, so what's the option? Ah, there is none. Or: You're dead. Revive? Ah, sorry, you cannot.
If there are no valid options the only reason to ask is to annoy the user.

So: Cannot recommend yet, maybe later. But it's a cool concept.
developer_response: Sorry for your boring experience, we will add more content and randomness in the future update, stay tuned. And current system is not perfect enough and we will optimize it, please give us more time.

issues for devs to look at: 
Please remember which difficulty was last played.  Each time I restart the game, it goes back to normal and I click play, have to quit, come back, change to elite, then restart.  Really just a QOL. 
The monks in 3rd stage that teleport might be bugged?  2 times I got insta gibbed by them and have no idea how as I was full health and shield and all I know if one teleported behind me and im dead instantly with no reaction time.   If its a sort of backstab ability...its pretty unfun and hard to counter in a 1st person view.   Either should be changed or fixed bug...very lame way to die and very little counterplay to it. 

Wishlist: 
More stages / bosses. 
Starting chest should have more than 3 choices or maybe a reroll or two.  Its fairly minor since they are +0 weapons but would help at least get something you may enjoy as many times the 3 choices are terrible.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
One of the best purchases I've ever made. I can't believe this game is only $10. It is both very enjoyable to play alone and with friends. If you like rogue-lite and FPS games, this game is a must buy. It is similar to Immortal Redneck, despite having less stages and MUCH BETTER gunplay, upgrades, scrolls, mechanics... 

I think this game has a huge potential. The game is in early access, and the updates come regularly. The core gameplay is already awesome, and when more content is added, this game will be even better with more variety.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn is a pleasant surprise that succeeds in mixing different game mechanics from the roguelite/FPS genre to provide a fun experience in solo or coop. In short:

- a FPS projectile-based gameplay with good feedback and responsiveness, 
- a variety of weapons, passives (called ascensions) and situational bonuses (called scrolls) obtained as random drops that provide different playstyles,
- build choice during runs is impacted by drops and random weapon modifiers "ala A-RPG",
- classic roguelite experience (level progression, drops and currency is lost on death) but,
- permanent passive unlocks (called talents) via a "semi-permanent" currency randomly acquired by killing mobs, and new weapon/scroll drop unlocks via challenges, making the progression feel extremely good compared to most roguelites,
- frequent updates that go in the right way from my point of view,
- a price tag extremely reasonable considering the current content.

Cons:
- platforming feels clunky and could use better collisions and feedback,
- a few bugs, lack of polish and the UI can be improved (early access, fair enough),
- some weapons, scrolls and talents feel underwhelming or too strong, could use more rebalancing,
- lack of a kind of ending.

To conclude, Gunfire Reborn is an already good game in itself that needs a bit of polish to feel finished, but about every aspect of its core screams for more content, and that's a good thing. There's room for more characters, more weapons, more challenges, more levels, more difficulties... It's rare to feel that way, but I would gladly give a few more bucks for more content such as characters, modes or levels.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
The game's great, easy to pick up and play and really satisfying when you get to learn the ins and outs of the game more thoroughly like weapons and scrolls. If you like Rogue-lite games and shooters this is a fantastic game to try out. If I had to make a comparison it's kinda like Borderlands combined with Binding of Isaac. You can earn permanent unlocks as you play which help make your characters stronger overall, but each playthrough consists of a "run" which has you progressing through the floors, finding items and scrolls you equip to make your character stronger. Ending when you either die, or get to the final boss, at which point you'd have to start a new run.

Also the co-op is another strong point of the game, I've played at least 30 hours with my friends and never had an issue with connectivity or lag. The game gets a bit harder on co-op to make up for having another friend to blast through enemies but it feels like there's a good balance regarding the level of difficulty vs solo play. 

Overall, I'd definitely recommend the game, considering it's not even the full release yet I'm very excited to see what else comes to the game.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: Don't believe the high review scores of this game.  I feel like the scores are artificially buffed by fake reviews in order to bait you into buying this game.  If you are  any sort of fan of rogue-like games, this is as unfinished and unpolished as it gets.  I had nearly instant buyers remorse upon launching this game.  You can tell from a very early point that this isn't as lovingly crafted or deep in gameplay as any other game on the market.  If you're looking for a new roguelike game to play, this is not your game.
developer_response: Hi, we will continue add more new content, New Game Plus into the game to make it with more replayability. At the same time, we will continue the optimization and try to polish this game. Thanks for your feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
TL:DR  more fun with friends, better strategy too

This game was introduced to me by youtuber solodoublej, and i have not been disappointed... me and my friend (up to 4 players) have been going ham on this game when im home and not working lol.. and its super fun. playing solo just kinda feels like grinding for levels, but still fun to see new things as u go. we play alot all at once and really enjoy it. i think they do a good job at making this game challenging enough to make u want to get past that one part, yet fun enough that makes u want to keep playing even if u lose the round. that being said, its early access, so theres less content than i want there to be... still its not bad at all... there are almost no bugs... like... i dont even think ive seen one. when i first started out playing, my framerate was hitchy, but i havent noticed that in a while... so... on to the bad stuff, which honestly, isnt much. its a random based game and sometimes u get poopied on... but u can still get thru it, and feel fulfilled in the end... more stuff is needed, honestly its worth 12 or 13 bucks... as is rn its worth that. but i would love to see more, maybe different stage selects as there is only one u can choose (and by one i mean u start in one stage and advance to a harder stage after a boss... but u dont get to select any stage at all.)on top of that,, i find myself stiching to one weapon (prism) and my friend sticking to one as well (thunderclap gloves) and this combo seems unbeatable. so balancing may be an issue, but im no game dev. the other guns just dont seem as fun to me so that may be personal opinion. hit boxes are the biggest problem and def need tweaked... i could smack someone in the face point blank and it wouldnt count as a crit... and some hitboxes seem really small. i should be saying crit boxes... bc i have no problem hitting them... at all but sometimes im hitting them in the head and nothing happens... idk y... so hitboxes for crits are my biggest problem... so to break it down:

Pros:
-Super fun overall
-pretty good graphics
-good balance of rewarding and challenging
-great with friends
-few bugs (if any)
-def a 12 or 13 dollar game id prob pay like 20 for it honestly...

Cons:
-crit hit boxes suck
-not a huge amount of content as far as level selection or hero selection
-kinda feels like u only want to use one gun...

worth the buy... cant wait to see where this game goes, ill be playing it for a long time i hope

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game, although in early access, is well worth buying! There are a lot of different mechanics and combinations you can play in your runs, making it diverse.

PROs:
Fun (and even more so with friends)
Affordable
Easy to play, hard to master
Skill tree

CONs:
Game still has some bugs (expected in early access - and they don't make the game unplayable)
English translations need improvements
2 playable characters (at time of writing)
Can get a little repetitive and boring, especially playing solo.


Overall, definitely worth the buy! You won't regret it.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Fantastically fun roguelike shooter. Challenging, yet offers a good sense of progression. Tight, crisp shooter controls and a mix of strategy and reflex combat.

The game feels like an early access game in terms of the amount of content available, but the core gameplay experience is so fun that you quickly become addicted. 

Gameplay - 10/10 - this is where the game shines.

Graphics - 7/10 - the visuals are cartoonish and cel-shaded, light on detail but otherwise stylistically pleasing and streamlined for high performance.

Sound - 6/10 - the music is appropriate and fits the style, but otherwise doesn't particularly stand out. I feel there is room for improvement in this regard. The sound design is, similarly, appropriate and functional, but could be richer and more unique. Many aspects of the sound design are currently missing, from menu & UI sounds, to combat cues that could help the player hear and react to combat situations. Creature and environment sounds are understated and don't particularly stand out in an immersive way. The gun sounds feel like the most polished aspect so far, which is understandable for an early access title that appears to be focused on perfecting the combat experience.

Characters/Story - 3/10 - the character designs are nice, but otherwise there currently isn't much character or story to speak of. The two playable characters don't have vocalizations or dialog to flesh our who they are and why they are shooting their way through dungeons.

Systems - 8/10 - the systems for upgrading, leveling, and choosing skill bonuses are well thought out and meaningfully impact gameplay, though it would be fun to see even more variety in this area.

Level Design - 7/10 - the first 'level' area is pretty basic, comprised of small rooms and tight corridors, but the second level showcases more open arena combat areas and make for a more interesting experience. The third level is similarly more open and interesting.

Weapons - 8/10 - an interesting variety of guns that lend themselves well to different playstyles. The more I play, the more I discover that certain guns I didn't initially like can become very powerful with certain inscriptions or scroll powers. 

All in all, very excited to see where this game goes. It's a lot of fun even in it's current form, and I think it will only get better with new additional content in the form of weapons, levels, characters, and audio design. 

Shout out to Mr. Sark for playing this on his channel and getting me interested in the first place.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is refreshing. It knows what it is and it seeks to do it well. If you want a game with Dead Cells like progression combined with the hijinks of borderlands elemental and diverse weapon system this is the game for you. Runs of the game are done at around 2 hours if you go all the way through, which is a perfect sit down and play with friends for an afternoon amount of time. It also has a system of permanent progression that can be quite substantial so when you die it is not too frustrating.
    
    It does not suffer any pesky story to get in the way of your projectile mayhem. That being said like borderlands a big fun factor of this game is playing with friends. Runs are varied due to the pickups with a scroll system that vastly can change play style but you will be seeing around the same areas with suble variations every run. Also loot is instanced but if you want to share it with teammates just pick it up and drop it.
     The biggest issue honestly is just that the random matchmaking can be quite unstable if you play with people from faraway and it often randomly groups you together. Another is that if you have a full group of 4, enemies can be a little spongey but that can be easily mitigated with the right build.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Great FPS roguelite. Would highly recommend co-op play, has online coop, so buy the game for yourself, then gift it to a few friends.

One negative is that the game has a bit of a grind built into it (like Rogue Legacy and Undermine) to get stronger and progress further into each run. Would have preferred unlocks to be item-based (like Binding of Isaac or Neon Abyss) instead of level-up based, but I'm sure the game will still be balanced more during the course of Early Access.

As there are not many FPS roguelites, this is a welcome addition to the steam library. Would recommend.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: This game is a wonderful blend of my favorite parts of Risk of Rain 2, and my favorite parts of Borderlands. As a roguelite, it has the fun of hoping for good loot rolls, such as a preferred weapon, or a scroll you know is useful. As a shooter, the gunplay is pretty crisp, and easy to get a grasp on. As an RPG, the progression system is rife with flat boosts like +Shields and +Health, as well as other, more interesting upgrades in the way of granting special boons to weapons you find, and makes no L feel too infuriating; you're coming back stronger next run, and god help the Octopus that waxed you five minutes ago. For 12 dollars, it's an absolute steal. I just hope the developers beef it up with updates. It's rare for a game to be this entertaining at this early in its life cycle, with seemingly so much room still to grow.

Also the controller buttons don't always work so I can't reload or select in menus etc. I'll hold on to the game for a while to see if this improves since it was so cheap, but I unfortunately can't play or recommend until fixed.
developer_response: Can you tell us what exact controller did you use? And it will be great if you can send a video of your issue to qhstaff@2980.com

review: One of the best co-op actions at the momemnt. Simple mechanics, decent variability with builds and weapons. Guns also get random rolls on stats. Add this to scrolls and ascensions and every run become somewhat unique. There is a lot to be done about the game, though. Levels can vary, but they are not procedurally generated and at some point start feeling repetitive. Would be cool to have more bosses and levels. I would like to see more playable chars and maybe skins for them, or at least different recolors to be able to distinguish players. Other than that, highly recommend. Fun and chill.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Awesome gameplay with lots of cool enemies and weapons. Some guns could use a slight change or buff and there are minor bugs but none that ruined my experience. There is a lot of variety and the elemental system works very well! 

Skills and scrolls make the game very interesting and change the way you play every run. After a couple runs you will be hooked, this game is addicting haha.

A lot of people do complain about the parkour puzzles, some are very easy and others took me a while to be able to speed run it. Use lighter weapons for parkour, the guns have a weight on your character.

I can't wait to see what they do with this! I'm having a blast with my friends and definitely recommend if you enjoy co-op looter shooters.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
9/10 a fantastic game. Great gunplay. Smooth movment.

The game reminds me of risk of rain 2 the most however it changes the formula more than enough to have its own game identity. It incorporates the best parts of borderlands and doom eternal as well. The game is foremost a FPS with everything else, like platforming, being completely optional.

Even for an early access game it is very polished. progression is rewarding but not overpowered.

The game is worth it at the early access price and a steal at any sale.

Gunfire reborn has truly earned an overwhelmingly positive ratio!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Game has potential and is quite polished but in it's current state it's extremely lacking in content. 

Runs get repetitive very quickly and the game completely lacks the variety/longevity of games like Risk of Rain 2, Synthetik, Noita etc. 

I'd give a tentative thumbs up due to the sheer potential of the game and how fun the gunplay is. It will be amazing once: 

- more levels are added and there's more randomisation of levels.
- scrolls/talents get completely reworked (they're very boring/lackluster. Very few interesting builds/decisions)
- more classes are added.
- more weapons are added (most weapons are functionally identical, with a few fairly creative exceptions). 
- additional items area added (more consumables etc)

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
EDIT:

My initial review was a little harsh, so after playing the game for a while longer I've decided to add onto this a little less harshly.

First, a positive note.

The game is fun for what it is, primarily if you're playing co-op. It has gotten better the longer I've played it. As it stands it has a lot of potential to be a very good game, especially as an early access title. That said, a lot of my initial opinions haven't changed.

- The mobility is a big issue to me. Maybe I'm just spoiled from other games, but the mobility in this game is really lackluster. The dash isn't a dash so much as a slightly larger than normal step in one direction that you can take every three seconds. Mobility scrolls make this a lot better (increased movement speed, triple dash, decreased cooldown), but without it the mobility feels practically useless unless if you time it perfect. It feels particularly useless later on when you're facing ten enemies that each shoot a barrage of homing projectiles while being hounded by other enemies. That said, it would be difficult to buff the current base mobility aside from just adding a small distance increase or cooldown reaction without having to rebalance the previously mentioned mobility scrolls. Honestly, I would suggest just adding in a hero who focuses on mobility, maybe they have double dash in their base kit or something, in exchange for a lower initial HP pool or something to round them out. That way players who still enjoy the current mobility for its difficulty can have it. Just like how the dog character is based on dual-wielding, have this character focus on mobility. Their talents could give them movement speed buffs or give them buffs depending on how much mobility they have (as an example, the scroll that increases your movement speed based on your shield %). Maybe receive a certain amount of damage reduction for a couple seconds after dashing, better shield regen rate based on movement speed (which would synergize with the aforementioned scroll), or passively reload ammo while they're moving. 

- Secondly, the essence not being persistent is extremely jarring. I came into this after playing other roguelites wherein it was normal for you to keep progression currency after each run. It just seems odd to randomly destroy a player's reward at the end of each run if they choose not to spend it, especially if you gamble your essence away on reviving or simply die to a boss before your teammates kill it (you don't get any reward and have to wait to be revived from a peddler for a good chunk of gold). It seems like the devs are trying to counter this by specifically adding in a talent that lets you keep a % of your essence after each run, which just seems weird; taking a base game mechanic from other roguelites and locking it behind progression currency. This should just be one of the initial talents you get if it's not something you simply start with. As it stands the game feels more grindy than it should -- if I die during a run I have to choose between abandoning my run and ruining my enjoyment just so that I can end up with some kind of reward, or gamble my essence away to self-revive and hope I end up with enough essence at the end to get anything - which is rare, because by the time I get to the desert level it costs over half my essence to self-revive. I personally don't find that fun. Don't get me wrong I like difficulty in games, but there's a difference between being challenging and being obnoxious. You could just say "git gud" but that's not the point - you're meant to die in roguelites, but gradually become stronger so that you can get further, that's why progression currency is persistent. In this you're encouraged to play great and never die or don't get any progression currency, which doesn't make any sense.

- The revive mechanic doesn't feel great, particularly when you die to a boss in co-op. Your teammate kills it and you get 0 reward. Literally nothing. No weapon, no scroll, no gold, no essence. It doesn't matter how much work you put into killing said boss, you get nothing, and if you previously self-revived you're punished even more. Then you have to wait for your teammate to fight their way through at least one stage in order to find a peddler so that they can spend roughly half their gold to revive you. That's pretty rough, especially when you're playing co-op with just two people but the enemies have tripled HP (and whatever other difficulty buffs they get with multiple players). Players should get revived after a boss is killed or at least make it a talent that people can acquire if they choose. The self-revive feels like more of a gamble than it's worth especially at later stages when, as previously mentioned, self-reviving costs over half your essence which means you're unlikely to get much of any reward once the run is over unless if you manage to beat the next boss.

- The gun disparity is pretty obvious to me. A lot of the guns don't feel very strong, whereas others are ridiculously powerful. It obviously depends a lot on RNG, whether or not you can get good modifiers, but even then there are a handful of guns I would simply never use unless if I had no other choice. The fire sniper rifle and double-shot shotgun, for example, are my two least favorite guns. I was excited to get the sniper rifle at first, until I actually used it. I ended up getting more use out of it by using it like a shotgun and walking up into enemy's faces at pointblank range to shoot them rather than wasting the time to scope in. Maybe I just never end up with a good build or get bad RNG on my sniper rifles, but it never actually feels strong or worth taking over anything else. This is a lot harder to fix because it's so heavily reliant on RNG and I have a feeling the gun disparity won't ever be balanced -- but that's an issue other games have as well.

- The boulder vault rooms are just silly. The boulders are so close proximity and come at such a random rate/position that you're honestly better off just tanking the hits to your shield than wasting the time to try and dodge past them -- which, obviously, shouldn't be the case. The point of traps is to bypass them, not facetank them because they're so obnoxious. The primary issue is that because the game's base mobility is so bad it becomes extra ridiculous trying to dodge between a  one-inch gap through two boulders when your dash is just a glorified sidestep. On the plus side, as much as I dislike how the mobility feels in this game, the jump puzzle vault rooms are ironically my favorite and are actually enjoyable. There's nothing enjoyable about the boulder vault rooms. You could say they're not meant to be enjoyable because it's a challenge room, but since when did difficulty equate to not being fun?

Those are my current primary issues with the game that, to me, are really holding it back from being as good as it could be. It's enjoyable enough to play with a friend, but I don't think I would play it solo in its current state. Maybe others find it fun, but not me.

Would I recommend the game in its current state? I'm still going with no -- I'd wait until the next update, at least. Like I said the game has a lot of potential, but it's also too often more frustrating than it is fun. I was tempted to refund this game myself when I first got it, but I decided to hang on because I do acknowledge the game's potential and hope that my money goes towards making it better.
developer_response: Thanks for spending time providing us the feedback. We find many currently existed issues through your feedback and we will gradually optimize them in the future update. Please give us more time. Thanks for your feedback.

review:
Usually I don't enjoy rogue-lite games due to the non-persistent progression such as losing items and starting over.

But this game, has a bit of magic that captures my heart, where the loot and ascension random-ness adds to the fun of playing the game.

One example:
Had a god-roll round for the team, perfect rolls on weapons for everyone, everyone running perfect builds.

But failed to kill the 3rd world boss.

Tried again:
This time, abyssmal weapon drops, and running lousy builds = defeated 3rd world boss.

This is magic factor that makes me go back to this game.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
The game is fairly fun, and the art direction is perfect. But the movement speed is way too slow to be enjoyable, and there are too many weapons that either don't feel good / don't do enough damage / or frankly do way too much damage and make the others look pointless. 

I know you can collect movement scrolls in the game, but nearly every run I wasn't able to find them. When you get to the boss that translates to "just give up" because even with dashes you aren't going to be able to avoid his later attacks. 

I really wish I could like this game, but I just can't recommend it. Maybe once the creator puts more time into it, but for now there's not enough content to really entertain you past an hour when you realize the game's major shortcomings.
developer_response:
Thanks for your interest! There are some Occult Scrolls that can increase your movement speed and you can have a try. In addition, you can use "Shift" more frequently to move quicker.

Plus, the Vault is the major place for you to get Occult Scrolls. Once you see there is a crevice on the wall, you can shoot it to enter the vault. Challenge success will bring you an Occult Scroll.

And using weapons with lightning damage can easily break BOSS's shield, and you can evade its attack behind the pillars. Hope you can beat the first BOSS soon!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
While still in early access and slightly lacking in content I can say that after a bit over 50 hours of game play it is well worth it's price. The difficulty scaling and progression is quite rewarding and you will even when failing (which you will do most of the time) gain some persistent progression. As you level up, and unlock more weapons and scrolls (passive buffs), the game will get easier. The large amount of different weapons is very satisfying, and it is  particularly fun to see a new weapon or scroll you just unlocked drop.

The largest negative is balance. Even with the large variety of weapons, scrolls and inscriptions (weapon attached buffs) some easy to get combinations are way better then just about everything except the rarest of combinations. 

The other main negative is that the elite mode (new game+) is not particularly more difficult than normal. It would be nice to see the difficulty for that scaling up significantly but with higher chances for more and rare inscriptions.

+ weapon variety
+ progression
+ early difficulty scaling
- balance
- late game difficulty scaling
- late game play variety

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I would like to recommend this game, but I can't with the game breaking bugs that keep occurring. The game will sometimes rubberband you, even in single player, which can cause you to die. Sometimes the game will lock up right before an explosion hits preventing you from dodging it and thus killing you. I'm guessing the particle effects and sound effects are loaded on demand and are not preloaded, which means they can cause this lock up while loading the assets. And sometimes I will dodge out of an explosion area and somehow still get hit by it. I've had Nihilation Monks spawn under ground beneath me and it doesn't show the damage area, so I don't know what is hitting me or from where. The hitboxes for enemy weakpoints seem really off. Sometimes it's super easy to hit them and sometimes no matter how hard you try, it won't count shots against them.

I also don't know what kind of "end game" they have planned. Like will there be some form of infinite progression? Longer term unlocks?

The game has potential and I enjoy it up until I hit the bugs and then I stop playing it. Hope to see it improve.
developer_response: Sorry for your bad experience, we have figured out the issues, and we will try our best to optimize our game. Thanks for playing our game and providing feedback.

Though there are some things I personally would like to see:

Character customization
at least different colour pallettes
Hats and hair styles
(I'm sure they are planning on adding more characters, but right now 90% of games have 4 identical cats)

A bigger skill tree
The more things I can do to improve my character the better
I'm keener to play a game that has development. (Killing 100 tough and rare enemies in the final stage of the game to unlock a weapon may be development for you, it's not for me)

Less janky platforming

(Maybe) slower progression through "worlds" i.e. one or two more levels per world. Some might find this boring, but the levels could be vamped up a bit/a bit more unique.
There is an obvious spike at least in the first world between the last level before the boss and the one before that
These extra levels will also give you the chance to potentially acquire some nicer gear before the first boss.
Sometimes you get there and it's like "oh, are we here already"(I know experts in the game might not feel this way)

More worlds(but I assume this is in the works, if not it should be!)

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Satisfies the looter shooter borderlands 3 itch for a fraction of the cost of other similar titles. Just how much does it share in common with the big budget release from gearbox? Well the two currently available characters feature active skills that are more or less a 1:1 match of Salvadore's Gunzerker and Maya's Phaselock abilities. The elements of shock, fire and corrosive (i.e. decay) are all present. The game also has some creative ideas all its own! The Crown Prince (the feline Maya expy) can combine the elements of shock, and fire with his own built in corrosive grenade to create the "fusion elemental effects" of miasma and explosion that do even more damage than the basic elements. Also just like borderlands your build is going to end up being an interaction between your characters skill point investments (called ascensions in this game), your choice of weapons (there are over 30 all of which are like borderlands legendaries) and your distribution of skill points in the persistent talent tree that is conserved between runs. Enemies include both cannon fodder, elites (some with elemental attributes) and bosses fought in arena environments which spawn them in waves. 

In terms of weaknesses expect a product that is still not fully polished. I found framerate drops would occur regularly without uncapping my frame rate. The localisation is also not complete right now though its adequate. Given the asking price is just 10 USD the value for dollar is huge but this is by no means as massive a title yet. There are just 3 zones so far and while I can't say what's the case with each zone but I know there is just one boss available for zone one. I recommend if you're not convinced you keep this one on your wishlist and revisit to see exactly what kind of progress the devs have made. 

TL;DR this can become something really special possibly a match for Risk of Rain 2!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
For a game that's still in early access and is so cheap this game has so much to offer.   Gunfire is a fps rogue like game with a cell shaded art style that seems to take influence from games like risk of rain 2 and borderlands in order to deliver a very re playable game that despite it's grind never gets old or boring due to the many different weapons and scrolls that change your play style.

Gunfire currently has two playable character's though I expect them to add a few more before the final update. The two we have currently are the cat and the dog. The cat seems to be a very elemental character with two main ability's, one allows him to freeze enemy's for a short amount of time and the other is an explosive that deals toxic damage over time. Though both of these can be massively changed due to items that are picked up each run. The dog also has two ability's. The first is the ability to due whiled for a short period of time and his second is also an explosive though this one deals direct damage to the enemy rather than toxic overt time. 

Another change between the two is the amount of health they have. The cat has less base HP but more shields where as the dog has more base hp and less shields. The different's between the two is that base hp does not recharge over time and shields do.  The cat is unlocked from the start and the dog gets unlocked after getting to level 30. I like to play as the cat more due to him being more flexible in runs though I know people who love to play as the dog and are really good with him so it's more down to personal opinion.  

Visually GF looks pretty good with it's cell shaded art style. Reminds me a bit of some of the older spyro games in it's design, even more so when it comes to the second stage. I also like the design of some of the enemy's who are all easy to spot from and identify from the moment you see them meaning that you can use your best weapon on some of the more difficult enemy types.

Now for the downsides that I think mostly could still be sorted out in early access. The first is a small but still minor annoyance. There does seem to be some odd translations on a few of the things in game. Whilst it's mostly fine there are a few times I was confused about the wording such as one of the items having a description that never told me if the effect happened on me or an enemy or a chest that had a messy option that I only really understood after clicking it.  These are rare to come across but are a bit annoying when you do find them. Another thing I think could be sorted about a bit is the speed some of the enemy's kill you. There have been a few time where I walk into a room with full shields and hp only to be instantly cut down in a fraction of a second by an enemy I haven't even seen yet and this can become a bit annoying if you just had a really good run only to have it ruined by something you don't have time to react to. These is mostly caused by enemy's like the bombers than gang up on you and any enemy that can take down 3/4 of your health in a single hit. Even after becoming powerful in the game these enemy's still felt annoying to come across though I will admit there is nothing more fun that watching them all melt if you had the best possible run. The last problem I have is the second boss. There are three in the game and whilst the first and third bosses are quite good but the seconds is just crazy. The second boss is far more difficult than the final boss. Think of one of the instant kill enemy's and now give them two massive health bars and a beam of damage that can melt your entire hp from full to nothing in less than 2 seconds. Now make it move faster than your base speed and give it a large AOE. That is a real struggle. Though fixing that should be easy, Just make it so when he fires his over powered attack he moves a little bit slower than the base speed of your character so he can plan for it and move out of the way.

Over all those for what it costs GF reborn is an amazing game that already feels more polished in Earl Access than many finished games do and I can't wait for more updates to this amazing rouge like game.

review:
The only game I ever bought at full price and still feels like I underpaid.

The positives speak for themselves:
- Satisfying gun play
- Great permanent skill progression (that prepares you for elite mode)
- Wide array of guns and gun enchantments (like borderlands)
- 99% of runs are bug-free
- Unpredictable gameplay (Randomised gun drops, gun enchantments, acquired skill sets, etc)
- Runs well even on potato pcs

Needs:
- More guns
- More scrolls
- More stages
- More playable characters
- More game modes (Endless, higher difficulty, etc)
- Earned cosmetics
- Basically, more of the good stuff

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is really fun, I can't think of any major flaws. The only annoyance is that in the early game, any XP you have remaining will be wasted until you unlock the perk to let some amount of XP carry over. Every weapon is usable and fun, and only 2-3 weapons are clunky or bad. 

The synergies that are possible can absolutely make you delightfully broken. Sometimes I will slog through the first boss that takes 5+ minutes (not often, however) but other times I will melt him because I got really lucky. 

Also the game is very RNG and numbers based. No garbage 'increase your damage by 1.3% on a tuesday if you're wearing red' nonsense, you can very easily stack multiple 'increase your damage by 30-50%' effects and that rules.

Finally, this game is full 3D (as the screenshots and trailer show) which is fucking absurd at this price point. That is to say, this game doesn't cost enough for the level of quality on display. The low-poly look adds a charm to things and the animations are detailed enough that the low-poly look doesn't feel like a cop-out at all. 

Get this game, lots of replay value, good polish, CATHARTIC. If the core gameplay loop appeals to you, you will very easily put 50-100 hours plus into a $12 game. 

I hope they add more levels. Like maybe another stage into the base game for free, and then another several as an expansion/DLC for which I will gladly pay another $12 for.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I've played lots of Rougelites and similar RPG-like single player games: Dead cells, Transistor, Risk of Rain, Hades, Enter the Gungeon, Wizard of Legend, Moonlighter, etc. 

There's three main parts of roguelites: The rpg powers, the gameplay (aka how do you survive?), and variety (aka replayability).

a) The rpg powers are varied and sufficient. Lots of roguelites get this pretty good to be fair. The system in this game is closest to Deadcells out of all the games I've played. Basically, you have 2 weapons, a hero power, and a grenade power. The weapons have random bonuses and the weapons can be leveled up. There's synergy possible as well, that results in powerful weapon effects, like Dead cells.

The power leveling is more akin to Hades. You can pick from 3 paths and each power up affects one of those three (grenade, element dmg, hero power). 

b) Gameplay/survival

So most rouglites are platformers or top-down view. Gameplay-wise, this almost always results in kiting back (i.e. running away) as necessary at high levels. And aim/mechanics don't come into play because frankly you don't need precision aim with top-down games. So the result is just kite back over and over and over. I really find that annoying in Diablo and bullet hell games. Just avoid...

In this game, you still must avoid dmg, duh. But for you fps gamers, hitting crit shots is really important, combined with movement. If you like fast moving fps games like Destiny or Titanfall, you will like the shooting in this game. If you come from CSGO, you will also enjoy but obviously you know that R6 and CSGO are unique games.

In summary, SELECTIVE offense is your best defense here. Relying on skill synergy and prioritizing enemy types, with good aim headshots and avoiding AOE dmg is key. 

c) Replayability

Probably the weakest point of the game. I would say it's in early access but that's no excuse. Never ever assume that a game will be different once it's "out of early access". That's coming from a Dayz player. People who say "stop complaining it's early access" are fanboys. 

There needs to be additional levels made, it's that simple. But it's scaled so you won't be able to get to the end right away. You probably need to be level 50 and unlock the whole skill tree. 

Also the difference between levels IS big. The first level is a dungeon all close quarters. The 2nd is a desert and you need a sniper or long range weapons. Lots of AOE. You can snipe enemies from super far. 

So the base is there, but there's only 3 levels now.

CONCLUSION: A total steal for $10. Probably should be $15 but that extra $5 difference definitely made me buy it NOW compared to waiting for a 30% sale. So whoever was the marketer for this game I give you props for that decision.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I paid $60 for Fallout 76 and this game is about 10 times better.  

The gunplay is ALREADY excellent.  The visuals are ALREADY excellent!  PLEASE teach Gearbox Studios how to write a menu and framework.  This game is prettier than Borderlands and already preforms EXCELLENTLY.  There's already a ton of cool weapons, augmentations and character builds!  It's SUPER simple in the controls dept.  No left hand cramps trying to keep 30 buttons within a 500ms strike.  WASD to move.  Shift to dash.  Q for grenade and E for orb.  Both mouse buttons.  Very intuitive menus.  Very interesting implementations of Vaults for extra optional content to beef up for the boss fight.  Roguelite system is excellent.  As you level and invest talents the path to that first boss gets quicker and quicker.  The difficulty ramps up in a FUN way as you increase player count.  The boss is definitely easier to solo than he was in a party of 4.  I CANNOT WAIT to see the final release of this product.  It's already a better investment than Fallout 76 or Borderlands 3 were.

GET THIS NOW AND PLAY IT WITH ME PLEASE I CAN'T STOP.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
At the time of this review, Gunfire Reborn is my favorite game. 

To start off, I don't really LOVE first person shooters, but for some reason the game + the artwork is a reason why I keep coming back. Honestly Gunfire Reborn is a chill rougue-lite shooter that brings me back memories of Borderlands 2 and grinding for loot and gun stats.

With friends it offers a similar experience to solo, except better. You get more loot, enemies scale so it is little bit more challenging, but with a team that refines their gun stats and finds OP scrolls, it won't be much of a struggle. 

Something about crit-hitting the enemies and running around and dashing is just so refreshing. I play spotify and listen to chill songs, almost like lofi and just vibe. its a huge stress reliever and  I enjoyed every mechanic of the game. 

With more content being added soon, I cannot wait for possible more classes, more stage/levels, more bosses, guns, scrolls, etc! It feels like such a great game compacted into three main areas (each with 3-4+ stages), and when they add the updates, it will for sure be my most played!

Play this game, it's worth the money, especially for 12 dollars at the time of the review.
