title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Update: Left the game for a bit hoping to come back to an update...Nope. First boss still has wonky hit detection and no new content. Devs might have ditched it already.

***Unfortunetly had to change my review to negative due to the first boss having some very broken and unfun mechanics. Massive bullet sponge, Broken hit detection, and infinetly spawning ads when you play Co-op. So far the game is fun, until you get to a boss.

Feels very grindy. Some enemies in the second area have so much health that you just can't deal with them fast enough before you get overwhelmed so you have to keep grinding the first act over and over to get upgrades which just isn't that fun.

Pros:
-"one more run" is alive and well
-Good variety of guns so far
-guns feel punchy and fun
- enough content right now for the current price

Cons:
-The same levels in a row everytime gets boring.
- difficulty (will be a turn off for some)
-environents are a little stale and uninspired.
- Many builds but seems like only a select few will get you through past tougher areas.
- A little too focuses on the run grind (using crystals to increase shields, health, and cooldowns to make it easier) instead of natually getting better to progress farther.

Can't wait to see what they do with the game. I know I'll be throwing it on for a few runs a night!
developer_response: Thanks for your feedback, we will evaluate the difficulty of the game and make adjustment in future update.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
With how the devs are treating this, it may be the next early access success story. The gameplay is super smooth, I get a consistent framerate even with a lot of action on screen, and the game is challenging but extremely fair. 


Allow me to state this, I am trash at all FPS games I play. Which usually causes me to just not play them after a while. This, however, is different. Even with the short amount of time I've played, I can feel myself improving. As a person who sucks at shooters, that makes me feel like this is a different breed of game. While it's PvE, I still feel myself improving with my tracking and snapping to targets. 

That being said though, this game isn't without it's flaws. Right now with it only being one set of bosses with different level themes after each boss, it can and will get same-y, but I imagine that as dev goes on, this game will continue to improve. Right now though, I definitely recommend picking it up. It's only 12 bucks, and this game can honestly only get better from here.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game really picked up for me once I got the ability to bank Soul Essence, a currency used to buy upgrades.  I played the game for maybe 30 minutes at a time, barely getting past the first boss before dying in the second stage in a 10 minute run, before this point. Now I am to play runs that can last upwards of 40 minutes, with time flying by, and then start another one right after!

After I understood how the game was supposed to get easier over time it also became easier to keep playing towards that goal. In turn this lead towards understanding the game better all around and fully enjoying myself. I feel like the game/developers do very well in easing you into the game.

Unlocking Elite mode is wonderful, aside from a few personal issues like my spacial awareness having me killed on a trap, and provides both a better challenge as well as fantastic scroll options for future runs.

Fully recommended, I love the game.

I had more fun with a similar game called Immortal Redneck. Maybe I just don't like Borderlands type of games.
developer_response: Thanks for your interest, we will add more content and optimize the gameplay in the future update, stay tuned.

I'm only giving the game a thumbs down because the bosses need to be either nerfed or make coop accessible from the getgo.
developer_response: Sorry for your bad experience, using weapons with lightning damage can easily break BOSS's shield, and you can evade its attack behind the pillars. Hope you can beat the first BOSS soon!  And we keep adjusting the game difficulty and game balance, please give us more time to polish. Thanks for your feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Wonderful game with tons of potential. I love the style, the gameplay, and the replay-value. I can't wait to see what the full-release of the game is like! I hope you guys add even more levels/characters!

If any of the devs happen to see this: One thing that I would love to see is more game settings/options. A couple of my friends have complained about the crosshair options and one of my friends had a hard time with motion sickness (specifically on the dash and jump). It's a shame because they REALLY enjoy the game. I wonder if you could add options in the future to reduce any motion blur or head bob to help those who suffer from simulation sickness.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
For those of you who are looking for something to play that isn't Risk of Rain 2(If you haven't played it yet, I highly recommend it), then this is what you're looking for: Gunfire Reborn. It might not be THE replacement since there's still content to come and feels dry in that sense but it does a great job of being a good rogue-like game. While you only get to play two characters at the time of writing this, there are tons of unlockables and weapons to experiment with that are wacky and powerful, such as elemental damage, instant kill and extreme rate of fire (Hopefully they add more weapons in future updates since there are only 41 at the moment). At the end of a run, you'll earn Soul Essence which allows you to upgrade your "talents", which are permanent upgrades to your runs that'll make you stronger and provide runs with more spammability, for lack of a better word. I'm the type of player who enjoys a run and gun play style and brushing through enemies so if that's how you want to play, this game will definitely supply. 
The graphics aren't anything to rave about. However, if you played the Sly Cooper games on Playstation, you'll easily be able to tell that the art style is similar to those games which I personally enjoy. Do note that if you try to run this game without v-sync, your game is prone to crashing easily (Currently using a 144hz monitor). Turning v-sync on will avoid that, but your move may vary.
Multiplayer is peer-to-peer in this game so if your internet sucks, your teammates will have a bad time and probably want to leave. In otherwords, get better internet nerd. My experience with multiplayer was great so far in that players were extremely cooperative and there's no toxicity in the player-base(yet). Most people have mics but never really use them though.
Overall, this game is worth giving a try. The only sale I've seen was this past(2020)summer sale with a 12% off. Even without the discount, this game is worth your money if you're looking for a fun rogue-like with vast amounts of replayability, play styles and decent multiplayer. At the end of the day, you can always return it within the two hour period if you don't like it. As Reggie-meister once said: If the game's not fun, why bother?

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Very simple and fun game currently. It was much smoother than I thought it was going to be even though it's early access. From what I can tell there are 3 bosses and 2 characters currently which is a decent amount of content for $12.

The gun play is similar to borderlands with the element matching aspect and there is a decent variety of weapons so far. The roguelite aspect reminds me of Enter the Gungeon for the item unlock system and Rogue Legacy for the skill tree system. I feel like both systems are implemented well so far. 

The only real cons are character/gun variety but I feel like that will come eventually. I haven't made it far enough to know if the game will just wrap like Risk of Rain 2 and scale or if after the 3rd Boss I'll be done with game so length could potentially be a con.

I have not tried multiplayer yet.

Overall this is a fun little game when you don't want a serious shooter. I think it's definitely worth the $12 even in early access.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
For starters, this is still in early access, it is not complete. The game has a good art style that makes it visually pleasing. The sound design is on point with hit feedback, skill use, enemy location, combat in progress, etc. Content that is accessible at this time is fun and engaging with a good scale for permanent upgrade progression.

The multiplayer aspect is a strong selling point as it is much more enjoyable to team up with friends and do a run or two.

The few issues I have are related to the platforming and time commitment. If you like jump puzzles and platforming type games this will either be great or terrible for you because it is a bit floaty with how the character moves in the air, making jumps harder to control. Practice definitely helps, but it is still frustrating to slip off of stuff when you think you are on it. The time commitment issue is a run of the current levels can take upwards of 2 hours from my experience and it may be an issue for some groups where people don't have that time available.

I look forward to seeing the game evolve and more content to be added, it shouldn't need said but it's more than worth the cheap sale price even without further updates.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game... is an anomaly. Not in the fact that its hard to describe what it is, which is a FPS rogue-lite, but in the fact that I've spent so much time in the game in two weeks despite the fact that the amount of content it has shouldn't be keeping my attention for as long as it is, to the point that I'm honestly trying to speedrun the game. 
           Now, lets start with the basic loop of the game in to set the scene. Which, like pretty much all rogue-lite games revolves around killing enemies, getting weapons with randomized added effects to it, obtaining power boosts or items that changes your playstyle, getting as far as possible, with beating the final boss being the end goal, and when that loop completes you spend all of the special currency that drops in low quantities throughout the game to give your character small buffs and quality of life improvements that add up overtime that turn your character from a little baby man into a Giga Chad. 
     And with that, we can get on to the actual review. 
                       First, the bad, which are few, thankfully. Besides some balance issues with some guns being blatantly useless, overpowered, and some being uninspired, plus quite a few scrolls and inscriptions being much more hindrances rather than side-grades or playstyle changes like I assume their for; The main issue with Gunfire Reborn is that their is just not enough of it. And don't take it as "Oh the game is unfinished," or something like that. I mean that its simply impossible to enjoy this game as much as it should, and the general additions that many rogue-lites and rogue-likes have such as looping the same stages as before but with stronger enemies, or more stages and playable characters is woefully absent. Seriously, if the devs just added 2 more stages/areas and the ability to loop your run then this game would easily be up their along with Risk of Rain 2 or Slay The Spire for me.
                   Now, lets get on to the good. First of all, the gunplay is just amazing. the sound all of the guns make barring a few exceptions(Rainbow Arch) and the sound it makes when you land a critical hit can only be described as " killer, dude." Second, the game is polished as Fuq. Not only for an early access game, but for an independent title made by obscure developed the amount of polish in this game is outright disgusting and puts many of the initial and even current quality early access games to shame. Third, the artstyle is, in a word *pop* Noice. The Cell-shaded artstyle and Chinese aesthetic work phenomenally well with the feel of the game. And Fourth, its just a fun and addicting game in all the right ways, I don't really have much else to really add besides that.
          In Short, buy this game. Its well worth the price, the problems with it are simply that you can't enjoy it as much as you would like to, and gahd-DAMN that doggo is THICC.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is incredible, its an extremely good mix between the feel of the guns/health systems from Borderlands 2, and the replayability/items from other great roguelites like Enter the gungeon and Binding of Issac. If you like those types of games I cannot recommend this enough.
(and for only 12 dollars?!)

[b]Pros: [/b] 
[list]
[*]Gunplay is amazing
[*]Interesting, consistent, and well implemented art style
[*]Very unique modifiers on weapons, and extremely powerful "gemini" modifiers if you combo them correctly
[*]As with most roguelites, extreme replayability
[*][b]Consistent weekly updates[/b]
[*]2 unique characters (With more coming)
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*]Some weapons, like the laser gauntlets, tend to fill the screen with damage numbers when they chain to lots of enemies, very satisfying, but cant really see anything as the numbers take up a large part of the screen
[*]Multiplayer animations are a [i]little [/i] lackluster, as the characters just glide everywhere
[*]Small typos here and there, but nothing that i couldnt easily understand with a single read
[/list]

Edited to fix formatting mistakes

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
As a "gameplay first" kind of person who hates to stop playing the game to walk and find resources, I appreciate everything this game is doing. I only have played 4 hours so far, but I agree, it is worth more than the $12 I paid.

I really enjoy the gameplay. It feels like it has a solid loop that doesn't leave you bored part of the way through. For firefights It actually takes some influences from Borderlands and improves them in ways that I enjoy.

The possible builds for damage feel varied. For builds I've melted enemies with rapid fire electric damage, chunked enemies with my precision-based fire weapons, spammed grenades at things, and increased the damage of my Cooldown skill significantly, all on one character in different runs. It's just nice to feel like everything has a use and I'm not just begging for a specific drop on a casual play through. 

I appreciate the progression. it feels like I will be a while before I have unlocked everything, and its based on how well you have done instead of a bunch of challenges like in Risk of Rain 2... I just know what I need to progress: just keep trying to beat it. 

Overall I enjoy it, and really I enjoy it more than Risk of Rain 2 right now.

review: I thought this game would be good but it needs some work, the bosses are almost impossible to kill from how long it takes to kill them and then they end up one hitting you by the time you've nearly killed them... game it way too difficult and not very fun either. I expected better from what I heard about it being like borderlands but personally this is nothing simular to borderlands. I can see how this game is like risk of rain, it has the same concept from it. You go into a level, you get loot drops from enemies, you can upgrade your abilities and fight through waves of enemies in levels then at the end there's a boss and if you die you start over from the beginning. Not the type of game for me, but worth a try.
developer_response: Using weapons with lightning damage can easily break BOSS's shield, and you can evade its attack behind the pillars. Hope you can beat the first BOSS soon! And we keep adjusting the game difficulty and game balance, please give us more time to polish. Thanks for your feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
The core game loop is very good.  Reminds me like borderlands multiplayer but roguelike game world vaguely reminiscent of TF2 MVM mode.   It has the occasional platforming element for bonus spells.  It's a little easy, but not too easy that you don't die regularly.   Overall very polished / balanced for a pre-release title.

One nice thing of note...  They make you grind to level 10 before going online. Things start getting more interesting around level 30, with character unlocks and bigger skill boosts.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
PROS :
Great Game for $12
Plenty of replayability
Just as good with friends
Cons : 
Netcode seems to be off. Boss and enemy animations seem to cut short especially for multiplayer. This is very noticeable in trap rooms with boulders too.
Many optimization issues. Too many deaths due to the game just stopping on a single frame and you have no idea how it happened. The game will get stuck on a frame, then you're hit with game over after 2-3 seconds. This needs to be fixed fast since it can make the game unplayable in the last zones where tons of enemies and particle FX can cause this issue. I can run AAA games just fine at 60fps. This issue is pretty much what makes me not want to play the game for hours on end since you know your run will pretty much end to bullshit. 

Still a good game overall.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Good game, has it's issues that hopefully will be solved when out of Early Access

Cons:
- First issue is probably the most important. This game does care about you learning how to play it. There are text boxes, sometimes, but there are complex mechanics everywhere in this game, and the game doesn't give a damn about teaching them to you.
- This game feels locked behind lots of grinding. Which is just super frustrating and annoying. 
- Not a lot of options how to play the game, it feels like. Only 2 characters, a handful of weapons (but you'll quickly find most of them don't really work for ones playstyle. I personally come back to the same ~5 weapons over and over), and a handful of scrolls that effect the game in a meaningful way.

Pros:
- Great artstyle
- Gameplay is, in general, fun and addicting
- Good use of talent trees, even if grindy
- Good variety in enemies, maps, and challenges
- Lots of content that slowly (through grinding) gets unlocked. Should be able to give you ~50 hours of content, I'd think.

review:
I don't play too many shooters so I was hesitant at playing this game in the first place. This game is definitely trial and error, but exploring and unlocking all of the scrolls and weapons is a real nice time trying to find your playstyle. For an early access game (7/12/2020) it is surprisingly polished and smooth. The only thing that really could use just a little bit more work on the descriptions in some of the inscriptions and other details, which is a given as the developer is from what I assume a company of Chinese origin. 99.8% is understandable, just when reading over certain parts it does make you take a step back and think for a moment. 

tl;dr Amazing game for an early access, just some small stuff lost in translation.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn is the lovechild of Risk of Rain 2 and Borderlands infused with a heavy dose of stylization that can only be described as Okami but Chinese with a heavy dose of chibi.

Gunplay is pretty standard, most weapons are projectiles but a good chunk of them have projectile speed fast enough to feel reasonably close to hitscan at close range, and as a result only really deterring the freshest of newcomers from taking longer shots, not to mention the weapons that are -actually- hitscan. The sound and visual design is what really helps sell this here, as the variance in weapons is closer to the first Borderlands, which felt like it was full of guns that happened to be slightly magic, than it does to the rest of the series which could fire pretty much anything out of a barrel for the sake of a joke or a shock to the player. This gives the game a more gritty dungeon crawler feel while still being darkly cute in its more blatant aesthetic.

Enemy variance is a little less interesting than you might think, you'll be dealing with melee guys, relatively low hp crawlers, grenade guys, tall skinny snipers, and heavies with either shields or close range high damage weaponry. The affix system ripped straight from Diablo III helps quite a bit here, as do some minor changes in how you have to interact with the enemies depending on how far into your run you are; the crawlers in area 2 are a lot larger and more powerful, but their size means their additional HP is basically worthless. The heavies from area 1 to area 2 become absolutely devastating, as they go from being large horse statues that mostly serve to annoy you in the middle of a fight to being large scary Roadhog lookalikes with flamethrowers that will nuke an unsuspecting player in the midst of a sniper duel.

Level design isn't necessarily exceptional but there's enough verticality and variance to room shape where I don't mind that I'm fighting in the same rooms a lot of the time. It helps that many rooms/chunks are locked to specific areas, which gives me hope for more rooms added down the line as more weapons are added and need to be accounted for. My only real complaint here is that the challenge rooms are very samey, especially the platforming sections. Platforming sections which require perfect dash and jump placement/timing, otherwise you have to start entirely over again, which turns to frustration quickly on even the shortest sections. We need more variance here, and we need some of these sections to have added hazards and more forgiving platform spacing. Less boulder rooms as they aren't difficult, they're only boring.

Weapon inscriptions, much like red text in Borderlands or any text in Diablo, add small bonuses to your weapon that can change  how you play and how viable your weapon is. This is great until you realize that you can only upgrade your weapon's damage, you can't change, buy, or affix further inscriptions. This can make finding your favorite gun early in a run  disappointing and depressing rather than exciting like it would be in a game like Synthetik: Legion Rising.

Overall, combat feels really good and even though I only bought this 2 or 3 days ago it's quickly become one of my favorite roguelites/roguelikes of all time. I hope that the characters get added with more interesting abilities and that maybe you get more options to what your dash ability can be as you level up. I hope that more guns that resemble Borderlands 1 get added, kinda like the Star Devourer or Concealed Ammo or Piercing Flame. The dev team would do well to skew damage scaling away from straight number-walling like Risk of Rain 2 as there is no organic leveling system, and skew it more towards interesting stacking with damage over time elemental effects like Borderlands or even Immortal Redneck, a game which clearly shares a lot in common with Gunfire Reborn.

My only complaint is regarding sounds. The gun sounds are good and make them pleasing to use, but almost everything else, enemy sounds, ability sounds, warnings, are too quiet and soft, and barely give any audio feedback. This could be subjective, but I've been spoiled by the overloaded audio design of other games such as doom and borderlands.

The only thing that lacks is some sort of prestige system or harder difficulties. I've reached level 100 (which isn't quite max yet) and the game is far easier now than it was when I was level 20. The skill tree is very rewarding which is great, but it makes end game fairly effortless. What I think there should be is an endless amount of difficulties that get much harder as they progress. Everything else about this game is incredible, don't even take what I said into account when you think about buying this game. Buy it.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
If you think you're going to like it, you're going to like it. And it's easily worth the money, even though it's in early access.

Notes:

Co-op isn't necessary; solo is a good experience.

Sensitivity goes from 1 to 100, so you probably won't be able to get just the right sens. In my case im forced to use 7 instead of 6.6.

It isn't possible to change viewmodel size. You can change your FOV though.

Some of the translations are poorly done. So understanding what things actually do, can be hard sometimes: It doesn't kill the game, just sometimes ruins your flow.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
[h1]Superb Shooter and Good Roguelite[/h1]

You like shootin' stuff?
You like lootin' stuff?

Then do not buy this game if you don't want to do anything else 'cause this game is addicting.

Even though, it's still in early access you can feel how well polished it is.

The combat feels amazing, it's fun shooting around with your guns. The feedback is great, the guns sound well, headshots sound different, the movement is responsive, all the tiny details have been taken care of. The enemies are also varied and make you prioritize some or change your strategy, which makes the combat so satisfying. And then there are 50 guns or so, which all feel different. This is a shooter well done.

The roguelike part of the game is also good. The RNG is balanced. You can beat the game just with the standard gun if you're really good and that's because of the solid shooter base this game has. Heck yeah, I almost beat the game only using my energy orb.

In the end, the randomness spices up the already solid gameplay. The game can feel a bit grindy, though. But once they add more heroes it should be better. It's still in early access. I mean some released games feel less finished than this one. It's also not an easy game, but you can always read a boss guide when you're stuck.



If you're interested, here's my first gameplay in an edited video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mKLDF_jFCD4

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I've only played 4h so far but I'm having a blast.

A Rogue-lite FPS with permanent upgrades similar to Rogue Legacy (+x% to damage, +y% money gained and such). The upgrades give a nice small goal to chase but aren't some must-have +100% damage or such.
There's different weapons you can find, think similar to an arena shooter. You basically find different weapon archetypes (not like in Borderlands where there's several dozen of each archetype). There's a burst rifle, a rocket launcher, a sniper, etc. Those weapons have random rolls on them (think Diablo or Borderlands) like more reload speed, bigger clip size and such and can be upgraded (like in many MMOs) to +1, +2, +3, etc. to increase their stats. There's also elements that work exactly like in Borderlands (fire is good against normal health, shock against shields, corrosive against armor). The mixture of the upgrade level, random rolls and elements give enough variety and force you to make some tough choices. Do you keep your favorite weapon which is rather weak or go for a super well rolled rocket launcher?
The weapons you find and some other ugprades will only last for the current run but they can be a pretty nice damage/defense increase while the permanent upgrades are smaller (like 5% more health).
The jump'n'run rooms are also a nice change of pace that will give you some bonus loot for the run.

Multiplayer was fine, didn't notice any problems so far. The built-in voice chat is surprisingly usable. It's not as good as something like Discord, but it's probably among the best in-game voice chats I've used. There is just a little bit too much gain on microphones so they peak when someone gets... too excited ;)

The game is in early access but I'd already consider this fully playable. Probably more polished than some games are at release these days.

I only have very few and minor negative points about this game so far:
* The music stops in the post-game screens which just feels weird
* When you're in the menu, the music auto-ducks when you speak (music gets more quiet). Nice in theory but in practice it's more annoying and it should active when OTHERS speak, not you
* I had one bug where there was one UI element on top of another, thus blocking it. Walking away and back fixed it, so really not a problem
* During loading screens the voice chat is not really usable. You can technically use it, but the others will probably only catch a fraction of what you're saying

None of these are really a big problem and since the game is still very frequently being updated, I expect those to change soon. More content also seems to be in the work, though I personally don't like buying games based on future promises. Fortunately the game is already very fun to play right now.

If you like Borderlands style shooters, Risk of Rain 2 style Rogue-lites and/or Rogue-lites with progression like Rogue Legacy, you will very likely enjoy this

review: If you like Borderlands and Risk of Rain 2, this is the perfect game for you. The guns have a unique feeling to them and every gun is viable. You unlock perks and skills by playing the game. It is a rogue lite, so you will be starting over a lot. But you can unlock certain passive skills with souls you collect while slaying enemies. That way there is a constant feeling of progression. title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/34564470-The-Awesome-Duo/]The Awesome Duo[/url]

This game sees continuous updates and the attention the developers are putting towards this game are amazingly positive.  Currently there are two characters to choose from, a cat or dog.  You'll play through 3 different worlds with multiple stages in each.  Fight enemies using a variety of weapons while choosing the right one for the task at hand.  The bosses you'll face at the end of each are varied enough to ensure each are offering a different experience.

As you play you earn soul shards which you can use to upgrade your character and perks.  The higher your level, the more perks.  The more perks, the easier it is to stay alive and the better your weapons will be.  

You can play solo, and that's fine.  But it excels when you're playing with other people.  With friends is great, but the matchmaking system is very good so you'll almost always find a group to play with in under a minute.  For those of you not wanting to share your voice with the world you can always type in your chat comments to your teammates now.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Honestly a great rogue life fps, but so far, the second boss, is unfair. Literally one shots you when you perfectly time a dash out. I don't get it. 

Biggest issue so far is the platforming, honestly its garbage. You can fail a lot of the hard challange modes for the vaults very often if you don't get percise top level BHOPing. On the second biome, its almost impossible to run through the hard sections, because for some reason my character cannot seem to be able to jump high at all. title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Let me explain one thing first: I am not your typical FPS fan. This is not my favourite genre. I am the kind of person who gets dizzy and nausea when playing FPS game. Even the badly rendered third person shooters makes me dizzy and lightheaded - Like Pubg.

But this game.. is okay. Its one of the rare FPS games that does not make me dizzy.

The game is a PvE coop game, which I do recommend playing with your friends rather than solo. Just buy multiple copies of this game and gift it to your friends. You'll have lots of fun.

You can also play with randoms via matchmaking, but I only managed to find games once. and if you're new, you'll be waaaaaay underlevelled that you might as well play a private game with your friends and have a good ping.

the AI is a fun challenge. They still behave predictably like an AI, but they have these unique moves that you have to learn to hit them effectively. Some enemies likes to jump a lot and others like to shoot you with large projectiles.

The main complaint at the moment was the bosses. Some of the bosses have insanely high HP when played multiplayer. Heck, the four of us can't even deplete the bosses' shield, let alone his actual HP. I'm okay with the bosses have his HP multiplied according to the number of players, but don't buff his shield too much :D

Also, why is the cost of reviving characters is so expensive (from stage 2 onwards) ? 
We've already have problem with the short timespan for your teammates to revive you.
Which basically means, if you die in the middle of a warzone, there is no way your teammates can beat the stage or beat the boss.

at least either reduce the cost to revive,
or increase the time to revive your teammates
or even better, allow your teammates to be revived for free prior to boss fight.

and also, I hope there is also a stage select so that not every time we have to start from the first stage.

This game is still in early access, and it does look promising.
hopefully the developers will continue supporting this game with more stages to play.
I'm hoping that we get at least 2 more characters - as playing with 3 - 4 cats with same skin and color palette is pretty meh.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Basically rogue-lite Broderlands with better gunplay and cute animals.

It is very similar to Isaac at the start, you barely have anything unlocked and it seems simple, but then you start getting all the achievements and unlocking scrolls, weapons and characters and it keeps getting better and better each run.
The progression might be slightly too much dependent on the "talent" tree, which is available after each run using the game's general soul currency you gather throughout the run. It outright adds health/shields/damage, making it objectively easier for the next run.
Not sure if they plan to change this later on but right now it seems that you either need ridiculous luck or have serious upgrades to kill a boss your first time around, or even complete new levels since you wouldn't know the attacks of new enemies and they can have the potential to one-shot you.

P.S. my specs are listed below:
Windows 10 Pro (64-bit)
CPU : Intel i7-4790K
GPU: nVidia RTX 2060 SUPER
RAM: 16 GB (DDR3 1866)

Edit 1 (July 10th): I've sent an email to the devs with information of my problem. We'll see how it goes.
developer_response: Sorry for any inconvenience. Please turn off Vertical Sync and increase your Maximum Framerate in the setting. If this still doesn't solve the issue, please record your screen in game and send it to qhstaff@2980.com. We will try our best to figure it out soon.

review: If you like Warhammer Vermintide and Deep Rock Galactic, then you'll like this game. I've played both games and liked them for a little while, but got burnt out eventually. 80 hours in DRG and 96 in Vermintide, but the last 15ish hours of both were just me trying to maintain interest, but couldn't. I definitely got my money's worth from both, and the same applies here. Got 18 hrs in so far and it feels as though I'll likely play close to what I've played from the other 2, but the game is still in Early Access, so can't say for sure atm. The other 2 games have more content in the amount/variety of levels( for now), but this has more variety( to me at least) in build and weapon variety. Highly recommend it, and I believe there's much here for the price. Devs are consistently updating too. This is a game where the gameplay trailer gives you a pretty good idea on if you'll like it or not. If it looks fun, you'll most likely enjoy it.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I bought this on a whim after watching Northernlion try it, and was immediately put off by the difficulty. I‚Äôm relieved I gave it a second chance because it‚Äôs extraordinary.

The movement is crisp and responsive, letting you bounce around the environments just a few feet ahead of enemy fire. The enemy pool may not be massive,  but it‚Äôs roster of baddies all play off each other to create an interesting flow of combat.

The difficulty is balanced on a razors edge, and as I learn new build possibilities (of which there are MANY for each character), weapons I had discarded as trash have come back around to become amazing, like the Prism in a crit build or the Infinite ammo Big Hippo dual wield build. Multiplayer is significantly more difficult then single player, even when just upped to a duo. So far I managed to clear the game solo, and I‚Äôve reached stage 3 but not completed the boss in multiplayer.

There‚Äôs one thing worth noting that detracts from the fun. The occasional unbelievably tanky unit that got defender and healing modifiers. I‚Äôd rather have a unit do more damage or run faster then an enemy that is easy to dodge on it‚Äôs own that simply takes 3 minutes to kill due to whatever reason. 

That being said, I haven‚Äôt had this much fun in a roguelite since Enter the Gungeon and am happy to see this enter the ranks. So far, the grind to get good enough and face that third boss is the most entertainment I‚Äôve had from any game in a while.

9/10 current, but I truly believe if they keep adding to content to this game that it will be 10/10. I can see myself playing this game for years to come.

review:
For 10‚Ç¨ it is a nice and entertaining game. It is still in early access and content-wise not that diverse BUT even then an game worthy to play and grind. 

Pros:
* easy to pick up
* can play with up to 3 friends or randoms (whatever you desire)
* different typs of builds (sniper, explosive and other; which crunch enemies)

Cons:
* jump and run parts feel slippery 
* translation is sometimes off or wierd (they are working on it)
* grindy in midgame (mostly only one lvl up after a run; which could annoy people who only play one run per day or less)
* some weapons aren't powerful enough to compete against the rest

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
The concept of the game is very simple which is basically you launch an instance (a run) and just shoot your way through 3 zones (each zone has multiple levels) and beat 3 bosses to complete your run.

[list]
    [*]There are current 2 heroes as of writing
    [*]There are a lot of guns and every gun dropped during a run has random attributes
    [*]Scrolls are available as well which add properties to your run (+move speed)
    [*]Additionally there's upgrades per level you complete to your current run
    [*]Outside of the run/instance you have a upgrade tree that is permanent
    [*]Two difficulties (normal and elite)
[/list]

Now the game is good for what it is worth I think everyone into some mindless shooter should buy this and just click some heads. What I will be doing here is critiquing the game even though I very much enjoy it, I think it could be much better.

So the first thing is the [b]heroes[/b].

What we see here is two heroes that share similar traits, they have dash and grenades. The only difference between the two is one heroes special skill is dual wielding and the other one throws a bomb that locks enemies in their position for some time.

From what it seems because dash seems to be a focus on level design and what concerns me is whether other heroes are just going to all have dash and variation of 2 skills or 1 skill plus different grenades.

I've played both heroes and frankly the primary skill is pretty much bound to a key I will never press because you don't need it. I think all 3 skills should be varied uniquely for the heroes.

For level design which is primarily the special levels you find, you can focus on level design for one hero with dash or movement speed to complete them (like dash button can be increase movement speed for some) and then other heroes that may have different speed, no dash or so can complete special levels differently depending on their unique skills.

This also applies for scrolls, so some scrolls apply to all or a subset of heroes while others are unique to them.

Like I'd say if the future heroes (if any) are to come and they all dash, they all throw a grenade but they just have one skill that is virtually unique, that's just samey-hero implementation from my point of view. I've got ideas like a hero should be able to charge their shield (while the shield is not rechargeable but they get twice the shield) and they get to teleport around the map (instead of dashing)

The second thing is [b]difficulty[/b].

The reality is, normal mode is harder than elite mode because you obviously don't have the upgrades (out of the instance) to support a stronger build so often you'll lose till you unlock things that really help in terms of say increasing health and damage. The other thing is, this but 5 of them are shared for all heroes.

Once you finish the game once, elite mode is available.

In elite mode you have a lot of supporting scrolls, immensely more coins and drops. It makes the game very easy because often you become overpowered.

Which isn't a bad thing because games like Slay the Spire, Monster Train and Risk of Rain 2 get to this point where you want to feel overpowered and just wipe ass sometimes.

So in terms of difficulty I'm not asking for the easy raise HP and damage, that's the lazy way out and that's called artificial difficulty. What I'd like to see is more ideas on traps because traps are a good way to implement difficult or change the event of a game.

For example, a flash bang trap would be kind of cool, white out the screen like a CS:GO flash if you stepped on the trap and didn't turn away in time. Then you have to have some memory of the map layout to jump your way back. 

At this point I think elite mode health and damage is in a good place. It just seems too easy to become overpowered but I also don't want this going away, I think a good balance is a 35-65 in being overpowered vs overwhelmed in elite difficulty.

The third thing is the [b]AI and shooting mechanics[/b]

There appears to be a hit reg issue, I've been noticing it not hitting and there's also issues with the AI getting stuck or not being aggressive.

In fact I think aggressive AI would increase difficulty more especially if you varied the way AI behaved because right now nothing poses a major threat if you just keep moving and kiting. The only one I am afraid of is that big blue thing that hooks you.

That is great implementation.

There's also weak spots that I think should be different per unit too, so far it's just headshots.

Finally I'll put some [b]positive feels[/b]

For the money spent, I played this for nearly 40 hours and will enjoy any content that comes. It's really chill to play. Now I don't know the road map but this game has got my moneys worth.

Let me just put this out there, Borderlands 3 was boring, for a game about shooters and story, the game was just mechanically boring. This game was more fun than Borderlands 3. I literally put more hours in this than I did BL3 because I had to quit since it was so boring.

Like I know about feature creep and that the community/myself have lots of ideas but you guys keep doing and working on your road map. It's a good game!!!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: Gunfire Reborn is fantastic. it has more, ' I guess you could call 'mini-games', which are very hit or miss ,while staying faithful to the show. It brings back great memories of the earlier seasons of Gunfire Reborn. The characters play and control really well, giving you the feeling of being a real ninja game. The game has a load of content to experience with each mission having bonus objectives for a bit of challenge if that's something you're into. Some of the challenges however can be a little annoying but for the most part these are finished within 2 or 3 tries. Each missions is ranked by difficulty from D to S with D being the easiest and S being hardest, providing a well balanced experience. Fun boss fights providing different variations in size and scale, making for some epic immerse boss fights as seen in the Anime. All and all I'd say Gunfire Reborn is a mild improvement over the first game and worth playing if you're a real Gunfire Reborn fan. Solid 9/10 Better Than Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice

I've found the cat character to be less consistent in runs than dog simply because you need to find an elemental weapon dominance pair, while dog you have to specifically go out of your way to do anything but explosives. They're both good though.

The game is fun, and has an enjoyable gameplay loop, so definitely worth the money.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: This game is a mix of borderlands and risk of rain with the combat flow of doom. All my favorites games combined into one. If you like unique guns, unique enemies, playing the same map over to unlock new abilities, and fast paced action then this is the perfect game for you. I'm addicted to this game, it's like playing minecraft in terms of how much time passes before you realize it's the next day and you've played all night. I definitely would like a bit more when it comes to the soundtrack, but besides that this game is awesome. I feel it has a really unique style that not many other games have and really shines in the gameplay. I think they tried to give it a little story and I think that is fine, it was obviously just to fill you in on what your doing. There is so much potential for the future of this game if the devs decide to expand more upon what they have here. It takes a bit to reach the endgame and unlock all the abilities and scrolls and guns, but I've only put in around 30 hours at the time of this comment and I've unlocked almost everything so I would like to see more added. After you have unlocked everything the map becomes much easier to progress through, even on elite mode. At this point though after unlocking everything or just about everything you will want to play multiplayer part of this game because it does start to get repetitive after a while by yourself. Overall though this has been my favorite game so far this year and I would rate it 9/10.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: This one is pretty borderline, but I gotta go with a thumbs down.  As of right now, the game is just not very much fun.  They have a decent set of rougelike mechanics in place, but there's really nothing stellar.  I've seen these systems before, and they work fine, without being adventurous or innovative.  A couple of critical mistakes I think were made that make this a bit of a ho hum title.  The theme is just all over the place.  It's a mystical ancient Asia vibe, but very generic and kind of lack luster.  Then the characters, which are...animals?  I guess?  But they have guns, kind of.  Magic guns maybe?  I dunno, I'm not really given much to work with on that front.  Enemies are some kind of golem things, which is fine.  Works well enough.  My biggest problem is that there's just nothing to latch onto.  The theme could work, and really well, they just haven't given me any reason to care about it.  No gameplay tie ins, just the playground we are sent into.  It really doesn't make a lot of sense to me and there's just nothing about it that I can resonate with.   This just feels like a kind of half hearted version of Ziggurat.  Gameplay is there, and could be solid with some tweaking of their upgrade system, but as is this game is boring after a single run and I find myself wondering if I'll even break 10 hours played on it.

review: Well.. this is a good game. It's simple and intuitive while leaving room for players to master the mechanics and build paths providing via scrolls picked up. The game reminds me of binding of isaac, if it were a first person shooter with more emphasis on skills and damage scaling vs. ability augments themselves. For early access, I've found myself able to play for 22 hours so far with or without friends. It's great mindless fun, without feeling cheap or too repetitive. Probably one of the best roguelites i've seen in a while, and it's in early access! Keep up the good work.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I've been craving a game like this for YEARS. This game is a first person rogue-like shooter that is a fusion of borderlands and risk of rain 2. The gun effect variety still could use some improvement- but the game is still early in it's development and the developer has stated himself that he hopes to add more abilities, scrolls, weapons (of which there are already many), and more weapon effects- so it's not likely to be an issue for too much longer.

The gameplay is incredibly addicting, when you first start leveling your character making it beyond the first series of dungeons (and especially the first "boss") can be difficult- especially when you factor in the RNG of getting an exceptional weapon or scroll, but that all builds into the charm of the game. In my 13 hours played I have managed to reach level 45 and have nearly beat the third of four currently existing dungeons- I'm not sure what happens beyond that given the difficulty of the boss fights. In addition to dungeon sweeping there are little portals that provide additional challenges in the form of mini-boss rooms and platforming challenges that are quite fun. The gun's feel great- though I'm still not a big fan of a couple of the existing weapons and hope they are further balanced in the future to make them more useful (looking at you cavalry), but as of the latest patch those balances are already coming across.

All in all I can't recommend this game enough. Whether you intend to play with yourself, 3 other friends, or just utilize the online matchmaking- the game is simply an incredible experience and easily worthy of it's price of $11 (honestly, having played it I feel its worth at least $29.99 even in it's current form). I can say without a doubt that this is my game of the year for 2020 so far.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Crazy amount of replay value for only $12!

Guns are well thought out from a design point of view, and the developers have been making nice adjustments for the weaker weapons to make them feel better. It feels like there's a flavor for everyone and the Occult Scrolls and Ascension Tree really help augment how powerful your weapons feel.

Excited to see them add more randomness and depth to the stage levels but otherwise the layouts are pretty standard at the moment. Although at the time of this review it is still currently Early Access and they have stated that this is something they are working on!

Progression system is enjoyable and each point in the talent system feels impactful. The only criticism I have of it from playing is how slow it feels to start. It takes several hours and a handful of runs to start getting the ball going in terms of levels and unlocking guns and whatnot. After you hit level 30 the power curve starts feeling much better but it does feel almost like a wall in a way until you level up enough. I'm concerned it may impact how a new player would feel about the game since they may just feel like it's impossible and never get to the point where they can have fun.

Overall, I think this game is phenomenal and I have a lot of fun each run! Most games that reach the end of the stage take approximately 40-60 minutes and when you have a build going the payoff feels great when you're mowing down masses of wolves and catfishes and golems!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Obliterating everything in sight with dual wielded mini-gun and rocket launcher that shoot endlessly from my reserves as a bandit pupper really made me love these randomized looter games, and I will tirelessly seek out that level of gameplay forever.

+cartoonish artstyle
+satisfying gameplay with weapons, abilities and mobility

-you start to know the level layouts quickly even if they are thrown at you in different orders and the timed puzzles are always the same
-lacking in characters to choose from.

This game is far from some kind of Borderlands roguelite game, but it was well worth the time I spent on it. Because it is in early access, I expect a lot more content in the future. Some refinement could make this game go from "worth the buy" to "absolute must"

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I bought this during the Summer Sale, and it was probably one of the best purchases I've made since I've been on Steam.

A lot of the weapons are comfortable to play with and can always switch up gameplay with different combinations of weapons in your current arsenal. And as every upgrade and perk are randomised, every run can play out differently.

There's also quite a bit of replayability too, especially with the unlockable weapons/perks. When you unlock them, the enemy you kill afterwards always drops that unlocked weapon/perks, giving you a chance to try it out and see how it functions. Even when I fail a run, I still get the satisfaction that I unlocked something in that run.

I still have quite a bit of the game to go through (I'm only around Level 26 or so by the time I've posted this review) but if you have the chance to, pick this up if you like Roguelite FPS games, you won't regret it. The game is still in early access, so expect more and more content to come.

Keep up the good work, devs!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I can already tell I'm going to sink a lot of hours into this game. The gunplay is fun, the variety of upgrades and guns themselves always leave you choosing what to take and what to leave, and I love the idea of having your upgrade points also be the points you use to revive yourself, to make you think if its worth it cashing in now, or pushing on to see if you can unlock more.

The game is already extremely polished, and during my time playing it, hitboxes were fair and glitches were non-existent. I know the game is only in Early Access at the moment, but it will definitely benefit from adding more content as it updates (which I don't doubt they plan to do).

If you love those "one more run" Roguelikes,and you're looking for one that yes, you can play with friends, pick this up.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I'm using this game as aim training and seeing what builds I can get away with. At the time of writing, i've died a bunch, but got my character to level 25 with the special currency. I've managed to kill the first boss after many failures and misunderstandings. Haven't reached the second boss yet, but i'm slowly getting better.

The store page describes the main aspects of the game. Some enemies drop a special currency called Soul Essence. Like money, it will only last for the run. However, you can use it to either revive yourself or save up to upgrade your character's skills at the end of a run. Skills slowly start getting more expensive. Soon, i'll have to kill the first boss consistently if i want to upgrade. It's slightly annoying, but i understand how they want progression to go. Roguelites like this are all about replayability and honing your skills in order to get more unlocks and better loot.

I've only played this game solo. It does have 4p coop. I'm unaware of how the loot and items work; if the drops are client-side (diablo 3) or if the drops show up for everyone (borderlands 2). I've been having a lot of fun with the weapon variety and the different builds i've attempted. I'll have to see how the other character plays when mine reaches level 30. 9/10

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Don't get fooled by the "Early Access" tag on it, this hidden gem is fun to play, dabbling brilliantly in the concoction of  the best bits of looter-shooters: guns and stats.

Although Gunfire Reborn doesn't bring anything particularly new to the table, it certainly feels like a smart and fun game with the goal of making you feel powerful without wasting too much time getting there. Things are kept simple and familiar - enter a room, fill up the baddies with bullets, loot, repeat. Chests are scattered about, containing Hero Enhancements, ammo and copper, and the occasional Occult Scroll which aim at modifying your stats or opening up new passive abilities as a way to change up play styles.

Great and fun game, even more so if you have mates that are willing to tag along for the ride.

review: Stupid fun game for some reason, with friends or solo. Gameplay is an FPS with abilities in a room-based layout. So far when writing this, there's only two heroes but I can see two more coming (? or not), first one's a CC-type hero who can freeze enemies in place, second hero is literally Salvador from Borderlands 2, down to the abilities that he has. title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
TLDR:
Expect to repeat the same ridiculously easy content over and over again, just to make it to the weirdly difficult and tedious boss fight, die, and start over. 

I want to like the game, but in its current state, it is more frustrating than fun, at least for solo play. Combat is like playing borderlands, except you can only walk, and your dodge is short, single-use, and has a cool-down.

For the random mob encounters, this isn't a problem. Some people call it "rogue-like" and you can play it that way, I suppose, except mobs can see you through walls, and will fire endlessly at that wall, like it isn't there/. Still, I was having fun taking out the random mobs and finding gear to improve. 

However, this all changes for the very first boss fight. You walk into an open arena with some big monster-dude remote-AOE-slamming the ground beneath your feet, trying to jump on your head, and throwing attacks at you from afar. 

The fight takes multiple rounds, requires timed dodges that get more difficult each round, is way too long, and is overall unforgiving.  To add to the fun (frustration) your character moves horribly slow and your dodge, which is crucial for survival, is single-use and on a long cool-down. Seriously, it makes no sense to have the very first boss fight be so tedious and difficult. 

To the Devs, I would recommend...

- Adding a few health pick-ups during long boss fights
- Reducing the radius of the boss's attacks OR increase the dodge distance/speed of the player
- Allowing for 2 dodges before going on cool-down (like DOOM)
- Increase the player's speed by 25%-50% overall
- How about making the very first boss fight a little less of a PITA?

I will try the game again later, or maybe co-op. I have heard coop is easier compared to playing solo. If things improve I'll revise my review :/.
developer_response:
Thanks for your feedback. The first Boss is a bit difficult to beat, and we are aware of this. Here are some suggestions for you to play against it: 
1. Use Shift to dash timely and carefully. When you see the alert zone, you should move outside of it with dash immediately. 
2. You can hide behind those pillars to avoid some attacks.
 3. You can easily break the shield of Boss with lightning damage weapons. After that, you can use fire damage weapons to kill Boss easily.
 4. You can try to play with your friends, so you can be revived even though you are knocked down. In addition, you can upgrade your defensive talent. Thanks!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I thought I could get an EA game once more, trusting user rating... but there are no real roadmap.

First : nice game loop, and introduction/immersion to game. Ennemy animation are ok, and they have varied/mixed behavior routines. I haven't met game breaking bugs at this point.
It was fun for the 2-3 first hours. Apparently they are platform puzzles, later in game...

But I actually don't want to invest more time on it, so I regret purchasing it.

Game needs polishing, especially awkward UX/UI, like link to change current save or make a new one, located in the game quitting confirmation dialog... 
is UI a puzzle game on its own??

Or useless confirmation dialogs that either have no impact after death as whatever you answer you get redirected to end screen... or else...

Several typos (in localized version), but they are kinda expected in EA games.

Due to numerous suggestions to make in basic in-game form, i have joined their Discord for better process, submissions and exchanges.
At my first UI suggestion, it got deleted and argued by one of mod saying their solution was the best possible, so I left it to their own...
That kind of communication must explain some UI things...
developer_response: Sorry for your bad experience. We will optimize UI and fix other issues, please give us more time. Thanks for your feedback!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Good gunfeel, and gets the "just one more run" aspect right. Not very creative, as in it's a shameless mish-mash of gameplay ideas and styles, but it executes them (mostly) well. 

Very early access though, environments are barren, UI is extremely basic, and the English is incredibly broken, making simple item descriptions difficult to understand sometimes, but I expect these to be improved. 

The main issue for me is the main progression system, which they really need to change IMO.  Losing "unused" points between rounds is really frustrating, when let's say the cheapest available upgrade costs 30 points, then the 29 points I gathered that run will be useless, making the run essentially a waste of time.

Dead Cells got it right: the upgrades/items needed more points, but even if you only collected 5 points that run, you could still pour that into an ability's unlock bar, meaning you still progressed, even if only a little. Literally the devs should just   copy that.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Not in great shape at the moment...presentation and UI feels a bit bare bones...not a lot of detail or creativity in the art design overall. It feels a bit empty and lacking not only in the presentation but also in the story telling and tutorial. Just feels like it's not ready yet...and what is there feels a bit obvious and...boring! :/

I do like early access but compared to most recent releases i have purchased none of them have felt as "bare bones" as this game. I played 20 mins and enjoyed the gun feel but the presentation looks worse than most early access games I've played. It's similar to that FPS roguelike based around pyramids (cowboy something?) and also Ziggurat...but they are getting old now and they still look a lot better than this game...a lot better!!

It's got potential but i've gotta be honest...the first impressions were very quick and immediate: "This game is not ready yet...and feels so damn empty and lacking in almost every aspect!" When played after Hades, Curse of the... and even indies like Noita...it just feels like i need to give it more time in the oven...

The UI and overall presentation though need some serious attention!! The graphics are not that important in a game like this but when the art direction is so bland it means the lack of textures and decent lighting make it feel like a tech demo...not a game!! It really needs some personality...something to give it more identity.

Will rewrite this review in 6 months or so...
developer_response: Thanks for your interest, we will add more content and optimize the gameplay&UI in the future update, stay tuned.

title: Gunfire Reborn

You won't regret it, unless the devs go off the deep end and put lootboxes in it or something (I don't expect this to happen, but if it does, I will update my review).

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
[REVIEW WRITTEN IN EARLY ACCESS]   Gunfire Reborn is a First Person Shooter (FPS) Rougelite. Meaning you shoot stuff, die, get permanent upgrades then try again. So far the game has two characters; a dog and a cat.
The cat specializes in elemental damage, which deals extra damage to certain health types. They have a grenade that spews corrosion gas, which inflicts more damage to yellow health. They also have an ultimate ability that deals damage and stuns enemies. Then, there is the dog who survives less easy, but specializes in damage. They have a grenade that explodes on impact for heavy damage. They also have an ultimate ability that lets you use both of your weapons and fire them at the same time.

  Speaking of Weapons, the weapons are very diverse, having some deal having amount of damage, some having big explosions, and others dealing massive damage with elemental damage. 

  Being a Rougelite, you will go through randomly generated levels, and when you die go back to the start of the game.... wellll not exactly, through the game, you get soul essense which you can use on getting permanent upgrades. 

 Overall I recommend this game for sure, especially at the current price of $12.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn is a first person Rogue shoot em up which is unlike any dungeon crawler I have ever played.
The game has 5 rooms on each level. 4 have normal enemies and 1 has a boss fight.
As you progress through the level you get dropped weapons and item boosters that can help you when at the final fight.
The game reminds me of dungeon defenders but with guns and siege weapons and more of a Battleborn finish to it, which is a good thing.

BE WARNED: This game is immensely hard, especially when first starting out. You WILL die over and over again, but you wont mind as each time you feel like youve achieved something, for when you die you can use essence points to permanently upgrade your chosen character, in return making the next run slightly easier.

The boss fight that ive got to currently is challenging but feels well executed and doesnt suffer from some of the other tropes that bosses in other games have. (invincibility phases, impossible to dodge AOE moves etc.)

The co-op aspect works really well although it would have been nice to have dedicated servers.

Their is no real story to this game but I guess thats to be expected for a game that costs less than ¬£10

The guns all feel unique and each one has a purpose in combat. Sometimes you will get to a final fight and realise you dont have the correct weaponry for the job which makes you change up the way you play and causes you to think smarter about how to approach certain scenarios.

Overall GR is a shining example of a simple, but effective early-access title that respects the playerbase its aimed at and provides fun and ever-changing games.

9/10

review:
Fun as a solo game - does have a decent progression feel. There's two "classes" but only one of them is really worth using without serious luck on item drops.

The occasional cheap death from some badly balanced enemies takes some fun out of it and a few weapons in need of a purpose to exist over similar weapons (Looking at you, Concealed Ammo SMG)

The game is pretty fast paced otherwise and in combat you need to stay moving if you're not behind hard cover. The bosses seem cheap until you get used to them and then they become mostly trivial if the RNG gods have blessed you with useful items.

It's enjoyable.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Singleplayer review: 

Like all permadeath roguelites this will never have enough content to not get stale after a certain time. 

All in all this is bad graphics and great game mechanics. When it comes to builds there is a lot of moving parts here. 
The gunplay seems solid. The AI isn't entirely braindead which is always a plus. Also these big heads are a lot of fun.
I didn't have the impression of missing out on content for playing solo. 

Price of 10 bucks is fair imo. 

There may be balancing issues and an ugly ingame UI right now but the foundation is as solid as everyone says it is. 

Buying this game certainly wasn't the worst i could have done with that money.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn is an arcade shooter.
The game is a ton of different weapons, that play completely different.
There are skills that greatly effect tankyness and damage output. After each stage the player gets to choose between three randomly selected skills. This makes the game differnt each run and forces the player to adapt to the skills he gets.
The multiplayer mode is funny as well.

the only downside of the game is the balance between firerate, damage and so on of each weapon. But this is easy to fix during early access, so no reason to not buy the game!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
So having played this game for 20 hours thus far, I want to give my initial impressions.

Gameplay: 
This game is buttery smooth when playing and the shooting feels incredibly satisfying, I'm not going to make the same comparison others have saying its a mix of Borderlands and (insert game here), because its not in my eyes. The only real comparison to Borderlands is the cel-shaded art style and damage numbers above enemies... That's the only real comparison. This isnt a loot grinding game, you don't keep any of the loot you get on a run apart from what is essentially XP to level your character and unlock new perks.

If you're unsure of this game think of it as Slay the Spire: FPS Edition. You continuously get power ups throughout the game making certain aspects of you stronger and sometimes weaker, you have to carefully select which different scrolls you pick up to maximise your damage and make it through a level.
Selecting which guns you use isn't something to give much thought in the early stages, but later down the line you NEED to in order to progress and take down the tougher enemies in quick fashion.

Graphics: 
The games minimal but clean cel-shaded style is beautiful :)

Performance: 
This differs from PC to PC on any game but for me it ran flawlessly with no hiccups or a single crash thus far, great optimisation.

Pros: 
Co-op upto 4 players.
Looks and runs great.
Can be good for the strategically minded.
Addictive gameplay loop(for the most part, read on).
Cheap.

Cons:
The maps change layout each time but you will see the same rooms again and again, can be repetitive.
Difficulty spikes can throw some players off.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Boy oh boy, where to begin with this gem. I'm closing in on the good 5 hour mark and I'm already 10 levels away from the secondary character, doggy boy gunzerker.

Pros:
>Lots of replayability, with semi-random levels

>Weapons. Hoo boy, lots of weapons

>More weapon drops based on what you do

>4 player co-op

>No need to worry about your friends stealing all your loot, it's individually rolled. You'll get a different weapon than your friends, and they'll only be able to take it if you drop it.

>Every run is different. One run you'll have a blackhole gun that shoots 3 different projectiles and an ability that heals you for every bit of damage you do, the next you'll be rocking an aimbot gun with an ability that does extra critical damage.

>Enemy health, shields, armor, etc. scales with how many players there are so they're not a joke. Still a challenge with a full 4 players.

>Constantly growing in strength, soon with the ability to start with a weapon other than the Foundry. (starting weapon)

>Vaults are great challenges to get you occult scrolls, which are ultimately the determining factor of how well your run will go.

Cons:
>Previous area enemies are somewhat forgotten. If they reappear in later areas, I'm unaware of that, let me know if I'm wrong.

>Fight an enemy once and you always have a viable strategy to beat them. You won't find a horsehead enemy that has special buffs or anything, so you can just restrain them with the Crown Prince's E power, then blow them away with an Argus shot to the head.

>Enemy damage outputs become bullshit quickly. Say bye to your shield and 3/4 of your health within 5 seconds, even if you have full on both.

>Lu Wu aggros almost indefinitely on a player in multiplayer until they're downed. It might be the same with later bosses, as well, but once again, it's hard to get further than the desert when enemies can one-tap you.

>Lack of vault variations.

Overall? Good game. Most of the points in the cons are just there because it's still quite a new game, and one in early access, on top of just being my personal preference for a game. I have no doubt in my mind that the devs will continue expanding on some of the areas.

It's a pretty fun game. In short: It's a roguelite, you level up by leveling up your skill tree. And that's it, really. title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Where do I start with this... 

I started off unsure, the roguelite genre was never my thing but the simplicity + the grind within this game is something I clinged onto fast, it's tough to get the hang of, but once you understand how it all works it's an extremely enjoyable game.

So many scrolls, so many builds to try from movement speed and attack to defensive and tank-y. It's something I massively enjoy personally after a fair few hours in the game, I recently completed elite mode and it's an amazing feeling when you commit to a grind like this game, I still have a few guns and scrolls to unlock but when that's all done I will be attempting speed-runs and messing around with builds.

Overall, this game is by far the best I have played in a long time, the reviews are overly positive for a reason and I can vouch for that. It's an early access game, too. This hopefully means new content is coming with time, and a whole lot of it, hopefully.

9/10 in my opinion, just needs some new content because I have finished it, as many others have.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: So, this is my very first steam review. I got this game because my brother said it would be fun. I went into to it not expecting much but was actually very happy with what I got! The game is insanely fun with many different combos that you can do each time you go through, For a beta, there is a solid amount of content in the game. It is very easy for a new player to pick up and go. Thought there are a few cons, sometimes enemies will do inconsincant attack patterns, the jumping can be a bit buggy in my time played, there is some odd clipping that can happen when doing the jump puzzles which is really aggravating cause it will feel like you get cheated from more loot. Also there are only 2 playable characters at the moment who are very different, tho IMO the cat is a far better character due to its Kit being able to do elemental damage, and all the skill trees work together well where as the dog, the skills don't mesh together that great (mostly due to the fact the he has 0 way to do elemental DMG on his own, and the sever lack of decent explosive weapons). Thought I do think these issues can be fixed/changed. I personally think the dog could get fire damage on his nades, and maybe they could add another roll for weapons allowing explosive rounds at the cost of mag size. I am not a dev. but these are just small ideas that could work. Also I do belive based off the art work there will be another character that is a bird and that would be neat. The gun play and fights are actually really fun, and playing with friends is SUPER fun with all the crazy elemental and weapon conbos you can do. Overall I HIGHLY suggest getting this game if you like rouge like shooters, The game is very fairly priced, the art is amazing and the gameplay for the most part is really fun, The game i can most compare this is Enter the Gungeoun, which is another really fun rouge like shooter. But again, try this game out, I think you will enjoy it!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is way too fun for the price. Here's a breakdown of what it plays like:

It's a simple FPS rogue-lite; you progress through 3 different zones, each zone broken down into several levels, and the last level is a boss fight. If you die, you get to spend some points to improve yourself before trying again. If you win, you get to spend more points. Currently, you can play as one of two characters, each with a distinctly different playstyle. It can be played in coop, and it's very synergetic and fun (more on that below).

Each level has potential of having optional side areas that can be a simple fight, a mini-boss encounter, an obstacle course, or a platforming puzzle. These are always worth doing, as they will give you extra loot. There's also an NPC traders and crafters where you can buy and improve equipment.

You fight using weapons, skills, and grenades. All attacks can be enhanced with elemental damage - elemental damage can also proc, and combining procs will result in satisfying effects. 

Progression during a run consists of scrolls, and ascensions. You start each run without any of either.
- Scrolls are found around the level in a variety of ways - killing certain enemies, looting certain chests, buying them from npc peddlers, etc. The effects can be positive (+40% run speed after dash), sacrificial (double shield, but health is capped at 1), or cursed (-50% accuracy). Most of the positive and sacrificial scrolls can be dropped, while cursed scrolls can't, but you will never "accidentally" get a cursed scroll - you get it through conscious decisions. 
- Ascensions are improvements to your skills, grenades, or elemental damage. They are earned at the end of each level, or very rarely during an optional side area called a vault. You choose one of 3 upgrades picked at random from the character's pool of 18 upgrades, and each upgrade is tiered.

With all of the above mechanics combined, you can make some very interesting builds, such as:
- heavy elemental damage
- infinite-ammo bullet hose, 
- long-range sniper
- close-range tank
- high-crit damage dealer
- etc
However, given the RNG nature of rogue-lite games, you're forced to experiment with new builds in each run, which can yield some very surprising results.

Coop is very satisfying. The enemies are tougher, and more abundant. Loot is instanced, so you won't fight with your partner over weapons and scrolls. Also, each person's instance has randomized loot, so if an enemy drops a weapon, one person might see an smg, while the other might see a rocket launcher (same goes with scrolls), so it's possible to help each other work on certain builds by communicating.

Overall, the only thing i find lacking is content - I want more of this game. However, the amount that I got from the current price tag ($12 CAD) is already amazing.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Not normally much of a reviewer but this one really deserves to be called out. Very fun rogue-like FPS with a well designed elemental combat system and some really fun weapons. Just as I started to get bored of it, finished a full run and unlocked the Elite difficulty - no enemy stat boosts in sight here, just a lot more enemies and more challenging hazard-filled arenas to fight through. Felt like you'd unlocked the 'real game' here and I have to give credit for anyone adding difficulty this way instead of the standard HP/damage buff.

A little shy on content just now (plenty of creative weapons and playstyle-defining character buffs to be had, but only two characters and three tilesets to play through) but an incredibly solid base to build on. Haven't had this much fun on constant replays since Risk of Rain 2.

A note that the English translations can be a bit... interesting but it's always clear what something does. Honestly just think it's kind of part of the charm at this point.

You enchance the weapons that aren't performing well, you don't nerf the weapons people enjoy. Stupid Devs, stupid game. Do not recommend. 0/10 would not even install. Deleted from my Steam library.
