title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is a lot of fun, but there's only three bosses and two playable characters. You'll see everything on your first day, and you'll unlock your whole tech tree (or pretty close to it) after about 20-30 hours, depending on skill. If you know you'll need more content then that, you should let the game ripen a little before you buy it, I have to assume that they have more planned later down the line.

Otherwise, it's pretty good in single player or multiplayer, and pretty easy to get into a group, at least at this time; it just came out a month or two ago. Check for more recent reviews if you're reading this far into the future.

If you're looking for more of an idea how it plays than what you saw in the trailer, then... well, there just isn't much more to it. The game is really minimalistic.

You shoot the bad guys, the levels are procedurally generated, and after each zone you get to pick a skill to upgrade your character. You'll find random weapons with random attributes, that may or may not fit your build, and after each death you can spend collected SP to get permanent bonuses on future runs. There's also a very simple elemental system (shields are weak to electricity, health is weak to fire, and armor is weak to acid) but that's pretty much it...

Shoot things. Level up. Grab loot. Repeat. If that sounds like a good time, then you'll like it, but if you need something with some more depth, then you may want to pass on this one.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
An fps roguelike with emphasis on gaining strength through death. Think Rogue Legacy. There are currently 2 character's ingame and it takes about 3-6 hours of gameplay to unlock the second one. Each character will has 2 abilities and a bunch of passives that drop from enemies killed. Weapons are unlocked by killing certain types of mobs or progressing a certain amount. 

Playing solo allows you to fly through the start but after that it becomes a slog. Multiplayer is a bit risky and there aren't too many playing atm. 

Very high replay value due to you constantly gaining power as you get further and further but you will face walls that just require grinding to get down. 

It's a bit of fun in the beginning and I recommend it as it's not done yet and has a potential to get really more and more solid.

More fun with friends but playable without them.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
What can you say about Gunfire Reborn?

First Impressions: Immediately fell in love with the cell-shaded art style. It has a pretty lack-lustre story to begin (early access at the time of writing review, so I can see something like this being fleshed out much more in the future), however the gameplay itself is what makes this game so GOD DAMN ADDICTING. Needless to say, I was quite happy with my $10 purchase. 

Gameplay: Absolutely fluent gameplay. Very straightforward control layout (keyboard, not a controller kind of guy) and just feels very polished for an early access game. I'm not going to go to far into abilities, simply because there is SO MANY abilities. Weapon choice is very diverse and every weapon feels like they serve a purpose in gameplay (had a great time so far putting killer combinations together). But by far, without a doubt, the greatest element of this game is replayability! I quite strongly HATE grindy games, however this game often rewards you for the effort you put in, and it never feels like a chore. I'm sure once I max level this will change, however with the often changing landscape and mob situations I'm sure I won't be bored of this game for a long time. 

Aesthetics: Beautiful game to look at, cell-shading has always been a favourite of mine but if it's not your bag I get it. The sound production is really well done, not too much going on even in intense situations; I'd say just enough to put you on edge in intense situations, but not enough to make you want to mute and turn on your own music. Music is pretty bland, at least in the title screens/loading/etc. but during gameplay isn't too intrusive and seems to set the appropriate tone for what's happening/about to happen. 

Bosses: SPOILER ALERT (possibly?) Anyway, interesting boss fights, difficult at first but with experience and levelling yourself up they start to become easier and easier (still haven't made it to final boss, however I usually only play solo and look forward to playing with other players in the hopefully near future). Once you get the patterns down, they can easily be solo'd.

Final Thought: If you're even remotely considering getting this game, just do it. The price is (very) right, and if you like FPS titles of any calibre, then this will be a great addition to your collection. Fun solo, and (more than likely) even more fun with friends! I'm really looking forward to the future of this game; it looks very bright, and exciting. 

Rating: Gunfire Reborn is a SOLID 8 / 10 (not too shabby for an early access title).

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: More neutral than negative but the overwhelmingly positive review average is very misleading. This game is just ok. 6 out of 10 IMO. Enemies become bullet sponges (even worse in multiplayer) and many weapons and scrolls are useless. Movement speed is too slow, especially when holding heavy weapons. Runs quickly become repetitive, yet you're expected to grind runs ad nauseam to level up your skill tree and make runs less tedious. I gave the devs feedback but there's a language barrier that resulted in them thinking I meant the game lags when I really meant the overall pace of the game is too slow. The update today was a tiny step in the right direction, but generally speaking the game still feels just as tedious as before.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/23741321]Follow our curator page[b] Alexander's Club Curations[/b], if you like and want to see more reviews like this one.[/url][/quote]

[h1]Overview[/h1]
Gunfire Reborn is a semi-randomly generated singleplayer and online co-op first-person shooter with tons of enemies, unique weapons, character perk upgrades, and passive skill-tree investments. 

[b]The Good[/b]
- Lots of weapon types
- Great enemy variety
- Much to unlock
- Massive skill tree
- Powerful perk synergies
- Stable online co-op

[b]The Bad[/b]
- Imperfect writing/English translation
- Minimal variation in level segments
- Only three bosses
- Four-player co-op with two playable characters
- Skilltree unlocks could be arranged better
- Progression in the skilltree can feel too slow

[b]Buy or Try[/b]
- "Buy" at full price or on sale, you can't go wrong

[b]Stability[/b]
- No crashes, graphical anomalies, sound issues, or framerate drops
- Occasional rubber-banding when played online (depends on ping of other users)
- My System: Windows 10, i7-7700 @ 3.60GHz, 16GB ram, 1060 3GB, played at 1920 x 1080

[h1]Description[/h1]
Still in Early Access, Gunfire Reborn tasks you with beating a series of three chapters, each concluded with an epic boss fight. Each chapter is composed of a series of levels, with each level composed of randomly chosen, interconnected room (arena) segments. While the first chapter is made up indoor environments, the subsequent chapters switch to outdoor locations, some being quite spacious. Each room segment or "arena" locks you in until you have defeated all the enemies inside. Backtracking is possible if you so desire. Enemies encountered, room conditions, vendors, weapons, and secret "vaults" are randomly strewn about each chapter. Room conditions can modify enemies in minor but interesting ways. They also provide an extra item drop upon the area's completion. Vendors come in two variants, a general merchant selling health, ammo, and weapons, and a weapons merchant, selling weapon upgrades of different types. 

"Vaults" are secret areas accessed by shooting at cracks in walls found during regular play. These areas are the primary source of scrolls, which are passive upgrades (or curses) which can modify your play but are lost upon death. Vaults vary the most in terms of differences to standard shooting. Some act as obstacle courses requiring timed sprints between moving boulders, or timed jumps across tricky platforming segments. All of them are optional. All loot, including scrolls, grenades, ammo, weapons, and player perks can drop randomly, as well as be discovered in chests. All vaults contain at least one chest which unlocks upon completing the task for the area. There are only two playable characters (so far) and both share the same skill-tree. You won't have access to the second until you reach level 30. 

Gold is collected during runs and is used to purchase items and upgrades from vendors. Essence is another currency, dropped from defeated enemies. Whether you play singleplayer or co-op, you can spend essence to revive yourself once during a single game. While at first essence collects slowly, by around level 60 you can easily collect 150 or more essence per run. Essence is spent after each run on passive upgrades in your skill tree. Unspent essence cannot be banked, unless you invest in certain skill-tree unlocks.

Each character can carry three weapons, a default gun with infinite ammo, and two which can be swapped out at will, reliant on specific ammo types. Weapons can be upgraded (leveled up) during runs, increasing their damage. Investments in the skill-tree can also provide a percentage chance that found weapons will possess additional bonuses. Guns will be replaced frequently, particular by new players still trying to learn which ones they prefer. Certain enemies and bosses are suspectible to specific types of elemental damage, made all the more important during co-op runs when trying to synergize your specialities with other online players. Outside of the shared skill-tree, each character has a linear, smaller upgrade path unique to them.

Apart from weapons are cooldown-dependant abilities and throwing projectiles. The starting player specializes in elemental damage, with throwable smoke bombs that slow and corrode enemies who linger within their area of impact. Its special ability shoots a ranged attack that immobilizes foes for a few seconds. These powers contrast to the second playable character. Its special is the ability to dual-wield weapons for a time, with its grenades serving as contact explosives. Both grenades and special powers can be further applified during runs by perks. Within blue chests and sometimes dropped by enemies, goblets grant a player a selection of one of three perks. Each perk belongs to one of three perk categories, with each level of the perk (up to three), granting additional improvements. 

[h1]Critique[/h1]
Gunfire Reborn is like a cheap variant of Borderlands. It doesn't have the same production values, but it is just as accessible and costs about a fifth of the price. Being pseudo-procedurally generated, it also targets shorter play sessions, just long enough to get a quick action fix without the story involvement of NPCs and other "epic"-type considerations. Aiding this, you are granted the ability to save and exit upon each end-of-chapter boss kill. You can quit mid-run at any time, and still invest whatever essence you acquired into your skill-tree. New mechanics like weapon bonus affixes, secret "vaults," new weapons, new scrolls, all of these and more are unlocked through normal play.

Player perks alter which weapons you seek out. I had one run playing the dual-wielder whom acquired perks that made it immune to explosive damage. I continued to upgrade the level of an early rocket launcher (weapon levels reflect base damage, increasable at the weapon merchant), which just so happened to have a bonus affix that would increase the number of projectiles it fired in a single shot. Coupled with several damage bonuses to explosive attacks, and an increased fire rate while dual-wielding, I was one-shotting most foes towards the endgame. And yet, I still lost. English is not the language native to the developers. However, you will be able to understand at least 95% of what the game is trying to say. The game is undergoing constant improvement, both in writing, and more importantly, in level segment revisions and additions. 

The only reason to not pick this game up is if you aren't willing to play it more than once. Being Early Access, it won't take long before you've experienced all the level-segments a chapter can throw at you. However, it will take long for you to survive long enough to realize it. There are a lot of things to unlock. This includes additional weapons, a harder difficulty mode, numerous scrolls, and more. You strengthen your characters through the skill-tree, and you lengthen your play sessions through learned ability. If you aren't the type of person that improves their play quickly, investments in the skill-tree can feel like a grind. In 31 hours I've beaten the game once, and made it to level 60 of 120 in my skill tree. This is not the end. A harder "elite" mode awaits, as do a dozen or so scrolls to unlock specifically in this difficulty.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
Gunfire Reborn is worthwhile. It is one of the only games I bought for a friend, specifically because I'd want to play it with them. This is a diamond in the rough, playable from start to finish, still undergoing improvement, and a complete steal at the price. Fans of shooters, not put off by cutesy enemy designs, will not be dissapointed. 

[b]In A Word[/b]
- "Considered"

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Decent gunplay, interesting aesthetic, varied and interesting enemy types - probably one of the better FPS Roguelite games out there. There's still a lot of work to be done though, and they could use a better English localization team as there are a lot of misspellings or missed grammar. Small things sure, but they're noticeable.

This game needs some extra content in terms of characters and side activities. Some things to change up the 'home base' might be nice too, though that isn't really as much of a thing in this game as the home base is just the main menu as it is right now.

Worth playing if you like Roguelite/like games and FPS gunplay similar to the Borderlands series and Overwatch combined - That's the best comparison I could come up with at the moment.

review: A very fun rogue-lite that combines elements of Borderlands (characters with abilities), Dead Cells (permanent upgrades), and Doom (dashing and arenas).  The gunplay is really solid and the gameplay loop is addicting, even though there isn't much content at the moment. title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Its a great game, except I have to severely question the designer's ability for one, single, reason. The jump puzzles.

Completely out of place in this kind of game. They absolutely KILL the pace, are frustrating, and time consuming. It doesn't help that the jumping physics are floaty, slippery, and inaccurate. High power items are gated behind a gameplay task that is otherwise completely absent from the rest of the game.

Makes me skeptical of the designer if they thought this was a *good* addition to their game.
developer_response: Sorry for your bad experience, we have optimized the "jumping level" and will continue the optimization. Hope you can have a better experience in the future. Thanks for your feedback!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
There are so so so many good things about this game. As someone who's Vermintide 2 player, this game is a breathe of fresh air while still being familiar. However, Just a few hours in and you can immediately tell the most glaring issues the game has and most of the criticisms can be directed to the fact that this is an Early Access game.

Since this is a co-op game, naturally you'd be teaming up with players. However, most of this game is just getting yourself carried by higher level players, where you'd hide behind cover as they kill everything because you deal 0 damage and dies to a single hit in higher stages. The alternative? You grind, hit a wall and die, repeat. Either way, these gameplay loops for new players just feels terrible to play with. I was planning to have a good time when getting into this game, but all of that just slowly disappeared.

Speaking of dying - when Bosses are defeated, they drop loot that are usually upgrades to your current arsenal. But the thing is, if you die during the boss fight (or before the boss fight and your team can't revive you because they have no copper), you can only spawn AFTER your team has left the Boss room. That means the person who died, who needs help the most in progressing the rest of the stages that are gonna be tougher than the previous ones, are stuck with the garbage weapons that they died with from the previous stage. Who.... who designed this?

Anyway, those are only two of the many gripes I have with this game. Even though it has so much good going for it, I've grown frustrated with it in the short amount of time I played with it. There's still a lot to complain about, such as lobby bugs, sound bugs, instant deaths, enemy design, overall game balance, etc. but I digress. I'm only 5 hours in, for all I know this could be the best game in the world and I'd be none the wiser. I was hoping this was going to be my next Vermintide 2... but oh well. I hope the game becomes better.
developer_response: Sorry for your bad experience, we keep adjusting the game difficulty and game balance, please give us more time to polish. Thanks for your feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Preface: Giving the game the thumbs down because it needs some polish overall, and there's just a few particular things I can't let pass. Then again, I'm not a paid reviewer or shill so imma b i t c h about it.

[b]Gunfire Reborn | Roguelite (Read: Random stuff, high failure rate, high restart rate) First Person Shooter Looter | 1-4 Players | ~12 bucks price tag.[/b]

[u]Positives:[/u]
+Easy to sink into gameplay loop. Load in, get going
+Multiplayer. It's the way to cheese the difficulty back just a little, since bosses will target one person, leaving the other 3 to get it done. Player revives are also a bonus. More enemies (with scaled up health no less) also spawn in multiplayer, making the gain of soul essences (permanent unlock currency) rather easy and plentiful compared to solo play. where you get far less.
+Guns all feel great thus far. each with their own effects and kick to em* (*devs already showing that they're favoring buffs over nerfs, though one gun -did- get nerfed slightly. This is great since...y'know, it's a fucking random game. Don't nerf things we're not guaranteed to get every run!)
+Variety of upgrades makes progression fairly obvious. You visibly see improvements and can quantify the upgrades you unlock via boosted ammo counts, health counts, damage reductions, etc. 
+Difficult. People fellate difficulty all the time and unless you're a god at this game, it's not going to be easy.

[u]Negatives:[/u]
-Spawn rates of high-threat enemies are a constant. Certain enemies will sit 800 miles away from you, shoot you with HOMING BULLETS/SHOTS, and eradicate you if you don't get rid of them. Yes, they're a priority target. No, the sniper bitch in the back of the desert shouldn't have damage resistance better than a boss you just killed while being a high powered threat! 1st area has 'Longbow' enemies that spawn in high packs and will end runs - take warning.
-Two characters (For now). One's viable, and one's only viable if you get god RNG and are able to survive long enough while being trash to get said god RNG upgrades. Won't say which is which - elitist scum will easily bark this one out.
-Dash Bug still prevalent (Press shift to dash! Automatically brings up your Steam Overlay and gets you smashed ingame. Might be fixed at time of writing? Who knows.)
-Difficulty spike inconsistency. If your luck is good, you won't have issues getting to the first boss. However, if your luck (read: with room types and enemies) is bad, you will get a longbow room and suffer horrors of low ammo and lower survivability. There's always one 'douche room' in Temple 4.  Also, the first boss is going to make a few people refund this game, since there's a massive learning curve when you go "AW YEAH FIRST BOSS" and immediately get oneshot because you dodged too early without knowing jank mechanics. The area after the first boss is also big fat booty cheeks with enemies that have double the HP of the first area, damage resistances, teleports and general nonsense of moving without sound and coming up behind you with flamethrowers. The game goes from EASY to STUPID very fast, and this isn't including the third area.
-Limited Biomes. Game isn't fast enough to consider this a positive. Wizard of Legend has the same few areas, but that gameplay is snappy and quick (though just as sponge-enemy heavy) so you don't get bored COMBINED with variety starts. You always get the same order in Gunfire Reborn (Temple > Desert > Coast). Game kind of gets boring if you don't shape up and escape the Temple, since that's 100% the most seen, bland area. and...
-Limited Rooms. ...the rooms are samey too. You'll find that at least in the temple, the rooms are made of the same 'tiles'. You know 'that one room with the right turn that leads down a staircase'. Stuff like that, doubly so for the 'vault' rooms. It'll always be "THE SAME BOULDER ROOM/FIRE ROOM/ENEMY ROOM" rooms. 
-Random Chinese invasion /(This game's Early Access)! Why does it say I <chinese symbols> someone when I'm trying to revive them? Why does it say I <chinese scrabble> the voice chat when I left it? Weird! Game needs polish and general de-bugging, but...that comes with Early Access territory.
-Difficult for the wrong reasons. Oops, first boss smashed you cause you didn't know what to do! Oops, first time in the desert, Coyotes bite your balls off! Oops, didn't realize that scroll you took that says "+damage, crits disabled" is actually a FUCKING NEGATIVE. Oops, game didn't give you a weapon to beat the boss with in realistic manner - guess you lose! Oops, last boss has mechanics far more than any other boss in the game and you get BRIEFLY told what to do and the warning goes away followed by instant death by cannonballs and the worst part is you can't practice bosses since it's kind of THE LAST THING IN THE GAME YOU GET TO!

It's better than some standalone Roguelites as is, but it's not in the echelon of glory that Nuclear Throne or say, Monolith - reside in As it stands, I'm giving it the thumbs down. I have nothing better to do so I'm playing it more and more, but I can't -personally- recommend it as is. For a Roguelite, it's just a wee bit too unforgiving. Maybe they'll add easier difficulties or more intimate fixes to make that first area a typical roguelite first area (read: easy to pass and naturally flowing in difficulty so you don't just slam into a brick wall in the second area.)

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Good game, great mechanics, just a few tiny things that should be adjusted
Communication:
[strike]We all love text chat. To not have someone you dont know hear your voice and so on. Sadly this is still lacking.[/strike] For those of you who are considering to buy, please remember, if you dont want to talk ingame, please go to the settings and activate the push to talk function. Hearing someone talk without them knowing you can hear them is happening here quite a lot since the voice chat is always active by default.

Playerfinding:
Most of us know the frustration of wanting to play a game and not finding players. But even worse as not finding players is that you can encounter any player from anywhere arround the world - and have them be the host. Its not really too horrible in most games, but here, where dodging is neccesary, its kinda hard to go with a higher ping. 

Other than that the game is pretty great and i'm going to continue playing it.

Edit: text chat has been added.

All in all, great game!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game has taken over my life! i dont usually play Roguelite games, or this style of games but this is SUPER ADDICTING!

great game to play with friends, you can play up to 4 or solo play, either way its fun!

so far, gameplay wise, i have not experienced anything game breaking or anything that would turn me off from the game...

Sometimes, it can get challenging, but thats what makes it fun! 

The Game does not have a "healing support class" or anything like that but if you want to be support like you can build tanky with grenade damage and pick up the bone dragon and keep the enemies gathered for your team mates to take down...

I personally like to see what kind of a build i can do as i go...

there are many builds and ways to go in this game... get it! and get ready to be addicted!!!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: Game runs like ass, huge lagspikes , the worst ones are before you die , so the game doesnt even let you dash the shots at the last moment. Poor design of the maps, most of the guns are useless as headshots are the best way to kill the enemies, body shots take for ever. Poor designed enemies that shoot auto targeting shots that follow you, sometimes the damage is already being calculated even if the shot hits after, enemies hitbox is bad. First boss is HUGE but the hitbox feels like he is 2 times smaller in reality , most of the shots miss even when directly hit. His attacks feels like hit all around the map, as there is not a good way to dodge them , you just have to be lucky i guess.  Cat skills are awfully programmed, his E the orb looks small but hits walls that are miles away from the actual orb depicted on the screen. The smoke screen grenade needs a total redesign as it just goes to wherever it pleases, the damage is negligable and the skill upgrades are poor. Also why the hell cant i upgrade the first gun we get? Its the best gun in the whole game. Refunden , might buy later on.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: Unbalanced and in need of greater variety in all areas of the game. I enjoy roguelites with this style of gained bonuses that carry over between runs and have had (and continue to have) fun playing this game, but it has a ways to go. The enemy balance is my biggest concern at the moment. GF:R currently has 3 worlds and a 2nd difficulty after beating the game. The ending dialogue seems to suggest that the Devs intend to add more, but I'll have to wait and see. Tweaks and bug fixes happen very frequently, often twice a week. I think this game is a good value even in its current state, but it could be something incredible if it keeps getting new content.

review: The movement speed is incredibly slow and the dash is incredibly short. it makes the game feel very clunky, which is unfortunate because the gun play is pretty good. Which would be fine if the movement speed wasnt so slow making it almost impossible to dodge two attacks in quick succession. With these issues the game just isnt very fun. I would wait until this is changed, unless you enjoy slow and tedious gameplay
developer_response: Thanks for your interest! There are some Occult Scrolls that can increase your movement speed and you can have a try.Using weapons with lightning damage can easily break BOSS's shield, and you can evade its attack behind the pillars. Hope you can beat the first BOSS soon!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Enjoy games like Borderlands? This game "borrows" many elements from it, but as a roguelite, and you get to be a cat with a gun.

-PROS-
-The controls are tight and movement feels great for early access (Have not used a controller yet)
-Lots of randomness in your scrolls (abilities) and talent trees.
-Currently two characters to switch between with different talent trees.
-Easily 30+ guns all with unique feeling to them.
-Multiplayer is easy to use and I have not personally had any trouble playing with friends (Have not used matchmaking yet)
-Great progression system leaving you with a feeling that every run gets you closer to unlocking more.

-CONS-
-Currently only one weapon is seriously powerful without a ton of bonus' to it. Prism (throwing dagger)
-Needs more curses....I like to be punished for my hubris.
-Could use a few more enemies.
-I'm struggling to find cons now, as I can see most of them getting fixed with more updates and additional content being added.

Just buy this game if you enjoy rogue-like FPS games. Great game at a great price.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn, even as an Early Access game, is extremely polished and a lot of fun. 

- The art style is lovely
- The characters are adorable.
- The gun play is rewarding
- The weapon drops are fun, plenty of variation to suit your playstyle
- The co-op experience is very good. 

It reminds me a lot of Risk of Rain meets Borderlands, but slowed down. 

The devs are constantly updating the game. They just recently added text chat, which is good because some of our team only do text.

I found the difficulty slope between getting 10 soul gems per game, to getting 20, was a bit steep. But after that point things got easier again. I suspect the devs will tune things like that over time, especially if people bring it up a lot. 

I highly recommend this game if you like procedural roguelike co-op shooters.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Multiplayer matchmaking can be very frustrating:
I join a matchmade game, and the host is AFK. 
So i leave the lobby and start matching for another game. It's the same AFK host. 
Even after restart and waiting for 30+ minutes i get the same host and cannot play the game online.

Also it can often not even find matches for 10, 20+ minutes. Even though there's supposedly 5k+ people playing...

Also death in MP is too punishing, the time to revive is too short and it costs way too much to revive at peddler. I was playing with friends and one of them had to wait for 15 minutes for a revive. That's not fun at all.
developer_response: Hi, we are aware of this issue and optimizing it, please give us more time.Thanks for playing our game and providing feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
One of the best early access experiences I've had. It has all the best aspects of the classic rogue-like genre combined with fun and engaging 3D FPS gameplay. Enemy attacks are well telegraphed, but don't be fooled, you will find yourself overwhelmed very quickly if you don't pay attention. The gun play is fun and rewards skill for hitting weak spots, and the gun combinations themselves can be fun and quite powerful, my favorite gun is the Bone Dragon, an explosive gravity ball launcher. The ascensions which are guaranteed at the ends of each level make for nice and steady progression of your abilities, and each ascension path has its own strengths. Occult scrolls are like items; their effects can be positive, negative, or both, and they aren't guaranteed drops. The only complaint I would have about this game is that the Occult scrolls feel like they don't synergize very well. Their individual effects can be beneficial, however the wording of some scrolls leads to  confusion about how the scrolls would affect each other, if at all.

Overall, the game is very fun and well polished, and the bar is already set very high in early access. I have great hopes for this game, and definitely recommend it to any fan of the action-roguelike genre.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
As of right now, there's not much here.  Lots of guns, sure, but there's only two characters and you're going to be seeing the same level over and over.  Overall, it definitely needs more polish.

But if there's one thing that is absolutely imperative for this game to get right, it's the moment to moment combat.  And it nails it.  90% of the guns you find feel great and the enemies are fun to fight.  I still haven't even gotten to the second boss -- I haven't tried co-op yet, but I'm sure it's even better -- and yet I keep getting pulled back in.  Very excited to see to how this game grows through continued development.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Doom, Hades, Risk of Rain, Dead Cells, Enter the Gungeon & Borderlands had Sex & that's how GUNFIRE REBORN came to light!

Pros:
Extremely addictive!
Lots of masterys with upgrades to unlock
You can replay everything with different difficulty.
Challenging enemies.
Weapons look and feel awesome.
Beautiful visuals and smooth game play with very few bugs.
Play as a gun wielding dog or cat.
Cons:
Only 2 characters we need more! and 3 stages only :(
Needs more balancing when it comes to duo or playing with 4 players

Overall i rate this game a 9.0 out of 10!!! it's a masterpiece that needs more recognition and it's unique in it's own way ! Once it gets more content it will be a 10 from me !

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Amazing game for such a cheap price. Yes there's a lack of content at the moment but give it a bit of time and this game will be one of the best of it's type. 

Extremely satisfying gunplay, movement and just combat in general. The progression of the talents tree from what i have seen looks to be pretty rewarding and balanced and the progression during a run (scrolls and weapons) not only gives the opportunity to make a unique build every run but also makes it so that you actually have to think about what weapons and scrolls work well together. 

I just like how this game feels like some of my favourite games (Borderlands, Dead Cells ...) blended into one, taking what i love so much about them and give an amazing and extremely enjoyable experience. Very much looking forward to what this game will become in the future.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: Not right now. The gunplay feels great, and there are some really great ideas and synergies here, but its misses are outright infuriating. Precision platforming feels absolutely awful, probably the worst I've experienced in a decade. It's also way too easy to just get caught and stuck on random pieces of the environment. Lastly, if you insist on having enemies with tracking weapons they should absolutely not be nearly as powerful holy crap.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Unfortunately, in the current state of the game, it is nothing but a frustration. The enemy/boss tracking is so aggressive it's nearly impossible to avoid half the stuff flying at you. The platforming system feels random. You can do the exact same thing multiple times and 20% of the time it'll work. Getting stuck in objects and clipping into platforms. Weapon/Ammo scaling is terrible. Far less than half the time you can throw together a build to do SOMETHING but the rest of the time you're left wondering why your weapon is basically healing the enemy. 

With some tweaks to numbers and an overhaul to the jumping/platforming, this game can be a nice potato salad.
developer_response: We are still perfecting team revival mechanism, and we will perform more optimization over team experience. Stay tuned.Thanks for playing our game and providing feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Highly overrated.

I mean, it has potential, but it's incredibly unpolished, the translation is a constant barrage of Chinglish, the tooltips that pass for a tutorial don't really do much to explain the mechanics of the game. ("Your Widgetry is important to the advancement of your character! But not too much! Careful about your widgets!" ... what???), the gun drops are kind of randomized like borderlands but unbalanced as heck (sniper rifles seem to be irredeemable garbage), and it's extremely heavy on twitch reflexes as opposed to tactics or strategy. Worst of all, the difficulty ramp merely consists of "enemies now have more HP and do more damage than previous." The lazy way out.

I mean, it's only 12 bucks, so I'm sure it's super popular with the fortnite kids with a $12/week allowance looking to slum it in something with a change of pace, but it really doesn't resonate with me at all.

DOWNSIDES
  
  The connection on here is almost unplayable if you want to play with someone who isnt local. For some reason regular match making gives better ping chances for a smoother gameplay, which they do deliver. In the future I would like to see more stable servers so im able to play with friends over seas, the game devs have done a great job so far and I do know that its still early access. Hopefully they will expand in the future as well.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
GOD this game is fun.

Let me start of by saying, if the tag 'roguelite' detours you from this game, do not fear, i've played PLENTY of roguelites, this feels so much different, you're given a reason to go back. During the game you pick up these things called 'soul essence', which help you level up, plus, you unlock new scrolls, scrolls are usually picked up by drop but mostly found in 'the vault', which is a key thing to do in the game for progression. These scrolls in corolation with certain weapons can make a CHEESY wombo combo, which just feels so satisfying to do. roguelite games usually make you feel like it's your fault, but once you reach level 10 you get co-op, so instead of blaming yourself your more subject to "what can i do to help my team more", or in my case, you and your pals diss every bad part of the boss. 

The satisfactory level in this game is INCREDIBLE, like i said, you can use scrolls with certain weapons to get S T R O N K, for example, lets say you have a fire weapon, fire weapons deal really  good damage to health, but not much to shield,  if you grab an occult scroll that pierces enemy armor on critical hits, you can obliterate a large enemy EASILY. and also most of the bosses are pretty fun, most of them, MOST OF THE BOSSES ARE FUN I GUESS YEAH ESPECIALLY WHEN THEY JUST SPRAY POISON IN EVERY DIRECTION AROUND YOU SO THAT THERE IS NO ESCAPE FROM THE G R O U N D S L A P. 

TL;DR - if you like guns, satisfactory (not the game), dying and starting again and a not toxic community, this game is for you.

For the developer - Hi i love your game please add more sniper rifles :))))))))

review:
Even in current state, the game is worth significantly more than 10‚Ç¨.

With more content added, this game can easily become a huge time sink. Currently it has around 40+ hours to max out the characters that are available. All I want is more characters, levels, scrolls and possibly "loop" feature similar to Risk Of Rain 2.
   
Not everything is quite balanced yet, but it allows for some really fun and OP runs, when the synergy of your weapons and scrolls is just right. So satisfying to melt through masses of enemies.

Highly recommend.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
WHY IS THIS GAME SO ADDICTIVE???
48hrs played.  Many co-op MP with mates but also plenty of hrs solo.
Said elsewhere, this is the bastard child of Borderlands, Torchlight and Deep Rock Galactic

The good,
GOOD VALUE (you'll get your monies worth!)
Satisfying headshots, damage #s and crit ping
Smooth gameplay and good FPS feel
Somehow the slight randomness doesn't make the repeat grind a drag
Elemental effects and compounding damage keeps you thinking
Death has a heavy penalty or is basically permanent.
WEIRDLY addictive

The bad,
Boss scaling on MP is TERRIBLE.  Good luck defeating a boss 4-player!  Seriously, this needs a patch BIG TIME!
Mob/difficulty scaling gets away on you with 4-player in Act2 (desert).  Would be impossible by Act 3.
Short on content and no 'continue' so you're back to square 1.  Needs to somehow break the current linear RIP rinse repeat.

EAGERLY awaiting some content and assume the MP scaling will be reviewed in patches.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Even in it's early access state, this game is very fun and shows a LOT of potential. The gunplay is tight, the skills are satisfying and diverse enough to warrant many many runs. The overarching skill progression system rewards you for getting further and further each time, and gives you a concrete goal outside of simply finishing all the levels. Each weapon you find seems to lend itself to a specific skill set, and has a unique trait that shapes the way you use it. The gameplay feels very heavily inspired by the Borderlands series, but utilizes concepts from those games in a refreshing way. It's also pretty appealing visually, despite the environments being very simple. My only complaint so far is that the english localization is a bit... off. Nothing serious enough to impede my understanding, but it's noticeable at times.

tldr; For an early access game, this is surprisingly fun and shows a lot of promise. Buy this game so they know people want it!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I really enjoy this game. Im new to roguelite style games so I dont have much experience with the genre but I saw this was on sale and thought I would try it. Definitely worth more than the few dollars I paid for it. 

Combat is satisfying and bosses are challenging but simple enough to master. Im eager to see what new things will be added in the future as I am already at the point some 25 hours in that I've beaten the game multiple times. 

Something that I find myself doing is going for the same weapons and builds every game though. I would like to see either more weapons or buffs/ scrolls/ or skills that specifically improve on weapons that I dont even use because they just arnt good enough. 

Also upgrading at the forge guy is nice but you can either upgrade damage or reforge a weapon. I dont mind the reforging but it would be nice if weapons had tiers, like the classic gray to yellow/gold tiers we see in lots of other games, and a choice to upgrade the weapon to the next tier with random stats.

I also find myself never really buying anything other than scrolls or buffs from the merchant. There are plenty of runs where I never even stop at him if I dont need ammo. I end most of my runs with stacks of cash because neither the merchant or forge guy seem to ever have anything worth spending money on. Maybe im playing wrong but it feels like there could be different things sold from the merchant. If the merchant had a good chance to have 1 of the weapons I already have but with different stats that would definitely make me stop by more. 

All in all a really great game and I cant complain considering its still in development.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
When I first saw Gunfire Reborn, I had concerns that the controls might feel weird - I wouldn't like the gunplay - the skill trees wouldn't be interesting enough for me - the combat would get stale - etc.

I'm delighted to say that none of my fears are true. I'm 22 hours into playing, and I keep thinking about my next run. It has all the elements of a rogue lite that I enjoy. Another cool thing is there's online multiplayer, up to 4 players. The servers are currently player to player based, so as long as your friends don't have crappy internet or live across the world, you'll be good to game without lag issues. The huge bonus about this game? The price. It's *very* affordable. Don't pass up on this one.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: https://i.imgur.com/ThpYjm7.gif

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I'll start off with the bad. The content is pretty lacking as you'd expect from an EA title, so you have to be the kind of player who enjoys rogue-likes and/or theory-crafting build synergies to get the most out of what's currently good with the game. There's only 2 classes and the randomness in the levels doesn't really feel very random at all since it's really just what order chunks appear in and no randomization within the chunks themselves, and it's the same enemies all the time. There are interesting challenges that rarely spawn (maybe they're more common on higher difficulties that I haven't unlocked) that make things a lot more interesting, but I rarely see them. The difficulty curve is a bit ridiculous, as the initial levels are a fucking cake-walk and then Lu Wu comes and smashes your shit. You'll eventually be able to beat him but fuck, it is too much too soon. I needed to bring a lightning gun for his shields camp around the pillars and then I was able to start consistently beating him solo. The graphics and audio get the job done. Not really good or bad. Just good enough to not be a distraction.

Now onto the good: there's a TON of guns! the guns are all have pretty unique gameplay hooks, and they did a great job making interesting modifiers for the guns. On top of trying to find guns with cool modifiers, there's also rogue-like style items (scrolls) that gives your character interesting modifiers AND an arpg-like skill tree that you can try to flesh out each time, AND game progression at the end of each run. The customization is really the highlight of the game and you can tell that's where most of the work has been placed, and it's what makes me the most confident about the game going forward, because the diversity of builds and guns alone is rich enough to be worth $12, I was that impressed. Slap on multiplayer and decent gameplay (it's a tiny bit too cover-centric but there's enough mobility to not be boring), it's hard not to like the game. 

There's really a lot of directions this game could go, I don't know if the developers are going to continue to focus on adding depth to the gun pool, make new classes, or flesh out the randomness of the levels, or just add more stages. Really, any direction the developers go is probably good because the starting point is really solid.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/33401179/]Follow my curator page for more recommendations![/url][/quote]
[b]TL;DR:[/b] An FPS roguelike with a solid amount of content, polish, fun/unique weapons, and a good amount of variety in enemies and levels (ignoring the first area). On top of all this, the developers have been updating the game [i]every week[/i]. Highly worth the $12, or $10.55 if you get it while it's on sale.

Gunfire Reborn has been compared by many as "Risk of Rain meets Borderlands". While I'm not sure about the Borderlands comparisons, the developers were definitely inspired by Risk of Rain 2 while developing this, and that's not a bad thing. Risk of Rain 2 is a fantastic third person roguelike, and turning it into an Asian-themed FPS sounds good in my opinion!

I currently have 7 hours in the game and I've completed it once. The game currently has three areas, each of which has 5 stages/levels and a unique boss fight. Each stage is slightly randomized with many different layouts to switch between, as well as randomization in the form of vaults (mini-stages with challenges, occasional mini-bosses, and extra loot inside), and the chance for challenge modifiers in the main stages. 

There's a good amount of variety, especially with the second and third areas. The first one starts to feel a bit same-y, there's really not enough variety in level design with it (and some rooms are much too cramped for four players), but hopefully they'll work on that one more in the future. The other two areas however are excellent and drastically change each time I've gone through them.

In each stage you have a random chance to also find the Peddler and Craftsman, otherwise these two are guaranteed to spawn in the room prior to the area's boss fight. In exchange for gold coins (which you collect from kills), the Craftsman will upgrade your weapons or change an inscription (weapon attributes). The peddler sells food (pork buns!), ammo, grenades, three random weapons, and a final slot is saved for either a fourth random weapon, or a scroll.

Scrolls are basically the same idea as items from Risk of Rain 2. Perks with various benefits (and sometimes negatives to counter a large benefit). There are also Cursed Scrolls which will give you a large negative, however these can be countered by a Scroll that simply makes you immune to them, if you're lucky enough to find it.

Unlike Scrolls, which you lose between runs, there are also Talents, which are character upgrades. You can buy Talents by spending Soul Essences, which drop from killed enemies occasionally. You can also spend these during a run to revive yourself if your teammates can't get to you in time. Any you don't spend after a run is over will be lost for good, so be sure to spend them all on that final Talent screen!

I should also mention that there are currently two heroes to play as. The one you start with, a cat, can throw smoke grenades (which leave a pool of toxic damage for the enemies to deal with) and an energy orb they can shoot out of their paw to freeze enemies for a few precious seconds. The second one, a dog, is unlocked at level 30. He has the ability to dual wield weapons and throw explosive grenades. Both are fun to play as and each have unique Talents to unlock.

At first I thought this game would be more like Borderlands, since so many were comparing it to that series. Where are the randomized weapons, the open world, and the hub area? Why can I only hold two weapons (excluding the pistol)? Because this isn't Borderlands. At all. This is a roguelike! You aren't going to be spending much time looking at your inventory, you wouldn't want to have to juggle more weapons, and you definitely wouldn't want completely randomized weapons. Other than the cel-shaded artstyle, I'm really not sure why people keep comparing it to Borderlands...

A hub area would actually be quite nice however, but the game doesn't need it, at least not right now. Would be a neat thing to add way down the road, though.

[b]Conclusion:[/b]

So, now you understand the basics of the game now, but is it any good? Well.. It's great. It's a very well-planned out roguelike with fun Scrolls to change up your playstyle, very satisfying weapons, a lot of enemy variety, and excellent level variety and designs for the second and third areas. If you're like me and you've been wanting a really good co-op FPS roguelike, you should definitely check it out. It's a measly $12, the developers update the game [i]at least[/i] once a week, and you're already getting a solid amount of content; and unlike other Early Access games, this one seems quite polished. I've yet to run into a single bug.

[b]Complaints:[/b]

The only complaints I have right now are that the first area's boss is a [i]wee bit[/i] tough the first dozen times you fight him, and that entire first area could use a rework as it's too cramped and close quarters, especially when you're playing with three others, and it doesn't change enough between runs. I'd also like to see more areas in the future, but that's almost guaranteed to happen anyway.

For a game that only released a month ago in Early Access and received NINE updates (!), this game is in great shape and I can't wait to see what they'll be adding to it.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
The desert areas after the first stages of the game are really hard to do single player, but the game is really fun. The stage progression reminds me a lot of Risk of Rain 2 and the combat is a lot like in Borderlands. The dodge mechanic feels good to use too ‚Äî when you pull off last second dodges against the first boss using the mechanic, it leaves you feeling like a god. I am sure that this game is a lot better with friends, but have not yet had the chance to play it with any. It is fun to play single-player though.

I can't wait for some more content to be added to the game. I hope they add additional hero(es) to use before level 30. This might give coop a little more variety, as multiple players won't have to all choose the same character and share the same ability for the first several hours. The only bugs I have encountered were minor. Other than bugs, there were some minor spelling mistakes.

Edit: Also I forgot to mention that this game is only TWELVE DOLLARS. Compared to other early access games (especially those in the past), this game offers so much more at much less cost.

Post-Multiplayer Edit: This game gets really hard with how health and enemy-count scaling works. Boulders are sometimes laggy and rubberband back and forth. The second boss gets so much health from multiplayer scaling that it becomes a war of attrition against death lasers. Other than that, good game!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I dont recommend this game - unless the full version will be greatly improved. 

I don't understand why it has so many favourable reviews. It is basicaly Serious Sam with just couple of very small, random levels - meaning it is getting boring quickly (many people say its roguelike mixed with Borderlands but thats absurd. Just beacause it has cartoonish graphics and numbers fly when you wound monsters doesnt make it similar to Borderlands...).

Bad:
- Very grindy - slow character progression & tough bosses
- Level generation is very simple. After couple of runs everything looks the same, including special mini-levels (vaults).
- Very random - sometimes you get great upgrades and best skills in single episode, sometimes nothing
- For a roguelike, it has very limited variety of weapons and their stats. (Again - it is NOT like in Borderlands, where one type of weapons can have much different combinations of stats/abilities). Forging possibilities are also minimal.

Good:
- Basic weapons look nice
- Opponents and bosses are interesting
- Had fun for first few hours

Of course there is a chance that the producer will improve and expand this game before the full release - but since it already has positive reviews I dont think he will bother....
developer_response: Sorry for your bad experience, we will add more content and randomness in the future update, stay tuned.

review:
If you can overlook the furry stuff, there is a truly stellar game here. Yes, even now, while it's in early access.

The game is like an awesome mix of Borderlands, Binding of Isaac and Rogue Legacy. 

It's also the best kind of Rouge-lite in my humble opinion; even when you die, you can give your character permanent stat increases. So even if you fail to 'git gud', you can still eventually pull through with enough persistence!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Honestly, don't let looks deceive you. Yes this is indeed a Chinese indie(?) game and yes, there are issues associated with that and the fact that this is an early access title for $12 dollars. I very much had those same reservations when looking at this game myself.

Only to play it for a bit and find that there are new and surprising things that come out of this game every time I play it. 

Now, as far as brass tacks are concerned, this is very much a Rogue-lite shooter. If you've played shooters like Borderlands and Doom, and played rogue-lites such as Dead Cells and Rogue Legacy, this is definitely going to feel //very// familiar to you, to the point where you might ask yourself "Hey, this just seems like it's kinda ripping those games off, doesn't it?"

To be honest though, the developers here do an absolutely great job at actually giving each element they have used from those games their own flavor and style, and they've put a shocking amount of effort into this game that really makes it shine. 

On one point, my favorite element absolutely is the gunplay. There is a vast variety of different unlockable guns that you'll find each play through that do things that, again, will feel very familiar, but will also feel like they have a fresh play style to them. Even the sounds of the guns in this game actually feel like even if it doesn't do damage, they've got some serious weight to them, which is always a plus in my book.

Another surprising element is how competent the AI actually is. Yes, you do have your usual lot of melee and tank dudes that run at you trying to get a hit on you, but you will also run into enemies that will keep you looking for cover and will even flank you at times if you're not careful. It really keeps the run-and-gun flow of this game actually really thrilling, particularly in the 2nd stage of the game, at least for now considering that I don't personally know if they will actually add more stages to the game.

Obviously there are issues with the game. Again, being that it's available in Early Access, you're definitely going to run into some oddities such as not being sure what actually constitutes as cover in this game, or translation issues due to this being primarily created in China.

Overall however, I've had a splendid time with this game. It offers the same risk-reward kinds of gameplay that you expect from other such games in the Rogue-lite category all in a very small and pretty package. For only $12 dollars, it's hard to beat  a game like this. I genuinely believe the Developers have rightfully earned the Overwhelmingly Positive rating that it's achieved over the past couple of weeks.

Give it a try, why don't you?

review:
This game slaps. I've always had trouble getting into grindy fps or even some of the more grindy rougelites, always settling for instant action fps games. But this sweet lil goober game satisfies my urge to shoot stuff while also providing me a cool progression method that, while grindy, doesn't feel too harsh or obnoxious. At first you find yourself stuck in the same area and dying to rando mobs, but within a lil bit of playtime, you feel yourself getting stronger all while you're learning the rules and discovering new items. Each playthrough brings new surprises and new builds that shred in new ways that you didn't know were possible. Even though the content is limited, it does a great job giving you diverse scenarios. I genuinely CANNOT wait for any crumbs of new content the devs pass to us. I haven't even tried the second character yet and I'm still happy. For early access, this is a gem among other Steam titles and I would've gladly paid 20+ bucks for all the fun I've had so far c:

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
[h1] This game is so close to being amazing [/h1]

[h1] Pros [/h1]

[b] Guns [/b]
The gun variety in this game is incredible. Each run in this game is different, with each chest and enemies dropping different weapons and loot every game. Gun-play is super smooth and crisp, with each gun having different recoil patterns, muzzle flashes and even different effects (Decay, Burn, etc.)

[b] Abilities [/b]
Both of the characters have 2 skills: secondary and primary. For example, one characters primary ability is an Energy Orb that does AoE damage and freezes enemies in place, and his secondary ability is a smoke grenade, which [i] somehow [/i] does damage. Where as the other characters primary ability is dual wielding weapons. Both characters have a passive ability which allows them to dash forward. All of these abilities feels smooth and have beautiful effects and graphics.

[b] Multiplayer [/b]
Like most games, this game is 10x better with some mates. Nothing else said.

[h1] Cons [/h1]

[b] Level Design [/b]
The levels is this game are very bland and each feel as clich√© as the other, [spoiler] until you get into the next world [/spoiler] When moving from one level to the next, sure, somethings change, likes some boxes or props sprawled out, but they all have pretty much the same layout, and can get quite boring after hours of play.

[b] Lack of characters [/b]
Gunfire Reborn (At time of review) only contains 2 characters. I would love to see some different characters in the future, all of which have different appearances, abilities and maybe even voice lines. The characters at the moment have no emotion, and share no personality or voicelines.

[h1] Final Verdict [/h1]

All things considered, this game is awesome. Gunplay is amazing, sound is superb, and multiplayer is super fun. Sure, its a little rough around the edges, but when this game releases from Early Access, I'm almost certain the developers would've made the game better then it is at the moment, not saying its bad in its current state. I highly recommend buying this game, even in its Early Access state, because it is purely amazing, and is super cheap.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I haven't played a campaign-based first-person shooter in years. I tend to find them either too frustrating or too boring. I also don't like competitive shooters; they incite too much anger in me and others. So why did I buy this game? And why am I reviewing it? I suppose it all boils down to curiosity. There was a lot of praise poured into this game, and it looked intuitive enough watching gameplay and review videos that I thought I would give it a try. If I didn't like it, then I probably would have mired myself even further in my disdain for FPSs. So, after two hours, what did I think?

Well, when you begin the game, you are instantly dropped into the perspective of a samurai cat-person wielding a gun. The game's tutorial teaches you the basics very quickly, and the mechanics it introduces are quite easy to grasp. I played the two hours I spent with this game using a controller, and a few quirks aside, I didn't have much problem playing with it. Obviously, not having much experience playing these types of games, I missed a lot of shots and took damage when I could just as easily have dodged it. In a way, it made me feel like I was a kid learning the ropes again. But while I did get frustrated sometimes, I was always motivated to keep playing.

When you begin an adventure proper, whether solo or coop, you are tasked with reaching the end of a set of rooms and dealing with the enemies in your path. At the end of the last room is a treasure chest that contains a power-up and a portal leading to the next section. There are several sections leading up to a boss; while I have never gotten as far as the boss, these sections do get increasingly harder to deal with. And since this is a roguelike, no two runs have the same types of rooms and enemies, so strategy must be put together on the fly. I tended to play a little cautiously, taking careful steps to make sure my ammo was high, my shields regenerated and my skills replenished. 

You start out with three skills: a dash to quickly avoid enemy projectiles and attacks, three smoke grenades that deal damage over time to all within the blast radius, and a purplish orb thing (I can't remember the actual name for it) that freezes enemies in place for a couple seconds while also dealing damage upon impact. These are very useful for taking control of the battlefield, and there are occasionally other hazards that may help or hinder your chances of survival. As an RPG fan, I appreciate this kind of strategy.

Sadly, the fact of the matter is that if you're not good at FPSs like I am, you will die quite often. When I died at the end of a run, I was greeted with a results screen and the option to spend Soul Essence on upgrades to my stats. I didn't always have enough Soul Essence at the end of a run to upgrade, but it kept me motivated to get more so I could improve my chances of succeeding a run. I really like that dying doesn't put me off from playing another run, but encourages me to play better. Heck, I would've played more if I wasn't compelled to sleep for my own health.

Although I've only played this game for a short while (up to the point where I can't refund it anymore), I can't say I didn't enjoy my time with it. I intend to play more in the coming days, and I certainly look forward to the developers' progress on the game in the near future. Here's hoping I can convince a friend or family member to play with me. :)

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
The only performance issues I had were after the first couple of levels. Even though my fps is still at 144, the game feels like a slideshow even when nothing is going on. 

So far it just feels like a long grind to unlock stuff that doesn't really do anything better than the previous weapons. Over the 2 hours I played, I made it as far as the 2nd boss and the whole time never cared about anything I was unlocking. With most weapons it really doesn't make a difference what you pick up, other than fire rate and ammo type. The pros and cons of each weapon are so negligible that I didn't bother swapping once I would find the rocket launcher and the big machine gun. With any other weapons, the boss was so spongy that I couldn't even get the through a quarter of his health after 4/5 add spawns. The machine gun alone dropped the boss before the second wave even started. I couldn't ever tell if the synergies were working, nothing seemed to ever make me feel more powerful. Even in a run with 7 scrolls, I wouldn't have been able to tell the difference to not having any all. So I feel like I'm just going to waste my time grinding for stuff that isn't much better, or just isn't fun to use. The weaponsmith also didn't really do anything, upgrading a rifle twice still took the same amount of hits to kill a basic enemy.
 
Can't say much about the AI cause every single roguelike fps I've played has had awful AI. It's all auto-follow until melee range, move to line of sight and shoot, or throw some AoE at you. Playing aggressively felt like it took much longer to clear a room, compared to just hiding behind something and nailing headshots constantly. 

I think a couple of these problems could be fixed by playing co-op, but I'm alright without that these days. Just hoping it has a lot more attention spent on the solo experience. Bought it because everyone compared it to isaac, dead cells, and borderlands. Honestly, I don't see any of those games in this other than the randomization, and bullet sponge enemies of borderlands. Isaac and dead cells both have so much depth to them and this game is missing all of it. Those games have the potential to either make you feel like a god, and/or sometimes give you an awesome challenge, and I'm just not seeing it from this game. 

I'm still recommending it because it has some potential and was a good price. I just really hope that it's not just another early access let down. The performance is pretty great, other than the stuttering I encountered. Maybe just wait a year before getting it. While they have a decent foundation, the core of the game is pretty bland and simple.

Ontop of the fact that; Please let me drop the starting weapon XD. I have three different ammo types, i wanna use em all at the same time! But seriously very well done! Can't wait to see what the full release has in store.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
After playing to get to max level (120) and 60+ hours, I feel like it's time for me to give a review and experience playing the game. But first what is this game about?

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Weaving through semi generated dungeons, you take on a variety of enemies where they all have small but unique patterns solo or coop.  It takes the elemental factors of borderlands where fire is good against flesh, lightning against shield and corrosive against armour.  Mix that with collecting occult scrolls which act like artifacts form slay the spire (give you a passive bonus) hidden behind vaults (can range from destroy all enemies in a room to tricky platforming), and a decent weapon variety.  You slowly understand which weapons and play styles benefit more from certain scrolls you pick up.  This makes for some pretty unique runs. You currently can play as two characters at the moment, the crowned prince (as I'll relate to the cat) and Ao Bai (the dog). The cat has the ability to shoot a projectile which stops time for the enemy and puts them into stasis  (reminds me of BOTW and link's stasis ability in a small AOE) and the dog which duel wields like the gunzerker from borderlands.  Each character has shared and unique talents between the two that you purchase at the end of a run with soul essence which you collect through your run.  This can range from more HP to crit damage to other various things.  Since this is a roguelite game, you are going to die... a lot.  Enemies can sneak a surprisingly amount of damage when you're not looking so you become more aware of them in next time you face them.  

[h1]Pros[/h1]

[list]
[*] super fluid gameplay that feels rewarding as you try and try again to beat  enemies and bosses alike
[*] large weapon and occult scrolls (give passive bonuses) to adventure through
[*] challenging enemies
[*] the producers have a very solid (and successful IMO) foundation in what they want to achieve, which to me is to have a tactical run and gun gameplay
[*] Devs are super responsive to feedback
[*] it's like $12 for a game that will easily give you more than 12 hours of gameplay if you like shooter roguelites
[*] I like big numbers I cannot lie
[/list]


[h1]Cons[/h1]

[list]
[*] Overall movement might be a tad slower than what you expect, and thus your dash becomes absolutely essential to master.
[*] If not paying attention, enemies can hit surprisingly hard
[/list]

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I like this. looks nice, feels nice.

Suggestions:

please, please, please add boss variation, enemy variation, room variation, more player characters. I love grinding through this, and being the type of gamer I am, I don't mind grinding through the same levels over and over, but I think you could reach a wider audience with people that are less tolerant to grindiness. Plus, as far as rogues go, this one is currently pretty monotonous. The boss of each level is the same every time. While it is a sufficiently challenging boss, I think any good rogue is gonna thrive most on as much variation as possible in the runs. A lot of the rooms are also the same, and the enemies in each type of room, seem to always be the same mix.

Also I've felt at times that my inability to progress was more linked to a need to level up my talents more and do more damage in general, than to an inability to overcome the situation skillfully

Basically, I've loved this so far, but it could get old quick without a great deal more variation/content per run. I really really am looking forward to seeing what you'll do. If you consistently update and add more and more, I'm thinking you could have players for a long time.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
First off, the name of the game is terrible - but that aside its a cheap enjoyable little roguelike shooter, with asian cats and dogs (currently, needs more heroes). Like in binding of isaac where you go through rooms and levels killing bad guys picking up money guns and upgrades (some are good, some are bad and some are even cursed) all of which change how you play and can further change on how you upgrade. There are temporary upgrades (ascension paths) and permanent upgrades you get by collecting souls and spending as much of them after you die (talents) but you can't hoard souls as any unspent ones are lost encouraging you to spend what you got even if its on sub par talents like higher ammo capacity.

Small tip: you run slower with big weapons and faster with small ones, so swap to your starter pistol for running trap vaults!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
So I'll start off with the fact that this game is fairly overhyped in my opinion. Sure it's early access, but some of the negative reviews here have a point. It lacks a bit of polish. Don't get me wrong, it's not really expensive, but I believe that this game could do more in the long run so I'll list down all things I've noticed so far.

CONS
-Lacks Music - each level is randomized, but the lack of music in the background just makes the whole thing stale for me.
-A lot of terrible guns - I've played Borderlands and yes, there will be stale weapons, but I think you guys might keep adding and I do hope so.
-Stale Level Generation - Oh man, this is one of the worse for me. Every level is randomized as I've said before, but oh boy, like one of the reviews I've read, it just seems the same. Maybe adding variety to the walls and so on would help this.
-UI Design - The menus of this game could use some work to be honest. Of all the things that I thought would be polished, it would be the menu screen.

I won't list down Pros because a lot of it is still halfway there but here's my TL:DR

I would still recommend this game to anyone who would like to try something new. The enemies maybe bland but hopefully you guys get to add more. Definitely grab this during the sale if you can and support the developers. The reason why I made it seem so negative is that so the devs will take notice of all the things they can improve upon on. I have high hopes for this game and I still enjoy it despite its glaring shortcomings.
developer_response: Thanks for your interest, we will add more content and optimize the gameplay in the future update, stay tuned.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Well, now I feel like an idiot!  I held off buying this game because I am a penny-pinching tightwad, so instead of buying it weeks ago for $11.99 I waited for the Steam Summer Sale so I could buy it for $10.55.  I missed out on weeks of fun just so I could save $1.44. And make no mistake, this game is so much fun.  Imagine that Borderlands & Slay the Spire had a baby.  It's name would be Gunfire Reborn.  Seriously, I think this game would be a great deal at $19.99.  (don't tell the devs I said that).

It's listed as an Early Access game, but it feels like one of those games that is great just as it is, and further work by the devs will just make a great game even better.  I am playing it solo, but I imagine it is even better in co-op.  (not that I have any friends to play with).  

Pick up this game, and try it out.  You will know within the first 15 minutes that this game is a keeper.  You will say, "They won't get Gunfire Reborn away from me until they pry it from my cold, dead hands.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
In Gunfire reborn you play as (to this date) one of two animal heros, gunslinging your way through randomly created levels, looting weapons and occult scrolls which give you some neat perks. This games feels like a mix of Games like Borderlands, with its elemental types of weapons and the wicked shooting or weapon design, mixed with stuff like Heavy rain and the core of roug lite games.
At first you will die for sure, but you will learn the enemy patterns and at the end of every round you are able to spent point gathered throughout the run to improve your charakter in certain ways like overall crit dmg, grenade capacity or something like that. Its fun, but hasnt much depth to it if u play it regulary, since your character  become stronger every run. 
I would like to see some more levels, bosses and overall content. Now in June 2020 this game has only 3 Stages, with 3 Bosses which play out in the same order every time. 
The coop also lacks some spoting-mechanic for teamcoordination, or just a simple voicechat would do.

All in all im hooked and would like to see some more stuff, just more, gimme more pls 
(there are defnitly major writing mistakes, but i dont care. this review is just to give you insight of my thoughts <3 )

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game could be something really huge, if the devs continue to follow up on the development of it

I enjoyed my time playing this game, and feel that I've gotten a good impression of the game, it currently has 2 heroes, to choose between.

One irk is that you have to reach lvl 30 to choose the second hero, I do not know why this is, as I really felt the second unlockable hero was worse than the starter hero. (cat) I switched back after two runs with the new hero.

The gunplay is nice, the weapons are nice, although it suffers from the fact that there are a few weapons like prism that are viable throughout the run, the rest are honestly terrible, making you ignore 85% of weapon drops, which is sad. If I recall correctly there are 37 guns in the game at the moment, this is really noticable ingame, which currently is acceptable as this game is in early access.  I hope the devs go the same route as Enter the Gungeon, with a vast arsenal of guns to choose between!

I am not sure I like the talent tree system at all honestly, I like getting better through method and skill, not adding more damage to overall percentages and whatnot. I do hope they make the talents less valuable so to speak.

When you die in game, you have the chance to spend half your skill points aquired that round to ress yourself, I don't know if I really agree that that's a good way to go about it. I would rather have insta-deaths unless you get an item at hte shop, or a scroll to ress you, that way there is more risk involved!

The AI in the game is something I found at times really bad to be honest, it seems like if an AI targets my friend, I can literally walk up to it and shoot it in the face, and it will still try to hit my friend across the map instead of focusing on me. This is something REALLY frickin important to fix.

Something I would have liked the devs to take a look at is the enemy spawn system, sometimes you are at an encounter where waves of enemies spawn, but a big problem is that the spawn points seem to be static, so if you complete a wave, and stand in the designated spawn area, which you won't know until it's too late, enemies will spawn on you and instantly kill you, this is something I have experienced several times. This is terrible.

I mean, the rest of the game has organic enemy entrances where they jump over rocks and come out from places you can anticipate, why not do this for all spawn? It is ridiculous sometimes.

There is still a LOT of work to be done here, A LOT, but for now it seems to be solid start!

A big gripe is still that the maps are really repetetive, you will grow tired of them in about 1 hour, the vaults you jump into has very little variety to them, sometimes you will enter two vaults in rapid succession, and they will literally be the exact same vault map, with no difference at all. I mean, why not code it so that if one vault instance is entered, that instance won't be selected from for at least 1 vault, so you won't get two in a row, this is some minimum requirement thing I feel, and it is really weird that it isn't the case.
