review:
Gunfire is a really good game, especially for the price. Multiplayer is a fun time with some friends and the devs have been fairly active at fixing bugs and adding new things to the game. The game is a bit light on content currently, but more difficulty levels and hints of a new character keep me interested in the title. 

Hopefully in the future some more behind the scenes design things will be tweaked. The game has a really good sense of style but I found myself initially a bit distracted due to some HUD assets looking extremely similar to a certain Blizzard FPS... Some people don't see it, but the game definitely took a bit more than inspiration in some of it's animations in particular.

The game is still in early access and most certainly has some rough edges. It will be cool to see the game evolve as time goes on. Hopping in now is pretty guilt free due to the low price plus it's incredibly fun for what it is! Definitely recommended!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I'm writing this review after having "completed" the current Adventure content available in this build of the game. It took me 24 hours of game time and 70+ character levels to beat the game on the hardest difficulty. The great thing about it is that I feel like working my way down the talent tree truly did make a noticeable difference in my ability to progress in the game.

Some of my favorite features:
- Save points at level transitions allow you to continue a run at a later time
- Weapons feel distinct and have loads of personality
- A complete run of the game only takes about an hour
- Actually useful and game-changing talents
- Really fun / ridiculous skill and item combinations

Some of my not so favorite features:
- Frequent insta-kill deaths where you're left wondering what happened
- Timed platforming challenges. Feels extremely out of place in the gameplay loop
- [strike]Bandit sniper enemies in Stage 2 have very tiny / seemingly inconsistent hitboxes[/strike] (This has since been adjusted in a patch)
- Early game may not have enough "fun" factor to keep people playing
- Characters can get soft-locked at a lower level if they are unable to beat the first boss to afford more expensive upgrades

In conclusion, I've thoroughly enjoyed this title. The current content is fun and challenging. The core gameplay is solid and performs well. I definitely recommend this title if it interests you. Just know that it involves a pretty hefty grind to unlock the full arsenal of fun combinations.

review:
edit: They updated the netcode. It's all butter

It's Risk of Rain, Borderlands, and Hades all wrapped in a very slick package. Oh and Overwatch because it's a fps

You take the 4 player aspect for coop and general mayhem, the insanity of stacking skills upon skills to make wonderfully stupid builds, and the replayability rouge-likes in a tough but fair progression system. 

The game demands a more active playstyle compared to Risk of Rain, but is quickly rewarded with how ridiculous skillsets become as you start accumulating more as the run progresses. Earning and exploring new weapons as they are unlocked is one of the most sastisfying things the game has to offer, as each new gun offers a new play style encouraging the player to reevaluate potential synergies and novel tricks.

The game purposely holds back all it has to offer in a tight progression, keeping things very fresh. I don't expect the game to get old for a while yet, even as players progress into endgame.

The feedback system is surprisingly accessible, 

It's worth every penny, even for early access 12 bucks criminally under priced. 

Pick it up, and grab some friends.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
A game I would recommend to people who enjoy the playstyle of Borderlands, with a bit of roguelite mixed in. (think Risk of Rain) 

You progress slowly at first, leveling up as you repeat the same levels to grow your character, obtain traits, unlock guns that will drop the next round. 

It is on a level of challenging, but as you repeat the levels, you learn, adapt, and develop strategies based on what cards are dealt to you. Do you choose a gun with more elemental chance to synergize well with what abilities you have chosen? Or do you avoid picking up an artifact that would boost an aspect of your kit, but has a detriment attached as well?

A lot of on the go thinking and planning is involved and that is what has had me hooked onto this game. It's fun, and even more challenging with friends.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Tl;Dr - If you're a fan of roguelite's & have been searching for a solid FPS roguelite, this game is for you. If you're searching for a more traditional FPS that has set levels, chests, weapons etc, this game MAY be for you, as long as you accept that it has none of those features and is a true roguelite. Also, if you like to try and defeat a game of the first run you might want to look elsewhere, since it's a roguelite you'll die.... ALOT.

Performance: Aced. The game runs smooth and I haven't encountered any considerable FPS drops, although I'd note this is one of the games where it's best to let your gpu handle AA & V-Sync and just turn those options off in the game. I'll also note that due to the above, this game doesn't really like to play well with gpu "enhance game settings" options so, you either want to let the game run those settings or your gpu, not both. I use the gpu and have had no performances after making those adjusments. My current rig has a quadcore processor & the game runs smooth as butter on it, so, if you have a mid range pc, fear not, you don't have to minimize visual settings to get 60 FPS.

Visuals: The artistic style is consistent and immersive. The low poly/cell shaded design feels just right for the game and, with the above setup, I might add that this is one of the few games where I could turn on/up settings for water and shadow & max post processing. That tells me that the dev is good at visuals and optimizing said visuals. The fonts, for the most part, are complimentary and the HUD fits in naturally. The gunso are unique and reflect that, it certainly doesn't feel like they are just reskinned clones and the visual effects differ, giving a feel that you are genuinely firing different weapons. Complimenting that, the firing animations are unique too. Maybe just so slightly depending on the fps, but it's definitely noticeable and is a nice touch.

Sound: 10/10 Great soundtrack, excellent ambience, wonderful sound effects. The game is spot on in this department too.

Gameplay: First, allow me to reiterate what I did in the Tl;Dr. This game is NOT a traditional FPS. Its levels change, the enemies are extremely difficult, and though the game mechanics allow for skill based success in terms of things like crits, it's wears a roguelite badge and wears it well. If you're looking for a game that can be played from the beginning to the end without dying, you'll be sorely disappointed as the power creep starts happening as soon as you start a run. If you buy this with that mentality, it's very possible you won't make it past the first boss. The game was designed with death in mind. Dying is something that will happen, and may happen often as this is a roguelite to the truest extent in terms of unforgiving difficulty even on the initial difficulty option (normal). I feel it important to stress as I've seen a decent amount of complaints about how the game is flawed because it's nigh impossible to beat the first boss in the first go. Since it's a true roguelike experience, please understand that means its difficulty is consistent the whole game through. You must learn/be willing to learn to expect the unexpected and also anticipate that the AI operates at the same level, bosses were meant to be gatekeepers, less actual bosses. Once more, as this is important, if you're looking for a game that has 0 RNG and is purely skill based, this game is in the wrong game for you even though it's an FPS. For those who are looking for a good roguelite, on the other hand, this game is right up your alley as long as you're not looking for a Gungeon or Binding of Isaac clone as it is a clone of neither and it should be pretty clear that it shouldn't be a clone of either. I'll probably add to this section later as I need to touch on other points and there's only so much you can say with only 1000 words. Suffice to say for now, that if you are looking for an original game that does the roguelite bit right, I'd recommend getting this game for certain.

Difficulty: 11 out of 10 would die again. The game encourages accuracy for most of the weapons. It utilizes a weak point based crit system that, once you learn for each enemy, can help make most runs long ones. Otherwise, it's what you'd expect from a roguelite Learn. Adapt. Compromise. Kill. Die.

Controls  = Solid. Keys are rebindable and this game thankfully avoids using the arrow keys for anything by default, although, if that's your fancy you can gimp yourself by rebinding to arrows. Importantly,  I can't notice any lags and though I think the dash mechanic needs tweaked, still fires straight away when shift is pressed. 

Overall: This is another excellent example of Early Access done right. The dev is responsive and their game feels well polished and complete even now. Sure some might not like that there are only 2 classes & 3 levels, however, the characters are different enough that that's a non-issue & from what I've heard, dev's going to be releasing at least another character sometime during the development cycle. As far as levels, think of it like a chapter less a level, each level is comprised of I think 10 maps that vary from the claustrophobic to the expansive. I do believe there will probably be more levels added later, in the meantime, this game is fully functional and provides a well polished experience even on a mid-range pc and possibly for lower end rigs to boot. I can tell by how the game plays that the dev cares for this game and has technical expertise and am glad I bought the game as I'm interested to see what the Tao has in store for them in the future. I'd recommend buying the game and trying it out if you're even vaguely intrigued in roguelite fps's as a concept. I won't compare this game to Binding of Isaac as I really get sick of seeing people berate an original game by comparing it to that aesthetically displeasing mess. The only comparisons I can think of in terms of gameplay, would be RoR2 although, it's 1st  person not 3rd and I really want to emphasize that's a loose comparison as it truly is its own unique gem of a game. If you've stuck around to read this end to my review, then I'd say the game is probably going to be a good fit for you, plus, it's only around $12 US, but is more complete than most games that are triple the price.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Looks and plays like a poor man's Serious Sam or Immortal Redneck. Two characters, same enemies over and over. 

Don't buy the "looter shooter" idea, you can carry two weapons per run and they don't carry over into other runs. You have to decide which two guns you want. Guns all have different types of ammo, which seems to run out pretty quickly. 

Yeah there is a skill tree but it's very impotent. The fact that I can "unlock" +5 health is absurd. Oh wait.. if you play more you can unlock.....+10 health. OMG guys don't even get me started on the awesomeness that is +15 health. I'd tell you that you can do the same with ammo but I don't want your brain to explode from the amazing awesomeness of the skill tree.
developer_response: Sorry for your boring experience, we will add more content and randomness in the future update, stay tuned.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Pretty cool game. I'm not yet addicted but I can see where the others are coming. If optimization (aiming and interface) and balance are prioritized this game should be a hit soon enough. I think there are some errors in the US ENG translation hence my occasional confusion with the descriptions but decent enough to be understood. 

What could be improved:
- Interface (light blue text on dark blue background on a poorly lit environment wont grab the needed attention)
- Fonts could be improved as well as alignment in the menu. I get the theme but we could use some less wild fonts.
-  The alerts could be more dynamic (opacity/size reduces as projectiles are farther). I panic a lot when I see the exclamation points only to realize I was out of range anyway.
- Slightly more enemy visibility (looking at you sneaky spiders) especially in very poorly lit environments.

Overall I'm happy with my purchase and this game surely deserves more attention. Soundtrack is great too really gets you the feels of dungeon crawling (I'm still on the first boss).

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
[h3][b]EDIT:[/b] Now rating this positively, after the devs response and taken action. :)[/h3]


Great, fun little indie game. Among all the early-access titles out there, this is surely a little gem.

It is a bit short and repetitive, but a lot of fun nonetheless and surely worth the small price. The developers delivered a surprisingly challenging, smooth and pretty much bug-free experience (which in itself is a nice surprise these days).

[h3][b]Negative:[/b][/h3]
[list]
[*] Quite repetitive, as you always start from the "beginning" aka the same environment. The map order is random, but mostly they look the same.

[*] Not enough true weapon variety. There is a lot of different weapons, but they don't really alter the play-style that much.

[*] No close-combat weapons aka swords.

[*] You are stuck with the cat character until lvl 30. This should be a choice from the beginning.

[*] The rolling ball maps are just not fun.

[*] Matchmaking works fine, but currently you can't decide to only play as 2 or 3, it's always 4 - which makes the game way too easy.

[*] Some of the "upgrades" effects are not very well explained, you see the stats but don't know if it's good or bad.

[*] The critical-hit sound is way too loud.
[/list] 

[h3][b]Positive:[/b][/h3]
[list]
[*] Very bug free so far, I only encountered a few (e.g. getting stuck in the lobby) but they are rare.

[*] Combat is smooth and fun, yet suprisingly challenging.

[*] Hunting for upgrades and new weapons is quite addictive.

[*] The enemy AI is "smart" enough to actively seek cover or flank you.

[*] The artstyle is clear, good looking and not distracting. The effects fit the artstyle very well.

[*] Sound is good (except for the above mentioned crit-sound).

[*] Updates happen quite often and bugs are adressed rather fast.

[*] The community is very friendly. I haven't met any toxic players yet, which is surprising and nice. =)
[/list] 

So all in all, for this low price and considering how hard working the single developer seems to be, you can't go wrong with this game.

It's a great fun to sometimes just "jump in" for a while, to let off some steam and blast your way through hordes of enemies.  >:)

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I had just come across this morning and I have to say that it was the best thing that I have ever come across when it comes to rougelite  games. After buying the game I played for 4 hours straight and then when I went to take a break to see if any of my friends would buy the game, I went to play something else but every minute that had past I thought more and more about opening it up again. That's how addicted I have gotten to the game.

For the people that are looking at the game considering buying it, I say you should. If you like games like borderlands, Dead Cells, Risk of Rain 2, or even any other games that are in the rougelite category then you have to at least try the game out. Although there is not too much to the game yet, only two characters at the moment and the fact that it is in early access, I still think it is one of the best games to come from a small company in 2020.

The graphics are very pleasing and for me I consider them very cute. On the way of controls, I think that there is a bug that has to be worked out with walking backwards where I would get stuck on something that wasn't there but other than that I would consider them very well done and smooth.

The last thing that I want to say is that I think this game is a good one that if you are still not sold on, to keep your eyes on and either follow the game or add it to your wishlist. Other than that if anyone is looking for a game to stream or make a video on (since I think streamability is a thing to talk about) this is one of the games that can if people have an interest about is the perfect game to play.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
A pretty decent game even though it's still in early development! Lacks polish here and there and you may find a bug or two sometimes but it's pretty well-made. 

Worth the full price in my opinion. Having a blast with this one so far.

Things worth mentioning:

-15 levels with 3 different themes (A crypt/tomb/shrine, a desert city and an oriental-style village)
-3 bullet-sponge bosses
-2 playable characters (a cat and a dog)
-A lot of guns, maybe like 40?
-Gun variety is very interesting and fun
-Parkour levels
-Challenge routes in parkour/trap levels
-A heckton of explosions (watch out!)
-Getting absolutely wrecked by enemies or bosses

and so on...

I'm pretty sure this game will be great, given the time. I can't wait to see new content!

review: The game doesn't cost too much and it is worth the price I paid, The art style is great for what the game's environment is. Guns mechanics are great, no Iron sight only weapons with scopes can ADS. Leveling system is quite fair for the player, The more you play the more you can upgrade your talents. You wouldn't be able to upgrades the higher costs talent without progressing far into the stages. It is repetitive, but it is also fun in its way. You will grind further and further just to get to higher stage and just to upgrade higher cost talent. At some point you will reach the "end" where there is nothing left to upgrades and the only thing you can do is shoot. Until then enjoy the game!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This is a fun CO-OP (up to 4 players) FPS. The gun mods, ascensions and talents work together to add replayability, progress, and complexity as you die and try again. And Again. 

Pros:
+gunplay is fun and diverse
+CO-OP online multiplayer (the world needs more of these!)
+high replayability
+low price (less than $20 at the time of review)
+unlockable dog who can shoot two guns while diving through the air (hot fuzz style)


Downsides at the moment are:
-platforming is not the best. Movement is mushy and laggy, which is no problem in the main game, but in optional side areas, you can frustrate yourself trying to get the puzzle scrolls (the devs recognize this and are working on it) 
-boosts and bonus texts are sometimes vague. For example, do the corrosive on-crit-kill explosions built into my gun count as explosive damage, corrosive damage, or both? Some of the text needs another English localization pass as well. It's completely playable though.
-Co-Op is through peer-to-peer networking and can be laggy. Your milage may vary here, but I suggest having the buddy with the best internet host the session.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: At the asking price, Gunfire Reborn is an incredible value for any friends looking to shoot stuff together. You don't have to commit to any huge campaigns or fiddle with settings and menus -- you just boot it up, party together and then play. The mechanics are super straightforward and the item, weapon, enemy, and ability variety is robust enough to keep several runs in a row feeling fresh. Plus the gun-play is satisfying and bug-free -- as far as I can tell at least. I never buy into an Early Access title unless I feel the game will meet my needs in its current state and Gunfire Reborn does not disappoint. Anything they add to this game is just going to build on an already excellent foundation.

Gunfire Reborn's gameplay is so fun, even you play alone or with your friends. But because this game still early access so I think the developer will have many improvement in their full release. I found some minor bugs but it's not a big problem for me because I believe the developer will update the game. Can't wait for the full release of Gunfire Reborn. I highly recommend you to play this game if you want to try a roguelite game with FPS mechanic.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This is an Early Access review

Typically I don't even bother looking at Early Access games, but this one looked so polish and crisp I thought I'd give it a try. You probably keep seeing borderlands thrown around when describing this game. It definitely has that vibe, but in a dungeon-crawling-esque setting. Enemies can have shield or armor on top of their hp, and like borderlands, shock, corrosive, and fire elements each have a use. 

You get 2 weapons plus a starter pistol. You can only carry 2 weapons at a time, so you have to mix and match as best suits you.

Weapons: weapons are quirky, have special effects specific to each gun as well as small bonuses called inscriptions. If you enjoy borderlands weaponry for its wackiness, you'll enjoy these weapons. Most importantly, however, they're all fun and satisfying to use.

Enemies: what makes a great game stand out to me is enemy variation, and this game has it by the spades. If you enjoyed games such as Sanctum 2, Borderlands, Destiny, etc for their enemy variation, you'll like this game.

Movement: like everything else about this game, movement is crisp, responsive, and clean. You can't sprint but you have a dash. 

You'll die a lot at first, but pretty soon you'll get the hang of it. At the moment, my only real complaint is there isn't much content. And by that I mean, I'm at 60 hours and starting to feel the repetition as I grind for the last few unlocks currently available. If this game gets more content, it will have a chance to ascend into GOAT status.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn is a fun rogue-lite FPS with 4 player COOP. The game runs very smoothly at the moment with tons of weapons and abilities that are fun to use. As its still in early access, its not completely filled out. Just like other rogue-lites, you pick up guns and abilities on a per run basis, and then gain points to spend on permanent upgrades to health, shields, ammo, and other stats and abilities.

The shooting is fun and tight. Enemies are deadly and can easily kill you in a couple hits if you don't avoid their attacks. There seems to be a bit of a story involved, but its not central in any way. 

The 4 player coop works really well. I can't comment on the lag since I was the host each time, but everything seemed smooth. You don't compete for powerups as everyone gets their own. It is definitely more fun to play with friends than alone.

This is a solid game on it's own merits, and it is certainly a solid value for about $12. Enjoy!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Note: As of this post, I'm on the verge of defeating normal difficulty solo.

Generally has 'easy bake' FPS mechanics that flows quite well to the games pace of it's Rouge-like, dungeon run, PvE nature. As an early-release title for it's given price, there is definitely a lot of potential put into the games design - giving possibilities for new playable characters with different playstyle opportunities. 

The maps do get a bit repetitive, seeing the same line-up (Catacomb - Desert - Fjord) and up scaling difficulty (bigger enemy shields).

The only con to this game is how linear the use of soul essence is as an important currency to player leveling. Simply 'Play, Farm, Die' is easy to understand for any player to grasp and can continue to do so without any thought. But the RNG nature of this game for enemies & chest rewards; plus a sometimes brutal difficulty increase as a reward for defeating a boss, feels grueling to experience; at the very least not fun.

If gaining soul essence had a stronger incentive like essence skill tree access in the 'resting area', in anticipation for upcoming difficulty; or maybe players can use soul essence for opportunities to guarantee a rare scroll or inscription appropriate to the immediate dungeons; than players could have a stronger interaction with influencing the more immediate state of their experience; rather than waiting for sweet death so they can start over again. And again.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn is an extremely-addicting roguelite FPS inspired by titles like Risk of Rain and Borderlands set in a stylized fantasy China. In Early Access, the game more than holds its own and has a solid foundation held up by its dedicated developers. Even after reaching max level with nearly 65 hours in the game, GR's gameplay is so fun that I still keep coming back to it.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
GR's gameplay loop is similar to other roguelite titles; kill enemies, get resources, spend resources, repeat. As of June 26, two characters are available to play, which I'll go over later in this review. You're able to carry three weapons, with your first being your basic weapon with unlimited ammo. There are three elemental damage types for weapons: Fire, Shock, and Decay, and this results in a rock paper scissors-like style to counter enemies. Shock tears through shields, but is weak against armor and health. Decay rots down armor but is weak against shields and health. Fire burns through health but is weak against both armor and shields. In a coordinated group, you'll want to diversify the elements you have access to kill enemies efficiently. If you're slick, you can even combo elements, like Fire and Decay, causing an explosion.

The game rewards you for accuracy and knowing thy enemy. You're able to target specific weak points on foes, such as the head or back on certain enemies, to deal increased damage. Loot is Diablo-like, and you'll always be making judgments on what weapons you pick up according to what kind of playstyle and build you're looking to achieve. For example, if you're going with a MORE DAKKA minigun build, you might want to look for weapons that have rate of fire or ammo gain stats. If you're going for a sniper build, you might want something like crit% to increase your crit damage on a headshot.

As you progress through levels, you'll gain scrolls which buff your abilities or give you unique effects. These scrolls will synergize with specific builds. For example, one scroll permanently removes your shields but allows you to regen health passively. This synergizes extremely well with another scroll that increases your damage when you have no shields. Scrolls often build off each other this way, and you're able to explore builds for each character because of it. I remember a build I ran with the dual-wielding dog that removed my shields but allowed me to leech health because of my Fire damage on enemies, effectively making me nigh-immortal so long as I was continually shooting enemies.

You have a dash and two abilities, grenade and active. Your grenade and active change according to which character you play. There are two characters currently available in the game as of June 26, both with their distinct playstyles. The Crown Prince is built all around elemental damage and field control. He has a grenade that lays down a poison cloud that deals DoT damage and an energy orb he can throw out to freeze enemies. Ao Bai, the Dog, is more of a brawler built around no-nonsense damage. His grenade is just straight-up explosion damage, and his active is the ability to Dual Wield. There is some speculation of a third character coming up, which may be a sniper, but that isn't confirmed just yet.

There are currently three stages, which each take around 20-30 minutes based on how fast you go. Each stage is broken up into four to five levels. The levels are designed like arenas, where you'll need to kill enemies to open the exit to go into the next room, similar to titles like DOOM. Occasionally, you'll also be able to enter secret rooms. These rooms can be one of two types: Platforming or Combat. Platforming can include dodging boulders Indiana Jones-style or leaping across platforms. Combat means you'll need to clear a room and often kill a miniboss that spawns at the end. Either way, you'll get a scroll at the end of it.

At the final level of each stage, you'll fight a boss. These bosses will be hard when you meet them, but they all have counterplay. The game can be hard, but it is never unfair. You can avoid every single attack an enemy can throw out if you know when to dash.

[h1]Presentation[/h1]
GR's setting is based in a fantasy China. You play anthropomorphic characters, like the Crown Prince, a cat, and Ao Bai, a dog. Enemies are either humanoid or also anthropomorphized animals. For example, there's a sniper enemy in the game who are seagulls in straw hats. Later, you'll find beefcake Sharks who reel you in with a hook and punch you. No enemy is a carbon-copy of another. You'll have to approach each one differently, each requiring a specific type of counterplay.

Weapons are also extremely unique and endearing. Two of my favorite weapons are the Justice and Fire Dragon. Justice is a red lizard that shoots out remote-detonation bombs when you squeeze it. You reload it by slapping the lizard over the head. Fire Dragon is, as you guessed, a dragon who wraps around your hand and shoots fire at your enemies like a flamethrower. Most weapons feel very good to shoot, and I can't help but smile at the ones with unique reload animations such as the mentioned two.

[h1]Progression[/h1]
GR has a strong foundation for progression. You have two currency types: Coin and Soul Essence, and you gather both as you kill enemies. You can spend coins at a merchant to buy weapons or ammo, health, or grenades, or you can spend coin at the craftsman, who can upgrade your weapons' DPS. You lose your weapon upgrades and items if you end a run. You spend Soul Essence on talents at the end of each run, and all the talents you've bought with Soul Essence carry over to future runs.

There are also character-specific talents, like increased damage during Dual Wielding for the Dog or faster Shield Regen for the Cat.

[h1]Design[/h1]
In Early Access, the game's inevitably going to be rough around the edges. Certain vital features aren't available in the game, such as the lack of a pinging function or a scoreboard. The game is also peer-to-peer. If the host leaves, the run ends. But I do recall there being talks of adding dedicated servers. The English localization isn't as good as it can be. Wording on certain things can be incorrect or weird-sounding grammar-wise. And there are little bugs here and there, but there's nothing game-breaking. They'll get ironed out as the developers work on the game.

As it is, a lot of love and care is put into GR, and it shows. The devs are dedicated, and they genuinely listen to their player base and make adjustments to the game based on feedback. I wish other developers were like GR's. Even with the language barrier, their love for the game and their players shines through.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
GR reborn is a game that may be rough around the edges, but it has a rock-solid foundation that still proves extremely fun and addicting. It's criminal that the devs are only selling this for $12. It's an absolute steal. If you're a fan of roguelites, this title should be in your library, no questions.

Support an excellent, unique game that will only become even better from here. GR is an easy 10/10, and I highly recommend giving this a try with the low entry price.

this game is a fps in tight little dungeon spaces.  Here's why it sucks.

Think of it like a dungeon crawler, but the dungeon is VERY cramped.  The walls and obstacles have that annoying thing where when you try to shoot next to it, it hits that invisible part of the wall that goes all around it.  Also, your character will slow or even snag on walls and obstacles just by walking next to them.  All this combined makes for a pretty miserable experience alone.  How could you overlook this?

The game has the most annoying forced tutorial in the world, frame rate STOPS at random times, but it does have a small variety of guns.
developer_response: Sorry, about the issue that players may be stuck at barriers around the wall, we will optimize it in the following update. We will also make some adjustments on tutorial in the future. Thanks for your feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I found this game whilst browsing Twitch. And honestly, I've had an absolute blast so far with this game.

The core concept of the game is a roguelike FPS as advertised. Currently in Early Access you are dropped into 1 of 3 zones, each ending with a boss and a portal to the next. Each time you die or kill the last boss, you are taken to your perks screen where you buy perks that carry over game to game and make you stronger as you invest more time into the game.

The weapons system in this game is akin to a dungeon crawler or a looter shooter. There is a selection of weaponry that all have their gimmicks, yet come with randomized stats that you can sometimes reroll and level up at certain chests and the Blacksmith NPC.

The heroes, currently only two, play quite differently one from one another. Each have 18 'Ascension' perks that alter, improve, or change how the character operates.

Overall, the game is quite good for what it is currently. For once, it appears the current developers are invested in bug fixing the game, but I do hope it continues to expand with more levels, characters, and weapons in the future. It's a good start, and I would love this game to expand into something that matches the quality of Dead Cells, Binding of Isaac, Heroes of Hammerwatch, and the multitude of other fantastic roguelikes on the market.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I had high hopes for this game as it has been described as being similar to Dead Cells, Borderlands, and Risk of Rain. I have played a lot of all three of those games. This game is like none of those games. 

I imagine people draw these comparisons due to the fact that weapons drop out dead enemies randomly, there are skills to acquire, and because you can get resources from the environment. So why isn't it like any of those games?

This game is lacking in polish first of all. The argument that it is in early access could be made, but this level of polish is fundamental. Enemies don't make sounds when approaching you, feedback on being hit is non existent, enemies and their head hitboxes are comically large, shooting feels wavy and airy even on low sensitivity, enemies are so so easy while bosses have mechanics that make them unfun, feeling like a "hard" enemy that is designed to keep you playing the same part over and over just to unlock more for your character (which would be fun, if this game was fun). 

This game has some interesting ideas, but the execution feels like it is trying to take from a lot of things without bringing anything incredible to the table. This game takes from all of the previously mentioned games without improving on that formula. It's actually just a worse way to try and play these games, which is why I feel it is similar to none of these. I could see maybe playing with some friends, but honestly, there are a lot better games I could be playing with my friends. I do not recommend this game.
developer_response: Feedback on being hit does exist in the game, and we will continue the optimization. Thanks for your feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
The latest update nerfed everything through the skill tree. It took out combos that were very fun and powerful. I understand that they want balance but what they forget is that this is a co-op Rogue lite game. If you have the right combo you will find a way to be overpowered. Just look at other famous rogue lites-Binding of isaac-Heroes of hammerwatch-Risk of Rain-Enter the Gungeon.

Nerfing popular items is not the right way. If you want players to use a specific gun or scroll then those items need to be buffed. Human psychology responds more to positive reinforcement. 

For example. Fire enthusiast was an item that causes constant Fire damage but gives you a bit of lifesteal when using fire weapons. They then increased the fire Damage over time to a point where it only has a niche value. No player will pick up this scroll without having an established build. Couple that with the fact that it's a tier 1 scroll that you will most likely receive before it's higher leveled partner and it's obvious why no one uses it.   

In the Current state the game shows lots of promise. 
1-This game was translated from an asian language and it shows. Lots of grammatical issues. Makes some of the guns effects hard to understand. 

2-Multiplayer is broken right now. The ping is unbearable. Please fix the Server Issues. 


3-Revive mechanics are wack yo.  The new revive system through the shop leaves something to be desired. Using your teammates money to revive you. IF there is a peddler.

Overall great game.. Good graphics. Weapons feel good, which important for shooting games for some reason. 

The game feels like there aren't enough opportunities for gaining power between levels. 
RNG has to really be on your side to advance. There isn't enough gun drops so variety is very low on singleplayer. 

This isn't an issue on multiplayer, but that has it's own issues.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: It's good, but not yet great.  More content will come, but the balance still feels a bit off.  There's a fine line between difficult but interesting and difficult but boring.  Too often late game battles are tedious instead of epic.  But the foundation is good.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is absolutely phenomenal, i purchased this game about 10 days after its release, and glanced at it and said hey. This looks like for the king and borderlands mixed with risk of rain. BOY WAS I RIGHT. the price for this game certainly is well worth it, the devs have been consistently updating and releasing patches for any bugs in the game, i myself and my buddy have found a few bugs. He comes home from work, i finish my class work and we get on this game and just grind it. Im kinda an achievement hunter and just had to get every achievement, I am almost there only 7 more achievement. 

Overall i would have to say:
Playstyle: easy to grasp
Replay value: extreme, hopefully devs will add more levels and more content within the next year
Gameplay: The game plays like a looter shooter mixed in with a risk of rain aspect
Original state vs current: about 2 weeks ago, there was no revive option if you died, it was more unforgiving, but they did add a way to buy back your teammates but its expensive, but more forgiving than before, there were some game breaking bugs that were patched out, there were also a couple fun bugs i loved which was glitching out of the map before the final stage. sadly it was patched. 

All in All, i love playing this game, its relaxing not stressful, some RNG involved sometimes you just gotta know what to build but the styles vary alot. Have fun, try this game out

review: So far, the game's missing content and it needs more time in the oven. But holy shit, I'd be lying if I didn't say they nailed the mechanics and gunplay. It's challenging and rewarding, albeit a tinch grindy. Is it worth your money? Absolutely. I can't say my foresight's always panned out well, I mean, I'm one of the smooth brains who bought Sean Murray's lies, but I honestly don't see any possibility where this game goes through the shitter. The devs have made it more clear than ever that they care about the game, being so quick as to punch out patches within three days of receiving the bug report. So, this game's got potential and I have high hopes that Duoyi IE can make this into a success, because even now, they deserve it.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: I paid $12 for the best roguelite game I've ever played. Fun great and fluid gameplay, fun enemies that all have counters and move-sets. The game has 3 elements that all serve a purpose against the 3 types of health bars, scrolls that mix gameplay up a lot and can give you really fun buffs (and nerfs) to use and test with. The style and art design is everything its supposed to be and more, the areas are great and the enemies design is so cool to me. As I'm typing this I am trying to think of negative things about the game and all i can think of is there isnt enough of it (which is always the best problem to have, especially since its in EARLY ACCESS). The balancing in this is game is pretty damn good too, the enemies always felt fair and if I died it's because I overextended or misplayed. The gun balancing is pretty good but sometimes it feels like you end up using the same couple weapons but even then if you want to use other weapons you won't suffer for it. All in all ive never heard of these devs before this game but if the developers are reading this, GOOD STUFF. 8.5/10

review: While the start is certainly slow and may be a bit of a grind based on prior experience, once you begin unlocking talents and in particular the ability to carry forward the progression currency, this becomes easily one of the most fun games of this year. I look forward to what the developer has in store for the future.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Underexposed, underrated, and underpriced, this game is SERIOUSLY fun.

It plays well in co-op, but just as well solo.

Each run lasts between 20-60 minutes, which is a good healthy amount. It's not an easy game, and you will die. But just as the Dark Souls experience goes, learning and building muscle memory is fun. Every run is different, and you'll find yourself catering to both your play style and item drops.

Speaking of item drops, the weapon design is sick. Each enemy has their own behavior, which you learn to play around.

Early access as it should be - weekly updates from the developers. The game is pretty well balanced, but still allows room for some insanely-powerful synergy, which is always fun to discover.

Buy it, you won't regret it.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is a blast solo and with a partner.
Fun gameplay loop.
Well designed enemies.
Different builds add variety to the experience.
Reminds me of ROR2 X Borderlands.
Probably needs a bit of balance tweaking so certain abilities and weapons become more viable.

Hoping for many more levels/bosses/enemies in full release, as that will increase replayability.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: This game is extremely fun, a good variety of weapons and relics that allow the player create a unique play style on the fly with each run. I'm 38 hours in and have only beaten the game once, whether that is a testament to my own lack of skill or simply that the game itself is challenging (which is what I choose to believe). If anyone is looking for a casual roguelike shooter this game is for you.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: The game is alright. People describe this as a mix of Risk of Rain 2, Borderlands, and Enter the Gungeon (of which, I only like one and immensely dislike the others). I would not say that is accurate. If there was one that it did match out of the three, it would be essentially a linear Borderlands with smaller levels. A more condense (and as a result, solid) package in a way. I wish it didn't have stat-increases that you purchase after runs because it makes it feel as if the player will run into a statistical wall that they can't get past unless they grind level up tokens. I have yet to discover every build but at the beginning of the game it feels like they all the viable ones are just elemental builds. This is a result of all the totems that you use to give yourself a perk often have elemental bonuses. Enemies also take more damage from certain elements. Guns do feel good to me because they actually do damage surprisingly. I haven't unlocked every weapon yet. I hope they have more variety and secondary skills because most of the guns I have only have a primary fire. I'm not a big fan of the first boss because he runs off to recharge shields and health, which only prolongs the fight. It does bring enemies in to give you ammo, but I'd prefer if they just attacked during his fight with me. Overall, I think the game could do a lot of things better. I haven't unlocked everything yet and I imagine there's a lot of content. I hope they keep adding more that's actually good because it breathes life into a roguelite. It's certainly as a package, better than every other FPS roguelite I've played or know of off the top of my head. Cautious recommendation, I'd recommend trying it out for two hours and then returning it if uncertain.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
At the moment unplayable due to balancing issues but it has a great potential and it is super smooth regarding controls.
Unfortunately, this game took the worst from borderlands and risk of rain 2 - tragic elemental system which is only required for health bar minigame "yellow hp bar means I need green damage, blue hp means I need blue damage, red hp - red damage, yay, fun, I almost pooped a little thinking about the excitement". It could be just dps+effect and that's it, no need for this nonsense that ruins the fun.
Regarding risk of rain 2 - amazing getting one shot system and barely dodgable homing attacks.

EDIT1: After additional 23 hours and reaching level 90 I can say that balancing is turbo terrible. 80% of weapons are beyond useless especially those that don't have element or aren't explosive. There are only 2 builds: elemental fusion (2 element combo) and one shot bazooka build, that is it.
One of the most absurd things is that the most builds use constant weapon swapping. Most runs take up to an hour, so it becomes very tedious very quickly to weapon swap for an hour. It would be fine if only 1 build had it but both characters even have skills that are related to this, several occult scrolls are related to this. Atrocious.
And a cherry on top is the fact, that updates are nerfing useful stuff and leaving op enemies and crappy weapons as they are. So at this point this game is at the path to ruin.
developer_response: Thanks for your feedback, we are working on the game balance, please give us more time, stay tuned.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Early access game, for the most part it is quite a fun game to play.  Co-op play is a must to advance through the permanent skill tree because as you progress through each scenario/dungeon, the enemies get a bit harder to kill.  There are two skill trees in the game, one permanent and one temporary as you progress through the game.  The secondary skill tree is interesting because you get and encounter certain buffs/debuff items that for the most part will help in making you stronger.  For the most part, in the beginning you'll start off with a basic gun and will pick up other types of guns as loot drops from the monsters killed.  You can only carry 3 guns, one of which is your basic gun with weak unlimited ammo.  Different types of guns use one of three types of ammo that you pick up throughout the area.   Certain gun types do affect your movement speed.
Now, the permanent skill tree needs a bit of work because the only way to progress through this skill tree is by collecting Soul essences(SE) that you get from enemy kills and not all of them drops this.  SE can be spent between scenario clearing or when you die.  The accumulated SE can't be saved up and has to be spent entirely at the end or your dungeon run.  Initially, you can collect enough SE to clear the first tier but it gets grindy to get to the next tier because now it ramps up so high that you'll not collect enough SE to progress very far.  On top of all this, if you die in the dungeon, you can spend these precious SE to revive yourself.  But if you die again, you'll not have enough SE to upgrade your permanent skill tree to the next level, this can become quite frustrating after a certain number of unsuccessful dungeon runs and all collected items are reset to zero including the accumulated SE.  This grinding fest can become tiresome and frustrating, if playing by yourself.  As an example, let's say you do an unsuccessful run, die and at the permanent skill tree menu. You've accumulated 28 SE, depending on skill tier you can only spend points in one skill tree item.  Tier skills cost go like 5, 10, 15, 20, etc. you get the idea.  You spend all the SE that you can but ultimately you'll lose the remaining SE because it does not carry over to your next attempt at the dungeon run; later on there is a permanent skill tree pick that will allow you to carry over a certain amount.
Shield and life bars: this is influenced by your permanent skill tree (temporary dungeon item buffs to some degree).  Shields will auto-restore itself but your hit points don't and can only be restore just a little by either monster drops, dungeon vendor(purchased by in-game coins), or item bonus buffs.  Some enemies have shields and armor bars that you have to overcome too.
Weapons: There's different types of guns that you can pick up with different stats/effects and uses different ammo.  You can only carry two special guns at a time so pick your preferences on which to carry.  So far running out ammo doesn't seem to be an issue but you can run out of them and have to switch to another weapon or drop to your weak default gun. Special guns from dungeons do not carry over to the next scenario. You'll always start with your basic gun only.
Item buffs:  You'll encounter different buff items as you clear each area from area chests.  Some helpful, some not or I could not tell the difference. These buff items are random and do not carry over from one scenario to the next.
Enemy AI:  To some degree, not bad.  A good mixture of melee and ranged attackers to keep you moving.  The enemies will move to cover or dodge your gunfire.
That's about it for now, I'll update this more if there are noteworthy changes. It is an early access game after all.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
We'll start with the good: the gameplay is solid - a cross between borderlands gunplay and roguelike structure. Mechanically sound, lots of variation in weapons, perks, and enemies - it has the core of what great roguelikes/roguelites need. Balance is imperfect, but the game is still very much being tweaked in that sense, and in my opinion, having broken combinations in a roguelike makes it more fun, and I consider it balanced if they're rare and have conversely terrible combos that render your run hilariously impotent.

I am a little bit disappointed in the way progression is handled between runs right now. During runs you collect currency used for post-game upgrades, your Talent Tree. A set of the upgrades you can invest in will enable weapons you find in future runs to have more properties attached to them, giving them more variety - these bits of progression are ones I consider proper in a roguelike structure, they unlock more possibilities in your future runs, but not always in a good way, and encourage more creativity in making combinations work, or just generally deciding whether or not to take a weapon. However, the rest of the upgrades are just objective upgrades to your character eg more health, more shields, more damage; basically they make your numbers bigger and better with no real change to how you play, which feels like padding the content.

Overall, I would recommend the game, just with a bit of nitpicking

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
The game's not done yet and some of the translations are a bit rough, so the English version feels a bit unfinished.

Having said that, this game is insanely fun. The mechanics are a bit of a throwback to the strafe-n-shoot style of old FPS games, like Quake and the original Duke Nukem 3D. But then the designers added a bunch of clever mechanics in the form of elemental damage, random scrolls, weapon mods, and talent trees. And somehow the combat system feels particularly solid, much more engaging than AAA shooters.

Oh, and the co-op mode is unbelievably fun. Shooters like this often feel weird with multiplayer because there's no way to map the main single-player game (quests, waypoints, progression, etc) to multiplayer. But because this game is effectively an FPS roguelike, the multiplayer mode experience is exactly the same as singleplayer - with friends! 

If the videos look fun to you, then this is your game.

(srsly though, this game isn't Risk of Rain, stop saying it looks or plays like it at all xD A table is not a chair, dudes. You can't claim two games compare to one another just because they both share one mechanic)

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Was it worth the price, I SURE THINK SO. after 55+hours playing this game yes I 100% believe this game is well worth the price.  The developer has been listening to feedback, which is great.  This game plays/feels like Dungeon Defenders but if DD had some platforming, and was FPS non stop.  As a person who isn't that great at Roguelite games it does an amazing job. After 25 hours I don't believe I had beaten the 2nd boss, yet now I can almost 75% beat the 2nd boss. I have beaten the current game, but after you beat it on normal you have "Elite". At this moment I'm not going to try Elite. 
In summary if you liked the feel of DD, but want a pure FPS with roguelite elements than get this. 

Pros:
Developer
Rogue Like
Level Design simple but crisp.
Look/appeal factor. 
Weapons are unique
Both current playable characters feel unique, and may have different roles. 
Rewards 
Platforming unique but difficult (it's very very little) and the recent changes were great to it.

Cons
If you die during the boss animation (3rd boss) you can't be "revived". 
There are still bugs but it's beta, but not a single one I have seen that's game breaking.
developer_response: Hi, we will make some adjustment to polish our game. Thanks for playing our game and providing feedback.

review:
Yeah, it's great. Addictive, plays nice, balanced pretty well (if not pretty easy as far as 2 current difficulties go), mildly grindy (with exceptions. looking at you *demonlore*), even with (so far) lacking content gameplay loop is satysfying and what's there feels complete (besides one effing loading screen art that shows character that is not in the game yet and he looks soooo promising). Probably the only places to criticise are translation which is...slightly edit machine translation? idk. needs work. Aaaaand...(plz don't ban) questionably sourced assets? Absolutely not a problem from players POV but a funny thing to mention and funny thing to discover while playing.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Fun Rogue-like Lite game in early Access:
+ Progression System
+ Level Ups for varying build
+ Cool variety of scrolls, some upgrades, some with trade-offs and interesting cursed scroll system for trade-offs or spicing things up
+ Interesting Arsenal of Weapons
+ Diverse cast of enemies, keeps you on your toes
- Can use more characters
- Some level upgrades are clearly superior over others
- Some scrolls are wonky, like "blood ammo": they do not work properly
- Few oppertunities to trade scrolls at golden chests; so you are better off leaving undesirable scrolls behind.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Do you want a Rogue-like Borderlands? Because this is a Rogue-like Borderlands. 

The gameplay is pretty standard, but can be surprisingly challenging in the later areas. Just leveling up your character each run doesn't necessarily guarantee the game will get easier and weapon drops play a huge role in just how successful you'll be. Each and every gun has some little interesting quark that makes it fun to use, although some guns definitely need a re-balance as they range from incredible to absolutely useless even if they have a decent inscription. Most of the runs I've been able to complete boiled down to getting lucky with crit damage scrolls and weapon inscriptions to hit insanely hard along with the deflection shield to take next to no damage whatsoever. 

Besides some bugs that the devs are constantly ironing out and a few balancing complaints, it's a pretty damn solid game for how cheap it is and it's definitely worth picking up. 

I do hope that they take a look at adding in some form of endless mode or even a few more zones because you can easily beat normal/elite in less than an hour if you get the right gear. Thankfully the game is extremely replayable and just outright fun.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: At the moment of this review this game is still in Early Access, and that's why I can definitely recommend it. There are still many things that need to be done to get this game ready for launch (like the abysmal localization/translation issues and horribly unplaytested jumping puzzles), but despite that the game just has that feeling that it will really be something special once it releases. Blending the rogue-lite and looter-shooter genres is a match made in video game heaven and I'm grateful to be here for its inception. The fact that this game is so cheap is really a testament to how amazing video games can be and still be marketable to those on a budget. Buy this game.

If you're on the fence do it, well worth it.
It is "easy" solo if you think out the room and can get to the last boss with maybe a few fails. This game really should be played with friends imo, makes the game harder and allows you to swap guns, scrolls and help feed eachothers builds!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
If you want to get the most out of your time in this game, you'll have to learn parkour for some bonus levels to access useful scrolls which augment some aspect of your gameplay in meaninful ways. You don't really need to use parkour outside of these levels, but it does seem the world is built to allow for you to move around in surprising ways. 
Gunplay is solid, it feels impactful to fire and to throw grenades - the sound design really does a wonderful job here. 
There's challenge, and you can die for reasons you can't necessarily control, but you'll still have earned some points to spend for permanent upgrades - these things seriously start to have a lot of impact later on too, but each talent is useful.  
Can't complain, could use some touching-up, but stands as a 8/10 for me.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This is a nice little FPS rogue-like. There is permanent progression (which is quite solid), pretty diverse weapons, and quite good gameplay. 

Pros 
- Fast gameplay, snappy action
- Seems very well optimized, or at least compatible with lower end machines. Never seen it drop below 140 FPS on a mid-high end PC.
- Multiplayer!
- Loads of ammo and nades so you never really run out, making the gun-and-run style flow seamlessly
- Most of the upgrades feel super powerful, but the game is scaled accordingly well - you get both a challenge, and that feeling of "being overpowered"
- Permanent progression/character upgrading feels pretty good and has a noticeable difference
- The elemental system feels pretty good though some of the descriptors are a little unclear

Neutral
- Tile-based levels can feel repetitive, but also means you know the layouts after a few runs
- Some abilities/talents definitely feel much stronger than others, which makes the weaker ones unappealing
- Most of the weapons are okay to decent, while some are overpowered af and others are absolute garbage. 
- Some enemies feel kinda same-y (especially in the first zone)
- Visual direction may not be appealing to everyone
- Some weapons and animations are clearly ripped off from Overwatch lol

Cons
- Still EA so limited content overall (2 character choices, fairly small artifact/"scroll" pool)
- Some weapons are definitely overtuned, which means a lot of runs might end up feeling similar (Kunai/crit/poison build)
- Some hitboxes feel very very off or misaligned
- Perma progression can feel super slow after level 40 or so due to upgrades costing ridiculous amounts of currency
- Some visual jittering due to limited animation frames; more noticeable at 144 hz

Recommended if you're looking for a light looter-shooter or a rogue light FPS.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
They need to have stages of early alpha when a developer marks a game as early alpha, because some early alpha games are mostly complete and just need a little work. This is the OTHER end of that spectrum, where it's something you would show as a proof of concept for the first level of an actual game, using stock assets as placeholders.

They would need to remake the whole damn game before I'd recommend someone buy this for anything more than $5-$10, and that's if you're desperate for something to do for an hour, because by then you've seen it all. The only thing left is grinding the same build over and over because there's only one build for each character.

There is no "Rouge" elements here. The maps are the same exact maps every single time, in the same order. They're all generic looking and flat....I legitimately think the developers didn't even make the maps or models... They look so cheap and corporate I wouldn't be surprised if those were leftover assets sold by some closed-out Korean MMO Developer from like...2000.

And right now? There's two builds. That's it. 

That's because the game is so "Basic" with it's one randomized element, the scrolls and chalices (Items and "levels") that there's no synergy or neat effects to discover. 

Sure, "Chance to throw a free grenade" sounds nice, except grenades are already LITERALLY POURING OUT OF THE GROUND. Sure, it "pairs" will "regenerate a grenade every 10 seconds" but in the end, you're playing the same exact character as everyone else. There's no in-character diversity.

If you are the cat, you are playing elemental damage and occasionally pressing the "skill" button.

If you are the dog, you are playing explosive damage and occasionally pressing the "skill" button.

You can't build these characters any other way, because EVERY skill that you get funnels you into these builds. You can't make a cat build where he uses explosive weapons or uses stealth using his "smoke" (poison) grenades. You can't make the dog better at using elemental weapons or being a rushdown dual SMG user. And even if you did force it, you're just making the game a slog for yourself because you're denying yourself upgrades to counteract the horrific health scaling of some of these enemies. 

You have to pick your character knowing that you're going to be stuck following the same path as you did last game.

And that also means finding two of the maybe 3 "good" weapons and then using those for the whole game. The rest of the guns do such terrible damage even against the enemy types they're "weak" to (also the weaknesses are either not working properly or they managed to code fire to be weaker against enemies who are bare flesh (Which fire is supposed to be strong against) than enemies who are in shields. (Which is supposed to be lightnings thing.)

If you're the kind of person who actually enjoys watching terrible, boring movies just to laugh at them, this game is for you.
It's like "The Room" but in videogame form.

The final version is supposed to contain "more perfection."

They should start with trying to make the basic gameplay good and enjoyable before they start shooting for perfection. Right now, there's unavoidable attacks that one shot you, environmental damage with no visual indiactors, Enemies getting stuck off map and ending the run for everyone, puzzles and challenges that actually cannot be completed.

[b] ‚Ä¢ TL/DR ‚Ä¢ [/b]

Honestly, if they just upped the movement speed, jump height and gunplay to be more snappy and less slow and grindy, It might be more fun, but as it stands? No. I would not suggest this game. And do I have faith about the future of the game? Not really. It seems pretty low effort and cash-grabby.

I do not really have faith that the developers can even make the game more enjoyable though updates and patching, since their current "idea" is just as generic as humanly possible. There's no substance whatsoever. The gunplay doesn't feel nice, the sound design sucks, the graphics are bland and look like assets. I don't really think this is something you can save, because there was never any heart behind the creation of it to begin with, and it shows.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is a blast, its super fun and quick to pick up. Obviously it's still in early access but it's really stable.
There isn't a ton of content to do but it's really replayable as it's a roguelike with permanent upgrades, randomized paths and some good challenging bosses.

It's not super hardcore in terms of optimizing builds which is nice, makes for a more fun experience and easy to jump into random matches, as you don't have to communicate with your teammates too much.

I'd like to see a ping added for enemies, in order to call for help/aggro, that sorta thing as there are enemies that are very difficult to take out on your own.

I would recommend this game to anyone looking for something fun without too many strings attached!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
First I would like to say, this review will be in three segments whole. The first, visuals, the second, audio. Last but not least, the content/game-play.

The low poly graphics are not original but beautiful. It is not a secret that low poly graphics are simple to make, but they allow for more of the beauty of the game to show. This game, unlike the common triple-A game, does not need amazing graphics to be fun. The animations are crisp for most things that include the character such as gun reload, gunshot, ability use, etc. If I were to change anything involving graphics, it would be enemy animations. I don't find them to be bad, in a way, I see them to be repetitive. For example, the first boss is often too slow to catch up to the player at absolute max speed, including scrolls and dash that effect so. This forms a long-winded still frame of the large entity that is right in front of you. There is also a great number of visual effects with particles and the like but I know the devs patch many of them daily. The last thing I can think of when it comes to visuals is the map. The map design is very original and fun. What I don't like is how bland the first set of stages is with the dark blue and seemingly nothing else. It would be nice to see tome texture or perhaps a wider variety of colors.

For audio, I will talk of music then the sound fx later on. 
The music is good, but not outstanding. I often find myself listening to my list of songs because the in-game music can be both too frantic and too calm for the situation at hand. I would also like the team to flesh out, perhaps, a different ost in general. I will not push this too hard as this is just personal taste and music does not make or break a game. 
The sound fx are often a little buggy when character actions are protruded quickly along with enemy interactions that bog with the sound emitted. These bugs could include silent shots, very loud claiming sounds of scrolls, and player upgrades. Along with much more that I can not think of. 

The game-play is where this game stands tall; it is quick-paced, thought-provoking, and replay-able. No matter what gun you head-shot with, whether that be a gun that only does around 70 damage when you do so or a gun that does 4000, it is still just as satisfying. The enemies have A.I that is memorable and easy to attend as your playtime increases.
 For example, each boss and elite monster seems impossible until you learn the power your utilities have. This includes your character's kit or the scrolls and upgrades you get through time. 
While I would like to throw straight compliments at the devs the whole time, I would also like them to know my feedback on the overall game-play loop and content. The loop is fun, just repetitive. The leveling system earns you powers and great abilities but I would like to see more ability and less percentage count increase. Sure, taking overall less damage is great, but a different type of smoke bomb would be good too. I would also like to see more enemies and guns added to the game. But I will not complain too much about content such as that because the devs are most definitely focusing on patches at the moment. I just hope to see more content soon. 

This is all I have to say about this game, for now. I hope you all have a nice day!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game, in a nutshell as described by Woolie on YouTube, has the skill trees and weapon gameplay of Borderlands, combat pace and action of Doom, and has the gameplay loop of Risk of Rain 2; all three games which are hella fun! The game contains a variety of playstyles perfect which can be complimented by the skill tree which you can progress up, the weapons you can unlock in-game, and not to mention you can play up to 4 characters! I'd absolutely recommend this despite it being Early Access; rather, I'd actually recommend it BECAUSE it's in Early Access! It has tons of more content on it's way and I don't regret it especially when it only costs $12! 

TL;DR: Gameplay is amazing, has character/weapon progression for different playstyles, really cheap, 4 Player Co-op, would HIGHLY recommend!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: This game is literally Borderlands 2 Endgame from start to finish. Each gun is unique and has play style-altering variants, so in a sense, each weapon (although at the time of this review there's only 34) is a legendary weapon. There's also the scroll system which are run exclusive perks you pick up, and the ascension system that levels you up as you play, it's excellent and a well flushed out game. It's 12 dollars, buy it bro.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: If you like enter the gungeon or borderlands chances are you'll like this. It checks all the boxes, it has fun guns, fun movement, unique enemies, cool areas, skilltree abilities that take multiple runs to unlock, and really fun combat. Of course it has its minor issues as it is in early development, the main one is the engrish as it has been translated from another language. A lot is wrong with the wording but its still easily understandable and will definitely be changed as the updates progress. Also it runs really well on computers that aren't amazing and over 1000$. All and all I'd say its definitely worth it and it will surely get better as its still being updated often.

review: Gunfire Reborn is just plain fun. It took the combat formula of borderlands, removed all the unnecessary and tedious garbage, and provides a focused and combat centric experience. The controls are fluid and satisfying, the weapons are fun to use, and the enemies have a good enough variation. The game is just fun, and has good replayability. The game could use some content updates and balance patches, but for the price point it is well worth it.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I played 10 minutes of this game the first time I played it and instantly bought it for a buddy so we could run it together. We then Streamed it to our discord channel for the rest of the boys and they all bought it. You'll notice a lot of aspects from a lot of other games even some of the guns seem to have projectiles or play styles similar to other games you've already played. Having said that I personally think they took the best elements from a lot of games and mashed them all together and they have truly created something great, the potential for this game is incredibly high, i just hope they stick to what the game is, i'd like to see a time based competitive system rather than just a straight pvp one, more rooms, more heros, more everything.
Devs are very active and update the game frequently, they are also taking the community into account very seriously right now so if you want to help shape this game, go into the discord and the use the ingame feedback feature so that we can truly make this a game for the ages.

TLDR

If you like games like gungeon, risk of rain 2, borderlands, this game is for you
its a Cell Shaded Procedurely generated fps bullet hell with overwatch guns and projectiles that can get an incredibly long list of traits, along with your hero(es) getting permanent and run specific talents and passives

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
TL;DR at bottom

Pros:
* Frequent game updates and community suggestions get implemented fairly consistently
* Very clean art style
* Good gunplay with variety of weapons
* Okay gun sounds and enemy sounds
* Secrets and non-mandatory bonus platforming sections
* To date 2 characters with very different playstyles and abilities
* Large variety of enemies divided into 3 thematic areas
* Large variety of skills you can gain while playing, resulting in "unique" builds and synergies
* Scratches the Risk of Rain itch of being a rougelike with satisfying power creep if you build your character right and are lucky

Cons:
* Enemies sometimes shoot out of their behinds
* Seemingly lack of enemy composition balance on Elite difficulty, resulting in extremely spongy one shot enemies in extreme cases
* Some enemies have homing missles and/or rapidfire capabilities, making them very difficult to deal with if they surprise you
* Despite the variety of weapons, only a few are actually useful - you collect others as a stopgap solution to deal damage
* You are forced to build characters a certain way in order to keep up with enemy HP creep, which can be a major run killer
* The platforming is sometimes frustrating and sometimes requires precision above what I would expect from a shooter.
* Some scrolls are nigh-unusable with the penalties they incur
* No fox hero to play :(

Random info:
* 4 player peer-to-peer coop. Occassionaly the game will rubberband you during a puzzle, but it seems rare. Netcode seems solid.
* A full run takes around 1h. No endless mode as of now.
* All items need to be unlocked by fulfilling certain conditions. Took ~60 runs (including failures) to unlock everything

TL;DR
A very well made game that is a pretty great coop experience and replacement for RoR 2, when you get tired of it. I intend to keep on playing this, and do so at least once a day. It has its flaws, but you can learn to overcome them and appreciate the challenge. The developer(s?) are working really hard and churning out updates in a really good rhythm, listening to the community as they go. Worth giving it an honest try, especially if you have friends you play with on the regular.

review:
An extremely solid rougelite FPS, easy and fun to play alone or in a group. The mechanics are extremely solid and playing the game multiple times rewards you in both future play-throughs and the current run.
Plus the games like 12 dollars which and it is EASILY worth the price.

The only negatives I can attribute are to early access and even then theres suprisingly few, like maybe one or two mechanics are annoying or not polished such as a certain enemy or some of the ways reviving is handled, but otherwise the game is truly great.

I especially look forward to future character additions because I find that only having two at the moment isn't great but since its EA I can easily forgive that. Personally I hope they add a rabbit character but that's me.

TLDR: Should you buy this? Yes. It is totally worth the price at 12 dollars and its only going to get better.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
[h1] Gunfire Reborn[/h1]


So like, this game is like [u]Borderlands[/u] mixed with a hint of  [u]Dead Cells[/u]. Gunfire Reborn gives you so many options in every run, I don't think in the 20 hours so far I have had the same build. You can base a build around a gun you find, that have a bunch of different modifiers, or base it off your ascensions (aka what powers you up after each 'area'. The difficulty scales reasonably, and in multiplayer it has its own challenges. It feels kind of like  [u]Slay the spire[/u] at times as well, because you need to build in a certain way to defeat certain enemies, as some have armor or shields, and these enemies are encountered around the same time. So far this early access game has been fun, and should continue to be fun for a handful of hours. Excited to see how this game gets updated, but

[b] Gameplay 8/10 [/b] (Very satisfying to play and win, especially with Elite mode.)
[b] Story 5/10 [/b] (Not much going on here yet)
[b] Graphics 8/10* [/b] (It has a unique style, not super flashy, but styled in a way that it flows well with the game)
[b] Replayability 9/10 [/b] (As stated above, every run feels different)
[b] Potential 8.5/10 [/b] (We could see different areas, random chances on areas, and new characters, plus higher difficulties.)

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
The game, while fun, exhibits a lot of balancing issues common in early life cycle rogue-lite games. In particular, the first boss is particularly rough [for no good reason, almost all of his attacks one shot you], so grinding, and repeatedly dying, is a must in order to beat him. This hasn't been the case in any other roguelite I've played, where with enough skill difficult bosses can be beat even with the most elementary of gear

In addition a lot of enemies will, seemingly at random, take off almost all of your health with one attack; this isn't only unfun, it's incredibly frustrating and takes away from how good this game could be

On the upside, in spite of all this, the game is very fun for short stints. The gunplay is smooth, the guns themselves are varied, the enemy types are [for the most part, looking at you homing arrow archer] fun to fight against and provide variety. The active ability and smoke bomb provide a good deal of strategy with dealing with groups of enemies, and the elemental weaknesses work in tandem with the gunplay to make for some satisfying gameplay, when it works

That being said, I cannot recommend this game to anyone but hardcore roguelike fans until they manage to fix the awful balancing issues

Nice game for ~10‚Ç¨, semi roguelite since you can permanently buff your character after each run in a skill menu which leads to grinding (meh). But as long as the game is fun im fine with it.

Each run you can unlock new abilitys/weapons by achieving missions like "kill x amount of enemy y" for your future runs.

The balancing is "ok". I played the game Solo. The first 24 hours i spend struggeling at the last boss in normal mode, after finishing that one i unlocked the expert mode.

Amusingly enough i finished the harder expert mode in my first run because i got a insanely strong weapon with good traits in the first level...RNG at its best

I hope they add a new level or even mode, since i dont see any reason to keep playing after finishing expert mode.
