title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Really good, especially for the price. My biggest issues are that the game tends to be a way too easy after you start getting a handle of the game and unlocking more content, and there is just not enough of the game (only 2 characters, and 3 "zones" with 5 stages and 1 boss per zone without a "looping" mechanic).

The game is gorgeous and feels really nice to play, and has a Borderlands like arsenal where every gun has unique stats that you'll never see twice but are based off of a couple dozen interesting base weapons. Having 4 player coop with reasonable difficulty scaling is always a plus. Having frequent updates is also cool.

I highly suggest buying this game, especially for its price, especially if you or your friends enjoy FPSs or roguelikes. There is a lot to like here, and while I have a bunch of little niggles (most weapons should be full auto but aren't, a ton of translation errors, money is pretty much worthless, coop is even easier due to revives and being able to swap powerups and weapons, enemies with CC attacks and weapons that slow you down when equipped kill the momentum), my biggest issue is that I want more of this game.

review: This game is incredibly fun, and a shining example of Early-Acess done right imo... however, despite the rating, I am find it difficult to recommend at the moment. The game freezes often enough to the point that - though some of the enemies can be difficult - it is the most common run-killer for me. I will freeze for up to 10 seconds, and when the game catches up - I'm dead. Extremely frustrating, but the potential here is undeniable and immense. I will patiently await an update that fixes this issue (more levels, randomness, and variation wouldn't hurt either).

- Its Damn cheap $10
- Easiest roguelite imo in terms of progression

Con's:

- Lack of characters
- Lack of characters costumization (appearance) since it would be nice to not be 4 cats looking exactly the same.
- Lack of content (excluding guns and scrolls) but lacking on enemies, maps, etc
- Very poor optimizationon the last map/level before area 3 final boss, all went super smooth all maps and areas but on this section all the sudden fps nose dived like a ww2 divebomber.

But its important to mention that this review is about the game at the current state and its an early access game, so the review will change for better or for worse as the game develops further.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is one of those truly special gems that just never stops impressing. It's so well polished in so many areas that games of its type usually wait years for progress in, and it's tons of fun to play with friends. Somehow every run is a bit different, and that really keeps you playing.

I'd describe this as the best of Risk of Rain 2, Borderlands, and Hades all packaged into one amazing (and very easily affordable) game that you'll play again and again and again.

review:
Nice concept but has some major flaws.
Graphics is cute, but a tad too blocky which takes away some precision and satisfaction from aiming.
Movements isn't as smooth and has some weird blocks here and there.
Difficulty progression is a questionable. Some of the jump vault is like ???? I mean the movement is weird already, so having jumping platforms that require smooth & precision movement is kinda making people realize how bad the movement is.

Also a bit too grindy for my personal taste.

For the price thought it's good to try. Problem is there are way too many good games out there, not enough time. I'd rather spend time on something I enjoy more.
developer_response: Thanks for your feedback, most of issues you point out do exist, and we will fix them and optimize the game in the following update. Please give us more time.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
How to describe this?
It's a primarily Co Op PvE First Person Shooter. It has (2 at the moment) heroes you can play as with interestingly, unique and complimentary skills.

You unlock and customize your character's potential through a 'skill card' system on each play through, picking cards (goblets) that enhance your skills, grenades, and damage - also complementing the weapons you've picked up onthis play through.

Weapons are randomized with random traits, allowing and enabling very different style of play - do you go for AoE, Elemental effects, One Hit Kills, stun/confusion, Crowd Control?

Elemental effects change the gameplay too, and combining different elements (eg shock + decay/corrosion) causes a 'new' elemental effect (Miasma/ AKA Poisionous Radiation DoT ) and mastering these is mastering the game.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn is an impressive game. It is a game that starts again when you lose, but it enables you to upgrade some stuff to make the next run easier, opening the opportunity to reach farther than the previous run.

For me, the hearth of this game resides in the following question: "What can i do with what i have now?"

It is a constant answer to the same question. You kill, loot, but the loot is always random. Maybe you can buy a thing or two, but most of the time you'll be guessing what to pick, in terms of skills, scrolls and weapons. You can also destroy your own build with bad choices, or you just can lose because no good weapons were dropped.

This is a mandatory game in your library. It's tottaly worth it. Almost doesn't have bugs.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: I simply cannot recommend this game enough. The progression is absolutely addicting and the gunplay is crazy fun, especially when you unlock the ability that allows weapons to have more/better perks. Seriously I picked up a grenade launcher that had a perk where the first round from the magazine did +80% damage (there's only one round so every grenade did the extra damage). I also picked up a scroll that gave +50% damage to to the first round, essentially giving me a grenade launcher that did +130% damage. It makes every run unique, hoping you'll find that weapon with a god roll. There are some balancing issues and some of the scrolls definitely are a hinderance more than a help, but I've not enjoyed a rogulite like this in a long time. You won't regret spending so little on this game!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Already got more than my money's worth out of this, so I can't help but recommend it.
Genuinely addictive, has some great roguelite mechanics and is a ton of fun to run through over and over.
I have a few complaints about the game but they're relatively minor, especially as I fully expect them to be fixed as it gets updated.
My main problems are how the 3 areas are frankly, rather boring and don't switch it up enough to really stand out.
Then there's the English within the game, genuinely hard to understand what's being said at times, but it's not a HUGE issue and will most likely get adjusted as the devs get more feedback.
And finally the build variety, while there's plenty of guns to unlock in the game and plenty of variety therein with all the inscriptions, I do wish there were more passives to pick from in the Golden Goblet, it feels really limiting at times as most of them boil down to "more damage for x element/skill/grenade"
All in all though it's a great game and I'm excited to see where it goes.

title: Gunfire Reborn

The only time it's not stutter-step laggy is when you're hosting. If they can make multiplayer playable then my review would be overwhelmingly positive.

Edit: Server issues seem to be fixed, updates rolling out at a good pace. Changed review to positive.
developer_response: We are aware of this issue and continue to optimize it, please give us more time. You can play with your friends in the same region first.Thanks for playing our game and providing feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
It was really fun learning about all the different weapons and what they do. They are very versatile and add a lot of replayability to the game with the random traits they come with.

The ascensions are a good way to perfect what you want to use. 
For example, if you use the bear character or whatever it is (forgot its name) then you will probably want to stick with explosives because most of the ascensions are for explosive weapons. 
And for the default character stick with elemental weapons (fire, lightning, corrosive). 

I feel like it is well worth the price especially if it is on sale. Hopefully, there will be content additions such as new characters, weapons, scrolls, maybe even ascensions and areas? Idk but this game is in early access so I don't see why there wouldn't be.

The only real issue with it I had is that the elite difficulty is not really harder than the normal difficulty so once you beat normal you pretty much have enough stuff to beat elite. First time I beat normal and unlocked elite I  tried it out and got all the way to the final boss on the first try and the only reason I failed was because of my poor choice of weapons (I chose a close-range fire dragon weapon that didn't have enough range to even hit the boss) but even then I still got it down to about 20% hp.

I will definitely keep playing for now at least until I get all the upgrades that require soul essence and unlock all the remaining items and stuff.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
As a Game Designer:

I recommend this game, but i will say that playing in multiplayer is oddly off-putting.

One of the major things I'd like to point out is pacing.
Once you enter multiplayer, the pacing of the game is much like that of Warframe.
You are suddenly thrusting your way through levels, you would normally find difficult.
While, in retrospect, that makes perfect sense.
In a game design aspect, it's actually extremely detrimental to the overall game feel.

Suggested Fixes:
*** If anything, please please please PLEASE update the character model to take up less space in the game world.

* Polish character movement and animations.
* Add cosmetics, for multiplayer appeal.
* More player characters
* More enemy types

***** PLEASE BALANCE MULTIPLAYER *****

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: This game really surprised me to be quite the gem with its unique playthrough, customizability, and replayability. Although the developers were unknown to me I gave this game a shot based on it's screenshots as well as the price. I'd recommend looking into this as well as youtube videos if you are on the fence. When playing through the game you obtain different guns with different mods on them each time keeping the play very fresh with new builds to adapt to on the fly. You also get scrolls when playing through a run which augment your abilities. These scrolls are also all random chance of dropping with unique effects also adding onto the adaptability and freshness of each run. There are also "golden goblets" you find at each section of a level which augment your character in a unique way and you will have one of three random choices at each of these checkpoints. What I'm getting at if you can't tell is that each run is uniquely different which ultimately keeps me wanting to play the game more. As you play through you obtain currency to upgrade your character permanently as well so even if you die or don't progress far nothing feels like a total waste of time. The gameplay itself is rather fun with different guns to shoot arcade style at enemies. For the price alone I would highly recommend picking up this title. I would be willing to spend easily four times that for the fun I've had so far. The only real negative so far for me is I'm approaching the level cap and I wish there were more levels.

Love every bit of it, from the variety of weapons to choose from to the flush movement mechanics and abilities that make the flow of the game almost too good to be true. Can't wait for further updates to the game, absolutely wonderful design.

review: So first of all, this game is addicting as hell and you'll easily lose track of time. Fun weapons, cool skills and solid game mechanics. It wish it had more content and variety in level design but it's still in early access. It would be fun if there were secret stages that you could unlock with a specific weapon which would lead to a brand stage progression with unique bosses and enemies.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Yet another game out of the blue, surpassing everyone's expectations, Gunfire Reborn remains an impressive feat of taking the torch that, no, not Risk of Rain 2 was carrying, what Immortal Redneck was.

For some reason I don't see this comparison, maybe because Immortal Redneck was that small of a game. But imo this game and IR are both great examples of Rogue-Lite FPS games. Where Immortal Redneck stood out by the comedy style and it's movement, Gunfire Reborn stands out in its gameplay. From the guns to the characters, and the enemies, everything is polished to a very smooth degree, providing intense action in a surprisingly chilled out way.

Immortal Redneck died due to lack of support, both from players and developers. Nobody really played it, nobody really watched it, and the devs didn't have a reason to care for it despite its unique gameplay. Now Gunfire Reborn is able to succeed where it failed, I hope this gets the care that it deserves, as plankton said, "Don't let the good die young!"

It's like an 8/10 tbh, it's a good time all around.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: It's a great game, reminiscent of a strange but beautifil mix between the movement and shooting mechanics of Doom and Borderlands, and a roguelike that's guaranteed to keep you grinding for those talent points. It still has some translation issues since it's original language is chinese, but Devs are very responsive to the feedback button, and tend to fix small issues fairly quickly. For an early access game Gunfire Reborn plays like a fairly polished game. There are some issues with hitboxes as with all FPS games, but not enough to make it unpleasant to play. I bought the game, and liked it so much that I bought 3 aditional copies for some friends. The game is really promising, and has a bright future if the developers keep at it like they've been. I hope more people start playing it, since it's most entertaining when played in a full 4 people queue.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn is a surprisingly fun and addictive little rogue like shooter that seems to tick all the boxes of just being a good time. It's challenging without being unforgiving and rewarding without being stingy, as each run has a tendency to throw many weapons at you to play around with. The gunplay is traditional, but decent; there's no aiming down sights here, which honestly makes me feel a bit naked, and the game doesn't boast a whole lot of unique mechanics that separate it from something like, say, Borderlands (though it doesn't have random gun generation). But on the flip side, the weapons it offers are unique and fun to use, and the enemy design is solid enough that it turns mundane gameplay mechanics into exciting encounters. There's a bit of a balancing issue in that the second act seems to have enemies scale in difficulty exponentially, but I wonder if that's just a "me" problem since I don't think anybody else has complained about it.

I've seen the game be compared to Risk of Rain but to be honest I don't see any similarities at all. If. Anything this is a lot more similar to Immortal Redneck, where you're placed into arenas to take on a group of enemies before moving on, albeit with much more generous gun loot.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Not worth $12.

The first 2 hours, the game is fun. However, after the first 2 hours, you realize that the game is a entire grindfest just to progress. You play the SAME sequence of maps over and over again to get inches of progress.

Multiplayer helps, but it does not hide the fact that there is so little content.

BTW, I bought the game with my brother. He joined an online game and finished/got carried through the entire game within 3 hours. There's nothing else to do in this game except grind to max level (but no needed since you can beat the game at talent level 20) or grind to finish the game on elite mode--which is the same game but with a multiplier on the stats.

Highly recommend to WAIT to get this game on sale and/or for more content.
developer_response: We will add more content in the future update, thanks for your support! Stay tuned.

I also think that a good idea will be to lower the damage enemies can do just in general because a lot of enemies have aim hacks, shot guns that deal way too much damage, or just attacks that make you sit there and think wow such a good run is about to end because they deal way to much damage. title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn starts off hard! I failed to reach the first boss for a while, then I repeatedly got stomped by that boss and was getting a bit frustrated. My advice: Push through that wall. Once you have a few hero upgrades, the game becomes both easier and more interesting. The weapons are a lot of fun and the upgrade system is meaningful without being too complex.

Some feedback for the developers, if they read these reviews:
[list]
[*] Make the damage type of the currently equipped weapon more obvious. e.g. symbols next to the weapon
[*] I'm not sure how to use Gemini mods, if they have to match both weapons and there is no additional weapons storage. You would have to give up your primary weapon, for which you probably invested ascensions. so that becomes really unattractive
[*] Run speed penalty on some weapons seems a little high
[*] Jumping challenges in the later vaults are a PITA. I actually have not been able to complete one. This could be a "me" problem, but maybe consider pausing the timer for a bit after entering the vault, so that players can assess the map. Start timer when the player moves
[/list]

Looking forward to the updates!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
It's two core design philosophies are at odds with each other. On the one hand you want to wreak havoc with all the cool and interesting weapons and see how efficiently you can mow down enemies. 

On the other the rogue lite elements mean that towards the end the majority of enemies one or two-shot you and you have to be extremely careful, hide behind cover and take potshots at the most lethal enemies. This completely stops the pacing and makes the majority of guns completely unusable. 

The issues are only amplified in co-op since enemies turn into walking tanks and unless you have a pre-formed group that knows when and how to target specific enemies it turns into a clusterfuck of chipping away at whatever enemy you can see without leaving your cover too much. 

The self-revive system is also terrible online, only one person has to pay the price of giving about 30% of their progression reward in the form of soul essences and there is no guarantee that you can revive someone, that you will finish the encounter or that the other teammates will do the same for you. So it turns into a stalemate where nobody wants to give up their admittedly precious progress for nothing because if they lose again, they are the only ones out of extra reward, the others are not.

I would very much welcome an arena style, non-rogue lite mode where you can just experience the pure gameplay for fun, with more plentiful health pickups. 


As it stands I enjoy each run less the further I get and that's completely detrimental to a good rogue lite experience.
developer_response: Hi, thanks for your helpful suggestion, we will think about what adjustment to make and try our best to meet your expectation!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Let me start with I do understand why people enjoy this game for the most part it can be fun but here are a list of my gripes with it.

*Co-op is not as fun sure you can plan things with your friends but the point of a looter shooter is to just try out different guns without having to be super efficient with your friend. The enemies and bosses also have insanely increased damage and health pools. The first boss is a good example you do X amount of damage he jumps up and regens his giant shield so if it is your first run you dont learn until after he stomps you that you needed lightning damage but here is the kicker the only lightning gun you get in the beginning is not very good and the chance of you getting a different weapon that may do lightning damage can be slim. If it is single player then everything feels like a cake walk for the most part.

*If you are online and you have slight lag you can say goodbye to your health bar this still kind of applies to the co-op section.

*This is more of a gripe for me since its used to make people play certain games longer but I really am tired of the you have to die over and over to progress further into the game. Something like Monster Train you can beat on your first or second attempt but this one doesnt expect you to beat it until you are probably in the 30's. It doesn't feel like I got gud but more like I finally unlocked skills that just makes me breeze through everything.

*Dashing legit feels like trash, the parkour vault is terrible for a game that isnt really meant for it, and let me tell you about that boulder vault they never stop spawning and they spawn randomly on top of that sometimes at the exit the game likes to put flamethrower traps right at the exit so expect to die on these or just skip them in my opinion because they arent worth it unlike the kill all enemies or fight the bosses one.

Well thats over for my mini rant. I want to like this game and maybe later down the line when more things are fixed I will give it another shot. I don't regret buying it and I see the potential it has but right now it just is not for me.
developer_response: Sorry for any inconvenience. When you play in a team, you have more people to deal damage to monsters, so monsters will have relative larger HP. There are some designs that are not very reasonable in the team mode, we will continue the optimization. Plus, we are also optimizing the latency in matching and the difficulty of "jumping level". Please give us more time.Thanks for your understanding!

A few bugs here and there but it is way more stable than some AAA games out there. I look forward to more levels, guns,  scrolls, and characters.

9/10 game. For 14$ CAD its a steal.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Great game that is easily worth the price already. I would say this game is everything I wanted from risk of rain that that game couldn't provide. There are a ton of different weapons with a huge number of unique buffs to them, lots of unique enemies, and the few worlds feel very polished and look great. The game actually rewards skillful aim with enemies having headshot (or whatever they have for a head) crits and this combined with the amount of damage you can dish out makes the game so much more enjoyable. RoR feels like an absolute chore to play for me with how little aim the game requires of you, how little damage you do to bosses, and how few options you have for unique builds builds. There is also very little in the way of dodging in risk of rain, you are mostly just completely safe while running around except for the occasional enemy that has a lock-on ability with zero counterplay other than stay near cover at all times.

Gunfire reborn on the other hand requires you to constantly be on your toes dodging quick, yet telegraphed abilities which makes it feel like you're actively learning whenever you get hit rather than the "oh I guess I should have camped behind cover" feeling I get from playing RoR. The cherry on top is that, unlike many other rogue-likes, it never feels like the randomness screws you over in gunfire reborn. There is enough variance that most games will play completely different, giving you different weapon and ability upgrades that all have unique playstyles.

The game isn't perfect but honestly I think the only thing I can complain about is the damn snipers, they need more of a telegraph before they do 80-100% of your hp bar. Some of the weapon projectiles feel a bit slow so it would be nice if they were sped up a bit and more hit-scan weapons were added. There isn't really a way to aim a slow projectile at an enemy that jumps somewhere else every second, though it does make some sense that weapons have different use-cases. Overall not many downsides, this game is more polished and has more content than most AAA games released nowadays. Not that that's saying much, but really this game is great.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Keep in mind this is in early access.
It cost 13$, was it worth it. 100%

Now is there room for improvement... for sure,
Just from a Suggestion point of view:
‚Ä¢I'd like to see level variants primarily, as the first floor gets repetitive, and in time so does the second.
‚Ä¢A few more guns might not hurt, but that will come in time.
‚Ä¢Characters, I know there is work on this so that will come, Ignore the next part just suggestions.
(I'd like to suggest two that come to mind: 1) a Turtle whoms skill is essentially a bubble shield. This would encourage the not moving scrolls as well. 2) I named him Ottis the Attack Otter, a commando otter who specializes in normal guns, Which I love but typically have no element which makes using them against bosses hard. And possibly give him like auto aim as a passive, Or possibly a healing pad situation making him into some sort of a combat medic.)

Negatives of the game I've found so far, are very few in between. There is a few Scrolls thats are just over the top, such as the level 70 scroll. and I wish that each character had an expanded hero leveling system, possibly independent of the general upgrades. But once again, this would be

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
TL;DR: BUY IT! It's awesome and well worth the money!

You'll be hard-pressed to find a better value proposition for a game at this price point. 

If you're a fan of rouguelites and/or shooters, this game is the safest bet you can make. 

In fact, despite it's aesthetic and presentation i think this game is more akin to Diablo than to Boarderlands (but i haven't played much Boarderlands so my estimation may be wrong)

Here's how the game goes: 
You play a character that has a talent tree (shared between characters so once you unlocked something for a character it is unlocked for every character, EXCEPT ascension skills)  you unlock with leveling up (fairly typical RPG progression) and special currency (every enemy drops it). The character has a primary and a secondary skill they can use (an orb and a grenade for instance). 

There are guns. Many guns. Colorful guns. Think Borderlands. You can upgrade them (damage only but i really hope they add other attributes as upgradable later on). 
There are also occult scrolls. Think of them as the artifacts in Slay The Spire. They help augment your character and refine the playstyle you want to go for. 
There are also goblets that help you build your "spec". Each character has different upgrades that these goblets can enable. 

The mechanics of progression are very tight and satisfying. You have a great deal of variation and synergy between the system's moving parts and hence a lot of room to explore weapon/scroll/goblet combos. If you like min-maxing, you're going to have a lot of fun figuring out how to squeeze every drop for the most bang possible.

The fights take place in arenas spread out across levels in a stage (think of a stage as a floor in Slay The Spire). So "stage" 1 has 5 levels with a number of arenas in them. 
Enemy variety is pretty good and boss battles are suitably tense. The last boss fight is really cool. You have difficulty modifiers to play around with if you like testing yourself against harder challenges.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
*EDIT: They fixed the Rubber-banding issue and the game feels wonderful to play now. 11/10 every day of the week. I can't wait to see if/when they add more content.*

If I had to rate it on a star system, I'd give it about a 4/5. 

It's a really solid game, it's challenging, it's got decent music, and many unique enemies. The only problem is the net right now. Rubber-banding is a serious issue at the moment, whether you're solo or in a lobby. Which makes the jumping puzzle vault rooms just the worst because you're not missing the jumps because you're bad at parkour. No, you're missing them because the game put a hook around you and yanked you back.

Otherwise great game, recommended.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Grab friends, grab guns, blow stuff up! This is a deceptively fun game that keeps you coming back for more!

This, my friends, is Early Access done right! 

It has enough content to make the price point well worth it and just enough polish to instill hope that more good stuff is on the way. The diversity of builds (character + talents + scrolls + weapons) is amazing for an Early Access release and I'm eagerly anticipating even more additions!

The best part about this game is that it doesn't try to do anything groundbreaking nor does it try to be a clone of something else. It's a simple, fun, co-op shooter/looter that, in my opinion, is definitely worth a buy. 

Kudos to the developers for actually understanding what players want and for making a great game at a reasonable price. With so many disappointing and uninspired Early Access cash-grabs out there, Gunfire Reborn is a breath of fresh air! 

So give it a try...trust me, you'll like it!

Enjoy!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This is  an astoundingly great game for the price point. I bought it with a friend as something to play when we were both bored and quickly became one of our favorite games for the past month. Levels are challenging and you have to be smart to survive the levels. You have to grind to get new guns and abilities which adds a level of replay. Also it is rewarding to struggle on a level and die just to come back and conquer it with new abilities and guns. This game is also ONLY EARLY ACCESS, so the fact that there is plenty more to come is highly promising. 

The only downsides are repetition and often game breaking abilities. This game doesn't have much in diverse level design. Many of the bonus stages are the same and don't really require a lot of skill to overcome. There is also a point where you can become easily overpowered with abilities. A lot of the abilities can combine where you simply take no damage, and deal obscene amounts of damage back. Now these cons are not really that big of a deal as both of them can easily be fixed by simply adding new levels, characters, and fine tuning some of the abilities to make them less over powered. 

Overall I'd give this game an 8.5/10. I've seen many people say this game is "too difficult" but I find it perfect. If you find yourself struggling to beat anything it means you need to play more, as the more you play the better you become. I'd recommend this game to people who enjoy Diablo and Borderlands.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: This game has so much future potential. It's extremely fun and addictive. The progression system is really good. Only thing lacking is different maps and maybe harder difficulty. Not that its not challenging because it definitely is. If you don't have a good team you might not make it far. The weapon randomization is some of the best I've ever seen. They didn't shy away from overpowered rolls like some AAA games would. It really lets you play the way you want to, and that makes it so much fun. 100% worth the money. Hell, i would have paid more if i could.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
A good fps rogue-like game. Not many of these out there so if you're interested in the genre like I was, this is a good experience.

As it is in Early Access, I know critcism is hard to take seriously because any issue can be addressed the next patch. However, I think its justified for a review because the dev's are still accepting our $$$ to play.

The good:
FPS
Rogue-like
Nice progression with Weapons and Abilities for first 2-3 hours.
Crisp models, animations, and gunplay
Sounds
Boss-fights

The bad:
Enemy variety
Progression after the initial playthroughs (~level 15)
Map repetition*

*This is the most heinous problem. It kills the feeling of progression because you face the exact same rooms with the exact same enemies. The only variety is what you get from a reward at the end of the room and where "secret rooms" spawn (but then the secret rooms are repeated every run). Even the placement of that reward is the exact same. I look to other looter games comparison and this seems like a no-no (RoR2, Borderlands, IR).

In Conclusion:

Unfortunately for me, a rogue-like fps needs to have an interactive environment. If that comes via extreme player mobility or through more map variety, I would be happy. But as it stands there is none. Even the rewards in older rogue-like games are more interactive than this game (think FTL, a game that has very little map variety).

However, as an fps fan and a rogue-like fan I want to see this game shine. If you enjoy these genres and want to see more, I would definitely recommend this game.

title: Gunfire Reborn

Once you get to a higher level it gets easier, but its still fun. I still got some weapons and scrolls to unlock, and i'm looking forward to new content.

TL:DR fun game, cool vibes, rewarding gameplay, not that easy, at 10E price tag will keep you bussy for a good amount of hours.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is fantastic, and the fact that it's very early access too is very impressive.

Gunfire Reborn is an arcade dungeon crawl shoot 'em up, a kind of Borderlands, Risk of rain, Dark souls blend. You start off easy and improve your special abilities and weapons as you go along. 

It's RNG based, so each dungeon run will change, there are many viable builds and weapons. It also has up to 4 player co-op matchmaking.

The developers are very active and have a pretty clear vision to keep improving the game. Well worth the $17.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
edit: To start with, I not recommending against buying the game. It is good value for 10 bucks. The thumbs down is more of a relative judgment in view of competing titles. I will update the review on release.

It's a nice enough diversion for some hours but no serious competition to Risk of Rain. There are no interesting enemies, only 3 maps and 2 heroes, the sole replayability stems from random boons and weapon mods. 
During EA there is certainly time to boost the content, however it would have to be an rather unusual achievement to get anywhere near RoR with its multitude of characters (8 so far I think), varied maps, cool enemies (more than the standard melee, ranged and exploders) and plethora of items.

This doesn't mean it's bad value for 10 bucks. It's great value for 10 bucks. Can't see me spending more than maybe 20h in it, though. The talent grind mechanic isn't really my thing.
developer_response: Thanks for your feedback, current system is not perfect enough and we will optimize it, please give us more time.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is really well designed. My favorite aspect of it is how every weapon is viable. The starting hero is mainly focused on elemental weapons with a skill tree that powers them up whilst providing some crowd control with their skill, while the second character is focused on explosive weapons and a more aggressive playstyle. While not buffing elemental weapons directly, the second character is able to make use of elemental combos like miasma (corrosive and shock I believe) with his ability, making it feel really great to realize new build choices. 

Overall, the game's progression is fairly linear with three different area themes each with their own unique set of enemies. The second area is a clear jump in difficulty from the first, while the third is more easily dealt with given the power you have accrued once you get to it.  

If I were to give one criticism with the game, it is that it can feel repetitive since the number of unique enemies is fairly low with each area, maybe 5-7 unique enemies (rough estimate). Because of that and the fact that the bosses are the exact same each run, the game can feel a little dry. Although the enemies and areas are repetitive, the build variety makes up for it as it is very satisfying and easy to understand given enough time to master it (which isn't that long). 

Before I end this review, I have to say that another stellar aspect of this game is the gunplay. Gunfire Reborn is a first person shooter, so it does require a certain degree of aim. There are many weapons, including shotguns, bows, rocket launchers, submachine guns, assault rifles, and other more unique guns. Some are much easier to aim than others, but at the end of the day, the gunplay feels very satisfying, responsive, and fun. I highly recommend the game to anyone looking for difficulty, satisfying gunplay, and a variety of build options that allow high replayability.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Fun little EA game.  Note that it is very unfinished and there's some obvious balance tuning that needs to be done (some guns are just strictly better than others, and damage ramps up incredibly high), and more content that needs to be added (more character options + cosmetic changes to each character type as well), but it's fun to play.  

Be warned though that you need to have a good ping to play it effectively; playing it with a friend in Croatia and the boss AoE prompts that warn you to GTFO are shown so late (and the game assumes your position to be behind where you actually are for them, feels like) that it's VERY difficult to dodge.  The host of course has no problems, but those with latency will.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
First, to preface this review, I absolutely LOVE this game, I have a few small complaints but as the game is early access I expect they will be addressed eventually, maybe!

The pros:
- Beautiful cel-shaded graphics with easy to 'read' level design that doesn't distract from the hectic gunplay
- Simplistic but easily recognizable designs of enemies and monsters that, at a quick glance, you know what they are and how to fight them
- Great controls on controller (speaking only for controller as I do not enjoy mouse and keyboard)
- Sound effects and music are very nice, music is pleasant without being distracting

Cons:
- Biggest issue I have right now is lack of ironsights. Not being able to ironsight with a weapon lacking a scope is just...baffling. It makes aiming some weapons difficult and would love if the weapon does not have an alt-fire if they could be ironsighted.
- Minor translation errors (these are not that big of a deal) but what is a big deal is lack of detail about some features, aside from loading screen tips, a lot of important info just doesn't seem available like what elements create what effects or if a scroll that removes an ability can be countered by a perk that improves that ability
- Lack of playable characters. After 25+ hours of gameplay I am...rather bored of the dog and cat, and from the loading screen I can see the next hero may be a bird and I would GREATLY enjoy playing a new hero. But again, early access, so I know those will come eventually.

Suggestions going forward?
- Color options for heroes, maybe some accessory unlocks so when playing and all 4 people are Crown Prince there can be some way to stand out.
- More heroes! The bird, maybe a reptile and a fish to round out the roster!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game at it's core is great, but there are many tweaks it needs to maintain it's player base. 
1. Change the progression system. The progression in this game is nearly nonexistent. You barely get any skill points in the first dungeon and it takes forever just to get a measly 20-30 skill points.
2. This first boss is absolute B.S. there is no reason why the first boss should be nearly impossible to defeat unless you have a full team of players that are level 20+
3. After you miraculously manage to beat the first boss, you should not have to go through the same old dungeon with the same old enemies and the same old final boss just to get to the second stage again. It comes back to the lack of progression.

All in all this is a great looking game with fun weapons and art style but in its current state just feels like groundhog day. That being said, I cannot recommend this game in its current state but I am looking forward to updates and I am hopeful for the future of this game :)
developer_response: Hi, we are aware of the difficulty and plan to make some adjustment in our future update.Thanks for playing our game and providing feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I just got burned by another Early Access game - luckily I refunded in time.

This game though seemed very polished and I watched a bunch of videos before diving in for $12.

WELL WORTH IT.

The gameplay is well done, just kill, get a new gun, kill more. Bosses are not easy, but about the right level of difficulty. This game seems at first like you'll run right through it - no, you won't.

If you like FPS games and like building your character over time, this is a great little game to pick up.

review: Very disappointed with the co-op experience. They apparently decided to give enemies (including bosses) 200% more health when you play with a friend, and god knows how much more damage. It took us quite some runs to kill the first boss. Seemed fun, good challenge. Then when you play solo, you melt all the levels and bosses with ease. I don't get this logic. Why would they make co-op this unplayable?
developer_response: Sorry for any inconvenience. When you play in a team, you have more people to deal damage to monsters, so monsters will have relative larger HP. There are some designs that are not very reasonable in the team mode, we will continue the optimization. Thanks for your understanding!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
The roguelike FPS I've been waiting for. Even at this early stage of development the game feels and plays great, with enough variety and depth to make nearly 20 hours of play absolutely fly past. The gunplay is really, really good - on par with AAA titles let alone small indie games - which is what has let down every other FPS roguelike I've tried. The abilities and progression - both in and out of run - are well implemented with enough depth to make each run varied.
The game requires a little balancing and some of the translation is a bit off (the dev team are from Hong Kong but have now enlisted help with localisation) but these are really minor issues which I'm confident will be ironed out during early access. The dev team seem very communicative and receptive to community feedback.
Performance can be a sticking point in early access games for me, but I've got no issues here. Running on ultra 1080p i'm getting really smooth feeling minimum 130fps - except for late game on elite mode, where it dips to 80-90 - with just a 1060 6gb and haven't experienced any game breaking bugs or crashes.
Overall I haven't been this impressed with an early access game since Slay The Spire. It's well worth the cost of entry and I think it'll evolve into one of the best games in the roguelike genre.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
The level of replayability and depth in this game is crazy good for an early access title. The gameplay and shooting is smooth alongside the co-op (offline and online).

The 2 minor critiques I would have currently (after 25 hours) is 1) when the host leaves, the match ends even if other players are going - so maybe host migration?, 2) the platforming mini-levels from portals in the second act seem brutal, especially considering that platforming isn't a major part of the game currently.

All in all, snag this up if you like rogue-lites or first person shooters when you can and enjoy. As long as you don't expect some AAA story or graphics then you will be pleased I imagine.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I was thinking about reviewing this game at an earlier time, but I wanted to at least unlock and play the second character before I did so. That happened, so here we go-

I love both genres this game utilizes, being FPS and Rogue-lite. When I had first seen this game, I was super excited. I've played a good amount of it now, and there's are certain things I want to mention.

For the positives, I really like the game's polish, the graphics are pretty neat, and there's definitely a decent amount of weapons to have fun with. In terms of sole positives, that's where I'm ending it.

Now it gets a bit more gray. The gameplay loop is satisfying at times, yet frustrating at others. The characters' abilities get extremely boring(especially the first character) and it leaves me WANTING some variance there. And once you keep playing more and more, you can easily get bored of the environments. Nothing really changes in the places you've been (and keep going to), and it starts to become un-fun in the earlier parts. 

Bringing into account this is early access, I have high hopes for the game's future, and want to drop some of my own recommendations down for it: 1. Variety in character abilities. The game is begging for it. 2. Possibly having things change/unlocking new parts of previously exhausted environments. Think Dead Cells, maybe have some different paths leading into different sections with different enemies and bosses? Or, if anything, different bosses per boss level that have different chances of spawning. 3. The game can definitely use 1, if not 2, more characters. The replayability would definitely benefit from more characters.

Essentially, to not make this longer: I want to see new, different content to allow variations per playthrough/run, so as to not make it feel the same every time. Definitely a chance to get inspired from other Rogue-lites, there's no shame in that if you ask me.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: This game reminds me alot of your games like slay the spire, dead cells. There's soooo much to love about this game between the gunplay, all the awesome guns, the tons of relics and the wonderfull upgrade system. This game has such an incredible amount of stuff going for it. Though the one thing I feel that truly sets this apart from other games is that it's also four player coop. Also I feel like for 12 $ the games severely underpriced for the replayability of it . Having had so much fun I would of gladly played double for this game. Even if the game hasn't fully launched yet I'd consider it amazing but just with content that's currently in the game. The community has also been really fun and are amazing to chat with. The worst part about this game is ironically the begining because it can feel a bit unforgiving at times to new players. Though once you get in a few runs and start unlocking talents it only gets more enjoyable with each and every play through.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: Risk of Rain meets Borderlands in a fun roguelike with tight controls and good gameplay. A little thin in a few areas due to being in early access, but plenty of unique and interesting guns and items once you unlock them. The game consists of 3 different zones each with a boss, (ignore the person with 4 hours claiming there's only a single boss and zone). Some of the text is a little janky due to translation from Chinese but it's all understandable and translation has been steadily improving thanks to the community helping the devs out. All in all, highly recommend, especially for the price.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Pros: 
- Very Addicting
- Have different builds based on weapons and ascensions (skills)
- Really fun to play with friends
- Grindy in a fun way
- As for an alpha, I have not run into much bugs at the moment
- Is updated frequently
- Has a lot of replayability as you are progressing
- Has an official discord server so you can ask questions if you are confused about anything.

Cons:
- Will get boring after you complete the game (unlock everything, max level, etc.)
- Damage numbers can obscure your view which can get pretty annoying
- You can't ping/typing system implemented yet

Overall: With all the cons, keep in mind that it is still in it's alpha testing. When I first bought this game (about like 3-4 days ago) I have been pretty addicted and as you can see I have roughly 70 hours in the game already. Since this game is being updated frequently I am expecting newer areas to be released with bosses and more weapons and possibly another character would be awesome. I am loving the dog so far as compared to the cat. But if a developer is reading this, I have already commented in your suggestions text chat in the discord saying to give an option to either minimize the damage numbers or an option to completely remove the numbers or possibly revamp it.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
TL;DR:
In its current form, don't bother with this game. But it has a lot of potential, so I hope the devs continue work

Long version:

Movement in this game is very poorly done. It feels extremely stiff and unrewarding. Contrary to games like team fortress 2 that blend rewarding movement with rewarding guns, I would say this game has neither of those paradigms pinned just yet. From the get-go the game breaks the flow with overbearing tutorial elements that stop the gameplay and immediately frustrate players. The further on you go the more you will find enemies with tracking projectiles, otherwise known as the lazy-man's solution to making reasonable opponents to fight and good AI, which remove  a significant volume of the reward to using the mechanics of the game.

My next point is the guns and sound design. The sound impact of hitting a headshot is good, however almost all other aspects are not very telling. You cannot tell by sound if there is a threatening enemy around, it's difficult and confusing to read the environmental and combat sounds from eachother. This could be fixed by making higher contrast sounds, heavy thumps and unique noises for each enemy. The guns can all be improved by better sounds, effects and "impact" from hitting enemies. Faster projectile speed, better reactions from enemies like simulated strafing or dashing towards you without providing too heavy a "punish" damage.

My final point is the visual language of the game.

The art design is phenomenal, I can't say it could be better by much. However the visual language of the game is very confusing. Why do we have all these cartoony enemies, then beetles, then giant humanoid like enemies and horse-headed figurines all that don't stand out exceptionally well or point themselves out from the environment? 

As someone who likes to play competitive shooters, I can clear an entire dungeon with just the default weapon fine. Why? In a lot of cases it's not even faster to use the pickup weapons. The visual language of the game is very confusing, enemies aren't made more dangerous based on colour and they strain the eyes to pick them out from the environment. Hitboxes are very clear at least. The boss that I encoutered at the very least felt very lazy, they just made something with a lot of HP, slow movement and a lot of damage. Contrast this to the Marauder from Doom Eternal, who doesn't have an exceptionally high volume of HP but forces you to rely on timing to apply damage, and you can really see what I mean by lazy. Everyone HATED the marauder but LOVED to beat him. It was extremely rewarding.

And my final point:
This game has a lot of potential. But it needs a lot of work, please buy it and provide input for the developers so they can turn this clear labour of love into something great.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: Very addictive gameplay loop.  Good pacing with talent upgrades, makes it satisfying to see more powerful items drop as you upgrade your chance to get them.  Still a good bit of work to do - I'd love to see the first level get a makeover.  It's pretty visually boring compared to later levels and the layouts are recycled too often.  Considering it's the level players will see the most it could benefit from some work.  Other than that, just more content like any rogue-like.  More classes, more weapons, more enemies, more upgrades.  Really good base to work with here and excited to see where it goes!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Yet another game out of the blue, surpassing everyone's expectations, Gunfire Reborn remains an impressive feat of taking the torch that, no, not Risk of Rain 2 was carrying, what Immortal Redneck was.

For some reason I don't see this comparison, maybe because Immortal Redneck was that small of a game. But imo this game and IR are both great examples of Rogue-Lite FPS games. Where Immortal Redneck stood out by the comedy style and it's movement, Gunfire Reborn stands out in its gameplay. From the guns to the characters, and the enemies, everything is polished to a very smooth degree, providing intense action in a surprisingly chilled out way. 

Immortal Redneck died due to lack of support, both from players and developers. Nobody really played it, nobody really watched it, and the devs didn't have a reason to care for it despite its unique gameplay. Now Gunfire Reborn is able to succeed where it failed, I hope this gets the care that it deserves, as plankton said, "Don't let the good die young!"

It's like an 8/10 tbh, it's a good time all around.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I have played roughly 40 hours of Gunfire Reborn, and I am really enjoying the gameplay loop. The best parts of this game is the combination of fun "Borderlands-esqe" combat mixed with the run variety of a game like Risk of Rain 2.

The things that still need work in the game:
(1) Bugs / Stability
(2) Netcode
(3) Build Variety and balance
(4) Floor layout and Map Variety
(5) Boss Variety
(6) Party/ Group quality of life improvements (ping, text chat, etc.)

Overall - very fun game, looks to be have a promising future.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: Great game! The only thing i would change is the RNG of the maps. Cause at some point going trough to same stages and same boss fights over, and over, and over again, its gets reallllyyy boring. I would prefer complete RNG-Maps and RNG bosses on every stage, i dont mind if its just the normal monsters with a lot more hp and stuff. Please add that to the game, U guys could copy some stuff from Risk of Rain 2, then you can understand what i mean. Game is great, weapons are great, enemies are great, but at some point reaching a certain level and dying to spend skill points and thinking.... a sh**t here we go again...is not the most pleasing experience i had in a game, if you know what i mean. The replayability gets lower and lower from every run to the next run, cause its the same level order, same boss order, very boring. If thats not going to change i cant keep playing the game cause i miss the freshness when i start a new game, cause its like a chore at some point getting those skill points, grinding to get stronger for the next levels.... but in doing so repeating the same boss levels in the same order every SINGLE TIME, i get a headache at some point. Fix that and the game is fantastic! Till then this game gets a thumb down, for 2 reasons, first its just 10 bucks so u can get it, second, u will understand after several hours of playing why its just 10 bucks....
developer_response: Sorry for your bad experience, we will add more content and randomness in the future update, stay tuned.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: This game has a lot of potential. I love the artwork, and overall theme of it. It's linear, and has a strong Borderlands feel to it, mixed with aspects of City of Brass and Risk of Rain. Stage paths are randomized, keeping things interesting. I really like the variety of enemies and their different attack styles, as well as the guns the player gets. You're not guaranteed to get the same weapons every time, which makes every run-through a bit more unique and challenges you to adapt to different weapon types. Combat and movement feel pretty good so far too. The talent system seems cool, being able to customize your play style. I can't wait to see what the finished version will look like.

title: Gunfire Reborn

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I really had low expectations for this game given it's eerily similar vibe and feature list to Borderlands 3. Was this to be an indie clone? It's not. It's really really not. There are certainly mechanics that are similar to many other games in orthogonal genres, but Gunfire Reborn puts them together in a really cohesive and addicting way.

It has the roguelike elements of Dead Cells, the gameplay feel of Borderlands (but better), and the randomization / artifact mechanics of Risk of Rain 2 or (believe or not) Monster Train. I found myself engrossed in the decision making of dynamically choosing weapons based on build ideas, and then proving them out over the course of a run. I find this learning loop to be extremely rewarding.

I will point out that by far the strongest element of Gunfire Reborn is the actual gunplay. I can't recall a single game with as tight, responsive, and rewarding single player FPS mechanics as this one.  

I love this game.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This is a great early access title and the developers have been open about what they are working on for new updates. The gameplay itself is very fun. As pretty much everyone has said, it feels like a mix between Borderlands and Risk of Rain 2. I'd throw in a tiny sprinkle of Dead Cells as well. The gunplay feels good for the most part. There are some hit boxes that could be reworked (the heads of the Crow-like shooty boys in the 2nd stage/world for example). 

Couple things that I would like to see improved: 
1. online play. There is a noticeable lag sometimes. I know the devs have said they are working on it, which is a great sign. 
2. I'd love to see a mode that doesn't end when you finish off the final boss. Something like the loop system in Risk of Rain 2. 

As an early access title this is one of my favorite games out right now. It is fun in single player, it is fun in co-op and it is cheap.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is inherently fun, it has lots of promise, and I recommend it at current state.

Pros: Combat is great, the roguelike aspects are fun, the art style is cool.

Cons: Content is a bit lacking, difficulty scaling is less skill based and more of a straight numbers wall, translation is a bit wonky and needs some love, needs more characters for gameplay variety, especially in multiplayer.

Really looking forward to the future of this game.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Honestly so far pretty enjoyable and not too repetative.

I am a big fan of the game Ziggurat (think this game meets wizards, I recommend it) and I could honestly see this game progressing in that direction.

Obviously it is in early access at the time of this writing so there will still be some more changes but for the current price I would recommend it for it's current state. Have not run into any bugs yet either on my PC so that's nice.

I get some occasional lag spikes (game freezes for about 3 seconds and then back in) which is annoying at this game requires fast movement but it isn't anything game breaking for me.

Long story short, if you enjoy a strange mashup of Borderlands style weapons, a Ziggurat styled game, and some interesting boss mechanics, you'll enjoy the early access state of this game!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
For it's price within the first couple weeks of release (¬£9.29), you'll get your moneys worth. The core gameplay is enjoyable, with a number of interesting weapons to mess around with and a fair few scrolls which give you interesting passive bonuses. It's also much more enjoyable in multiplayer. Loot is instanced, but you can drop most weapons/scrolls to share with you allies complimenting their builds.

The main gripe I have is the lack of area and enemy variety. You'll always be fighting your way through the same areas, repeating the same rooms with the same enemies often, and facing the exact same bosses every time at the end of each area. There are also only 2 playable characters, they do feel different from each other and can each be played in a couple of different ways.

The replay value currently comes from the rouguelite progression, where you can upgrade your character permanently at the end of each run. You'll also unlock additional weapons and scrolls for completing challenges. These will appear in future runs and even drop one for you to try out immediately which is a nice feature.

Bearing all this in mind, the game is currently in early access. The developers seem to be updating the game regularly, fixing many initial bugs and adjusting systems. For example, they recently added an alternative way to revive dead allies besides just reaching the next area. I've played a fair amount and may stop playing once beating the final boss (on normal difficulty), or possibly beforehand until they've added more features. If you're on the fence, I'd pick it up and try it out especially with a friend. Otherwise wait until they add more areas, bosses and playable characters.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
[b]Score is at the bottom of the review, while you are down there, leave a like if you liked this review![/b]

[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/37072886/]Great reviews can be found at our curator page:[b] Devils in the Detail[/b] Make a deal with the devil and join our curator for more great reviews like this one![/url][/quote]


[h1]Overview[/h1] 
An amazing FPS rougelike that is reminiscint of Borderlands. The game has solid mechanics and a great foundation. To join the annuls of greatness, more content will be necessary to increase the variety so the game feels less samey at times.

[h1]Game Breakdown[/h1]
[h3] Gameplay üéÆ[/h3]
 
[u]Characters[/u]
At the beginning of the game the player only has one character to choose from, but at the moment there are two to choose from. To unlock the second character, the player needs to invest in the progression system which will be covered later. Each character has the ability to dash, but they both have different grenades and a unique super ability. The first character is known as The Prince. He is a samurai cat who focuses elemental effects and his unique skill is Energy Orb. While the name is certainly unassuming its effect is quite potent. Energy orb deals a burst of damage and freezes enemies in time. The prince‚Äôs grenade releases a poison gas that damages and slows enemies that stand in it. They are both quite enjoyable abilities that can be used both offensively and defensively. The Prince is also the most balanced character in terms of shields and heath, as well as offensive and defensive options. Shields regenerate after not taking damage for a short while which contrasts with health which is only recovered with special health restoring items. The second character is Ao Bai who is a dog that has dual wielding as his super skill. Unlike The Prince, Ao Bai has low shields and high health, much higher than The Prince. This makes him tankier, but it is harder for him to recover his resources that help him defy death. Ao Bai‚Äôs grenade is a simple explosive grenade. Ao Bai is my favorite character because of the crazy dual wielding combos that can be achieved, but he is a high-risk and high reward kind of character. His only defensive ability is the fact that he will likely kills enemies before they kill him. This makes him more difficult but still really fun. I am excited to see what kind of characters the developers come up with next.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2127837215

[u]Ascension[/u]
Characters‚Äô abilites don‚Äôt stay static, as that would be boring. After a level is completed, the player is able to choose from three different ability upgrades. One such example for each character would be gaining Energy Orb charges on The Prince and throwing two grenades at no additional cost for Ao Bai. Powers are diverse, with there being eight in each category. Most power upgrades also have three levels that provide a huge bonus if level three is achieved.

[u]Weaponry[/u]
The weapons in this game are crazy, but they are also inspired by guns in other games as well. One gun allows you to throw it as a grenade which is quite similar to the Tediore gun manufacturer in Borderlands. The guns are diverse enough to not get boring, and this is further compounded by the fact that each weapon discovered comes with randomized inscriptions which apply various bonuses. These range from simple increased in crit damage, while one unique modifier I found gave my gun an extra shot in its one round magazine and if the first shot didn‚Äôt kill, the second shot got an extreme crit called a Lucky Shot in this game. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2127836297

[u]Enemies[/u]
Considering this game is in early access Gunfire Reborn has a great variety of enemies for each of three biomes to combat. One thing that really surprised me was that enemy AI is pretty smart and uses cover really effectively. Short enemies will crouch next to cover to keep from getting shot. Other enemies would dodge roll at times. 

[u]Status Effects[/u]
There are three status effects in the game which are decay, fire, and shock. Decay is essentially poison and it slows in addition to dealing damage. Fire just deals damage over time. Shock deals damage but can allow a shot to jump to another enemy. These status effects are pretty typical, except for the act that they can combine if applied simultaneously to an enemy. For example, shock and fire turns into manipulation which makes an enemy shoot at its own allies. This system is interesting and makes some of the weaker guns with elemental effects useful.

[u]Occult Scrolls[/u]
Occult scrolls upgrade the player‚Äôs character with passive effects. They are a rouglelike standard and are gained mainly by defeating vault challenges. They are powerful, but interestingly often come with drawbacks.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2127836649

[u]Shops[/u]
There are two shop types. The peddler sells guns, healing items, ammo, and the occasional occult scroll. The blacksmith improves guns with more damage and additional inscriptions.

[u]Progression[/u]
After a run is finished, whether it is a win or one of the many losses the player is able to use the soul essence gained by killing enemies to permanently improve heroes. While most of them are generic, there is a small skill line that is hero specific that further improves their specialty.

[h3]üìö Story & Translation üìö[/h3]
The story involves stopping some sort of corruption, but besides the beginning cutscene, this story is not brought up much afterward. The translation is one of this game‚Äôs weaknesses, as at the time of writing it isn‚Äôt especially great.

[h3]üéß Sound üéß[/h3]
The sound design is great in both the music and the sound effect departments. The music‚Äôs most notable aspect is its heavy use of a bass drum to create a strong sense of hype while the player lays ruin to their opponents. The sound effects for each gun and each enemy helps to give auditory feedback that allows for a quick dodge just in time or a well-placed shot that creates more kiting space.

[h3]üì∫ Graphics üì∫ [/h3]
the graphics remind me of would be cel-shaded games except without the black borders. I would also liken the graphics a bit to Legend of Zelda Windwaker, due to their bright color scheme with stumpy character design. Every shot from enemies was easily recognizable as well which made it easier to know which could be ignored and which should be dodged.

[h3]‚å® Controls ‚å®[/h3]
The controls are the typical FPS ones.  

[h3]‚öô Performance & Bugs ‚öô[/h3]

[u]Easy to Alt-Tab[/u]: [b]Yes[/b]
The game performs really well most of the time but sometimes there was a half second freeze or enemies were sliding. 

[h3]üí∞ Price to Content Ratio üí∞[/h3]
Gunfire Reborn is quite difficult while still staying enjoyable. Not only that, but this game has full four player coop included, which adds even potential playtime.

[h3] üåü Overall üåü[/h3]

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
So, to get my bias out in the open: i love roguelikes that have perma-upgrades. So, Gunfire reborn falls right into that niche for me.

More objectivly (Note: all of the below apply to the game in early access)

Pros
+Decent weapon diversity + random affixes mean most weapons can be viable
+Two characters feel mechanically different
+Online multiplayer in a early access game that actually works (Still has hiccups, but given that its EA, I am just impressed that it works at all)
+Interesting flavor backdrop for gameplay
+Game is only 12 USD, which is super cheap.

Cons
-Dog character seems less useful than cat (Though I could just be bad with the dog)
-Enemy HP scaling makes late game a slog if your build is done improperly.
-Elemental Fusions/Combos are almost mandatory vs just shooting more
-Game still short

Conclusion
Almost all the negatives are things I expect from an early access game, and that will (Should?) be fixed over time. Give the game a try.

title: Gunfire Reborn

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
An actual great game. Has the chance of becoming one of the best roguelites ever if the devs keep this up. Using borderlands weapon elements (corrosive, shock, and burning) and adding extra elements to them (shock effect deals shock damage to nearby enemies, corrosive slows, and burning dots), as well as combining them to enable even more powerful combos, shock + corrosive = miasma for instance, makes for a fun experience to try different weapons together and can make some crazy builds. Unlocks are through playing the game and using new combinations of weapons on enemies, such as killing a specific enemy with a specific element/element effect on them. You gain levels by using the essence you gain to upgrade talents, which allows you to unlock more things like the 2nd character, and other powers you can find. 

Through levels you can find vaults that have a small challenge before a chest that will reward you with a scroll, that grants usually a downside, but a big positive as well, or just a positive ie: -90% dmg taken from enemies far, but +90% dmg taken from enemies nearby (positive and a negative). Sometimes you'll stumble across a gold chest that will offer different things, taking damage to gain money, or permanent max shield/hp as an example. At the end of levels you will find a chest that gives a goblet that will offer you one of three choice of upgrades to your character or their skills, such as increasing the amount of damage a specific element does, or modifying your unique ability.

The game is a bit short, but it makes up for this with strong enemies, tanky or high damaging, as well as unique and fun boss fights. I do wish they had a looping mode like risk of rain does, but overall I am satisfied by the end of the game.

Overall, I love this game, and as I said this has the chance of being an absolute breakthrough (not that isnt already) and the best roguelite shooter in the market. It is definitely worth the $12 and I'd heavily recommend it for people that enjoy roguelikes and shooters.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn, even as an early access game, has a heaping amount of work and heart poured into it.  At nearly 40 hours into this game and about a week or so of playing, I still a ton left to unlock, master, and learn from this game.

Many reviews will say similar things: it is a roguelite with elements of borderlands (presentation, gun randomness, hp type division) doom's gameplay loop (fight one room at a time, different enemies and your weapon load out will determine how go about clearing a room, and a dash that can enable skillful gameplay with dodging and positioning), and the randomness of things like dead cells or risk of rain (stages fought in a certain order, spending money post-run on global progression upgrades, unlock guns/scrolls by accomplishing objectives while playing).  It is built from the ideas of many, but comes together in a great package of its own.

This all builds into a game where you're constantly on the move, analyzing which enemies to fight, how to best deal with them on your current build, and think about what you want next to ensure you will continue your run.  The second difficulty, Elite, is quite challenging at later levels, and you almost always need to feel broken before you can consider beating the last boss.

Of course, the game is in early access, so there are a few issues.  Balance is a bit iffy right now; a few guns are almost auto-pick, while some are literally irredeemable trash.  There are only 3 stages, and you always fight them in the same order, boss and all.  There's only two characters, which are fun in their own ways, but not quite as unique as many similar games.  The grammar is confusing and terminology sometimes unclear, due to the game being translated not quite as well as you'd hope, but about as well as you'd expect from an indie game.  Several mechanics of the game are unclear and only found through random loading screen tips, which‚Äîif you run this on an SSD like I do‚Äîmakes them often quite hard to read in time.

Despite all of that, the gameplay loop is fantastic.  As a huge fan of Risk of Rain, this game really scratches that same itch.  The sheer variety of guns, abilities, and interactions in this game is wild, making broken combinations you again and again don't realize the strength of until you see them melt enemies in a second.  Truly, if you like roguelite games and tight fps mechanics, pick this up.  At 12 bucks, you are losing very little on this gem of a game.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Great game for people who enjoy roguelikes and Borderlands. Can be hard at the beginning, but you will see yourself get farther and farther as you invest in talents (perks you carry over with you through runs) and learn enemy attacks. Can be somewhat grindy, but if you're familiar with roguelikes then you probably wouldn't mind a bit of a grind. It seems that playing multiplayer increases the spirit essence (exp) that you gain, so keep that in mind if you want to get strong fast.

All in all, a very good fps roguelike (first I've seen) that has high replay value and absolutely worth it at $12.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Wonderful roguelike FPS. Always coming back to chase that "perfect" build. 

Really clever combo of class-based skill progression along with the standard buffs, where you always want to try your hardest to align the two into OP combos. Based on what you get, this can totally change up the way your trying to build your character halfway through a run.

Crisp toon-style gunplay, lots of unique weapons, elements, enemy variety (some of whom you'll quickly learn to respect...), cool bosses, challenge areas, just so much variety to make every run feel a little different. 

The zones and pacing of the game feel really good. Compared to something like RoR2, where the game flows from empty/boring to over the top, Gunfire has a more consistent pace that I find refreshing, along with a tight campaign and a finite end. 

Each run rewards you with currency to spend on a meta progression tree. Normally I'd feel a little turned off by this, but here it lends to making your gameplay feel totally different over time.  Yes, you are generally just more OP as you level up, but this also unlocks new playstyles that don't really work at the earlier ranks. This coupled with the system where you unlock new potential scrolls (buffs) into your future loot tables makes for a pretty interesting and satisfying meta progression. And they have these sort of "save slots" where you can start a fresh progression on a new slot. I did this when playing with a buddy who was new to the game, and I was once again met with a brutally punishing early game that I had already forgotten about. Leveling up all over again was surprisingly fun. 

If you like these sorts of games at all, for $12 you are cheating yourself not to pick it up.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is incredible. Simply put.

If you need more to go on, I'll elaborate. To start, this game is in Early Access, but I've got 54.4 hours as of writing‚Äîthere is just so much to work towards. The sense of progression is rather fast especially as you're learning how the game works (read the loading screen tips, everyone!), and is accelerated in co-op. I can't honestly comment on how well co-op works given that my internet stability tends to be...questionable. For the most part, it's pretty stable, even when you're connected to someone else's lobby, but I've had terrible connections too, even as the host. 

Enemy variety is considerable, and their attack patterns can f*ck you up quickly, even on normal difficulty. The boss fight feel appropriately like boss fights‚Äîthey're huge, they have attack patterns to learn, and you're locked in an arena with them. You will learn to fear Lu Wu, the very first boss, too.

There are two playable characters as of this moment, but the best one is accessible from the very start (make no mistake, having a natural way of inflicting elemental effects on enemies to combo with your weapons makes you feel like a monster). Speaking of weapons...the sheer number of weapons...good Lord, the SHEER. NUMBER. Granted, it's not a super-insane number yet, but the game's theme allows for a lot of room for weapon and perk variety, similar to Borderlands ( sans perks). Yeah, I brought it up. I'm sure many others have, but it's reasonably valid to. Weapons drop from enemies and can be bought from a vendor who occasionally appears as you travel. In co-op, weapons that drop seem to be instanced at random, meaning there are times when you get drops that others on your team can't see. I'm not sure how many others have had this experience, but I've seen it happen enough to know this is the case (this might be restricted solely to drops of weapons that others may not have unlocked yet, now that I think about it...).

A final word about weapon drops, once you've picked over the things you don't want, pick up the stuff you don't want and then drop it, that way it becomes visible to your teammates. And for the hell of it, do the same for occult scrolls you don't want‚Äîit might fit into someone else's build.

Right now, the devs are focused on the stability of the player experience (including co-op things such as connection stability and resurrection methods), but I have little doubt that there is content to come.

I am genuinely impressed with what Douyi Interactive Entertainment have achieved and cannot wait for what's next. Join the rest of us who already love this game and you'll very likely see why. Join us.

Join us.

Join us.

Join us.

Join us.
