title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
At first glance, you may think this is just another low polygon game with little effort and little substance. However, once you scratch the surface of what Gunfire Reborn truly is, you realize how deep and complex the weapons, upgrades and enemies can be. 

Gunfire Reborn is a rogue-like first person shooter game. The main gist of the game is, your abilities, power ups and weapons are upgraded through scrolls and goblets, which are placed in chests spread throughout each level. The levels themselves change layout every time you start a new session, and the game lasts as long as you stay alive. Once your lives and revives are wiped out, you must start from the beginning.

After every run of the game, you use your collected 'Soul Essence' to upgrade a skill tree. These skills range from increased ammo capacity to more shield and health, and even unlock new features such as better weapon augmentations or the ability to choose a weapon right at the beginning of a new session. Each upgrade costs more Soul Essence, and the longer you last within each level, the more will drop from enemies and bosses until you die.

The bosses... as of the typing of this review, I and several friends have only made it past the first boss. What you can expect from these bosses is a heavy challenge. Whether you play alone or in a group, the boss will stack their health and shield to match the amount of players in your party. There will be mobs that get summoned in. There will be cover that can be broken. There will be attacks you absolutely have to avoid to survive. The challenge is fresh and welcome.

All in all, this game has a little bit of everything for fans of games like Borderlands, DOOM, Unreal, and other fast paced shooters. I expected a small gem and I found a wonderful treasure hidden in Steams store.

There are some kinks here and there that they need to work on and some personal issues that I have ran into along the ride. Overall though, they seem to be keeping up with solid updates and changes to fix some of these bugs and irritations I have ran into. I look forward to seeing what the full on release is going to be like and what kind of future projects this studio can put together. If you ask if I would recommend I would say 100 times yes, this is currently my favorite game and my new addiction but, who says all addictions are bad!? Try it for yourself, you won't be disappointed. Think of Borderlands and Risk Of Rain 2 having a beautiful baby together and you've found Gunfire Reborn. That's about all I can say here as I'm trying to rush back to playing!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
[h1]Disclaimer: This is an early access title that seems still quite early in development, I will be updating this review as more content and patches are delivered; current review written at Patch "6.9 Update"[/h1]


Gunfire Reborn is a Roguelike / FPS. Kind of like a lovechild of Risk of Rain and Borderlands. It utilities procedurally generated levels. Randomized gun loot from a vast armory, with a plethora of stats and effects. A permanent talent tree system that improves with every run you finish and a reward system just for playing!

The gameplay feels very fluid and the feedback from combat is great, sound effects and coloured text from scoring "crits". (Think headshots / weakpoints from Borderlands) and "lucky shots" (Think critical hits from RPG's such as Final Fantasy etc), along with the potential of elemental damage and explosives to add to the chaos, still allows you to clearly understand what hit what and for how much. The sheer amount of weaponry for a game this early in development is fantastic and the starting gun feels solid, even later into a run should you run out of ammo, as it is also constantly upgraded with your other weapons so it doesn't fall behind and become useless.

While the game does use randomly generated maps, the sample size of the room tiles available is still very small, so you tend to face the same 5-8 rooms, level dependent, in a random order, rather than feeling that each run is truly unique. Once you have taken the talent to open secret 'vaults' around the map, which can include battle arenas, jumping puzzles or trap-ridden treasure rooms, while in execution, are very fun and rewarding, are also doomed to being predictable and repetitive after the first few runs.

The randomness of the weaponry available to the player, is one of my favorite things about this game. Firstly the weapons themselves vary from Submachine-guns to Miniguns to Kunai to even a lizard that spits fireballs! The bonus stats, or 'inscriptions' can range from anything to increasing your mag size, reload speed or even changing the damage type of the weapon to a new element. Early into my time spent playing, I wrote off a lot of the earlier guns as 'useless' until I'd progressed down the talent tree and unlocked 'exclusive inscriptions' which can make a weapon vastly more powerful, or even change the way it functions completely. Players will also come across various 'occult scrolls' which will empower the player and truly bring the uniqueness of each run. These powers can make, or break a run and it feels amazing when you think you've found "the build". Alas, sometimes power comes with a handicap for example, some of the scrolls will bring you power at a cost, so it's down the the playstyle of the individual to make up their mind with what fits.

The game consists at time of review of 2 playable characters. 'Crown Prince' who is unlocked initially and 'Ao Bai' who is unlocked once you have reached level 30. Crown Prince has an ability that fires an orb, dealing damage and freezing enemies in place for couple of seconds, and gas grenades that deal DoT corrosive damage to enemies, Ao Bai's ability is to dual-wield both of your equipped guns, their grenade deals instant explosive damage. Both characters share the same starting weapon and talent tree. Crown Prince's permanent upgrades seem to change the way their ability works such as freezing enemies for longer, dealing more damage or mastering one of the elements, whereas Ao Bai's upgrades seem to utilise explosive damage, both from weapons and his own grenades and making himself more formidable while their dual-wield ability is active.

The talent tree is the main progression point of the game, shared between both characters (with the exception of a small 5-point strip on the right hand side which is unique to each character). This will permanently boost your power and make subsequent runs easier. Providing boosts to health, shield, reducing the damage you take, increasing the damage you do and even making it easier to revive your allies in co-op mode. While in a run you are granted 'Soul Essence' for defeating enemies and bosses, which is used in turn to power up the Jade Amulet given to you by your master. Whilst in a run, upon death you can also sacrifice some of the soul essence you have collected to revive yourself once.

Whilst the progression might sound quite grindy, the game is so fun and engaging and doesn't even feel like you're trying to grind. Being rewarded for playing with new unlocks such as weapons and ascension scrolls adds replayability and though you may not take down the boss this time, you could set a smaller goal of trying to take down as many required enemies as possible to grant yourself a new power or weapon. All the unlocks are available to view on the main menu with the means to do so, as well as a bestiary.

This game can be played solo or Co-Op with up to 3 friends. I believe it uses Steam P2P, so connection issues can depend on who's hosting. While I have experienced a few issues with co-op play such as rubber banding and latent hit registry, It's been nothing game breaking such as falling out of the world or desync. One of my main issues at the moment is I feel it's a little overtuned, especially on normal difficulty. Using the first boss as an example in single player he has 80,000hp. In 2 player this is raised threefold to 240,000hp and in 3 player it is raised fivefold to 400,000hp. Also if you should happen to die after using your revival in Co-Op you're doomed to sitting watching your friends/allies play without you for up to 4 stages as you are not revived until after the boss is defeated, missing out not only on gameplay but also the rewards required to meet the hike in difficulty for each stage.

[b]TL:DR[/b]
Gunfire Reborn is a Roguelike FPS that shows great potential. It's fluid and fun although somewhat repetitive. Lots of weapons and skills in a randomised loot system, rewarding gameplay and lots of replayability. In terms of game for the price, especially as this is an early access title, it's excellent quality. The game is being updated regularly and every update seems to make the game better. If you like FPS and dungeon crawlers, or are just looking for something to kill the time either alone or with friends, definitely give this title a go.

[b]Pros[/b]
- Cheap
- Plethora of weapons to play with
- Very fun and rewarding
- Updated regularly
- Has a lot of potential

[b]Cons[/b]
- Repetitive
- Co-op needs a bit of work
- Some of the bigger enemies hit(crit)boxes are janky

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
30+ year olds like me remember the days of good ol' campaign FPS shooters. With a tried and true formula of scripted waves navigating corridors with a challenging enough AI, cool guns and satisfying mechanics.

Well, imagine all these old titles that didn't try to reinvent the genre and give it a roguetype progression of skills, guns, powers and this is essentially Gunfire Reborn in a nutshell. This game is a lot of fun and the potential is there. 

Depending on how dedicated the development team is, I could definitely see this game being charged twice what they ask, that sure is amongst the reason it is 90% rated as of writing this review. The value is undeniable.

The game is fun, the potential is amazing, the gunplay is satisfying AND there is multiplayer with matchmaking. I mean.... It's mindblowing that no one thought of that before them, or at least no one executed it anywhere near as well as this game does. Don't sleep on this one, it's worth your time and your money.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn is very much up my alley, and very fluid and intuitive to play. Combat is satisfying, the general speed of play is perfect, and weapons have a nice 'chunk' to them. All up the game loop feels very refined. Devs are very active as well, which is encouraging.

Unfortunately, there's a limited amount of actual content and it therefore gets repetitive very quickly. Mobs are mostly archers, grenade chuckers and the occasional swordsman all the way through to the final boss. Despite the procedural generation, the layouts all feel more or less identical and the scenery doesn't really change, it's all generic dungeon rough-hewn granite in a couple of different pastel shades.

I'm also a little disappointed in the end of run levelling up. The bonuses are all generic (eg +5 ammo cap) and the grind more or less ends up meaning that you buy everything across the board rather than focussing on a particular speciality or ability.

In the end the game is a soft thumbs up for me. The price point is appropriate and I am hopeful that there's a fair bit more content, and iteration, to come, but I've been burned by early access games at this stage of the development cycle before.

Personally, despite the up thumb, my money is in as a kickstarter at this point. If you were more conservative about throwing your cash away it wouldn't hurt to wishlist and check back after six months.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
A cute little rougelite first person shooter, somewhat like borderlands with the guns that are dropped.

One grind every "run" to get a little stronger and get further, same time i think it gets a little harder too, but you get stronger faster, i think.

Allot of a "run" ofc depends on what "gear"(my description) scrolls and what upgrade skills one chooses during a map, and what guns one decide to grab, hopefully one can get some synergy with it all and go FAR.
But at the end of the map, when one die, one can spend the SPECIAL currency from the defeated foes on getting the char you played, a bit stronger for the next run.

Art is cute, nothing fantastic, but i have seen WAAY worse out there, for way less.
There are some rng in the maps i think, but the first level one really gets to know well, as there are no guarantee to even get to "floor" 2.

Perhaps later there will be a system to skip the first level, perhaps there are one that you unlock after getting up in levels already.
You are probably going to get a bit sick of the first floor eventually.
But it is still fun.
Getting better and smarter yourself helps enormusly naturally, so it is not all rng.

Co op seems a heck of allot of fun, and allot of the guns (and some skills i guess) seem to work best with two people geting more stats on enemies and by that doing way more damage, 
But i have no problem enyoing it myself solo.
Sure it can be a bit harder solo, and perhaps not qite as fun, but i find it plenty fun even solo.
The maps scale, so do not expect a cake walk just because you are two people.

IF my memmory do not decive me, i THINK it is up to 4 people co op, have yet to see that, but i would imagin allot of fun to be had.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I considered writing this review a day ago.  I had two hours of gametime and now at the time of writing this I have 3.  I can tell you that I was going to recommend this game even in its current state.  

I started out the game feeling like it was slow.  The character seemed slow to get around even though the first stage maps are small to begin with.  Enemies are varied and can surprise you but after a few rounds you learn the attacks and the timings.  You will die very quickly and easily in the beginning.  And I didn‚Äôt quite understand in the beginning that this game has serious ramp.  It goes like this:

You start out with 0 talent.  Literally and metaphorically.  You don‚Äôt know the moves of enemies to dodge them and you have no literal in game talent to earn new perks.  As you play and lose you will earn ‚Äútalent‚Äù which is used to unlock perks which begin the ‚Äúramping‚Äù process.  You see at first you will feel like a piece of s*** dying easily and not finding great weapons.  I thought that this was the game.
Its not.  You see eventually you‚Äôll gain the ability to unlock better weapon drops, more variation, better affects and so on.  And all the while you‚Äôre getting better drops more often for guns, you‚Äôre now also getting more scrolls.  

Scrolls are the wonderful mutators in this game akin to RoRs items.  They change your abilities and give you enhanced powers.  For example, I love the advanced jogger pants because it makes so that I can dodge with a 2 second cool down.  Partner that with the scroll that makes it so that 35% of the time your abilities don‚Äôt trigger a cooldown at all, and you suddenly have a good chance of double or triple dashing on the regular.
Now suddenly a stage that took 30 minutes and a guaranteed death at boss is completed in less than half that time and the boss is a cakewalk.  And it‚Äôs so satisfying.  Unfortunately, this game is somewhat brutal in a sense that as soon as you reach a new stage that is completely fresh  you are guaranteed to die from an unknown threat announcing itself.  

I generally don‚Äôt buy early access games anymore unless they are very far along in development.  So this one was sort of a gamble for me because it seems very new.  For $12 USD however this is a really hard game to not recommend.  Hell even if they were charging $20 I‚Äôd still be recommending it.

Bottom line is: Repetitive learn/adapt gameplay, combined with borderlands guns, and risk of rain items makes for an extremely fun game.  Add some coop seasoning and interesting and distinct art visuals for flavor and this is just a really great deal and a great game.  I look forward to seeing its development.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Very good dungeon crawler with a combination of elements from Doom, Borderlands, Hades, Risk of Rain, Dead Cells, and a few other greats. Unfortunately at the time of writing this the game suffers from extreme balancing issues both for and against the player. For example:

- Usefulness of guns vary extremely between the types of guns. Only about 4 out of the 30+ guns in the game are good at all
- Gun modifiers are very overpowered, where some can give you a 1/4 chance to one-shot when headshotting, and others giving you your ammo back if you miss
- Ground troops are quite weak. In comparison to Doom where the small grunts are easy kills and the bigger ones are each their own challenge, in Gunfire there are about 2 troop variations out of ~8 available per stage are any threat. With the right weapon they almost all get one-shot.
- Corrosive element is severely unbalanced. It slows for ~70% movement speed and lasts a good 8 seconds even after being unaffected. On top of this is deals DoT to the player, or the enemy. This leaves the other two elements, fire and lightning, to be completely shadowed by corrosive damage as fire on does DoT and lightning is useless. 

In light of these flaws I judge a game off of its potential in EA. As this game is fairly new I will see past these issues and trust the devs to see to rebalancing as the development cycle progresses. Where this game wins my heart is the other parts that I love. Gunplay is crisp, responsive, and rewarding. Headshot pings and kill response is absolutely beautiful. The item progression is great (imo) in comparision to a game such as Risk of Rain. Where in other games, gaining items are flat upgrades with no depth behind them, this game has quite a few double-edged swords when it comes to upgrading. This leaves the player to pay attention to what they are building, whether it be utility, sustain, or aggregate damage. On top of this the game just came out and they are roadmapping tons of new content to come that I can say I am excited for.

review: Two hours in and I already know this is a terrific game! This fact could be a real selling point for the game. The low poly count is done well too. Sort of reminds me of Orcs Must Die 2 (another shooter without blood). As I said, the lack of the red stuff could be the reason you purchase this game. Totally worth the money. And this early access version has been programmed very well. All there is now is just to balance the game and fix a couple wonky descriptions. 9 out of 10.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is basically perfect. It promises an FPS RPG Rogue Lite and it definitely delivers. The art style is amazing, but it is worth mentioning that many things in this game were clearly inspired by Overwatch and other games. There's a big fat shark enemy that hooks you with an anchor just like Roadhog. There's a gun that's basically a direct rip of Zarya's gun when wearing the Viking skin. In the same vein, there's a giant sword/shield wielding enemy that was clearly inspire by the knights in Zelda's Wind Waker, and I also wouldn't be surprised if the desert coyote was inspired by Jolteon. It's the same color, of a similar style and attacks with yellow lightning. It's kind of up to you to decide if coping so many other designs in gaming is lazy or not, but do try and remember this is a $13 game when judging it's overall creativity. 

Coping your friends homework, but changing it enough to not be plagiarism aside, this game is definitely worth the price when not on sale, which is more than I can say about a lot of the games I've played recently. 

The weapons are varied and there's basically something there for everyone. For a while I was a bit annoyed that some of the guns are objectively bad, but the game flips this on its head by allowing you to earn money with crit hits. All of a sudden the really poopy SMGs are great money makers for getting through the first dungeon, which at this point should be really easy to finish. I really like this mechanic, because the issue with Rogue lites is the early floors often get so easy and you've already been through there so many times you just wish you could skip it. This game does a decent job of avoiding that by allowing you to breeze through the level while also raking in coin. 

Aside from the variety, the majority of the weapons also look really cool. THERE'S A TINY DRAGON YOU USE AS A FLAME THROWER AND TO RELOAD IT FLIES AROUND IN YOUR PALM. 

What I'm saying is this game has great flavor, a great sense of progress, and solid FPS combat. The level design is probably the weakest part of the game. After all the brightly colored weapons and energy blasts, the dungeon and the desert levels just feel bland by comparison. Only the third area "The Beach" really lives up to what the level design could have been. 

Considering this game is in Alpha, I'm really looking forward to them adding more characters, weapons and levels. I would like to see this game do something other Rogue Likes haven't, which is add randomness to the level progress. Always always going from the temple dungeon to the desert to the beach, get's really stale and it wouldn't take much to mix it up. 

Overall I give this game a solid B+ and I really hope it only gets better.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn has quickly became one of my favorite Early Access titles I have ever played. 

The game is frequently being updated and the developers are actually listening to feedback and making quick changes based on said feedback. The developers, despite English not being their first language, are trying hard to communicate to an international audience by using English even in the patch notes and going as far as to thank their community's members for their feedback. 

This is a miracle these days. 

To think that their first ever FPS game is simply insane, the gameplay is actually plenty fun and doesn't feel at all like a first timer project. At the time of me writing this there are 2 classes who play differently and can lead to some insane builds. There are a lot of different guns unlocked by doing achievements ranging from killing X with Y to killing bosses. 

Tldr: buy this game, support the devs, holy molly I wish more devs were this cool.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is shaping up to be quite amazing! i have 42 hours currently and i've yet to beat the 3rd zone boss! In some rouge-lites you can get a feeling for a "God run" but in this game, there seems to be no such Godly runs for the sole fact that anything could still kill you at any point if you are careless, for example; you were too busy fighting a pack of sand wolves and forgot about the sniper who just blew your head clean off. (No gore! haha) but this game doesnt hand hold, its brutally hard in his paces but it trains you to be aware of your surroundings and not just mindlessly shoot at enemies filing up to attack you.  

My one gripe is i think you get the "2nd" character far too late into your gameplay, i thought he was gonna be level 15 or maybe 20, but now that ive invested so much time learning how cat boy works with his skills, i kinda dont wanna learn the other, since i got used to how smoke bombs work and doggos are on impact bombs (which, don't help against shield golems.) 

But other than that, this game is really fun! there are so many ways you can take your builds every run, you can focus making Enegry bolts crazy power or maybe do more things with your smoke bombs, can make em a defensive zone, a debuff zone, extra damage zone, carry double/triple/quad amounts of nades. The customization plays wonderfully per character and with the gun choices (and many more to be unlocked) you'll find your favorite for your playstyle soon enough but swapping around and testing other weapons is welcome! 

That cheap needle gun does CRAZY damage if you have the right perks and skills. Without spoiling too much, i had a scroll that places bullets into the chamber on miss, well, if you hold right click with that gun, it spits ammo at the ground like a madman! 

Just an example of silly meme builds also being possible and the amount of replay-ability, add buddies into the mix and it makes things a bit harder, even more adding more friends. (up to 3 friends) 

It is certainly worth, even in early access! i mean 42 hours, that was an old school rpg back in the 2000's. i certainly had my monies worth! :3

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
After having beaten Elite mode three times, I believe it is time to give a review.  There are a bunch of pros and cons to the game, some I went in expecting and others that kinda developed as I played.

Pros:
Good challenge
Fun guns
Interesting playable characters
Good soundtrack
Good visual design
Interesting use of Borderlands Elements
Can achieve Binding of Isaac levels of OP gear combinations
Big numbers on the screen when you build correctly

Cons:
Rather bland and repetitive level design (until you reach level 3)
Invisible walls result in a one way street straight to the boss
Little to no room for exploration
Can get very unbalanced very quickly for both players and enemies
Lots of typos and grammatical errors
Only 3 bosses that all have rather limited and predictable move sets
Lack of diverse Vault room layouts
Lackluster Occult Scrolls that clutter up an otherwise really good line up
Healing Buns are extremely rare and make getting damaged more punishing than you would think it ought to be
Peer to Peer Multiplayer service results in 999 ping in most players aside from the Host

Overall it will need some more time to cook in the oven but for what you get for 12 bucks, its very much worthwhile to give it a shot.

9.5 Rips / 10 Tears

I like these type of games so much, if you like games like Risk of Rain 2 it's kinda similar to that.
Now you might get infuriated by the first boss if done by one or two players that's new to the game but it gets easier once you get more skills and unlock new scrolls. And it wasn't even infuriating for me since I like these type of games and sometimes you have better loot in the next run and you can get Scrolls and skills in the game which makes you even more powerful. Scrolls are like skills and weapons you see in the game has different perks on it sometimes or often more if you increase talent points in that area. There is also cursed scrolls but I won't go into depth into that. all in all it's a good game for a really cheap price range! Beware it's still in early access the final game will probably be much better!

Fun, addictive and tight shooting makes this a fun game to lose a few (hundred) hours to :)

And this is coming from someone who usually doesn't play non-PvP shooters!

Despite the low poly graphics, they work well in motion. The feel of the different guns and the buttery smooth framerate are enough to make you ignore it; If anything, the simpler graphics help when you're in a 'mess' and need to figure out targets at a glance etc.

This is basically the FPS Roguelite that I've been looking for for so long.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: This game is fantastic. It feels like a dungeon crawler with risk of rain elements, but with an actual progression system that isn't entirely unlocking characters. The maps aren't very expansive and could use a little more variety. They more than make up for it though with their class building. One game I'm going full grenadier, duel wielding two rocket launchers and throwing my endless grenades, while another I'm a glass cannon from a distance that uses smoke grenades to prevent damage for me and my teammates. You will also find that you play the same class many different ways, ways you didn't think you could play them originally. The game practically begs you to theory craft fun builds with all of the different weapon effects and scroll combinations. I also cant stress enough how surprised I am that I'm going through the game with friends who recently got the game, and I am STILL unlocking new items in the normal mode. I don't know how many weapons and scrolls there are total, just know that I haven't found an end yet 40 hours in. For an early access game, as many of the positive reviews will reinforce, its absolutely incredible.

Great game with surprising depth. Lots to unlock and you really feel rewarded with each new run - initially 2/2 all the new weapons to test out, and later because the upgrades really do affect the strength of your character.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Two hours in, I'd call this a good time, and a solid Early Access title that has a ways to go before being complete.

In a nutshell: It has the same strengths and weaknesses you find in any roguelite, a cute aesthetic, and pretty decent gunplay. Little bit light on content in its current state, but it's also inexpensive. Recommended.

*A side note before I review the game. When I purchased it, it filed itself in to a Souls-like dynamic collection, which I would not call at all accurate. If you're here because Steam has told you this is a Souls-like, it is not. It has none of the features of a game that fall in to that category, I think the system just conflated Roguelite and Souls-like for some reason.

Roguelite: It suffers from the same problems you find in any of these games. Its a repetitive grind with difficulty spikes designed to force you to replay it. Variation is low at this point, but I'm hoping that's a symptom of being Early Access. Difficulty is wildly inconsistent, depending on which weapons/power-ups/etc. you have collected, and the types of challenges the game decides to generate on your run.

Gunplay: It's pretty good. A few of the weapons don't feel particularly good, but most do. With only two slots and a dice-roll on what you get it can occasionally feel like you've got a very bad hand for what the game has decided to throw at you, but hey, that's a roguelite for ya. 

Aesthetic: It's cute. Presumably you've already seen the dog and cat. At the time of this writing those are the only characters, and it seems like it's going to take a good many playthroughs with the cat to unlock the dog. I enjoy the cat's powers though, so I'm not going to call that a total loss. I would have liked a pair of options to start with though, with more to unlock later, more akin to Risk of Rain's catalogue of characters. Perhaps more will come in an update.

Content: A little sparse, at the moment. I am once again hoping that is a symptom of the game being Early Access. It's certainly cheap at the moment, so I can't say it's an unfair dollars:content ratio.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I've had a ton of fun with this so far. The gameplay seems great. It should be a little easier to select items and weapons off the floor. Sometimes I'll want to grab a weapon quickly during combat and it takes too much effort to aim perfectly at the weapon while trying to dodge bullets. Movement speed feels a little low to me, and I wish I could crouch, but those are just my own opinion.

The biggest issue that's going to hold this game back is the English translation. It's not awful, but it's not good either, and there's a bit of a prejudice associated with poor English. It's a good thing that there are great reviews for this game or else I would have looked at the store page, noticed the poor English, and scrolled past. In-game, the English can be confusing and distracting to read. I'd recommend hiring a professional translator to look over the whole game. It would make the whole thing look much more professional.

But overall, I think it's a blast, and you shouldn't miss out on it if it interests you just because the English puts you off.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
TL/DR: I felt it became a tedious and frustrating grind rather quickly. 

Thought I would be recommending based on first hour or two playing, started off fun, looks cool and has some interesting weapons, but after under 7 hours I have had enough of it, so I cannot recommend. 

If, like me apparently, you are not so good a FPS gamer as to plough through the early zones getting far into the later zones, it quickly gets boring, as you will be replaying the tedious temple zones over and over and over.... I understand it is a Rogue-like, so starting over is the nature of it, but playing through the same temple zones again and again just to get a tiny bit further before having to do the damn boring temple again gets old. It is apparently randomly generated each time, but this is barely noticeable between runs. Yes after a run you get points to boost your character for the next attempt, but the changes are slight and it just gives the game a real sense of being a grind. Despite the positive aspects I have stopped playing as cannot stand the idea of looking at that temple zone one more time just to get to a insanely difficult boss that would take numerous attempts for me to beat (meaning numerous replays of the zones I am already sick to death of). 

Since they went for a "adventure level-based game," they could have been a bit looser on the 'Rouge' aspect of the gameplay, at least in single player. An option to have check points or to use points for saves, or let you skip zones already done and play different zones in some kind of 'arcade mode'... anything just to make the game actually fun to keep playing and to reduce the repetitive tediousness.
developer_response: We are sorry for your bad experience. Here are some tips to fight against BOSS: 1)When it is about to attack, use dash to get out of the warning ring immediately 2)You can use 2 pillars to avoid the attack from BOSS 3)You can kill those normal enemies easily with grenades 4)You can use weapons with lightning damage to break the shield of BOSS quickly. Hope you can have a try again. BTW, you can revive each other if you play with your friends, so you have higher chance to succeed in challenge.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
PROS: 
-Great gameplay for a low price
-Diversity in guns, one for every playstyle
-CO-OP play up to 4 people
-Progression is similar to that of Risk of Rain 2
-Borderlands 2-esque guns and elemental effects (and fusions which have their own unique effects)

CONS:
-Clunky movement
-Sometimes movement isn't responsive (input doesn't register)

For the developer,
The miasma fusion is buggy. For example, when the Dark-faced Bandit is the only enemy alive and you inflict the Miasma fusion on it, it stares at you all the time, making it impossible to hit the critical point. Can you make it so that when it is the last enemy alive, Miasma makes it stare in the direction it was looking in before it was frozen?

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I loved the game , but i most probably will not play it until its final release 
cuz , 

I might not be the most mechanically gifted person but me and my friend have done co-op on a lot of hack and slash and shoot'em up  and various games over the years , we have beat tastefully designed difficulty mode games like dark souls series .
We both spent 5 hours  and atleast 14 tries to  "try" beat the first boss , and failed everytime ......
could we have pulled it off? , OFCOURSE ....if we tried maybe super hard to do so ......
But i do not think thats how this game was meant to be played.

So, what is the problem?
The boss is scaled bad .....really bad ....how much HP  , the mechanics as well , the 4th floor again is scaled riddiculously ,  there is no room for "tactical" play .....yet there is no mechanics to get to mob's face to kill them , without getting slaughtered  ....specially when you need to preserve all your chances to do the boss .

I think the game needs a  lot of balancing  and re-think some core "sustain" mechanics.

and the developers need to make up their mind , if they intend to make the players go tactical mode , or  "hack 'n' slash" fest  mode  .  it seems they are confused and are trying to hit some non existent spot .
developer_response: We are sorry for your bad experience. Here are some tips to fight against BOSS: 1)When it is about to attack, use dash to get out of the warning ring immediately 2)You can use 2 pillars to avoid the attack from BOSS 3)You can kill those normal enemies easily with grenades 4)You can use weapons with lightning damage to break the shield of BOSS quickly. Hope you can have a try again. BTW, you can revive each other if you play with your friends, so you have higher chance to succeed in challenge.

review:
44 h in and lev 120. 52/60 achi. 40% normal 60% elite 50/50 solo friends so i think i can talk about this game 

got it for 10eu. solid game for that money. good shooting good movement, weapons skills etc 

Combos are nice and you have to look out what you pick up since you can F yourself up but advanced depot + any weapon with 0,2 projectile on kill resets after reload is busted when you dont have to reload - pliz dont fix

Add more stuff in the future - even enemies are ok but floor plans are always the same as are enemies spawn points and types. its always the same doods in the same spots. 

more bosses more scrolls more everything 

As is the game is very fun and you will get your moneys worth for that 10 EU. again for the future - add more stuff and this will be a classic. right now its a 40 min run and done - you have to try very hard to even die on elite on first two stages but then again you can get one shot very easely on satge 3 

2 problems with the game - FPS drops with friends but to be fair we did have a rocket launcher that we stacked up to fire like 10+ projectiles at a time with advanced depot / perks and weapon stats. And for some reason when i open the game it moves whatever i have on my second monitor so i have to Tab move it go back to the game and its ok. it happens only when you launch the game. 1st world problems 

P.S. 1 i didnt have coyote spawn once so far 

P.S. 2 how do i even do "Unable to purchase any items at the Peddler in BOSS Stage/" achi when i have the "first item in pedler costs 0" perk?

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
[h1]Risk of Rain, Dead Cells & Borderlands all had a baby. And it's glorious.[/h1]
[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*]Super addictive gameplay.
[*]Lots of replayability with upgrades and unlockables.
[*]Challenging enemies.
[*]Gunplay is great, weapons look and feel awesome.
[*]Appealing visuals and art style.
[*]Play as a gun wielding doggo or cat.
[*]This review makes Damocles mad.
[/list]
[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*]Really unbalanced right now. Enemies will SHRED you some times.
[*]Can come across as very grindy.
[*]Only 2 characters and not many levels.
[/list]

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game definitely came out of nowhere and shocked me and a few friends. Its fun alone, or with others. Gunplay feels solid. Lots of variety in play style(speaking to just weapons really for now, since there are only two characters) the enemies feel dynamic enough that there are still occasionally rooms that I have not experienced in a run yet.

Replayability is my main issue right now(Early access) I find myself wanting more and gradually was less inclined to do the same run over and over. Or that my friends have temporarily moved on.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: Pretty sure everyone has said it already with different variations, but this is like Borderlands, Doom, Enter the Gungeon and Risk of Rain all in one package. Of course, everything has its originality twist too. Very fun and addictive to play. The permanent perks you have as you play and die makes the game easier the more you play, so it's an incentive to keep playing to be stronger and have more fun. Of course, there are some things that would be a quality of life improvements, but they have a feedback section in game for that. Make sure to report bugs and even suggest features too. Very fun and addictive even with friends.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: Although I do find this game very fun and enjoyable since it's a pretty simple concept and easy to get sucked into. Go in, clear enemies, unlock new weapons / "scolls" (power ups) and progress further with new items. The game is pretty bare min when it comes to enemies and shit. Most enemies have very basic attacks that are easy to understand and avoid, but what makes the game hard is the scaling they do as you progress. They really just increase the health of enemies and and more enemies and just swarm you with a shit ton of AOE and projecties and fast things running at you. Not to mention the weapon balancing in this game is awful, most guns feel extremely underpowered and I will never touch. And then you have all the stolen assests from Overwatch and borederlands it's so lazy. Every gun is just a reskin of those guns with the same reload animations. I'm finally about to unlock the second and currently only other character 7 hours in. Not to mention most of the power ups are pretty shit and really don't do a whole lot to your build, you basiclly pick up everything you see. The developers are lazy and stealing assets to make a game that is fun for the first week or two you have it and then stop playing after you've done everything 10 times over. I wish I only played two hours so I could refund this.

title: Gunfire Reborn

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game blows. Most of the positive reviews are from bots and people who're just looking to appease their favourite streamer. 

Rife with bizarre issues like singleplayer latency due to using some weird internal server arrangement, and full of completely useless weapons. Enemies scale seemingly exponentially with hardly any room for the player to keep up, only exacerbated with multiplayer scaling.

Nearly everything about this game has been ripped from somewhere else. This ranges from more general things like gameplay effectively being taken from Ziggurat and Immortal Redneck, to animations being stolen verbatim from overwatch (Kunai and Bone Dragon being the most blatant). 

Do yourself a favour and play something else. Hell, play Paranautical Activity if you HAVE to.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I literally have no clue what the hype is about and why this is overwhelmingly positive on here. Bots? Who the hell knows. 

This game is a massive clumsy mess. I thought it might be interesting at first but it quickly became apparent that it's a shoddily assembled mess of stolen overwatch and borderlands animations (literally all of them) with terrible aiming, sloppy translations, and badly scaling gameplay. Bought this because my friends were playing it and thought they were in for a good time past some rocky early-access shenanigans, but we were all wrong. Ultra-spongy enemies as early as mid first stage and the entirety of stage 2, the worst platforming and most limp and useless dash skill imaginable. This is just the glaring issues right off the bat too. I can only imagine it gets more sloppy and grindy as time goes on. Maybe the damage isnt so horribly tuned for solo, I have no idea.

All in all this game feels like a chinese mobile game for current-gen phones, just with the out-the-nose microtransactions not yet implemented. Ugly, stolen-assets, clumsy, bullet-spongy. If you want a really really cheap, sloppy fps rogue-lite, go play Tower of guns, Heavy Bullets, Paranautical activity, Ziggurat or Immortal redneck.

EDIT: just realized the page advertises "Multiple heroes!!" yeah, there's two. Neither are fun and one is unlocked at level 30 (that's a lot of grinding by the way)

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: Very fun game that rewards skill and punishes you for not paying attention

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
It's a fun co-op rougelike FPS RPG dungeon crawler similar to Borderlands x any popular rougelike out there (eg RoR, Dead Cells, Hades) with a lot of inspiration taken from many other games. From Overwatch, there are the Junkrat, Mei, & Zarya-inspired weapons with a Roadhog-type enemy. There's the classic hp-shield-armor and elemental system akin to Borderlands. Runs take around 25min - 1 hour. As of its current state (early access / just came out), there's around 20-30 hours of content to get a feel for most of what the game has to offer and around 45-60 hours to unlock everything for the completionists out there. 

My only issue is that the game becomes incredibly easy on elite mode once you put some time in and have most of the talent & scroll unlocks, but other than that, the game is pretty solid fun for its $12 price. 9/10

title: Gunfire Reborn

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Addictive game-play loop with snappy combat and extensive replayability. The builds are incredibly fun to assemble throughout a run. Getting the one specific gun or occult scroll or ascension you've been needing all run and experiencing the power spike is wonderful. Mowing down enemies is satisfying as heck.

This game is a flippin' steal at $12 as-is. Can't wait to see where they take it out of EA. 

[b]I can't recommend this game enough![/b]

P.S. To anyone struggling with some of the platform challenges - try swapping to the base gun; Seems to allow you to move a little faster which makes a big difference.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: I haven't put too many hours into this game yet (1hr played), After beating the first boss I realized the game had more stages following it. (After Watching Northernlion's video on it, I assumed the first floor boss was the final one). With that said, this is one of the best first impressions of any roguelike I have played, Having played Slay the Spire/Isaac/FTL/Noita and a few more, I could see this becoming a renown roguelike very easily. It reminds me of Risk of Rain 2 in all the right ways, but adding more to the experience. It is difficult enough to kick your butt if you don't stay on your toes, but also nowhere near frustrating when it does. The sense of progression you get while in your runs and following are great. I definitely recommend this game and i'm very excited to see where they go with this game in future updates.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game stands head and shoulders above the rest of the genre, and it isn't even finished yet. Snappy, responsive shooting meets randomized levels that don't feel like a chore to fight through, with a sprawling enemy roster and an arsenal of fun, interesting weapons to go with it. The interplay of player weapons and abilities, and the interplay of different enemy formations and all of the things that each enemy can do, make every session and every firefight unique and challenging. It's a blast.

Strong fundamentals go a long way, and with such a great foundation to build on, it will be very exciting to see what comes next.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Few thoughts from my first 14 hours.

Simple enough that you can just jump in and play for short periods.. Challenging enough that you can play for hours and feel entertained.

It's not going to impress the hardcore fps players, hitboxes can be a little bit vague sometimes, but for someone like me who isnt super into the genre, this is fun and the 'idea' of headshots for crits is there.. i just feel like some shots that should miss still hit.

This game is WAY more fun with other people.. be that pot luck in the matchmaking system (I've had decent luck there so far), or with friends. 

Gun varieties seem good, and the perks system while a little confusing at the start soon makes sense and is decently varied. 

Graphics aren't going to blow you away, but they're still decent.. sound is there.. never been much of an audiophile :D

Overall, if you're looking for a fun game to take time out with friends, this is a decent buy for an early access title and i'm very much looking forward to seeing where it goes. If you can get it on sale, then buy copies for your friends too and force them to join you :D

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
As i would love to give it a positive review , I had always certain  problems with rogue-lites like these.

1. The fact that you always spawn from the same chapter , making it quite a repetetive run everytime you start a new run . rogue-lites like  these will eventually add more chapters that some people will never reach in the same boring order. Making it feel like a waste off extra content , Randomizing the starting chapter would make it less off a chore and improve on the current  rogue-lite formula , so everyone can enjoy a genre like this! 

2. The need to be grinding to a certain level to have a chance to beat a boss or any levels/chapters available in the current game , it's something that was adopted like a MMO , i never liked the fact that i needed to be a certain level to proceed on a certain terrain. In my opinion a rogue-lite should be completely based on your skill level and not on how much hours you spend on it , not to sound a bit racist. But japanese/chinese games are just known for these ridiculous grinds and honestly most people don't like it. We all want the same chances , it makes it fun and fair for everyone to play.

3. Co-op should be unlocked from the start , people who buy a co-op roguelite expect to play with other friends the moment they buy it the fact that i needed to grind to level 10 to play with my friends or randoms , just made me already question why i would want to continue playing?

4. Respawns on co-op should be always right before a boss battle , not after "does not make any sense"?

5. Difficulty spikes between chapter 1 and chapter 2 are ridiculous and should be balanced out. The fact that i need to spray 30K damage hits killing monkey king in a matter off 25 seconds with a sniper rifle and Pure luck orb scrolls and skills and still not killing the NPC's on chapter 2 in one hit is beyond me , just not enough gold to sustain the ridiculous tanky NPC's with underpowered guns that are apparently as tanky as the chapter 1 boss monkey king?

 All in all  ,I only put this review negative so developers will read it! not to bash on such a great idea! i love co-op games and games like these are great additions to my library.
developer_response: Thanks for your detailed suggestions. Most of the issues you mentioned do exist in current version like upgrade, difficulty, etc. We will continue the optimization in our future update. In addition, about multiplayer unlock, there is no level limitation for you to invite your friends to play together. You can directly invite your friends at the preparation interface. Thanks for you suggestions again!

review: Borderlands meets Enter the Gungeon meets Doom 2016. A charming roguelite dungeon crawler FPS with RPG elements that's keeping me hooked for hours. It's worth the price. I hope they give the game more verticality and speed. Co-op must be fun as hell

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I'm a massive fan of Borderlands, and no game has come close to scratching that itch that Borderlands has. This game though? It has many of the things that I love: the gunplay, the movement, the skills. But it still requires you to put effort in to make those strides to make your character better. I played this for 5 hours straight, I had so much fun. Unlocking new weapons and scrolls, seeing what cool combinations for scrolls I could have, how I'd enter situations. It is a class experience.

If you're a Borderlands nut like I am, it would be a damn shame to see you pass this game by. Definitely pick this up, you won't regret it.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game, despite the painfully generic name, is a lot of fun. GR shows a lot of promise as the lovechild of Borderlands and Enter the Gungeon. The gunplay and ability comboing is satisfying. The guns and enemies are varied. The progression paths offer good variance.

Things I would like to see improved:
Have a "Dungeon Cleaner" function ala necrodancer to take out scrolls and guns you REALLY don't like. Maybe with a number of slots that can be upgraded with essence.

More heroes in the future (obviously this takes a lot of work, so a lot of time).

A reroll system.

Rename the game to something with personality. Shooty Bullets has more life than Gunfire Reborn.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
*REVIEW OF VER. 6.9 (Nice)*

Gunfire Reborn is a Roguelite FPS that takes inspiration of Chinese culture. The gameplay feels like Borderlands-esque Gun looting and shooting while also giving us buff mechanics like Dead Cells or Risk of Rain.

Whilst the core gameplay relies on delving into the dungeons to reach the end and fight through hordes of enemies with your skills and guns, there's also attempting to find good loot in the meantime, bettering your character with certain scrolls that will aid your runs or sync with your guns to provide extra firepower. GR also has a leveling system for your character so that in your future runs, you will become stronger and more versatile either to clear waves of enemies or to assist your team in progressing forward. As with the guns, there are many to choose from that interact in different ways i.e. a Lightning glove that can damage enemies close to your target or a... Lizard that can fire remote bombs ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø

Pros:
Its Fun to play! Solo or Multiplayer, you'll be having fun in different runs with different builds
The guns are neat! Some of them are really nice to use and the mechanics of the damage system somewhat make it satisfying
The Aesthetic is nice! Something about games that take from Asian culture end up being real nice to play in

Cons:
Early Access; The game is still well within development which means that yes, there are going to be bugs and underdeveloped features of the game. A lot of the games only cons is solely on the reasoning above.

TL;DR If you like Roguelites and had fun with games such as Risk of Rain, Borderlands, Enter the Gungeon and anything of those types, then this is a game for you!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Advertised as Risk of Rain meets Borderlands...no where near as polished as either. Still has a long way to go, so many balance issues (some guns are completely useless even leveled up, 2nd boss is too difficult, upgrades are either huge power spikes or insignificant). Not much enemy diversity. Overall, its just a game that tries to fit a mold, but offers nothing new or unique to the table. I know its still in early access, but even with some internal play testing, it could have been delivered in a better state.

I'd pass for now, I'll revisit it a couple versions later.
developer_response: Thanks for your feedback, current system is not perfect enough and we are optimizing it, please give us more time.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
The game reminds me of a hidden gem called 9 parchments on switch. Both are challenging and very rewarding to keep playing. Caveblazers is another game like this where it starts off innocent enough and seems a bit boring, but as you keep unlocking gear and traversing further and further, you see there is alot more depth. The english translations are a bit rough on descriptions, but you can use context clues to figure them out. Multiplayer is fun, but I recommend going solo until you have amassed some more upgrades to truly shine in multiplayer midgame onwards. 

The combat is fast and frenetic twitch gameplay similar to borderlands with the skills and cooldowns. The rogue elements fit well into the game and don't feel forced. You just have to play it until you unlock enough upgrades to get to stage 3 to really enjoy the scope of the game. From then on, you'll be hooked.

review: This is a great roguelite game that deserves a much bigger player base than it currently has. For $12 you get an addictive fps and rpg mixed game that keeps me coming back. The shooting is tight, the gameplay loop is addictive, the graphics are charming, and the rpg aspects make it feel rewarding. There's no stupid microtransactions that make the game feel like a money grab, instead it's a game that has everything unlockable by simply playing the game. I wish more game developers followed this practice and made games for gamers. I have nothing but good things to say about this game and hope that the developers continue to support this hidden gem. For $12 you can't get a better game.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I'll start off with a TLDR: At $12 this game is a steal, I put 37hrs into the game in just a few days. I recommend it to anyone that enjoys a game that you keep going back stronger then before.

Okay, time for the longer section, pros, cons, what they are doing right, and what they could improve on:

Pros:
- Simplicity of the art style: Cartoony but in a fun and enjoyable way, making it easy on a computer system too
- A lot of varied weapons before adding in the inscriptions which are randomized when the weapon drops
- Replayability: You rarely get the same items and scrolls in the same runs, making each run different
- Variety of enemies unique to each map
- Early on you'll feel punished for not spending all of your points on talents, wasting small amounts here and there, but as you upgrade you'll be able to start storing them. This helps a LOT with replayability, as you can always progress towards something, even with a bad run.
- Scrolls, there are a lot of them and they can alter your play style or they can just augment it. The best part is, if you get one that doesn't interact well with another, you can drop one on the ground. Only certain ones (mostly cursed) are permanent for a run
- Gemini Inscriptions - These are mostly a late run inscription that can add a little more flavor to your run, but are by no means a requirement to beat a boss, more so because you need both weapons to have the same Gemini
- Character upgrades: This almost made the cons list, due to the fact you'll very rarely get a skill you want, maxed out. I put it in the pros though, because they are another layer of difference for each run

Cons:
- Inscriptions - There are a large variety of inscriptions, which is very nice to spice up the weapons. I'm putting this under cons though, due to the fact you can get negative synergies in inscriptions. Example: Exclusive Inscription that limits the weapon to two rounds in the mag. Second inscription boosts magazine size by 60% (has no effect)
- Weapon upgrades from craftsman - This one is due to the issue of the craftsman ONLY being able to upgrade the damage and re-roll the Gemini inscription. Early weapons will only have a few inscriptions, and it seriously hampers you to keep weapons with little to no inscriptions on them, even if they are your favorite. - Don't upgrade weapons that only have one or two green effects
- Parkour: Ugh... it is nice when it is well done, but the Fjord one is a little too punishing, the non-challenge chest is harder to get then the challenge one. Granted, this is completely ruled out IF you have good speed upgrades.
- As much as the variety of enemies was nice, the con part of it, is the weak spots being the head as the vast majority of enemies are humanoid or beast. Other then bosses, only one enemy has a different weak point.
- Copper is a currency gained to buy items and upgrades inside each run, I'm listing this as a con, primarily because there are talents slots wasted on this, and it is only used as a gating mechanism to prevent players from upgrading weapons too much.
- Weak traps: Traps in runs are more an annoyance then anything dangerous, flame jets take several seconds to kill. Boulders are only a real threat if you are careless and you get bounced into others inside a trap vault.
- Only two difficulty modes as of this post: Normal and Elite
- Gated second character behind level of talents - If it was an early unlock, it wouldn't be so bad, but the second character can take awhile to unlock if you have bad runs.

With all that out of the way, moving on to what they are doing right. Honestly this game is off to a brilliant start, and the list above basically addresses everything I could go into detail about in a long winded post. Being Early Access, I just hope the devs take a look at feedback and maybe adjust some things.

What they could do better? More characters to choose from, and maybe add some skins so running in groups, people don't all look EXACTLY the same. Requirements for unlock certain weapons and scrolls, some of them are a bit insane, requiring 100 fire kills on an enemy that only shows up in the last few stages and you usually only see eight at most on elite difficulty?


So overall, I do recommend this game for anyone that enjoys a first person shooter that each run is different on. I know some people are saying it is a mix of Borderlands and Risk of Rain, but the similarity to Borderlands is only in the RNG of the weapon rolls. This is very much a roguelite game: Run in shooting, get new weapons, unlock in-run upgrades for your character, obtain scrolls, and progress until you drop; then? You spend points on talents to permanently improve yourself going forward, making each run a little stronger.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
First of all, I'm reviewing this product while in early access. There are some bugs, a lot of content is still missing, and the translations to English are bad.

But forget about all that. This game is exceptional if you like rogue-likes. It's fast paced, suitably challenging, and addicting as heck. It works well co-op or solo, and is quite affordable.

You play as one of two characters, and each time you play, you start at the beginning. Throughout the game you find scrolls that buff your skills, and chests that allow you to select randomly determined, and character specific, buffs. You will also find weapons with increasingly higher statistics throughout the run. When you die, your progress is reset. However, unlike other rogue-likes, there is an element of progression through a skill tree that persists between runs.

At the time of this review, there are three acts and two difficulty levels. There are a ton of different weapons, and an even greater ton of scrolls. Even though its missing a lot of content, if you like rogue-likes, you will get your money's worth.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: This game is extremely fun. Most rogue-lites are very hit or miss with the actual rogue-lite mechanics in my opinion. I feel like this game has nailed it. Progression never feels stale or stagnant. The talents that you can upgrade in between runs all feel needed, leading to the "just one more run" mentality just so I can get an extra 5% copper my next time through. Some of the talents undoubtedly feel better than others, but they all feel useful. The gun play in this game is phenomenal. All of the guns are a joy to use. Some definitely take more getting used to than others, but once you learn on a particular gun works, it is nothing but satisfying to use. Almost all of the guns feel useful too. Multiple times I unlocked a gun thinking it was garbage, only to realize I underestimated it, or some particular roles made it extremely powerful. This game is especially fun with friends, though the game does seem significantly more difficult in multiplayer. This is not an issue though, as long as the people you're playing with have a brain. The only things I would say are lacking in this game are the multiplayer and movement. There are some REALLY bad issues in the multiplayer that can lead from slight lag, to everyone in the game freezing, then resuming completely dead. While the issues don't happen too too often, they are very frequent and often ruin runs. The movement also seems a bit buggy. You will often get stuck on things you never noticed because of odd hit boxes. In some of the parkour vaults, certain platforms have arrows sticking out of them, that while seemingly insignificant, have a small hit box. These unknown small hit boxes often lead to feet clipping and failed jumps, something that can become very, very annoying, especially when the parkour vaults are timed. The platforming is even worse in multiplayer, where tiny, normally inconsequential, amounts of rubberbanding is VERY frequent. This is normally not an issue, but can sometimes make some of the jumps feel impossible. Both of these downsides are not really that bad in the long run, and a fix more multiplayer has already been said to be on the way. This game is infectiously enjoyable and nothing but a blast to play. As such a smash hit, less than a week after release in my opinion, I cannot wait to see where this game goes. I highly recommend.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
If you like roguelites this has potential, but if you enjoy Doom or Borderlands this is with no doubt a game you should give a try. Gunfire is all about random rolls on guns building a characters power along side acquiring scrolls and other powerups along the ride.
As of now the game has surprisingly a lot to offer you might think 3 stages and 2 characters ain't that much but the game just feels so good to play and was it not for exams I would have played a lot more that the 31 hours.

If you want to fully complete the game from a newbe state to 100% completion I estimate around 45-50 hours maybe a couple of extra hours to have all the Steam Achievements. If you know what you are doing and know what to go for progression wise 30-40 hours which is very very nice for 10 euro (11 or so dollars but I bought the game with an 11% discount).
Even after 100% you will still want to play the game as the combat and overall feel of the game is very enjoyable and you can expect more content to come as this is only early access.
I am personally very excited for the games future!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Its more of a Shadow Warrior 2 with the side of Dead Cells, sprinkled some Risk of Rain 2 and spiced up with Borderlands.

- nice variety of guns
- great variety of skills and perks
- plentiful of enemies and stages
- two characters to play, but I guess more on way
- it is grind to win, but at least rewards are satisfying

Tho since its early access, some problems are glaring:
- enemies with homing attacks (with all thats going on - you cant keep track of whoever is homing in on you)
- boss and elites balancing issues (timings too short, absolutely unavoidable damage due to movement mechanics)
- characters are too slow
- matchmaking is somewhat slow
- many weapons are just meh

Note, that game is chinese (?) - so translations are weird, and sometimes not quite clear what they mean.

For such a low price, game is amazingly fun, and I guess all the problems will be fixed during early access.
8/10, for now.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: Pretty well made game. Obviously still has a few things to work out (mostly the 4-player game mode, didn't run too well compared to 2-player) but it's a lot of fun. Took about 40 or so hours to unlock most things. Some weapons seem bad early on but eventually most weapons can be pretty powerful, depending on play style. title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
A surprisingly enjoyable FPS game with decently fleshed-out roguelite elements to boot. It's still a bit rough around the edges, however it is still in early access and there should hopefully be a lot of polish and content being made with each update.

[h1]What I liked:[/h1]
The gunplay feels pretty good, each gun feels distinct and there is already a large variety of weapons to use. You have your standard weapons like your assault rifle, your SMG, your pistol, etc, but there are also pretty novel weapons as well such as the Thunderglove (a glove you wear that shoots a beam that hits all nearby enemies) and the Bone Cannon (basically Zarya's cannon from Overwatch, it sucks in all nearby enemies and detonates after a few seconds). Each weapon is well animated and they're all worth using, even the starting pistol which actually scales with your other weapons so that it's still relevant throughout a run.

Next, I really think that the progression of the game is pretty well done. You have both run-related progression (such as weapon damage, scrolls which give unique modifiers to the player, etc) as well as permanent progression (such as increased health, ammo capacity, etc), and you always feel like there's something to strive towards as a result. Some of the aforementioned scrolls can really change the way you play, such as one that gives you two additional dash charges or one where headshots do 4x damage but at the cost of lower non-headshot damage, and it's fun to see what combination of modifiers you can get.

The two characters as of writing are quite fun to play as. You start with a hat-donning cat who can throw smoke grenades and has an AoE stun, which makes him pretty strong at dealing element damage and taking out large groups of enemies. Once you hit level 30, you then unlock the second character which is the dog - my personal favourite! He can dual-wield his weapons and can spec into being tanky while doing so, making him pretty solid for melting single targets with his unmatched DPS. There are more characters coming, so I'm hoping they are just as fun to play as the existing ones.

Finally, the aesthetic of the game is decently charming in my opinion. Yes, the graphics are pretty simple and the characters are a bit generic, but I do like the colourful environments and enemy design. But I think most importantly the game runs really well due to the lack of graphical fidelity which is always important for shooter games.

[h1]What I was meh about:[/h1]
If you've ever played Borderlands, you'll be aware of the different elements that each weapon can have which give additional damage towards certain types of enemies. This is pretty much the case for this game as well and it works identically: fire is strong against flesh (red health), corrosion works best against armour (yellow health), and shock makes short work of shields (blue health). That being said, I was never really a fan of this type of design to begin with as it means that not having a weapon of the required element just means that you'll take way longer to kill those enemies and you can unfortunately only hold two weapons at a time, so you'll be missing out on at least one element for your guns. This also trivialises weapons with no element as it's just too effective to combo elements due to the bonuses you get from doing so, which is where you can dish out lots of damage.

As for the level design, it's decent enough but it never really shakes things up. You start in the same zone and the level progression is pretty much identical throughout each run. Additionally, some of the portal areas you can access are a bit annoying as there are platforming sections in them that don't feel that great.

[h1]What I disliked:[/h1]
I only have one real aspect that I disliked about the game, but unfortunately it's probably the biggest drawback for me which is the online co-op. I feel that this game would be even more fun with friends or even just randoms as there is matchmaking, but in its current state it's simply too laggy and seemingly has client-side lag that occurs whenever enemies spawn, which has lead to a lot of cheap deaths as I wait several seconds for the game to update. Definitely the biggest area for improvement, but it's understandable given that this isn't a high-budget title.

[h1]Overall...[/h1]
For an early access title, this is already worth the price of admission and I've had quite a bit of fun with it. I definitely recommend giving it a go if you're looking for a new shooter to play or at least keeping an eye on it as it receives updates.

[b]Edit:[/b] OK, the devs have responded to this review and I think I should offer some more clarity regarding the online co-op of the game. As I was going off of matchmade games, the lag issues may just be on my end as I have yet to verify if they're because I am connecting to far-away hosts or just hosts with poor Internet. The game seems to use peer-to-peer networking so it could purely be a host issue and not an issue with the game itself.
developer_response: We are aware of this issue and continue to optimize it, please give us more time. You can play with your friends in the same region first.Thanks for playing our game and providing feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
[h1]Early access games be early access yo. spoilers are spoilers, sorry.[/h1]
I seriously mean the spoiler warning is a spoiler.

Multiplayer for whatever reason works as intended with some of your nearby friends... but for the other friends that are just as close to you geographically it doesn't work, when the host starts shooting you start lagging no matter who's hosting the other players suffer. [i](friend and I are in the same state, at most 5 hours drive away and we can't play together, its unplayable. while I can play with my other friends perfectly fine who are even further away and he has experienced the same issue with his friends.)[/i]

The game play loop is linear but still very bare bones, [spoiler]having only 3 unique stages and 3 unique bosses is fine. but I really hope more get added or we get to see a looping system similar to risk of rain/risk of rian 2.[/spoiler]

The gun play is fun, except for the times you don't get the "good" guns. Some guns are seriously underpowered and there for overlooked. After getting the hang of the game I've started just mentally blocking guns I've thought to be trash. Balancing is definitely needed, not just buffing weapons but also nerfing weapons.

The game is good, its not quiet there yet though. If you want a fun single player game that you can quickly bang out in like 20 hours this game is great, but I don't feel its met its standard of "multiplayer" or "co-op"
developer_response: Hi, we are working on this issue. You can play with your friends in the same region first. Thanks for playing our game and providing feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I started playing this game for a bit and really enjoyed it. Weapons are fairly balanced and game-play is pretty fun. The enemies are pretty difficult but not in an overpowered way, but more in a mechanic based way which encourages you to dodge and learn their attacks to survive. The bosses are pretty difficult in the fact that if you don't have good weapons or scrolls, then you will be in for the longest dodge battle ever. The 2 playable characters are really interesting. I have not gotten to level 30 so I cant use the dog, however you start out with the cat. I thought that the cat was pretty cool so I decided to buy a purple glass tesla ball and a pistol. I soaked the pistol in gasoline and lit it on fire to make it look like scorching rounds. I gave these items to my cat (I don't have a dog) and was hoping to see Freddy Meowcury shoot the pistol and throw the ball like he does in the game. Instead what heppened was the gun discharged a bullet (probably from being too hot but thats just my guess) and ended up ricocheting off the cement floor of my house and hitting a bystander outside my window. I grabbed the gun away from Freddy and ran outside to help the poor girl who was shot and she was out cold. I grabbed and put her in my van to take her to the hospital. As she bled out in the back of my van, I rushed down the highway to get some help. I live pretty far away from an ER so I was doing about 116 MPH down the road. Suddenly there were flashing red and blue lights behind me telling me to pull over. I couldn't risk any more time so I stuck my hand out the window to try and let them know that something was wrong. A bullet flew through the back window of my van and struck the radio. I forgot that I still had the gun in my left hand so I dropped it and tried to fix the radio, but to no avail. After only a few minutes there were at least a dozen cop cars and two choppers flying overhead with their lights flashing down on me. right as I got to the hospital, a cop pit-maneuvered me and I did at least 6 full barrel rolls into a ditch. The girl flew forward and cut her throat on a piece of glass, which sucks, but I decided to not worry about it and let the officers take care of it. I got out my trusty bowieknife and cut my seat belt away. A cop yelled to me "DON'T MOVE!" and tased me. The next week I was in court and was charged with kidnapping, first degree murder, sexual assault, speeding, reckless driving, and resisting arrest. Apparently an old man called the cops and told them that I shot and kidnapped some girl on the streets. I'm not too sure when that was, but it sucks I wasn't able to save that girl. 

Anyways 10/10 for an early access game and I hope the devs continue their great work.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: This is the perfect gameplay balance that large studios need to adapt. At it's core it's a mix of Risk of Rain's concept of repetitive runs and randomized upgrades combined with only the good parts of Borderlands, along with a roguelike leveling up component that goes across all runs making you feel that each time you go through you're a bit stronger. Though this game is about repeating levels and grinding it NEVER feels like it EVER. For having only 3 levels and 2 difficulty settings currently this game has brought more hours of enjoyment than most $60 titles. This game feels like a steal as the content feels like you would pay at least $40 for it. I can't wait to see what becomes of this when it gets out of early access.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
A charming and addictive, if a bit unpolished, roguelite FPS. Pretty standard roguelite core gameplay loop - each zone has a few floors full of regular enemies and a boss, you keep going till you die and earn points to unlock persistent upgrades based on how far you make it. You'll unlock various buffs as you go, and guns can have a wide range of effects, so each run you'll wind up with a different 'build' as you try to stack synergistic buffs and weapon mods. 

Some areas of the game are a bit rough around the edges. The second class with its dual wielding ability is a cool idea, but it feels kinda awkward to play. Some enemies telegraph better than others, and the numeric balance feels off in places. The peer-to-peer multiplayer has pretty severe lag/desync issues at the moment, which is rather unfortunate as co-op is a blast when it works. Hopefully some of these issues get ironed out as the game gets further along in early access. 

At $12 I think it's an easy recommendation. In its current state you can easily get your money's worth just playing solo, and if you're patient there's a lot of fun to be had with co-op when it actually works.

One thing to note: you can play with friends right away, but to play with randoms you have to reach level 10 (which will take a couple hours or so). So if you don't have a friend to play with, expect to start out solo for your first play session or two.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This is hands down the best early access game I've ever played. It's pretty much Overwatch + Borderlands + Roguelike elements (think Slay The Spire, Risk Of Rain, Binding Of Isaac, etc). It's got really good and satisfying gunplay, neat upgrade mechanics and solid progression, including a skill tree that you can put points in even if you fail your run, so you can always work towards something even if you fail. 

The only "bad" thing about the game is the lack of content right now, but it's highly replayable (and it just came out in Early Access.... and it's an indie game) but they're probably gonna add way more content down the line. Highly recommended if you like roguelikes or just want a game with solid gunplay and interesting guns.
