I'm always a bit skeptical when it comes to Early Access games but after trying out this game I'm glad to say that this is one of the cases where Early Access is done RIGHT! This game just released and there's already a competent game here. It really well optimized, running at a stable 60 fps on high settings. The gameplay is solid and things look really polished. The translation is far from perfect but you can still understand what the game tries to tell you (It's miles ahead of what triple-A games had in the 90s). Also this is an indie game made by a team from Hong Kong so it's completely understandable.

For a low price of ‚Ç¨9.99 I highly recommend this game. NOTE: I haven't tried out the multiplayer yet.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Well worth the price tag, plenty of fun.

Like everyone says it's kind of a mix of Risk of Rain and Borderlands but I don't think people put enough of a point on how good the abilities are. Both characters have three different types of builds, 6 builds total, and these builds have sub builds. For the first character you can either use your ability to freeze large mobs of enemies for a good chunk of time while you land some free critical shots or you can lose the freeze ability and start making it do even more damage. If you're playing with friends you can even turn your grenades into the perfect support action by making enemies take more damage and deal less on top of doing good DoT damage if you take elemental scrolls. That's three full fun builds that can easily last you until the second character, or if you prefer the first one for the rest of the game. The second character is my personal favorite and you can either go full gunzerker, explosives, or crit build. While *technically* you could go full crit with the mage I personally feel the gunfighter does it better because of his perks like Substained Fire and a few more.

TL:DR - With a minimum of 6 pure builds and 12 sub builds, 34 guns, 104 scrolls, and the class abilities it's really just up to you how long you want to play this game but it is EASILY worth the price tag and will provide you with hours and hours of fun with either singleplayer or with friends.

Disclaimer: Yes it's EARLY ACCESS people so things are not going to be perfect. You will find enemies that are far harder to deal with than all the other types put together, you will find a few bugs here or there and maybe some translation issues but in all my hours I have yet to find any major bugs.

I especially like the option of spending that run's upgrade points for a revive, sometimes it's a very tough choice. For the price, give it a go! I'm not a huge fan of early access but the game mechanics are polished and it looks great! I just hope they add more heroes in the future (not that I've even mastered the first!). Solid title.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
TL;DR : feels like a full non-early-access game with plenty to do and high polish (except the translation is a bit wonky), a great roguelite where you often feel you got stuff that shouldn't be this overpowered, but its challenging enough to still kill you, especially on elite difficulty
-
This does not feel like a game thats just come into early access at all. even with the only 3 levels, its still so fleshed out and polished that you could be mistaken for a released game. Running through the 3 5-stage levels also feels like an appropriate length for a roguelite. we'll just needs some more for variation.

this is basically deadcells progression with immortal redneck gameplay, and theres so many cool items that every run has something and when you get your favorite guns perks and skills and get some "shops" that let you upgrade some modifiers on your guns to your liking, man you feel like a god.

the gameplay is absolutely fantastic, really hits the nail on its head, gunplay feels fast and solid, and you really feel the gun upgrades and perks work when you get them. 

the graphics are low poly style, and it works well and the guns look and feel great and wildly varied in design and purpose.

combine that with plenty of permanent character upgrades and new weapons to unlock, and 4 player coop, and an elite difficulty that you get after completion, which adds traps and harder enemies throughout the game, and its early access and already this polished and full of content, this is going to be a great game once it sees its full release. But already 100% worth its money and fun to play

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
45 Enemy variants (between normal, elite, boss)

3 Biome Zones (1 major boss per)

106 Scrolls (passive abilities)

34 Weapons (across 7 types)

4 Talent Trees (cross-match progression perks)

2 Playable Characters (each are very unique)

Now add AAA quality visuals, animations, and gunplay.

What we have here is a VERY well polished and priced EA game, that's arguably worthy of being sold as a complete game in it's current state.

Assuming they add more content like zones and characters in the future, we are looking at a game that could easily surpass Risk of Rain 2 in popularity.

If it looks like something you'd enjoy, then I'd highly suggest picking it up and giving it a try.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I want to clear a few things up for people who are interested in buying this. Many reviews are comparing this to Borderlands and Risk of Rain. First off this is nothing like Borderlands at all. Borderlands is a loot-shooter with RPG elements and this game is a rogue-like FPS where death means it's back to main screen. It's more like Risk of Rain but it also isn't.

Gunfire Reborn is an obvious work in progress, it looks nice, it runs smoothly, has a lot of variety of weapons and upgrades to use throughout your runs, a talent tree to upgrade base stats and passive perks but the balance is what stands out most. You have to beat stages to reach the boss room and these stages are fairly easy which gives you a false sense of confidence about facing the boss because he can 1 or 2 shot you to death because he moves so quickly and strings combos to punish you while self-destructing mobs run all over the place during each phase. I attempted to beat the boss at least 8 times between levels 1-15 and I just couldn't get a perfect combination of weapons/passives in the dungeon that would increase my run speed and dashing ability. It was only when I partied with a group (4 including myself) of level 15-20's and we were still getting 1-2 hit by the boss constantly throughout the battle. Finally we beat the boss and move on to the beginning of the Desert zone only for the 4 of us to get completely wrecked in 30 seconds by a group of 10 or so enemies in the first area of the first stage. I enjoy a challenge and I generally enjoy grinding but the balance doesn't feel quite right, it's blatantly obvious it is the biggest problem with this game and I hope they  intent on working on it some more. All of this was done on "Normal" mode, I can't even imagine how hard it's going to be when I eventually unlock the next difficulty.

Edit: So I finally played a second time. This time I played for 5 straight hours and made a new friend and we did quite well. We were both level 20ish when we started and finished around 36 or so. We can consistently destroy the entire first zone and boss easily now with the exception of a couple of horrible runs where none of our preferred weapons are dropping and the scrolls are utter trash, but we can't beat Stage 3 of the Desert which is right before the boss. The game is still punishing us with maximum upgraded weapons, great scrolls and good teamwork. All 4 of us were communicating and sharing weapons, specialising in different elements and it just punishes us over and over and over. Yep..

TL;DR, 
+looks nice
+runs smoothly
+good variety of weapons/upgrades 
+talent tree that can be upgraded (passive bonuses to Heros and weapons)

-the game's difficulty doesn't scale well
-punishing difficulty curve

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Pros:
- permanent progression
- satisfying gunplay
- no consumables (most roguelikes have them and it always annoys me)
- quick rounds that don't require mental preparation before jumping in
- modifiers from pickups and weapon inscriptions that significantly change gameplay
- mechanical increase of difficulty instead of just inflationary enemy stats (both shouldn't be taken to extremes)

Cons:
- While enemies and loot are randomized, the rooms are only random in the sense that you don't know which one you will spawn into. The layout doesn't change and each biome has give or take 4 different rooms layouts. I would expect randomization of the layout as well, especially given how tiny the rooms are.
- There are some really cool weapons, but also a lot of boring ones that are weak at the same time which I feel could just be left out the game entirely. Looking at you, SMGs, autorifles and a sniper that deals less damage per shot than my starter gun, at 3x lower fire rate and an aiming wiggle no other weapon has.
- After each death you have to spend all the essences you collected immediately, but the cost of upgrades rises quickly. That means you'll often have a surplus of essences that you can't spend on anything, and that just always feels like you wasted a little bit of your time

Suggestions (on top of everything mentioned in Cons):
- Let us choose from 2-3 primary and secondary skills at the start. Of course this would mean additional work on many new pickup effects, but it would help a lot with mixing things up beyond of what's currently possible, in such a replay based game.
- Some scrolls give high rewards for high risk/penalty. Before picking up such a scroll, there should be a warning, like a very obvious red glow around the scroll. As even after a few hours you'll have picked up hundreds of scrolls and it becomes somewhat of an autopilot to press F. Nothing sucks more than going for a crit build and then accidentaly pick up a scroll that removes all crit multiplier.

I enjoy the game and for 10 bucks is totally fine. I imagine multiplayer being a ton of fun too. It's like a fast-paced version of Borderlands in small randomized areas with fast progression and no story or quests to distract you from gameplay.
7/10 in the current state.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Due to a developer response I shall elaborate the review:

Follow me on twitch - Twitch.tv/XtremeNugget

Original : It's okay but lacking content. also wish the levels were RNG


Edit : This review is in the first week of release into "EARLY ACCESS"

While the game is still in so early development it has a lot of potential to become a top game in the rouge-like section.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Graphics:

The art style of the game reminds me a lot of risk of rain 2 and in a good way, while it's in first person and the combat is a lot faster it fits well into the atmosphere of the world the game is building. Graphics 8.5/10
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Gameplay:

The gameplay while it is like any other rogue-lite/like games has it's unique style of delivering a system of RPG-lite with character skill building and personalizing a style of your own. 
While so early in the release the game doesn't have that much variety in guns from the start and you are quick to recognize what guns are the best for what enemy and you stick to it.

Start level/boss fights are in the same rhythm. It's always the same boss, always with the same moves and always in the same order.

I do wish more guns would be added and more RNG to the enemies/levels with a lot more variety of moves in the box. Gameplay 7/10

----------------------------------------------------------------------

Multiplayer/Co-op:

While multiplayer has it's golden moments of playing either with friends or random people in the matchmaking system the system itself has some major unplayable flaws in it.

Loot is personal while can be shared after you drop it, the same goes for money and rewards. 

The game has a lot of connection problems and lags while only in specific rooms (that i've noticed) and it spikes up at random but I am not sure what may cause this issue in the long run. Multiplayer/Co-op 8/10


OVERALL SCORE: 8/10 for Gunfire Reborn


I hope this game will grow fast and the developers will improve all aspects but stick to the unique style of their game.  For now the review is negative but will swap to positive after the next update
developer_response: Thanks for your feedback, current system is not perfect enough and we will optimize it, please give us more time.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Very good base mechanics - movement is responsive, gunplay feels great. Decent weapon variety improved by a massive amount of available inscriptions (additional effects applied to guns like conditional rate of fire bonuses, crit bonuses, big boosts that come with drawbacks etc.). Satisfying - for the time being - number of passive items a.k.a. occult scrolls.

As of right now GR seems to have a problem with the existence of some very powerful synergies between gun inscriptions and occult scrolls (like stacking luck or additional projectiles until cap because you never reload), as well as a few character skills and ascensions (most notably dog's invincibility on taking 25% hp of damage), which means that it is quite simple and consistent to become busted by the time you get to the final stages of the game. Admittedly that does not mean you cannot die - like in Isaac or Gungeon -, because here you usually are a glass cannon. These interactions IMO should still be inspected by the devs, with a couple getting the nerfhammer preferably.

I believe that if the low difficulty issues are fixed and if devs add more content like stages, bosses and rank-and-file enemies this game could have some major staying power and become one of the top roguelites.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
7/10 pretty fun fps roguelite for solo.

The game is pretty fun and challenging solo for the most part. I still have some issues with it but if you're only getting it for solo it's decent. If you are getting it for multiplayer I'd recommend getting something else. As of right now there isn't any kind of communication in multiplayer text, voice, or pings. If you plan on playing co-op with friends then this isn't an issue but there are still some issues.

In solo it has different problems. The first handful of attempts will likely be short because of the initial difficulty. As you earn more souls to upgrade your stats you'll get farther and farther. The optional side areas (vaults) are not so optional as you'll want every possible opportunity to get scrolls/weapons/ascensions to give yourself a better chance. Some of the vaults are timed puzzle platforming sections. These are mostly fine in single player but the geometry on some of them is pretty janky and needs some tweaking. The movement also isn't the most precise for these either.

In multiplayer the issues with this are just made worse. Now you may have lag and/or rubberbanding in these and they can become nearly impossible to complete within the time limit. The number of enemies increases as well as their health and damage. Which would be fine except many of the areas are hallways and with four people and the increased number of enemies it may be hard to see what you're shooting at or what's shooting at you. There will be times in which you get seemingly one-shot by an enemy because you couldn't see the attack, the damage, or anything at all. Thankfully your teammates can revive you but if they don't revive you in time then you're out until they beat the next boss fight assuming they can make it to it and beat it without you. And then you'll be behind in scrolls, souls, gold, and potentially weapons so you're probably not going to be much of a help after that.

There's not very much content in the game as of right now. Two difficulties. A decent chunk of weapons and scrolls but only two characters, three zones and their respective bosses. The occasional optional vault breaks up the gameplay with the platforming sections but that's it. There aren't many events worth noting outside of normal gameplay. Not much in the way of replay value once you beat the game. For the current pricetag of $12 this might be worth it but I don't recommend it for multiplayer, solo maybe, but the small amount of content that you'll be repeating over and over will get stale fairly quick.
developer_response:
Hi, we are trying our best to fix the lag in matching, and you can play with your friends in the same region first.
Sorry for the bad experience in jumping level, we have now made some adjustments. We optimize the normal route as well as the hard route, and we will continue the optimization of "jumping level". Please have a try again. Thanks for your feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
It is, as everyone else already said, the right combination of Borderlands with Risk of Rain 2.

The gunplay is smooth and the controls are pretty responsive, weapons and skills really have that satisfying kick to them and you never feel like you are trying to hit the enemy with a napkin to kill them. Oh and variety of weapons and the random builds you can create around them are pretty great too. The two characters (with apparently more to come) are very different compared to each other and each are as effective as the other.

I do find the enemy types a bit samey at times (dude who rapid fires, dude who fires homing shots, dude who carries a shield and what not), except for those that are unique to their own stages but they are generally very unforgiving and fun to fight through anyway so it is not much of an issue. At the 28.9 hours mark I finally managed to finish the game in normal difficulty, and keeping me occupied for nearly 30 hours in a single week at this price point is something I am not going to argue with.

8/10 pretty damn good.

However, it has satisfying gunplay, good potential for builds with just enough RNG-based things to feel interesting, and the co-op scaling doesn't feel too easy or too spongy compared to solo. 

Absolutely worth the 13-ish dollars to pick this game up, especially considering it's future potential.

review:
The gunplay feels great, the enemies are varied and interesting, and the permanent and per-run progression are both really satisfying. There are a couple of issues I've run into, mainly with some of the platforming challenges feeling a bit clunky and with a lot of the weapons and passive items either being super overpowered or completely useless with little in between. That being said, this game's been in early access for like two weeks at the time of this review and even with the few issues I've run into, it's some of the most fun I've had for 12 dollars. 
If you enjoy shooters or roguelikes at all, this game is absolutely worth the current asking price. This game has a ton of potential and I really hope I won't have to eat my words when I say that I'm really excited to see what more the devs will do with this title.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
There are so many rougelites on the market now a days, but the good ones are few and far between.
When it comes to FPS rougelites the story gets even worse, only ones I can remember from the top of my mind is "Hypergun" and "Ziggurat" and now this sort of.

This game has a good foundation and lots of potential but buyer beware.
It only have 3 levels with 5 "floors" before you encounter the boss, metabucks / metaprogression is a thing(ofc) so a lot of grinding before you are able to progress towards higher difficulty or even reach the end boss, already a lot of useless / redundant passive buff items(think buff / stat tweak items from Isaac), weapon balancing is bad and some weapons are really boring, only 2 characters to play as, some platforming sections that feels more wonky then they ought to be and you seem kind of OP in MP (note I have only played with 2 players so might be harder with 3-4).

Despite all these issues I chose to thumb it up because it is just plain fun to play and I hope that the devs that already crated the foundation hopefully have a direction and know what they are doing. If not this is $/¬£ 10 for for quite a few hours of mindless fun.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
It's a fun little game, BUT is incredibly frustrating. 
1.) Weapons are locked behind challenges like Kill 20 of X enemy. Thats fine. But in a fully RNG game sometimes you just won't see a certain enemy type thats locking a really good weapon, like the Prism. The game kept spawning me Lightning Grenadiers instead of Poison Grenadiers.
2.) The starting upgrades like +shields/health are honestly worthless. They are helpful in dealing with enemies early on, but this brings me to my next point
3.) HOMING ATTACK ENEMIES. They literally take out all the fun in the game. You thought the Longbow Archers on stage 1 were bad??? I have every shield/health upgrade. Here comes Stage 2. Straw Hat Snipers. They spawn in like CRAZY, sometimes there are 5 at a time constantly shooting at you. AND THEY FUCKING HURT! Getting hit by 2/3 of these is basically a death sentence. Whenever I see these Snipers spawn in, I immediately run away, get into a spot where I can shoot them but they can't shoot me and kill them. I literally have not made it to the Stage 2 boss because of these fucking Snipers
4.) Dodge is AWFUL. it's a core mechanic of this game, the first boss has huge AOE moves that you HAVE to use the Dodge ability to get out of the way.... but it's on a 3 second cooldown, BARELY FUCKING MOVES YOU, and it feels like they slowed your character by 50% to make dodging necessary....but it just feels slow as shit moving between rooms because your character moves like he has a broken leg

If they fix some of these issues I will gladly change my review to positive. The game has a lot of potential, but it just is not there yet. Hopefully they can fix everything since it's early access
developer_response: Hi, we are aware of the difficulty and plan to make some adjustment in our future update.Current system is not perfect enough and we will optimize it, please give us more time.Thanks for playing our game and providing feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Borderlands + Risk of Rain is the most accurate description I've seen

Cons: [list] 
[*]The translation from Chinese to English is incredibly rough sometimes
[*]Co-op has some occasional crazy lag spikes that can make you freeze in place for 30+ seconds just to find out you died
 [/list]
Pros: [list] 
[*]Overall pretty fun gameplay
[*]Pretty well polished for a game this early in development
[*]Plenty of variety in which we can only hope for more in future updates (Only 2 heroes so far etc.)
[*]Huge replayability, which is the most important part of a roguelike, similar to Risk Of Rain, has all sorts of modifiers and gun build possibilities to get you working for that "God Build/God Run"
[*]Graphics are pretty simple yet appealing, I find them similar to Deep Rock Galactic, and the game is only 1.8GB because of this!
[/list]
If the game gets frequent updates and the devs do a good job going forward, this will definitely be an amazing game.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is a gem! One of the best values one Steam for under $20!

It's an FPS rogue-lite (it has run to run progression systems, but you still start over on death). It takes clear inspirations from games like Borderlands, and other games in the rogue genre such as Enter the Gungeon, Slay the Spire, or Risk of Rain. It has surprisingly really solid shooting mechanics. It has fantastic RPG-like elements that starts with a really satisfying character progression tree. Run after run, I keep coming back to get those extra stats. Those elements extend to builds within runs as well, as gun stats have dynamic modifiers that could turn a gun you aren't typically a fan of into a powerhouse with the right synergies.

The game has satisfying moment to moment gameplay, with good enemy diversity and level design. The weapon design is very interesting as well, with options ranging from a ninja kunai, hand-held dragon, or a laser glove. It even asks interesting choices of the player such as whether or not it's worth continuing a run you are crushing at the cost of long term gains in the progression tree.

It's few downfalls are that the beginnings of runs can get stale and repetitive if you don't get long runs often because there are only three stages and they don't change in order. It is always the same stage and enemies in the beginning. Changing which level comes first and adding 2 more that could get cycled in randomly on any given run for the sake of variety would go a long way. There are two different playable characters that successfully differentiate themselves, but there are only two for now. 

As the game adds more characters, bosses, and perhaps something to play for beyond the initial three levels, like some sort of looping mechanic, it will become increasingly rewarding and addictive. As it stands now, it's initial offerings are very polished and satisfying. Totally fun, especially with friends, and more than worth the price.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: Great game, feels like Risk of Rain mixed with Borderlands. Fun gameplay. Only complaint is that multiplayer scaling can feel a bit unfairly difficult until you learn to share weapons and scrolls correctly.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: Most often comparison is Borderlands and Risk of Rain 2. Those comparisons don't do the game justice. Borderland inspirations come in the form of elemental damage match ups. However, unlike the borderlands series, the shooting in this game is amazing. Every weapon has a particular weight and feel to it. Headshots grant instant gratification. Recoil has a perfect balance between being there and being annoying. Heavier weapons actually feel heavier and have pros and cons. There are no guns that feel bad to shoot. As for the risk of rain 2 comparison, I think it's because that's the only popular Rouge like that people have played cause it has very few similarities. I'd more compare it to Dead cells as weapons and upgrades are unlocked in a similar manner requiring you to kill a certain type of enemy a certain number of times. Also similar, there is a currency that you get at the end of a run that can be used to unlock minor upgrades. This is also similar to how gold persisted after a run for upgrades in rouge legacy. Overall a fantastic game in its current state. My only real complaint is I'd like to see more movement speed upgrades as currently characters feel a bit slow, especially in boos fights.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: All in all the game is pretty fun but it's severely held back by its leveling system, where your characters get stronger the more levels you put into them. This is in direct contrast with the spirit of roguelike games, where your character never actually gets stronger, you just get better at the game. In this, it doesn't really matter how much skill you develop, you're going to be stuck running the first few bosses over and over to earn the souls needed to buy upgrades actually be able to get further into the game. This is going to need to be changed if they want this game to be successful when marketing it as a roguelike. Unlocking new weapons and scrolls is fine, gaining raw stats is not.
developer_response: Hi, thanks for your helpful suggestion, we will think about what adjustment to make and try our best to meet your expectation!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
A great time, especially with friends. Netcode is solid and matchmaking is a breeze. This game came out well done and it's only going to get better. Controls and shooting are super tight and all of the weapons feel fantastic to use. Abilities and scrolls can make for some crazy combinations, especially the further you progress. Never ending mags, setting enemies on fire heals you, etc. Its an absolute blast, especially because you can make scroll builds that synergize with others in your group.

Could use some better translations and maybe letting players respawn at the end of each stage rather than after a boss. The game is incredibly difficult and enemy health (including bosses) scales based on how many players you have. But if someone leaves or dies, it doesn't scale back down so it can end a run very quick, especially right before a boss stage. Going in to a boss room with 1 or 2 people when its scaled for 4 can be a nightmare. Plus its no fun to die early in a level set and then be stuck watching everyone else.

I would recommend this to everyone. For $12, this is a steal and will keep you entertained for hours and hours, even more if you get a group of buddies to go in with, but its still plenty fun on a solo run. Each run makes your character stronger and can potentially unlock new guns/scrolls for the next one, so feel free to grind levels when your buddies are away.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
The game is "ok" but don't get sucked in all the hype from reviewers, streamers, youtubers and whatnot who post titles like "THIS GAME IS GREAT OMG FOR ONLY 9 BUCKS" and shit like that for their sweet sponsorships/views money.

The game is ok, 9 euros ok, you're not getting any more value than that out of it right now, in fact it's probably not even worth that much. 

The shooting is ok, nothing amazing, nothing atrocious.
The vast majority of weapons is trash so you probably will just end up using the 3-4 everyone uses.
The movement is, again, ok, although jumping and platforming feels awkward and considering that some vaults/rooms require you to do some platforming (which is something NOBODY wants/expects in this type of game and it ends up feeling out of place/breaking the gameplay rythm) makes it an issue. They should remove all the little platforming there is altogether and be done with it.
The levels feel the same and the little randomization they have might as well not be there because it really doesn't matter. Also, some rooms feel too big, others not big enough.
The mechanics to regain health are a bit shit and a lot of stuff is just gonna flat out 1-2 hit you even on normal so there's a lot to be looked at there from the dev side.
The two classes don't really feel distinct enough, it's no ror2 in regards to classes so don't expect that, and if any other they add is gonna follow the same lines they won't be different either.

This game has some potential but a lot needs to be changed/added/fixed. The way it is currently, you'll probably play it 1 to few hours and never touch it again until some patch comes out, or at all.

It doesn't deserve a "negative" review in the harsh sense of the term, but people are blowing how good this is WAY out of proportions. It's not bad, but don't believe them. Also, the devs seem to read/respond to negative reviews so.. might as well.
developer_response: Sorry for the bad experience in jumping level, we have now made some adjustments. We optimize the normal route as well as the hard route, and we will continue the optimization of "jumping level". Please have a try again. Thanks for your feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
6/7/20 - Early Access so still a lot of potential for a great game. There's fun to be had and it's an inexpensive game. So I recommend it even though this review is of the things I didn't like.

The aiming feels a bit "off;" it doesn't feel tight like shooters or even Risk of Rain does.

Dashing as the cat doesn't feel quick, far, or exciting.  It's early access so maybe they update it, but they need some more intense WHOOSH feeling as if you've just made a narrow escape.

The game seems to be always online (can be played offline) or at least has issues with player positioning or actions used. Example, if an enemy is rushing and you use the chains on them. Unless you've hit them within the 1st sec of the animation, the game still says they got off the attack even if they're frozen.

I've experienced in the first boss, if he sends you flying (this my be true for any instance of being sent flying) the game will teleport you back to the position you got hit from. Ultimately, setting you up to take additional damage.

Surely has the bones of a good rougelite, just needs some QoL updates and more content.
developer_response: Hi, thanks for your helpful suggestion, we will think about what adjustment to make and try our best to meet your expectation!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: A great blend of Roguelite and FPS mechanics. The level design is simple, yet effective in not confusing the player which is a difficult feat to achieve in a first-person roguelite. I only wish there was more verticality and that some of the bosses attacks were marginally easier to avoid. Right now, even if you are able to effectively steamroll the enemies before each boss, the bosses seem well overtuned and can be overly punishing killing you in 2-3 hits easily.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: I just passed the return window.  I'm playing it, but I'm mildly disappointed.  It might be worth $12, but it isn't currently worth my free time. Maybe eventually, but right now it needs a lot of work. The dodge mechanic and the reliance on it is a big turn off, probably because it feels like the main character was handicapped in terms of movement speed and jumping to make the dodge more useful.  The first boss has attacks that can't be avoided without dodging, but can attack more frequently than you can dodge. This makes certain random pickups almost necessary. Also if you are going to make jumping weak, don't put platforming puzzles in your game.  Also the game feels like it was made for multiplayer without any optimizations made for single player (the bosses are grindy).  I don't normally leave negative reviews for early access, but the Overwhelmingly positive reviews lead me to believe that this game was better or more complete.  Oh and progress gating is pretty bad too.  You need to spend accrued currency to buy skills, but a lot of the skills are '_______ appears in dungeon now'.
developer_response: Sorry for the bad experience in jumping level, we have now made some adjustments. We optimize the normal route as well as the hard route, and we will continue the optimization of "jumping level". Please have a try again. Thanks for your feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This is a stupidly fun game that makes me wonder why the developers haven't charged me more. It's an absolute steal at its current price, I've payed $60 for games that were only a fraction of as much fun as this was. You owe it to yourself to give it a shot if the concept of a FPS roguelite interests you.

I will say it's not perfect, but for an Early Access game, it only needs a few minor tweaks to be fantastic. The difficulty is a bit bullshit at times, the multiplayer could use some polish along with some of the game details... and it obviously could use more content. But as it stands, I guarantee you'll have a great time.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Hey!
I really love this game. I'm super exited for updates and showed this game all my friends. I recently found a bug/glitch in the game. I don't know how this happened, but I putted my Computer on save Energy mode (with GunFire Reborn opened) and came back a few hours later. After that, the enemies started spazzing around and teleporting around. The also shot wothout any delay and gone super wild. I hope you fix this.
I also think that the leveling system is not that well made. It would be better that you could save the Soul Essence or only a part of it (like 25% or 50%), because sometimes, you just can't make upgrades. I understand why they did this, so you will lose everything, because the game is very new. But please come up with a better idea.
Now to the game itself:
I like the way it can be played, as a fps that is roguelite. The weapons are mostly balanced, but sometimes they are very bad (eg. the Sniper, it takes much ammo, does literally 0 damage). Maybe the next idea from me is stupid, but what about a mode where you can play against each other, collect loot'n stuff? Sorry for my stupid idea, but this would make the game even better. The idea of battling exists because I like the way how you play this game. Battles with friends are not typical for roguelite games, but hey... Why don't try something new? :D
I hope you work on the game for more updates :D
Lynex

EDIT: I recently unlocked the ability to carry Soul Essence. I didn't know that this was possible.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Fun game at a great price.  
As you rack up kills on different enemies you automatically unlock new weapons and scrolls/artifacts, ensuring the game stays fresh with variety.  
When you die you can invest in a variety of talents, like more ammo/grenades, free advanced gun when starting, extra health/shield, increase chance of specialized weapon signature, etc.  Making the game quite addictive wanting to keep improving those stats and getting further along in the adventure with more advanced and varied weaponry.
On the downside, where I think the low price offsets any temporary negatives (game is in EA), the shooting doesn't feel as good as many other shooters.  Some of the controls and key mappings seem a bit rough (at least for k/m, I'm not going to play a shooter with a controller) but on the plus side they are remappable which I recommend you consider doing.  Also multiplayer matches, at least late at night, can be difficult to find, especially if impatient.  
I've only played solo so far and don't feel you have to play multiplayer to enjoy the game.  
There are several enemy types and once you beat a boss the next zone is completely different looking.  The bosses are a real challenge, something to work those talents toward.  Game does a great job of keeping things interesting.
developer_response: Hi, we have figured out your issue, and we will try our best to optimize our game. Thanks for playing our game and providing feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn is a very impressive and addicting Rogue-Like Dungeon Crawler with MAJOR flaws. In no way shape or form is this a bad game. I just can't recommend a game that has this many balancing issues. I understand this is made by a single dev and well, it shows. Reasons why this cannot be recommended:

1. The progression system is a bit "grindy." You need to upgrade your damage resistance, health, and shield by doing multiple playthroughs. This wouldn't be a problem but the Stage progression immediately has a huge difficulty spike after stage 1. You'll take crazy amounts of damage and can even get killed in 2-3 shots on Stage 3! Also, the currency you use to upgrade your stats do not carry over and stack with multiple playthroughs. So if you get 30 souls and use 25 and there's nothing for 5 souls, that's it! You just lose them and you end up back with 0 after starting a new run.

2. The weapons feel a bit under-powered. Not saying you should be shredding through enemies with ease but the weapons don't really pack a punch to them. The elemental effects don't really seem to do much except for corrosion.

3. Co-op is pretty much broken in the fact that if someone dies in your party the health of bosses do not go down. Even if they die at the first stage the boss will have stacked health which makes it near impossible to kill within a reasonable amount of time. Partners will not be revived until you beat the boss and move on to the next world which is a questionable choice. Yes, they can revive themselves once (sometimes 3 times with a certain item) and yes, you can revive them but you are given very little time to revive your partner.

4. The first boss is way too powerful. The boss can 2 shot you if you aren't paying attention even for a second. He has way too much health and he will spawn bomberheads that can nearly kill you and slow you to the point where it's just game over. This is a huge spike in difficulty and needs to be a bit easier for a first boss.

5. I know I had mentioned this before but there are certain normal enemies that can easily 2 shot you and that's a bit dumb in my opinion.

I could go on and on about what this game does right but I just feel the flaws need to be brought to light and hopefully worked on.
developer_response: Hi,most of issues you point out do exist.We are aware of the difficulty and plan to make some adjustment in our future update.Thanks for playing our game and providing feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
The game is fun and needs some cleaning up to really shine. 
- Friendly collision in Co-Op should simply be removed. No reason for that to exist. 
- Weapon reloading animations need to be either trimmed or changed to match the ACTUAL reload speed. When a weapon looks loaded, sounds loaded, and should be loaded it isn't loaded. Another answer to this would be a small 'Cast Bar' or some radial progression symbol in the crosshairs to show the weapon's reload speed visually. All we have right now is feel and the animations are misleading for some weapons. 
- Along with animations / general clunkyness is weapon swapping. Abilities can be cast quickly and are fun to use but after the ability there is a small window where you cannot swap weapons. Spamming the button just causes problems. 
- Either make the default weapon better or non-existent unless you're out of ammo. Another option is to just have the 'Use Last Weapon' keybind pull out the default weapon instead and remove it from the 'Mousewheel' weapon selection in the controls. No point in having a keybind to use a previous weapon when there are only three slots and one of them is reserved for the crappy starter gun. 
- The Sniper Rifle shots should be hitscan. Feels bad when you can watch the enemy sidestep headshots and flip around. 
- Stop making enemies that can remove themselves from the field of battle i.e. Blinking / Teleport or digging. It isn't too bad YET but the theme seems to be there and please for the love of all that is holy don't make more of those. All they do is waste a player's time, and with how dodge spammy enemies already are with your non-hitscan weapons it's not engaging. Nobody wants to hurry up and wait for an enemy to simply exist.
- Last but not least, text chat. Please.

review: This games handling of resolution is utterly broken. Nonstandard aspect ratios completely break the games ability to report and set resolution. Initial loading of the game forces 16:9 aspect ratio, subsequently restarting the game results it the vertical resolution being locked down to some number well below 1080 while stretching the horizontal resolution across the wider custom aspect ratio, the game will then decide to report this resolution as 4k 16:9. Complete crap programming.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This is the best roguelike of the year, and underpriced for what you get even with it being early access. If you're at all considering this game, go ahead and buy it while it's still this cheap.

Gunfire Reborn is an FPS roguelike with immense depth - there's always another challenge to take up, another build to try, and another unlock to push for. The gameplay is fun on its own, but the progression system is one of the two big draws that set this game apart - whenever you unlock an item or weapon, a copy of it instantly drops for you to try out. With expertly set pacing that keeps you unlocking something or leveling up every run until you have it all, every run for your first 50 hours is guaranteed to feel unique. 

The other big draw is just how much care went into making all of the little niche interactions satisfying. I've lost count of how many times I've run into some strange combination of scrolls and weapon mods, thought "man, it'd be so cool if these worked like this," and then found that they were actually coded to work just how I'd hoped. Plenty of the interactions in the game are designed to be awesome rather than balanced - you can get builds that make you functionally invincible or blow up bosses in seconds, and the game is so much fun because of it. It's clear that the developer really enjoys playing their own game, since they'd have to have gone back time and time again to make all of the little niche builds they've thought of work in the most fun ways possible. Gunfire Reborn is a labour of love, and it shows.

Just buy the game. You won't regret it.

review:
Roguelites..Rogues, whichever you prefer to call it..games with "runs" are something I have enjoyed quite a bit.
So I may be biased here.

I have played DeadCells, a metric cock ton of Slay the Spire,ROR,ROR2 and other forgettable rogue esq games.

Gunfire is awesome..truly..It is probably the only game within this genre where I genuinely am excited to see how they progress the game further.
The combat is fluid.
The guns are pretty cool for the most part, some are shit and need balancing tweaks (iron man gloves..)
The art is meh imo.
The sound is passable. Nothing spectacular about the audio, but its fine. it works.
The gameplay loop however...is fucking fun..and addicting. Slay the Spire levels of addicting.

Recommended. Ill change to a fat thumbs down if they add nothing and give minimal effort from here till release. as it stands though, the game is clearly not finished,but goddamn it this game is fun.

+ When you finally get thru a tougher section it feels like you actually accomplished something.  
+ You can submit any tech issues to the developers right through the game menus

-  NOTHING

BEST PART -  It's really fun, even at early access!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
[h1]Biggest surprise of 2020?[/h1]

Fun looter shooter with in depth rogue-like progression. It's early access - but one of the most polished EAs I have ever come across. Gunplay is slick, good amount of variety to combat

Even at this early stage, I highly recommend giving it a shot. It's a great price for what you are getting.

My number one gripe so far is the localisation. The game needs a lot of work in regards to translation. The English is pretty rough with typos and confusing item descriptions. 

Other feedback:

- Why is there no melee attack?
- Stages begin to feel a bit samey, need more variety in the levels
- Need some way to customise hero to make us feel unique
- Alternate bosses for each stage would be good - like Gungeon

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is fun. It's definitely early access though.

At it's core, the game is a ton of fun, but certain issues need to be addressed.

1. Why is it treating it like I'm online when I'm in a solo game? Give the option to play offline solo so I don't keep getting frustrating, run ending lag spikes.

2. Stolen assets. Like it's pretty inexcusable for some of them. Certain one's I've noticed: 

- The Dragon Bone is just Zarya's gun from Overwatch. Similar in design, function, and I'm pretty sure in animations.

- The sharks in the 3rd stage are legit just Roadhog from Overwatch as well. Same hook animation as well as far as I can tell.

- The flamethrower dragon legit uses the Skyrim fire breathing sound effect. That one is legit just ripped from the game.

3. A better spectate or option for when players die. If you are playing muliplayer and you die, you are going to be having to watch the back of someone's head for the next 5-20 minutes, depending on where on the full stage you died. A work around for this would be not allowing yourself to use Soul Essence to revive yourself in multiplayer, but you respawn when you enter a new level portal.

That's all I can think of for right now. The game itself is fun, and worth playing, but I fear for it's future if those issues aren't addressed.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I have to say right off the bat, I am NOT good with RPG's OR FPS' in the slightest but it was the animation and Oriental vibe that got my attention to this little gem.  Runs very smooth and it doesn't feel like you're being pressured to move on to the next area. You can go in guns blazing or you can just take your time with it. The bonus with this is that when you restart a level after failing, it randomly generates the area and paths so it doesn't feel copy/pasted giving you a challenge without feeling tedious and gives you the opportunity to try out all the various, and rather creative, weapons.

Only (personal) issue I have is I'd rather have a double tap to dash on the directional keys that have it as a separate button all together. Again, that's just a personal preference.

All that's left that I would really like to see is a soundtrack.

Overall, highly recommended. Looking forward to seeing how this progresses!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Well, 27 hours in, level 75+ and still finding new guns and scrolls. My personal take so far is that the game feels too easy when you get lucky ascension rolls, and brutally hard/unforgiving/impossible when you don't but that's the genre in a nutshell.

Laser gloves is incredibly OP and needs some balancing imo, i just finished the game on Elite mode with a laser glove that I upgraded to +5, then got a lucky drop of one. I also had an occult scroll that took ammo from your reserve instead of your magazine, so that coupled with the laser glove made it ridiculously strong. The combination of scrolls I got was insane.

OP Build:

Laser Glove
- Coin Shot
- Mid-Air Strike
- Penetration Bullet
- Advanced Depot
Fire Ascensions/Grenade Ascensions (specifically +300% damage and decrease enemy dmg -50% and increase +20% dmg taken.

Advanced depot with Laser glove and Penetration bullet alone are really strong since laser glove dmg increase the longer it is channelled and Penetration bullet ignores shield/armor with crits (laser glove can crit). Advanced depot turns your reserve ammo into your magazine, so I had a Laser glove that bypassed armor/shields with a 1k+ clip.

Incredibly op and fun, but literally made the third world a cake walk. I killed the final boss without even taking damage as it took me like 2 seconds to blow up the cannons.

10/10 will laser glove again.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: I never leave reviews, especially for an early access game, but this game is truly amazing. This game is almost a blend of Boarderlands and another game I have played called Risk of Rain 2 and it does it really well. The progression in this game is really well balanced and I can't help but continue to play the game, even into the early hours into the morning. If you are looking for a rogue-like dungeon crawler to play with friends too, then look no father.  Word of advice, however, playing co-op in this game does anything but make it easier. After playing about 4-5 hours of solo, and about 10 hours of co-op with between 1 and 2 other people, everything scales proportionally and it makes the game much harder, but it is also way more rewarding. While this game is early access, and the aspects of it that are early access are clearly early access, what is completed for this game is well done. I haven't found anything truly game breaking even when playing with my friends, which I expected to. I highly recommend this game, especially if you are looking for a game to dump a ton of hours into.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
It's the rogue-lite FPS we've all been waiting for, and it's only $12. For it being in beta, it's very awesome. Could it be better? Yes. Will it get better? Oh ya.

This is the casual shooter that I've been looking for to kill time and mindlessly grind without having to think too much about what's happening. But I can also really pay attention and go try-hard if I please. The game is as you make it. Would I like more content? Yes, but it's in beta and I'm not going to neg the game because the potential for this to be an all-time timeless great game is already there. 

This game is such a hidden gem that I hope it gets the notoriety that it deserves. Looking forward to seeing what the dev's do in the future.

I don't want to rate the game because I think it's unfair since it's still in beta. But for the cost of a beer and a shot with tip, this game will give you hours of time to kill. It's super fun and please, I beg you, support this game so we can see it's full potential. They deserve every cent they receive. And it's better than most $40-$60 games I've recently played.

review: So, this review comes from someone who has played almost 2 hours of the game thus far. I have just beat the first boss of the game after a long period of grinding. Now to fully express my feelings for this game, I have to lay the scene. I had just gotten home from being away for a week, I was exhausted but I heard about this game so I decided to buy it and try it before bed. I played the tutorial and my first round and instantly, I was hooked. In fact I was so hooked that I continued to play the game until that first boss was slain. This game is the absolute perfect mix of everything you love about fast-paced FPS games, grindy rpgs, and tedious rouguelites all mixed into one. This game kept me up well into the morning despite my exhaustion because it was just too good. The shooting, painful grind, amazing designs, and everything else all make this game an instant recommend for me. Seriously do yourself a huge favor and buy this game. (If you need some team members lmk)

review: considering the rating i think this is overhyped. it is a fun game, and well worth 12$.  only 3 hours in.   little frustrating in the fact shit doesnt carry over.   you could earn say 25 tokens, u buy a new perk for 15,  so you have 10 left over? well everything is 15 and up, so that 10 goes to waste.  you could go without grabbing the guns you need that round (they have random perks and effects) to kill a certain boss and well, you arent gonna kill him. you dont "get" gun like in borderlands per say, but the more you play you unlock more, and they are dropped by enemies randomly. so you could have a fav gun in the game and never use it really... you get 1-2 shot by bosses and the "dash" is more like one quick step. i fly through the 5 stages or so with ease (20 min) then get demolished by a boss cause of no perks or bad guns or w/e.  gonna do another review (updated) when i get some more hours..

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Great, on-its-way looter shooter, but a lot of polish needs to be put into this before it's released to the public. Started my playthrough on solo - you're stuck with an uninspiring dash and grenade skill set coupled with an enemy-rooting CC tool on a long delay, then sent into a randomly generated dungeon with little fanfare. Enemies have the upper hand as your skills have long flight times and large collision boxes while their projectiles easily calculate cover and overcome you by surprise as you expect the same rules to apply to them.

You can argue all day that this adds challenge and a learning curve, but a balance team needs to first pick between "looter shooter" and "tricky and unforgiving". At least front-load expectations for a game that punishes you for not having full mastery of your abilities out the door rather than comparing it to Borderlands where you're allowed "fight for your life" and not be expected to think three moves ahead.

Also, the boss I fought two-shot me. There was no real lead up to this, or explanation that he was much harder than other enemies until that point. That was a little unforgiving and frustrating as my run unceremoniously ended. Other roguelikes like Gungeon handle this quite a bit better because you at least get a chance to learn when one hit = part of your healthbar, not most of it.

I look forward to what this game might become, but cannot recommend it right now.
developer_response: Thanks for playing our game and providing helpful feedback. Current system is not perfect enough and we will optimize it, please give us more time.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Definitely fun and with all positives I should note the surprise negatives. While it looks like a game with gear and equipment rpg  you restart without any every time. You do keep gaining skills and some other stuff but everything dropped is not yours after 20-30 minute dungeony thing is over. 

Another big negative that caught me off guard that is caused by the resetting loot thing. Whether you win/lose is not skill but 10000% rng. Yup get a bad weapon or scrolls (like ability modifiers) and you lose get right ones and its easy.  Which is not consistent gameplay. 

As most people are not me I came for persistent rpg charateristics and do not like the reset every time thing so while game itself is fun smooth best I can rate it is 6 out of 10 (for under 20 dollar ea game). If not so much fun absolute zero due to misleading advertising tactics that I hate with games. As well as rng curve far exceeding normal player skill level. Would have refunded. 

And to be completely honest doubt I will play much more might get a few more matches this weekend but definitely more think it was a honest attempt at something decent that I didn't like.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
To start this review off id like to mention this is probably one of the better rogue like games I have played thus far.
The gameplay: As every game you play, when you first start off it's quite challenging. The more rounds you play the further you will get. There's tons of weapons that players can use that cater to their specific play style. And not to mention a passive progression system that allows the player to upgrade their character despite having lost the run. 

Concerns with guns: So far all guns are viable but to get a game winning run, it really depends on the affixes the guns have. I've had really easy runs whenever I got a heavy base damage weapon that rolls either corrosion or lightening and if it rolls with 65% elemental damage you're in the home run. Due to these stats being in the game, it feels like I NEED them to have a chance at the last boss. Having a gun with luck chance + element conversion + decay + elemental damage and if you can get the 200% increased headshot damage it's probably the best setup you could ever get (i've gotten it once with the gauntlet and holy shit that was OP 20k per tick). From what i've mentioned before and you obtain a little more experience, you will start to end your runs prematurely until you get a gun with decent base stats, or that's how I feel about it.

Game Concerns: There's heavy amount of lag when entering rooms (This only happens in later stages for me) . When I get to the last boss it's almost unplayable, not because of lag but because the AOE move he does with the cannons registers before the phase transition it over and fires before I can move my character. Despite that bug when I actually can move my character and get to the next stage, the same thing applies, the cannons will fire the explosives before I can react due to the stage swaps. In the final stage of the boss fight, there will follow more lag + stage delay  and the bosses cannon move wont register a circle and will just obliterate me. ( I could be fighting the boss wrong but I dont really know the issue). I still havent locked a full completion yet but I've gotten really close, Not because of technical skill more so to my op guns. Every boss feels great besides the last boss. 

Conclusion: I really enjoy this game, but knowing that there's only certain traits on guns that will give me a run with ease can get a bit tiresome. That, coupled with stage lag and buggy transitions on the last boss make playing this game feel like a chore to get a win. Otherwise I would say this is a really solid alpha build I rate this a solid 8/10 at the moment.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Really good for an early access game. The combat is fast paced and if you play in single player, the experience is seamless with how it connects pseudo-random rooms together. The only exception to this is when you advance a stage or enter a vault, but the loading times are near non-existent. 

In multiplayer, you could experience a bit of rubber banding when advancing in a room, but it doesn't really matter since opponents down spawn until you advance a bit more towards the room in which your PC will have had time to catch up.

Gameplay wise the huge selection of guns allows for lots of replayabiliyu and the tutorial system is really good. Although you'll experience a bit of information overload with the scrolls, ascension, weapons and many more, it's easy to catch up, since your main objective is survive while you point and click at everything else that moves.

Overall the game as lot of potential and even at this stage of the game, it is worth buying in my opinion. Highly recommended

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game has a lot of thought behind it. It's a simple game at first glance, but it is done very well. I highly recommend you pick up this game, especially with friends. It's a steal at its current price of $12!

PACING - Fluid, not too fast paced, or slow. Take the game as fast as you want too! No timers or anything.

GAMEPLAY - The weapons and aiming feel really solid with a diverse unique variety. It is really exciting to find new weapons or try and find combinations that work well.

LEVEL DESIGN - The level designs are well done, where positioning feels very crucial. Often times, I find myself in a pinch because of where I am standing in relation to my enemies.

AI - The enemy AI is really good! This is a tough game, and it's not due to the enemies having scaled up HP bars, it's because they have some synergies that work together and some basic AI that is done well. Grenade launchers + bowmen? The grenades will flush you out, and the bowmen will snipe you. It's fun!

EARLY ACCESS - This game is in early access but it feels like a polished game. Best early access game I've purchased.

FUTURE - I am really looking forward to when they add more characters. I also hope they add more customization talent trees for each hero, as the general talent tree between all heroes has three trees, but the individual heroes have 1. 

Also, a suggestion I thought of: you could add a second set of levels that have a different weapon pool if you want to keep adding weapons but not dilute the current pool. (expansion?)

TLDR; BUY this game. I am really excited to see where it goes, and I'm having a blast even though it is in early access.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
fun, challenging, satisfying.

pros
-gunplay feels good, some guns feel as good as destiny's guns to shoot.
-movement is decent
-challenging; there's a learning curve so you don't just steamroll the game
-pretty stable for an early access game
-varied enemies with distinct counters
-gameplay loop is pretty intuitive
-runs great even on budget hardware
-difficulty scales with player count, so game stays challenging, engaging, and requires coordination.

cons
-you don't get revived in multiplayer until after the boss fight, even if you died in an earlier stage. should be changed to revive all dead players at the end of a stage.
-still has some typos
-missing an exp bar
-shotguns need buffs, the only way to make them viable currently is to have very specific set of inscriptions on them as well as certain scrolls
-first boss fight is pretty basic, could be harder without being impossible.

absolutely worth the 12 bucks imo

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Originally I was drawn in by the artstyle, but looking into the progression, enemy variety as well as build variety this game has a lot to offer for a low price.

The foundation it's built upon is solid paired with satisfying gameplay - The elemental usage can draw comparisons to the Borderlands series but takes it a step further by creating new elements when combining them on a target (I.E creating Miasma/Explosive/Confusion).

Progression is much like Risk of Rain 2, you complete challenges etc to unlock new weapons and new items.

With what the developers said they have in store for the game, I'd say it's definitely worth picking up if you're even remotely interesting in the rogue lite genre.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Review for Single Player campaign. First, I'm no noob. Been hardcore gaming for 40+ years. Play most games on hardest difficulties. FPS Veteran. It's a fun game for the first little bit. I'm giving it a not recommended because it's in early development and needs a lot of tweaking. It's a fuc king grindfest. I'm not sure if this game is meant only for 12 year olds or anyone with no job, family, or prospects and can spend their entire life devoted to this game, but I'm not one of those. I don't have the time to put in 1000's of hrs just to get by the first boss. I have spent too many hours and the game is only getting harder (on the same level) as I level up. The level progression is sh it and doesn't work. The npc's are leveling faster than me. I'm level 16 and it's harder to get to the boss stage now. I don't want to play the same level over and over AND OVER again just to beat the first OP Boss. Add some more content!!! I got to the Boss most times. After grinding for days, I got my shields to 65 and my health to 90 (I think). Going in to the boss with the best set up I got (super lucky once) I managed to bring him from 80,000 hp to 58,000 ish. And I was on fire. 2 fuc king hits from the boss and you're done from full shields and hp. One hit for shields, one for dead. Seriously fuc king insane difficulty. As it stands I can't ever see beating the first level.
There first level has 5 "sections", including the Boss section at the end of the first level. The sections are "procedurally generated" within narrowly pre-defined parameters. Meaning that they change in minor ways. The first section is too easy, lulling you into a sense of false security. It's over quickly and section 2 is not much harder. Section 3 can be tough. Section 4 can be insane. The same enemies go from one hit kills to bullet sponges.
The worst part of the game is the bloody random everything! Random weapons, random power ups, random times. You can get to the "end" of level 1 with many power ups and weapons or little. You can wind up with one or two of the few decent weapons or complete sh it weapons. The difference in the weapons and power ups is HUGE. The right set up of power ups and weapons vs most shitty combos you're given is akin to how lame you are at the beginning of Skyrim  vs how powerful you are at the end. Not cool. Most of the time you're pathetically under powered in this game. 
There is only one character to play. The second has to be unlocked. The currency and system used to level up you character is sh it also. You get these tokens as you play, but I don't know what generates the tokens. They are probably randomly generated like everything else. After you die you can use the tokens to resurrect or not resurrect and get more tokens for leveling (I didn't know this for quite a while!). You get tokens  individually, which means you're always wasting some tokens. You buy improvements with tokens but everything is extremely expensive with increments of 10 and the improvements are pathetically under powered . Ex. lowest level improvement (1/5), increase hp by 5 hp, or shields by 5 or some other pathetic, useless "improvement" costs 10 tokens. So I made 9 tokens the first playthrough. Oh, I guess I'll save up for next time. The tokens DO NOT SAVE! You must use your tokens and any that aren't used are discarded. Fuc kyou! I'm at the point where I can't level up anymore. All the improvements cost 40+ tokens and the most I have made on any play through was 37 tokens. I keep playing and never get enough tokens to buy any improvements! They're gone if you don't use them but I can't use them because everything is too expensive! Unfuc kingbelievable.
Random power ups!? WTF!? I don't get this choice at all in single player. Just plain stupid, stupid, stupid. The power ups should be well thought out and allow many possible builds that require specific play styles but are "equal". 
Player control and choices are required to make this game succeed.
I WANT TO BUILD MY FUC KING CHARACTER THE WAY I WANT! Seriously, random power ups are destroying this game for single player.
developer_response: Hi,some issues you mentioned do exist, and we plan to make some adjustment. Thanks for playing our game and providing helpful feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
[h1] Strong Contender for Indie GotY 2020 [/h1}

If you're on the fence on this game, I'll save you some time: pick it up right now. It's worth much more than its current asking price. For less than the cost of a AA indie release you get 20+ hours of challenging, rewarding, and usually balls-to-the-wall crazy gameplay that evolves as you play. It's beautiful, it's polished, and its unbelievable that a dev team made this on their first outing. 

As somebody who enjoyed Borderlands 1 and 2, as well as Risk of Rain 2, this game feels to me like a mash-up of those two great games with a dash of Rogue Legacy's progression system to tie it together. The gameplay loop consists of amassing Occult Scrolls and increasingly-powerful weapons to blow away increasingly difficult stages of enemies and bosses, earning Copper (to buy in-game upgrades) and Soul Essence (to purchase "Talents", persistent upgrades that cross over between runs).  

Pros
-Insane variety between play-throughs
-Skill-based gameplay
-Tons of exciting combinations of weapons and scrolls to experiment with
-Excellent enemy variety, boss design, and balance (in its current state, the game is difficult but fair)
-Meaningful progression systems
-Beautiful presentation, including a crisp UI and a timeless art style reminiscent of Borderlands

Cons
-Early Access means there are plenty of audio, visual, and gameplay bugs that are still being ironed out, but expect these to be patched out as EA goes on (the devs are on top of it, check the patch history)
-Very difficult (some players may need quite a few runs before seeing success)
-Some weapons seem to be strictly weaker than others (unless you amass the perfect combination of Occult Scrolls), limiting the amount of real options players have if they want to succeed in their run
-The English localization can be confusing or downright misleading at times (I will say that the Devs are doing excellent work to fix this issue, with a patch having just been released today to correct some of the more important localization errors)
-Although there is plenty of content in the current version, there are only two playable characters to choose from, so in a 4-player lobby there is going to be a ton of overlap (no spoilers, but it's obvious from loading screens that there's at least one character the devs plan on adding)

Cats and dogs raining destruction on armies of evil henchies has never been this good,. In its current state, Gunfire is absolutely worth a buy.
[b] 9/10 [/b]

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Feels like a mix of Borderlands and Risk Of Rain. A very enjoyable FPS roguelite that is worth being on your radar if you're a fan of the genre 

[B]PROS:[/B]

- Guns and shooting feel solid and enjoyable

- Charmful Asian aesthetic artstyle that gives the game a lot of personality 

- Controls feel very solid on PC

- Lots of replayability and stuff to unlock/spend points on after runs

- Two characters with their own playstyles with more to come

[B]CONS:[/B]

- There's no melee attack which feels weird, it would be an improvement to see one added

- Some bugs/glitches, I had one bug where I would get stuck on terrain after dashes

- Lack of on-screen information, it would be nice have more hit markers and visuals to see who exactly is shooting at you and other dangers during a run

- Still some localization problems, "Energy orb freeze enemies" instead of "Energy Orb Freezes Enemies". "When inflict fire dmg" instead of "When you inflict fire dmg" etc. However information is still entirely readable and this is mainly just a small nitpick

- Missing some key features like a map and a teleport system 

[B]Conclusion:[/B]

Worth the 12$ price tag. If you're a fan of roguelites it's worth picking up

We are sorry for any inconvenience! This issue is caused by Windows regional format, and the game may not be able to run in certain regional format, We are working on this issue, and will inform you immediately when we fix this. 

You can also try to solve this issue temporarily by changing regional format until we fix this. Detailed guidance is here:

1. Change Time&Language regional format setting
Windows Settings -- Time & Language -- Region -- Regional format, and set it as English(United States)

2.If you can't find this choice, you need to go to Microsoft Store and install English language pack.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn when you first jump in, feels like a pleasant surprise.  Its a bit of an fps, its a bit of an action rogue-lite, and its got some lighter rpg elements.  

But then I died for the first time, and was brought to the skill tree...

In a rogue-lite game, there should absolutely not be necessary progression in order to actually win the game.  It removes the sense of satisfaction you get for winning, and removes a large portion of the skill actually involved.  No matter how many hours I have in DOOM II and Blood, my skills in other fps games will not carry over.  Because if you want to win with skill, you have to first grind your way to the top.  That is not fun game design.  

While I don't particularly like Dead Cells (rogue-lites in general), I think its fair to use that game as an example of a rogue-lite done right.  You are only unlocking items that aren't necessary for the completion of the game.  You are not inherently more powerful or less powerful with or without the rogue-lite unlockables (other than the health flask).  

In gunfire reborn however?  Tell me how it goes when you reach the second area for the first time at a low level...  good luck...

There is a good game here, and I feel many reviews already point out the good well enough.  But it is buried under this grindy leveling system that just morphs this fun experience into an absolute chore to play.  

I will definitely continue to follow development, but until this system is either heavily altered or removed, I don't think I'll be coming back anytime soon.
developer_response: Thanks for your feedback, current system is not perfect enough and we will optimize it, please give us more time.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
For the price of $12, the amount of content in Gunfire Reborn is impressive, especially for early access. It took me about 20 hours to defeat the final boss on the normal and harder difficulty levels, and I am only getting started. I have yet to play with and master the second character, (I think his name is Ao Bai, AKA "the dog") whose playstyle is entirely different from the starter character, the Crown Prince, AKA "the cat." Additionally, I have yet to unlock all the weapons and scrolls, and I am only halfway through the permanent skill tree that persists throughout all your runs.

The cool thing about the two unique characters is that in order to use them effectively you have to build them each completely different throughout each run. The cat focuses around elemental damage, while the dog is useful for explosive damage and hard-hitting weapons. This means you will need to utilize different weapons with different modifiers, not to mention all the different types of scrolls that give you passive buffs and can create some serious synergy if you choose the right ones. This allows for a ton of replayability even if you have already defeated the final boss 5 times, and that is a great feat for a game that is only in early access.

Overall, Gunfire Reborn is a huge breath of fresh air considering a lot of games are being released nowadays with lackluster content and the feeling that they are "cash grabs." This game seems to be privileged with developers who have a vision for it and want to make a game that is purely just fun.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: This game has so many different random factors in it, that once you get a proper build going it feels extremely satisfying. We have scrolls with unique properties that can be upgraded up to 3 times, which are generally what you'll be building around I suppose. Then we have weapons with their own unique abilities to them, which can also have different properties such as bonus critical damage or bonus damage to enemies inflicted with specific elements and etc. There are only 2 characters to play in the game, 1 of them is locked until you hit a certain level and you have permanent "Talent" upgrades as you level. These give you more maximum ammo, more max shield and health, upgrades to your specific characters abilities or even unlocking more powerful prefixes for the weapons you find in game. The levels you'll probably memorize very fast considering there aren't many variations in each zone, but they are pretty well made none the less. One thing that is definitely taking some time for me to get used to is the movement, as it feels extremely floaty and slidey, there are a few instances where you can do jumping puzzles as challenges and I find myself slipping off edges more than I do coming to a complete stop once landing. Seriously a great game in it's early stage and can only get better from here, really excited to see what the dev(s) do to further this game.
