title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
An absolutely brilliant roguelite, even its earliest stage. Although at the time of writing this I have almost 40 hours in this game, I also have hundreds of hours in some of the best roguelikes in my opinion, including The Binding of Isaac, Enter the Gungeon, Nuclear Throne, Risk of Rain 1 and 2, and slay the spire. Additionally, I have extensive experience in FPS, including 2000+ hours in TF2 and experience in the borderlands series.

Coming from that background: This game is good. Really, really good.

It gets everything right- On the FPS side, the shooting feels punchy and each weapon has its own unique feel. Reload animations are crisp, the crit sound is orgasmic and you get instant feedback. In terms of a looter shooter, the modifiers are unique and can make the same weapon feel quite different, and since the game has only unique weapons every weapon has a very fun cartoon aesthetic- And there isn't just FPS mainstays like SMGs, pistols, assault rifles and rocket launchers, but beam weapons, a kunai, or even a dragon or a lizard that you use like a gun.

On the roguelike side, its honestly surprising to me that another game hasn't managed to do this before. The sense of change from run to run in roguelikes as well as the skill involved in making choices feels like it'd be right at home with a looter shooter, and yet no games have really nailed it. Well, until now.

Whilst occult scrolls act like items in most roguelikes and the weapons are, as previously stated unique and fun, the ascensions really ties the whole package together, allowing for choice from run to run and a real feeling of building your own unique playstyle as each run continues. You tend to consider all three and end- One run you might be the crown prince using ascensions to make your energy orb massively CC everything, while another you might be spamming out grenades everywhere that debuff everything.

On top of all this, even though there are only two at the moment, each character does feel entirely unique. While the crown prince focuses on elemental weapons and CC, Aoi Bai is a complete rambo who loves explosive weapons and weapons with low ammo counts.

All this being said, it is early access. 3 levels, 2 characters, almost forty weapons and a ton of occult scrolls. If you want a complete game come back in a bit and have loads of fun, but for any diehard roguelike or looter shooter fans I can guarantee you probably at least 10 hours of fun- Or maybe even more than 30 like myself.

review:
Gameplay is pretty solid and the abilities seem fun. 

I'm just personally not a fan of losing your weapons and perks after every level. Each time you start a new level, you start off with no perks and a basic starter weapon. 

As you progress through the level, you'll find items that you can use to level up your hero abilities, but the options available for you to level up each time are random so if you like a certain build, you're unable to use that build consistently as there'e not make sure you'll be able to select the perks you want. title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
[h2]Unfortunately--I can't recommend this game right now due to the "grind to win" mechanics"[/h2]

Wow.. I hate to do this but I am doing it mainly for the devs to see. I'm giving it a thumbs down which is awful stuff :( something I RARELY do with my reviews. If I don't like games, I typically don't bother giving them a review. So this game. Reason? It's near perfect except for one glaring issue I have--that it requires grinding. LOTS OF GRINDING!!!

I absolutely can't stand games that ask you to play them over and over and over, with each run, placing points into a system that makes you stronger for future runs until after 100-1000's runs your strong enough to win. That is super LAME. And unfortunately, this game is victim of that with it's "Talents" system. You play rounds, die, use points you earned from the round towards unlocks to make you stronger (more health, more damage, better stats/abilities, ect.). That's the WORST thing you can do for games like this. 

I'm heartbroken. I was so stoked to play this game and give it a glowing review but stupid grind mechanics??? I can't.. I can't recommend this and it kills me. I am a huge fan of rogues and I wanted to love this game and play the hell out of it but I can't. 

If they want to compete with the best action roguelikes, they must change this mechanic because it's.. well to be frank.. it's mindless and takes the skill of winning away. I don't want to play 50-70 hours to obtain the necessary "talents" aka "upgrades" to beat the game. That is horrible! Horrible.. I am surprised I've never read this complaint until I've made it but it's very unhealthy for games like this in my opinion and thus for NOW.. for now, it gets a thumbs down. It guts me.. 

I will say other than that huge elephant in the room.. I like it alot and see a TON of promise. It's a great little action rogue that plays as others said, a silly FPS similar to borderlands with some rogue'ish mechanics like permadeath and locked rooms like you've seen in games like Starward Rogue and Binding of Isaac. Music is amazing, graphics are amazing but man.. the ball got dropped on the progression..

Again.. I am sorry, I really am but.. grind mechanics as progression? I just can't sit by and say "that's awesome" because its lame as hell. If devs want a game that people will stick with for ages, they will need to change that because games that use that as a form of progression get left for dust. 

People either get too bored to grind up to be strong enough to win or they do it, then shelve it because there is ZERO reason to keep playing after you max your stats out. All in all, it's not a great way to keep incentive for people to play. There are much better approaches you can take to keep players engaged and reward progression, endless grinding to win is NOT one of them. 

Other than that major--lame issue.. I like it a lot and wish the devs the best on their future endeavors. This game can be HUGE but I don't see it getting there if the current form of progression remains in place and I am just being honest.
developer_response: Hi, we'll re-evaluate our mechanisms especially the "talent" tree and keep optimizing them. Thanks for your play and feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
[h1]Gunfire Reborn First 24hrs[/h1]

[u]Pro(s)/Con(s)[/u]
+Easy to pickup and play
+Fun weapons (Justice has best reload animation)
+Starting Character is very fun to use
+Wide Variety of builds are viable
+Cursed Scrolls (with their counter scrolls) give the game a lot of diverse game play
+Ammo/Grenades are easy to replenish and only high consumption builds have issues with ammo management
+Solo Play is very rewarding to play

-Co Op difficulty can be absurd with 4 people
-Lag Compensation/Net Code can end runs with rubber-banding or enemies hitting you with bullets/abilities from nowhere (this is being looked into)
-Vaults and Chests can really screw you over giving you either nothing helpful to your run or giving you something that hurts your build if you take it (I know its supposed to be fully rng based but setting a preference would not be a bad idea)
-Weapon Drops (I see either 1 weapon for an entire area or I see 8 its like there is no in between)

[b]Improvements (personal opinion)[/b]
Custom Runs - Most roguelikes have an option similar to this, the ability to adjust certain aspects of a run
New Areas/Characters - Im sure this is already in the works and so far I do really like the design of all 3 areas and both characters
Ping System - Only helpful for Co Op when pointing out a vault of an item you drop for someone nothing fancy

Overall the game is very well made and done, most of my complaints are minor and a few I know they are already looking into. Easy 100+ hour game before I think I will get tired of it.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is phenomenal, especially only being early access as of now.
I'll be talking about 3 categories:
-Graphics
-Gameplay
-Bugs/glitches
~~~
Graphics:
I love the graphics implemented in this game. They feel so simple, yet smooth and refreshing. The overall aesthetic of all the areas is visually appealing and definitely worth praise. It's also extremely easy to distinguish different sections of the map.
8/10
~~~
Gameplay:
Addicting. Just completely addicting. This game is balanced just right, posing a challenge yet still rewarding you for advances. You die, upgrade, and go through the map once more. The satisfaction of beating each boss is the best part. Headshots in this game are especially great. They do tons of damage, but still not enough to simply one shot a character. The weapons feel slick and easy to use, some being more difficult than others. I believe the scrolls could be a bit more balanced. Some just feel too good, while others feel completely useless. An example of this is the scroll that allows you to heal 1 hp / item/copper picked up. I personally think this should be nerfed or touched upon a bit.
9/10
~~~
Bugs/Glitches:
Not many noteworthy ones. However, during co-op, my friends and I have experienced some very noticeable lag. The game may freeze suddenly, with everything just sitting in place. Other occasions weapon shots don't register. I haven't encountered any solo (yet), thankfully. For early access, this game has much less bugs than other well known and polished games.
~~~
Overall:
8.5/10
This game is definitely worth the buy! It's a rewarding and enjoyable experience. Time flies by when playing it. If you want a fun fps rogue game, this is 100% worth the $12 it current costs.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
As people have said, this game is essentially "Risk of Borderlands". A pretty neat game that combines the rogue-like aspects of Risk of Rain with a temporary skill tree and replayability and the permanent perk tree of Borderlands and the random aspects associated with the guns.

Admittedly it is still in Early Access (Like literally not even a month into it so far) so it still has a way to go. Some of the guns personally feel a bit useless or extremely circumstantial, while the kunai (Called Prism in the game) and the lightning ball/power bubble gun (Called Lightning Blast in the game) feel extremely powerful. To me most of the fire weapons seem to not sync with the fast pace nature of the game, which makes part of the Prince's skill tree seem not that useful.

Still, I do highly recommend getting this game, it is a ton of fun!

-Green

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
WARNING - THIS GAME IS VERY ADDICTIVE

Born in the borderlands style of gaming comes this little roguelike gem that is not to be missed.
The game essentially boils down to a mini RPG in which you have a choice of hero (Only 2 currently) who then goes crawling into randomly generated dungeons in search of weapons, upgrades and a rare currency called 'Soul Essence' which is used to upgrade your abilities on the hero permanently.

You won't come out triumph though - You must push on until you die, on death you can spend any accrued soul essence you have so that the next run can be a little bit easier. You basically rinse and repeat this cycle over and over again, getting further and further each time you die (in true roguelike fashion).

The gameplay is very fast paces and feels very responsive, gunplay feels smooth and never really gets boring, there are MANY different weapons all with different perks and upgrades but it won't take long for you to find a favourite.
The level design can get repetetive but in a shooter where your main focus is - you know - shooting things, do you really care?

There is some kind of huge latency issue with multiplayer right now, so unfortunately I can't recommend it for multiplayer, however playing on your own the game appears to run very well and is a ton of fun. I am eagerly awaiting the patch that will fix the matchmaking and it will truly be a perfect game.

And to my surprise this isn't a feature in this game either. Hopefully at least these 3 things get implented, but untill then I wont bother with it, and I regret ever trying it. Would not reccommend at this stage.

Fun little rogue-like well worth it's price. 

I'd love to see it gain consistent development and updates like some of the other early access games that fall under the same category. 

There is a really solid foundation here and I'm very much hoping for more- the game could use a bit of touching up, certain animations fixed and improved- mostly smaller things. Also, some improvements on the translations too but otherwise it's been a delight. 

The strongest part of the game so far have been the different guns and gunplay in general, the sound effects, and designs are all neat and feel fantastic to use.

lastly, I love how most of the enemies function and move, they're very animated and mostly enjoyable to fight. I'm especially looking forward for more levels, level variants, and bosses.

I would say that you should reduce the health or damage on the tough enemies and increase the health or damage on weaker ones.

Otherwise, this game has great potential and can scratch your rogue-like itch if you are willing to give this game a try.

I would even correct the spelling errors for free if you wanted, because every time I get an item I remember the spelling error and get annoyed. Thx.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
For the 30 hours that I've played this game, I highly recommend this game. For a cheap price of $11.99, you get a whole lot more. Firstly, the experience when picking up the game, it was easy to get the hang of, easy controls, minimal interface, overall, nothing to crazy. While advancing deeper into the levels, items, abilities, and weapons become more complex and revolve around whatever build you choose. Every run will be different, and there are a few areas you'll discover that you know it like the back of your hand. 

There are two reasons why this is probably one of my favorite roguelike game. First is the multiplayer. Every player gets their own items and own weapon drops. It isn't visible to the other players til you choose to drop it. No more race to get the loot or better items. On top of that, compared to my other favorite roguelike, you can DROP ITEMS! It's so nice to be able to trade items and weapons to the other player that fits their build for the run.

My second reason is the skill tree. I love unlocking new items and seeing them in my next run after completing an achievement. But it feels even better when you use the souls you've collected through the run to get passive upgrades like more ammo, damage, health, and when you get even further down the tree, free items, more souls, more money when you crit! It gives another sense of progression that your working toward something whether you win or lose.

I highly recommend this game whether it be single or multiplayer, the experience is great! You won't find a game this good for $12!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is incredibly good! Lets get that out of the way...

To start with, the shooting here is insanely tight. Every gun has a unique feel and sound to it, and you have a lot of weapon archetypes to choose from - you will most likely find a couple of favourites that you will want to focus on, but even the others are enjoyable to use when you have to.

The progression systems are very nicely thought out and create a very addictive loop of "just one more run" much like popular roguelikes such as Risk of Rain and Rogue Legacy. Each run nets you souls that you spend on a permanent upgrade tree to get better, and during each run there are several upgrade systems to get more powerful as you go along.

As it stands, the only weaknesses of this game is that it needs more content. That said - its incredibly cheap, and everything that is there is incredibly fun and well made. Its in early access so hopefully the developer will expand the content library over time,  but even as it stands, its an amazing game. Well worth the price of entry.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Everything about the game feels mediocre. 

Early Access isn't an excuse. It tries to take roguelite elements from a bunch of different games and mash them together. I was excited at the prospect of an FPS that did this but it all falls flat. 

-Gameplay : Movement is slow and feels like a shooter from 10 years ago
-Design : Move from area to area getting upgrades that generally feel underwhelming and find guns that are equally so, and the entire Level Up system is uninspired and boring
-Level Design : Incredibly boring and uninspired

There are better roguelite experiences on the market.
developer_response: Hi, we will make some adjustment to polish our game. Thanks for playing our game and providing feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Extremely addicting. Lately I have been solely playing games that I can zone out to while listening to a podcast/Youtube. This is a great game for that. There's a satisfying feeling of progression with every run, and the guns generally feel good. $11 is a steal for this, especially if you can come back when content gets added (early access). As is, I have 14 hours and feel that I still have 50% of the content left.

The in-game text is a problem though. Clearly they did not spring for translation services, because there are a lot of things in broken English, often to the point of not understanding what scrolls/upgrades actually do. Also, I personally don't like the visual style. All in all, an impressive debut. Hope they continue to add content and refine.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Game is more polished than a lot of release titles we see these days. 

Guns are fun and somewhat varied, Scrolls add interesting gameplay changes.

Unfortunately the game is balanced heavily against the player early on. You'll end up playing the same level on a constant loop for hours just for some minor progression. Think Nes Era game developement. 30 minutes of fun stretched over hours upon hours through aggressive stat based difficulty. 

I understand The game is EA and brand new at that. But with competition such as RoR at least offering 2 level variety's per phase. And at least 4 playable characters or more from the gate. There's still some much needed developer love.

Ultimately I'd suggest waiting if the pocket book is tight, but if you plan on getting it eventually. It doesn't hurt to start now. Support the team, this one's got a lot of potential.

Disclaimer: I've only done solo play so far because my friends are bitches and won't pony up.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This is really well polished for a game just entering Early Access. The movement is satisfying, the combat is fluid, the weapons are fun and diverse, the progression seems fairly well balanced. I'm sure there are more to come, but the enemies currently in game are interesting and have fun mechanics. There are a ton of ways to customize your kit each run and the differences in my abilities from run to run is tangible. That goes a long way to making you play differently each run, which keeps the gameplay loop pretty fresh.

Criticisms: Jumping up onto ledges is a little clunky, but it's so early in development that I'm confident they'll address it at some point. I think the presentation of what effects do could be a little clearer. Maybe making the UI a little more user-friendly would help with that, but again, we're freshly into Early Access with this title. My complaints are minor and are easily out-weighed by the things I love about the game.

Gunfire Reborn is well worth $12 in its current state and I'll be playing the hell out of it!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
[h1] Strongly Recommend [/h1]

Picked this game up today and played for about five hours so far. It's a great game and very addicting offering plenty of replayability through random level generation, lots of weapon types to find, a large skill tree to unlock, and two characters (at the time of review). It's rogue-type gameplay means each run is different with a ton of unique character and weapon "builds" every time you play. It is rewarding to find new weapon and perk combos work with the weapons and perk choices you find throughout the run. I am very much looking forward to seeing this game develop - even this early in development it is off to a great start and offers many hours of fun at a very low price! The upgrade system is interesting, each run you'll accumulate souls, if you die you can spend a certain amount of these to revive ONCE per run or chose to end the run with your souls. After a run you can spend souls on persistent upgrades, BUT any souls that you don't spend are lost forever. This means to unlock more expensive upgrades (which you will hit within an hour or two of playing) you need to make it into and even past the second level which is, in my opinion, pretty challenging. What this means is eventually you'll hit a point where a lot of 10-20 minute runs will end, you won't be able to afford any upgrades, and you'll lose an entire run's worth of souls making the run essentially useless. As seems to be the norm for reviews here are some pros and cons:

[b] Pros: [/b]
- High replayability through random level generation in addition to loot and perk mechanics
- Very fun and rewarding shooter with good mechanics and solid gun and movement feel
- Enough persistent upgrades to work towards to reward continued runs
- Challenging levels keep each run interesting
- Highly varied perks and weapons provide a unique experience every run
- Private and match-made multiplayer, play with your friends or team up with people online
- Simple menu option to provide feedback on bugs, crashes, suggestions, etc.

[b] Cons: [/b]
- English translation is not very refined yet, this does not affect gameplay but is definitely noticeable
- Some in-game text (my guess is status effects?) are not in English, only noticed a few in five hours though
- Not being able to keep your unlock points between runs makes progress difficult once you hit your "skill wall" and are not able to progress far enough each run to afford upgrades
- Each run is randomly generated but in the same "level," so overall environment and enemy types are fixed

[b] Final Thoughts [/b]
Overall I am greatly enjoying this game so far and looking forward to the continued development. I am confident it will grow into an amazing game from its already impressive and entertaining start. I would absolutely recommend picking this up now before the price goes up!

review:
Games fun. I normally don't like games that auto-reset your gear, skills etc. every game but the talents the game comes with (which you buy using currency you get by doing stages) gives a very nice playing factor to keep you wanting more these DO carry over each play through. If you LOVE trying to find OP builds for single target or AoE mobs, it's a great game.

This is NOT a game you'll clear the 3 stages within 2hrs so if you want an easy game i would skip this.

IF you want a game where hours and exp. shows and high levels are generally better (due to talents game knowledge etc) this is a great game! One of the only times i'll say PLAYTIME is a show of skill (99.99% of the time in this)

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: Borderlands mixed with Risk of Rain 2 made this a must buy for me. Only problems are that there are only 2 characters playable in the game (You don't unlock the other character untill you have played the game a considerable amount) and there isn't a whole lot of polish to the game; mostly due to a rough english translation or multiplayer being slightly choppy (Both of these thing will probably be ironed out later in development). The game is still in Early Access so just know that before purchasing it, but I feel like the game has enough content to justify the $12 asking price.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunplay is actually very smooth and a lot of fun! Very addicting with it's dungeon crawling and makes you want to say "Maybe just want more run" when you die just so you can get more essence to upgrade your abilities next run and unlock more weapons to drop!

At the moment, the grind is a bit long, but personally, as someone who's spent years in Destiny/Borderlands/MMOs in general, I don't mind it. Plus, for now, the grind is just fine with the amount of content is in the game at the moment, keeps you playing so you can get more stuff!

For an Early Access game, it's really well done and pretty well polished! For it's $11 price it does have enough gameplay time to warrant it's price tag! Especially when the game is going to be updated over time!

Totally recommend playing for anyone who likes Borderlands-esk Looter Shooters/Dungeon Crawler gameplay!

review:
I have never written a game review before. I heard about the game 4 days ago from the Woolie video and I'm already level 100 with 44 of the 60 achievements. If Borderlands and Risk of Rain had a baby it would basically be this.

Its also worth noting the only major problem I had with the game was corrected the night I encountered it, which was being unable to rejoin with friends if you were killed mid match. The devs seem to be really actively trying to build the best game they can.

 I personally even enjoy some of the off translations because it makes it more discovery based.

10/10 easily worth $15

The game clearly has some tuning issues, randomly youll get two tapped when a room right before it you had no issues. The translations could also use some work but the ones I have seen so far havent been so bad you cant work out the effects. Outside of those issues I think the game is really fun, the gameplay loop is solid and the guns are varied and feel nice to use. My only hope is the add in more heroes over time. 

Runs surprisingly well despite being EA as well, basically rock solid 60 with a 4790k + 980, ive seen a few dips but its not an issue 99% of the time.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
So yes, it is Rogue Lite Borderlands. 

Beside some much needed optimization, the concept is great. Just a couple things I'd like the devs to consider.

1. Add some kind of scrapping/crafting mechanic. I hate leaving loot and guns behind in previous rooms when swapping for new ones. It drives my OCD nuts. Perhaps we could break guns we don't want to use anymore down into scrap that can be used to craft bullets for example.

2. Please let us swap out the starting weapon. Unless I'm missing something, I couldn't figure out how to change it out 
 for new guns in all 3 slots. Getting rid of our only weapon that has infinite ammo is a risk I think the players should be allowed to take.

Now this is after just an hour of play so correct me if my points are already answered or solved, but otherwise, I wanted to give this game a thumbs up regardless. Always wanted a Borderlandsy rogue lite. Immortal Redneck was the closest thing.

Great game - very addiction. Borderlands-like random generator on weapons, with the objective of creating the most powerful class you can make by combining weapon perks, class perks via completing "levels," and picking up dropped scrolls/buffs. Talent system in place that is shared between characters, and an achievement system that unlocks more weapons and scrolls. 

Have already sunk in 23 hours of my life I will never get back, and it was totally worth it. Even have my girlfriend enjoying the game!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn is the distilled essence of Borderlands weapons (culling a lot of the complexity and miniscule stat boosts on your loot so everything is pretty substantial and plays more heavily into builds and passive effects) built onto the foundation of a more linear Immortal Redneck. It's already a solid contender in the roguelike FPS genre and the cute graphics are just icing on the cake. There are a few issues I have which I'd like to see addressed, but even this early I feel like the game's already a fine investment of your money and time.

There are a few major points of frustration, at least in my experience. I feel like the pool of unlocks is hit or miss - the more awful options that are added to the drop table, the less chance you get one of the ones I consider essential. Movement speed, especially, feels like a stat that's almost a necessity, yet there are only a few scrolls that improve it... and even one that actively hinders it, if you use the wrong damage type! I would like to see some way to add movement speed through the end of level rewards, and I think some of the worse upgrades could be replaced with that. [spoiler](seriously, does anyone pick "first 5 shots while dual-wielding do double damage, but halve the duration of dual wield?" It goes against the very nature of how that skill works and the damage buff is almost meaningless when so many other effects give almost as much buff, more easily, without side effects. IMO, turn that into 40% move speed in dual wield and I'm happy~)[/spoiler]

I also think some enemies are a bit overpowered. Standing totally still too long should be punished but I think there's too much of a prevalence of enemies that rapid-fire homing attacks. Honestly, the homing could be toned down (look at Dark Souls archers) so that as long as you're moving you'll be okay, but standing still, even if you moved right after the shots were fired, would still be a bad idea. I've seen too many good runs end just because a couple of those enemies spawned in and immediately fired volleys toward me before I could realize I wasn't moving perpendicular to them. With the range they have and how quickly you can be overwhelmed from all sides (not to mention when you're slowed, that effect is enough to make those attacks guaranteed to hit) I think it's overkill. The player can't effectively respond to that.

But mostly, I think the game's really good, still quite fun in its current state. Definitely a recommend, but I'm hoping they will fix some of these pain points in the future.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
The game is OKAY... It has a lot of potential but at the moment it seems to get stale pretty fast. The levels aren't exactly the same every time but they're so similar they may as well be. There is a large variety of weapons and "power ups" you get get during a single run, however, most weapons feel insanely bad, and a large majority of the power ups feel identical, aside from some very rare ones that are actually very fun and probably the best part of the game. Besides those points, my biggest complaint about the game is the loot system. All of the weapons that drop have random effects on them such as "Increased damage when enemy has this debuff" or "increase fire rate" however, instead of adding excitement to a already good weapon, it seems to make you look for very specific effects otherwise the weapon is bad. This more often then not, leads to runs where you are slowly slogging through the levels because you're weapons are so extremely weak. 

Overall, I think the game needs some major tuning of the weapons system and replay ability but since it is still in early access there is a good chance the game will improve dramatically during the progression of the game.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Alright so I have compeleted the game both on normal and elite and here is what I think of the game. It is fantastic, at least for 4 days in a row. I am not sure what I am going to have to do next??? 

**The Art/Design**

The levels and different type of enemies are a piece of art, I love it. I hope there will be more enemies and level soon with more difficulties.

**Gameplay**

This game has this, I need to try again because I know why I died and next time I will do better, vibe. It is fantastic! Almost everything in this game feels fair. The guns are great and the game is optimized perfectly.

**Customization**

Now I love how much guns there are and all the script you can unlock but I wish there was this thing I could do to give my own signature to the characters in game. For example I am sure I am one of the first to complete the game on Elite, a cool cape or something would make it feel much more rewarding ^^

**Suggestions**

There however a few things I would like to see changed/fixed. 

1. The walls in this game are a bit inaccurate. With some weapons you can detect enemies before you can see them and this goes for enemy projectile as well, especially those who curve.

2. Some hitboxes of the heads of some of the enemies are really weird and inaccurate especially the lizards and ducksnipers.

3. There is a bugg in Elite, where in level 3 those ninjas who teleport towards you and start spinning do not do any damage! 

4. There is this one parkour level in level 3 that is simply not doable... at least not without the triple dash scoll.

5. The triple dash scroll is OP! It is so easy to complete the game with that scroll (both difficulties

**Final Note**

For the love of god, buy this game! It is amazing and the list of suggestions is hardly an issues when you play as you can adapt to it and some stuff is in your favor!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is amazing and only in its 2nd/3rd week of early access. Of course there are some flaws, it is not perfect, but that is the point of early access right? I have seen people complaining that it is too hard and all I need to say to that is that most rogue like/light games are this way. Yes the first boss is exceedingly difficult, I still haven't gotten past him myself yet, but the grind to get good enough to want to keep trying to beat him. Dark souls would be boring if not challenging, so would risk of rain 2, borderlands, etc. This game takes what makes risk of rain, doom, and borderlands great and packs it into a single game, that is challenging, yet fun as heck. It's $12, check it out, I can assure you will get your money's worth. One final point I would like to make, I am not sure what it is about this game but it takes me back to my childhood when I played games for pure enjoyment, it gives me the same feeling as completing a crash bandicoot mission or finally figuring out what i was supposed to do in banjo and kazooie, or perfect dark. I cannot wait to see what comes next out of this game

Edit: I would prefer a melee function, whether it is a future weapon or simply hitting v or f to melee.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Unbelievably good. 

It's hard to do GR justice through pictures or videos, but what the game lacks in visual polish it makes up for in spades for a really incredible core gameplay loop. It's a simple concept, take the gun mechanics from Borderlands and stick them in a permadeath roguelite. And it works. 

Oh boy does it work. 

If you've played any of the Borderlands games then the inspiration is going to be pretty obvious right away. Drops are going to be one of many "templates", which then have a chance of rolling various different perks, such as increased crit damage, bigger magazine size etc. The shock + corrosive + fire elements from Borderlands are also there in pretty much identical form. However, GR isn't afraid to tweak the recipe when needed, such as allowing you to + 1 your gun at randomly spawning merchants for cash, letting you keep your weapons base stats up to snuff against the ever scaling enemy hordes. While it might be less than original I personally see the overall combat system as fans building on foundation Borderlands laid down as opposed to a direct ripoff. 

In terms of negatives the only glaring issue is the occasionally lackluster english translating. Other than that there are the usual signs that this an early access game made by a small studio, repeated assets, simplistic level designs, reused assets, the odd bug here and there... But I can honestly say that none of these things detracted from how much fun I had, and for 12 dollars full price plus the heads up that it's an early access title I'd say even with these issues it more than exceeds expectations. Gunfire Reborn is clearly the product of a passionate group of people, you can see the love in every detail from the characters you can play as (an indterdimensional cat prince or a dual weilding bear) to the finely tuned loot and progression mechanics. I've already gotten my money's worth but here's to hoping there's a lot more coming.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
BORDERLANDS AND ENTER THE GUNGEON HAD A CHILD!!! 

This is the Early Access review and will be changed as more content gets added towards launch!! 

Pros: 
Elemental damage to specific health/shield/armor will be very familiar to borderlands players!!!
Lots of Progression trees and nodes
Easy to pick up
Challenging at the later stages
DOGGO!!!

Cons:
Limited levels for now
Some enemies archetypes feels very unbalanced and will shred you like swiss cheese
Some build types is very OP and can carry you thru the levels if you have good RnG early on
No resource sharing in co op
When your co op partner/s dies they cant respawn until the next level but enemies still scale to group size making stuff super spongy
Matchmaking is borderline unplayable. I get that its peer to peer but its really really bad sometimes

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Even in its early state the game is a great time, well worth the price. It's like a mix between borderlands and a rogue lite (Ziggurat might be the best comparison if you've played that). The weapons are varied and fun by base with meaningful & interesting stats tacked on, the goblet character progression system gives you a sort of baseline control over the direction of your run, and the scroll item system adds the unpredictable random spice to the run where you find one that is particularly neat and start playing around it. The permanent progression system between runs is a neat way to get some incremental power sort of like a version of bl3's guardian rank system: noticeable and meaningful but certainly still less important than what an individual run offers you. Toward the bottom of the tree you start seeing some really powerful options, but getting there takes a while and won't hurt the integrity of the core gameplay I dont think. It just provides some more incentive to keep playing and grind out those upgrades.

Gameplay consists of fighting through a couple zones (differnt color styles, enemy types, and room layouts) divided into a few floors (one guaranteed goblet character progression item per floor) divided into rooms (which individually hold enemies & loot). At the end of every zone there's a boss. The enemy targeting is relatively simple, so when you get hit it feels like it's your fault for not properly dodging, but with a wide variety of enemy types each with slightly different ai makes it so situations still call for attention still; overall they feel great to fight and learning how to fight different enemies feels rewarding. In terms of your character, you get your starter weapon, two additional weapons you pick up during a run, and two skills. Currently both characters have grenades as their second skills, but even those grenades feel different to play with since they function slightly differently and have different upgrades (not quite as diverse as borderlands grenades but getting close). The primary skills are vastly different and both are a good time to use. I should also mention that of those two weapons you pick up during a run, you often swap them out constantly as you find straight upgrades or just better options for the situations your facing since each zone has its own parts that are particularly challenging, so you will rarely ever hold one for the entire game (though the option is there to do so if you find one with particularly hot modifiers by spending some coins to keep it up to par with current progression).

Both online and solo work great. I, like most, have enjoyed online more when playing with a private lobby among friends, but the matchmaking is there and works great if you like that more. Multiplayer feels fairly balanced right now compared to single player, even though in MP you get the ability to revive downed teammates along with 1 optional solo revive while in SP you only get that 1 solo revive (which costs a lot of the permanent progression points you've earned for the current run, so it feels like a real choice to revive or not). Singleplayer is a great time too and I've done a number of runs there as well.

There are some translation issues right now but they're minor and still get the idea across just fine.

Overall, great game, and considering the relatively low price, certainly worthwhile even not on sale. To quell some early access fears, even if it sees no updates from here forward, I still think its worth the purchase for the content it has now. With more updates and content, it'll only get better.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: This game is positively fantastic and has one of the most specialized and fun to work with build systems I have ever experienced. The gameplay is tight and immediately easy to get into and hard to master and the enemies are tough with great AI that always keeps you on your toes. There are two things that hold this game back from being perfect and that are enemy variety and localization. Most of the enemies are just reskins from the first floor, which I can't complain about too much because they are very well designed enemies but i would really like something a bit more than a buff and a reskin. The second problem is with localization, although most of the translations from the game's original language (chinese I believe) went well and is readable without any secondary thought, some of the meaning was lost in translation for certain occult scrolls and weapons, making them incomprehensible. Obviously both of these problems are easily fixed and I am aware that this game is in early access, but I just wanted to point out how fantastic this game is even in it's primitive state, the gameplay is very fun and addictive and the level designs are all unique and special in their own way. For now, I would give this game a 9.5/10

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
6/10 GREAT GAME BUT NEEDS A LOTTTT OF WORK

i saw this game on the steam store for only ¬£9, looked quite cool and seeing as we are in a big lockdown and ive completed my whole steam library, twice, i bought this game and played it without any knowing of what it is. i was met with a fun charming game that gave me a fast paced looter shooter vibe, i played a few games and i had a lot of fun, i enjoyed a lot, however after 1:30hrs, ive come to realise that it is a repetitive, extremely difficult roguelite thats quite boring. The grind of getting all kitted up with the finest weapons and scrolls fighting until reaching that final boss and killing him with just an inch of health left just to be met with another relentless 5 levels that will last no longer than 20 seconds if that. My problem with the game is that it seems every time i load the game and play it, it feels like what im playing for is just useless. im not much of a roguelite player, ive played ror2 maybe twice for no more than 2hours but after my experience with this game, i dont think i will be returning to this genre. You load into the 1st level and your instantly put into a close quarters room most of the time during the early game with a pistol and about 5 enemies and thats it, over and over until you make it to the last levels where instead of just running round the same rocky corridors and rooms, its a fuck fest wave game with large amounts of enemies spawning that are incredibly difficult to kill with your awful weapons and useless scrolls. And when you end that level and make it to the desert level, your health is already so low that unless youre god himself and have not lost much health the first level, youre instantly fucked in the next level as the bosses are even harder and stronger, and to top it all off, once you die, thats it, you go back to the main menu and restart it. I guess once you rank up this skill tree thing it will make it easier but that must be a grind of the same thing for hours i am not willing to endure. 

PROS
- Cool cartoon graphics adds charm
- Unlocks that adds slight replay value 
- Rewarding but harsh
- Fun with friends
- Cool weapons
- Unique abilities 
- Rank up systems

CONS
- Boring after 2hrs of grinding
- Extremely difficult
- Pointless playing 
- Only buy one health kit for ONLY 30% once every so often
- End bosses can 2 hit you with ease
- Variation of weapon and scroll setups but only few are actually effective 

I will be keeping this game in my steam library as i do actually enjoy the game, and somewhat recommend it in "its not the best it could be right now", but the devs seem to be ontop of things and are pumping out updates frequently so thats a good sign, and for a low price of only ¬£10 in early access its an alright purchase but limited enjoyment.

Im leaning more towards a Yes Recommendation than a No which may surprise you from all the shit ive just talked about it, mainly because i know this game will be great in the near future and just needs more people to play it and see it for its greatness and weaknesses, and they can decide for themselves what to do with it. It has much potential and i really hope they can pull through with an update that will bring me back for more.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Early Access Review: Recommend, but....

The game is good, especially for EA. That said, I can't really understand the resounding praise this game is getting. The level maps are extremely monotonous, with little enemy variation and and little to offer. Weapon upgrades add a little spice, along with gaining access to "restricted" areas like Vaults. Your character moves very similar to characters in Overwatch: vary labored with small jumps and a short dash. That's not a negative, it just feels a bit jarring compared to your typical FPS movement. 

Its a Rogue-Lite, so you will die. The levels leading up to the boss won't present any challenge, then the boss will two-shot you into oblivion before you have a chance to think and then it's back to the beginning - rinse, repeat. You gain orbs to spend in your talent tree, then you go again.

The game needs longer, more complex levels to keep things interesting. I can't help but think of other rogue-lites, like Risk of Rain and Dead Cells, that absolutely killed it with level design and length. The levels need to be fun and rewarding. As of right now, they aren't. The arena style rooms have less fun and excitement than a 30 year old Doom clone. 

That said, the art style, combat, and weapons are great. The first run to the first boss was a 5/10, the next attempt was a 6/10, and so on. So, this game grew on me, and I'm pretty hyped to see what the Devs manage with this game. A solid FPS rogue-lite with killer weapons and fun, challenging bosses is exactly what the doctor ordered. Hoping they pull it off.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
The gunplay in this is extremely satisfying. It's like a mix of the shooting from DOOM, randomized weapons from Borderlands, and the gameplay loop from Hades.

There is a ton of enemy variety, and the all the weapons feel and sound great. You have everything from burst assault rifles, rocket launchers, smart targeting lasers, the Mastiff, throwing kunai, Tediore SMGS, and a dragon that works like a flamethrower. 

It can be a little tough at first, but since this is a roguelite you will gain more and more power as you go. You gain currency for your progress, then spend that currency to give permanent upgrades to your character. 

I am not fond of the platforming puzzles you encounter starting in chapter 2, even though I loved the platforming in DOOM Eternal and Titanfall 2. This is mostly due to a lack of double jump and 3 second cooldown from your dashes (Unless you get lucky and grab an item that gives you three!). Luckily those are optional. 

Currently there are two heroes, with one of them locked. If you've played Borderlands they have abilities similar to the Siren and Gunzerker. Make sure you use your abilities and grenades whenever you have the chance; The cooldowns are quick and the grenades are plentiful!

Highly recommended game even though it's in early access!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Fun Rougelite alone or with friends!

Combining elements of different games (RoR2, Deadcells, Doom and Borderlands) into an addictive and satisfying gameplay loop that can keep you hooked for several hours on end. The English localization has some grammatical errors but, that doesn't detract from the overall experience. With a few balancing updates and some more content this can become an amazing game.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I expected a lot more from the reviews, but truth be told this is a super slow paced boring and grindy game. It's graphics have charm, the foundation makes ya think it could be pretty good, but u go through a handful of rooms easily every run(like pathetically slow and easy pacing) and then you get to a boss that isn't possible to kill cause he kills you in 2 hits and has insane amounts of health. I get it you gotta grind your talents up to be able to take him on...but the game of going through a handful of rooms to die on a boss over and over until I eventually grind that exact same thing over and over is lame. I did a handful of runs, they were all the exact same, not what the dev broadcasts, the portals to dungeonlike puzzles for 2 year olds that anyone can beat or "challenge rooms" that are literally the exact same thing cept the enemies drop a minion like enemy that takes 1 shot of any wep to kill when the original enemies die(which isn't challenging at all).

Idk man I have no idea how people are calling this risk of rain meets borderlands, it's not even close to either. It's so far away from either of those 2 it's making me wonder if I'm the only person with a brain on steam anymore. This game is just a boring grind how does it have this much love? If you wanna play rougelites there are infinitely better options available out there this game was a letdown and made that very clear as fast as possible. Nothing about it makes me feel like i'd wanna put 10+ hours into it, and when I think of the best rougelites they are games I can see myself always coming back to even if it's just for a run or 2 but always coming back from time to time. This is not the case.

I've requested a refund it isn't worth my money. Took less than an hour to see through the hollow experience this game is.
developer_response: Hi, we have figured out your issue, and we will try our best to optimize our game. Thanks for playing our game and providing feedback.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
it's an easy, yet complex game with various elements that sew the balance in the game. 
you can find/buy items and guns that correlates to the current stage of your run.
If you die, it does become overwhelming to watch other players survive and get loot without you. 
it may not seem difficult, although the scaling will often kill you. 

I will say boulders suck, you cannot crawl when you're down, and there should be more random boss per level/stage.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
A very addictive game with many MANY different challenges to face, The enemies are numerous and also have different ways of being killed. The on the fly tactics you need to use gets better the higher level you are. 

I've played some really good RNG runs where I will melt everything and other times it's been scarce but fun. You never seem to play each time with the same items in the same order so it makes you think of alternate ways of getting past bosses or levels with different gear and guns. 

I'm surprised this is still early doors as the game is very good, yes some things have shown themselves but over the course of 22 odd hours I've had 0.0001% of things make a mare but nothing that has stopped me being able to carry on. 

At the moment you may struggle to find a CO OP and be warned, the CO OP brings its own challenges with bosses increased health so play solo, get to grips and try it. Just be aware there may be longer than normal wait times. 

Overall, a quality purchase and I would recommend it to anyone.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is very much worth it's price. 

Gameplay loop is really well done, only thing I would complain about is that the dash move is very unpolished and does not feel very smooth when using it (I'm playing on a 144hz monitor and the dash animation feels like 60 or hell even 30)

Game is not very demanding, I run it at complete max with a steady 225 fps.

Maps are good but more variation in layout would be nice (less hallways in early areas). I understand that later areas are bigger but that makes the first twenty minutes of a run a pain to get through. 

Make sure to let me know if I'm wrong about stuff I actually want to not misinform people on some things

Overall for a game that's only $11.99 currently and made by a smaller team this is a ton of fun. Small stuff here and there do bring the experience down a little bit though. The only major problem is probably the first areas, very very bland and not that fun when compared to later segments.

review: I have put about 3 hours in got to talent 15 beat the first boss and enjoyed the game quite a bit. I love that you have things that you level up while in the fights an you also get a talent tree to perma level your hero. I do wish the 2nd hero wasn't at talent level 30 but it does make sense as you slowly progress you  unlock more items, weapons, power-ups to you. the game is like a really long tutorial but keeps itself fresh will new weapons and different things you can use. I  would recommend this game especially for the price it is. the only downside is you start in the same area each time so the tileset gets boring, the other tilesets are nice as you progress further. I have run into a part where my game crashed when the host left but that is to be expected from an early access, honestly the game lacks a lot of bugs most early access games have and has a ton of content already in it. suprised they only charge 11.99. hope this review helps you make an informed purchase.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
A very good FPS rogue-lite, and while it is Early Access I will say it has some major outliers namely the first boss Wu Lu hits like 10 trucks and will 1-2 shot you commonly until you get some of the rogue-lite perks. 

In general though, the game is great. Best way I could explain it currently.:

Difficulty - Risk of Rain style. Longer you take tougher it gets. 
Weapons - Imagine if you only had Legendaries from the Borderlands series. Every gun is fairly unique, though not exactly the best for everything.  These guns become ever more unique as you gain the ability to find Unique-on-gun perks for each gun. 
Example: had a sniper with While scoped for 1s highlight enemies through walls. High-lit enemies are always counted as Crit-hits. 

Leveling up - Much like Rogue Legacy, You get currency for killing enemies, bosses. Every run you spend em or lose em and start anew with your unlocked buffs. These range from basics like Ammo reserves, or more HP, to exclusive weapon perks like mentioned above.

My biggest complaints would be Wu Lu the first boss needing tweaks. Recently got to the second boss and it felt insanely balanced / fair, so I think Wu Lu just needs a major once over by the devs.

 And it takes a bit long to unlock the second Character, If it unlocked quicker it would help  some of the repetitive issues of most Rogue-lites. 

Final note, it has 4P coop! So you can shoot and loot with buds too!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
It has it's issues being in early access and you might come across a few bugs but this game is the shit. 
If you're a fan of quick fps with rougelite elements this will easily be your jam. There are plenty of weapons each with their own style of gameplay and getting a run with the right occult scrolls (items) and ascendancies (character specific perks) that synergize with your build can really take you off. Two example runs I had that really popped off.
-Prism is kunai with 1 ammo and there is an occult scroll that gives you 50% bonus damage on your first shot of your magazine, giving you permanent bonus damage on that weapon. 
-I ran a grenade build that stacked grenades (ended on 32 with the cat prince) and grenade damage along with a lightning assault rifle that gave 65% bonus damage on enemies affected by elements which also came with shock. When you combine any 2 elements in the game they have a bonus elemental effect that occurs (i believe shock + decay results in a stronger damage over time effect that decay gives). I would just toss grenades like mad and fire away until everything was dead.

The big thing I want to end on is this game awards skill over everything. Enemies hit like a truck but for the most part it is fair. Aim is everything, if you don't get good you'll get punished hard. Even with a god build, you still need to be able to avoid enemies and take them out quickly as in certain areas you will be gunned down in mere seconds if you stay moving or keep enemies clear (looking at you tall bandit in stage 2).

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Surprisingly fun and very addicting; sort of a roguelike take on Borderlands. The weapons and builds are fun to use, and there's a decent amount of content here already. Once they add new characters, weapons, scrolls, stages, etc, then this game will be incredibly good.

Pros:
+ Fun combat.
+ Decent weapon variety with a playstyle for everybody. The throwing knife is my personal favorite.
+ Good enemy variety.
+ Lots of progression, both macro and micro.
+ Borderlands-esque loot system.

Cons:
- General lack of content that comes with early access titles. There are only 2 characters and not that many levels. But they're definitely going to add more at some point.
- Some deaths can feel extremely sudden, especially in later stages. Enemies can unexpectedly tear through your health with little warning.
- No melee weapons seems like a crazy missed opportunity. 

Neutral:
+/- Grindy as hell. This is a turn off for some, and a selling point for others.
+/- Difficult. You won't be beating the game on your first playthrough, or your second, or third...

Overall it's worth the $11, and you can even justify them raising the price later on when they add more characters. If there were more characters, levels, and a larger loot pool, I'd definitely pay $20 for this game.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game has potential, but I'm not sure I'd recommend it in its current form.
Sort of a disclaimer: Yes, I've played RoR2, I've played DOOM (old and new), I've played Borderlands, and potentially unrelated, Ziggurat & Immortal Redneck.

I would honestly veer away from saying the game is a mishmash of the three, since a lot of elements are missing from them. Borderlands I can kinda see, since all that I really take away from that as far as gameplay goes is random stats on guns and skill trees. Doom, you got the dash and I suppose rooms full of enemies, but lacking the satisfaction of blowing enemies apart. RoR2.. It's a roguelite. That's it. The scaling difficulty feels more like Enter the Gungeon, which my experiences consisted mostly of "Haha wow, I have garbage weapons and the health is inflating faster than the economy."

As for Ziggurat and Immortal Redneck, those were both games with dungeon layouts akin to Binding of Isaac, but in the FPS format. Having clocked 100+ hours into Ziggurat, the mechanical failings of the game started to show, but it's still pretty solid. Immortal Redneck felt like a step back with a ton of unsatisfying weapons and the same sort of post-run progression tree that this game has.

So what's the point of me bringing all of this up?
Truthfully, I'm not sure now that I've written it. Maybe it's because it doesn't quite feel like this game is truly the "lovechild" of those other titles as some have said. If that were the case, I feel as though the skill tree would be something that you progress in the middle of a run in perhaps a chaotic nature at a fast pace, you'd have incredible mobility with a means of quickly executing enemies at close range, and the weapons would feel distinct but just random enough that stuff dropping seemed exciting. Currently, we have a dash and some pretty okay gunplay.

I'll probably keep an eye on this game, as it seems like it could absolutely grow into something fantastic. For now, it's a bit unrefined.
But, that'd be Early Access for you, wouldn't it?
developer_response: Hi, thanks for your helpful suggestion, we will think about what adjustment to make and try our best to meet your expectation!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn is an exciting and surprisingly in-depth looter shooter, which many have compared to Borderlands and roguelites. The initial gameplay compromises of shooting enemies, getting upgrades, dying, getting permanent upgrades, and repeating. This is not an issue for most people, including myself, but I feel that this game could get boring very quickly for more puzzle-strategy oriented players.

Pros of the Gunplay:
Weapons are very unique by themselves, and also get additional characteristics called "inscriptions" which can range from a simple stat boost to dramatically changing how the weapon works itself. Inscriptions can make or break a weapon in this game, so it is [i] critical [/i] that you make sure you understand them before picking up a weapon. Weapons also gain more inscriptions the longer a run goes on, so weapons continue to feel unique and different, even if you did pick up the same weapon in a previous run. Weapons also use one of three different types of ammo: meaning you have to make interesting decisions as to what weapons you choose to take, as you can only carry 2 weapons.
The gunplay by itself is also very smooth: weapons feel interesting and satisfying to use.
Cons of the Gunplay:
I am sure this issue will be resolved in the future, as this was written during early access. This issue being that there aren't quite enough weapons in the game. Even if the inscription system makes each weapon unique, that can only go so far as weapons will inevitably become boring. Another issue I have is with grenades- throwing them feels clunky and not as quick as it should be. This doesn't sound like much, but it really distracts you in those heated moments.

Pros of enemy and room design:
I think that this game handles the whole "procedurally generated level" better than other roguelites. Instead of changing small aspects of the level, it instead adds or removes rooms, making a different pathway to the end. This is done well, and rooms don't feel very boring, even if you've seen it already. The game also occasionally throws small challenge events at you, usually in "vaults" (the game's version of secret rooms) which can really mix things up. Enemies also are unique, having easily choreographed attacks that are easily dodgable with enough knowledge, and good visuals really tie the enemies together. Bosses are also great, providing actual challenge while being completely doable.
Cons of enemy and room design:
The rooms themselves in this game don't really provide much: just a battleground for you and your enemies. This can lead to the game becoming boring very quick as the rooms feel empty once all enemies and loot are cleared out, providing no reason to stay or enjoy the visuals. I think puzzles or other small challenges could really improve the levels and provide more reason to pay attention to the environment around you. I also think that level variants would be a great addition too, to break up the monotony. I have no issues with the normal enemies, but bosses are a little bit unfair sometimes. The reaction speed to need to dodge the first bosses' rock throw attack is crazy, and is extremely difficult to dodge if your dash skill is on cooldown. And don't even think you can dodge the slam attack he does. The second boss has two phases, the first being unfairly difficult, and the second being way too easy. The laser in his first phase is almost undodgable, and will rip through you easily. The second phase is just a joke: the tail takes critical hits almost anywhere, the projectiles can be destroyed, and it only creates more waves as it's health goes down. No issues with the final boss, though.

Pros of Balance, Hero, and Permanent Upgrades
The balance in the game's single-player mode is fantastic- the enemies seem fair and the bosses are challenging but possible. Despite there being only two Heros to chose from (The Crown Prince and Ao Bai) the amount of thought and detail that went into their temporary character upgrades (called ascensions) is well done and thorough, and complement their playstyles well. The visuals for these characters is good too (having the color of grenades change on your character is a nice touch). The permanent upgrade system, called Talent, is done well too. To upgrade it, you need soul essence, which is collected from monsters along your adventure. The soul essence can't be brought along though, (without a certain upgrade) so you need to plan out your upgrades with the amount of essence you have to ensure you're not being wasteful. The upgrades are interesting and useful, so it always feels like you're stronger in your next run.
Cons of Balance, Hero, and Permanent Upgrades
As the run goes on, enemies feel a little bit bullet-spongy and deal too much damage. Slipping up can prove fatal most of the time, as it's usually enough to kill you immediately. The temporary upgrade system (not with your characters) are called scrolls: they range from stupidly overpowered (deflection shield) into being nearly useless and detrimental to pick up (brutal gloves). This can be very frustrating and not fun to deal with late in into a run, as being punished for picking up upgrades or making the game too easy is unfair to the game experience. I'm not going to count there being only two characters as a downside, as more will inevitably come, but the issue lies in their complexity: this can be really confusing for new players and a major turn-off. The permanent upgrade system is flawed in my opinion, too. The later on upgrades require stupid high amounts of essence, which can turn a game in which you get stronger every playthrough into more of a grindfest than anything else. 

Miscellaneous Pros:
The devs are [i] very [/i] active. They usually fix bugs within a few days, and will email you as well to make sure you're satisfied with any fixes they've made. I have a lot of hope for the dev team and this game! :)
Steam achievements right out the gate is fun and offers some more things to do other than the in-game challenges.
Miscellaneous Cons:
The multiplayer balancing is a little iffy. Enemies with x3 health on a two-player run?
If you die on multiplayer, you have to wait until the ENTIRE STAGE is over before respawning. Not level, STAGE. Meaning that your teammates will have to deal with a beefed-up boss by themselves.
The translations in this game are a little confusing and inaccurate sometimes. Not a huge issue as you can mostly make out the meaning, but a small issue for the mono-lingual among us.

Overall, I highly recommend this game. A great casual experience and lots of detail for the more hardcore players as well. For only $12, the amount of content in this game will deliver. If you have no problem with the issues above (and they'll probably be fixed or changed) then this game will easily deliver a solid 20+ experience for you.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
First off, Thank you Mr. Streamer (aka Woolie, big Risk of Rain 2 d00d) for giving this game the limelight for 10 minutes. It took only 2 for me to be interested in it simply by the title of the video, combined with it being on sale. Secondly, I'd like to scold the fuck out of Steam for not informing be about shit regarding this game because holy fuck is it an absolute blast, but more on that in the actual review.

Anyways, Gunfire Reborn is and will be an amazing indie title (if I'm allowed to call it that) for a while simply because of what it does and how it achieves it. Going back to Woolie's video, this has the same fast-paced dodge n weave n blast n bash style gameplay of Doom / Quake, the replayability of Risk of Rain 1/2 and Enter the Gungeon and Binding of Isaac, on top of the weapon uniqueness of the Borderlands series. With the addition of extra hidden chests and "vaults" that can give you that extra edge to come up on top with special power-up scrolls, new perks to your weapons, and even bonuses to existing stats and abilities, it's easy to think you're completely overpowered, until you hit some kind of brick wall.

You will be on your toes in a matter of entering the first area after the Tutorial, needing to go between finding cover to not get hit and dodging between enemy attacks as you hit them. I managed to get to the first area's boss right after the tutorial, only to die after getting him down to a sad 10%-ish heath and dying, netting me an achievement. It only took another 4 hours of trying, and trying, and dying, and trying before finally getting Lu Wu down and defeated, only to die in a matter of seconds after entering World 2 Area 1. On top of that, multiplayer scaling is a little nutty, with the first boss's health boosting from 8k to 24k with 1 extra, then up to 40k with a second extra. Thankfully, you don't have to share and fight over loot in this game, so when you open a blue scroll chest, everyone gets a unique scroll. (Plus, if a friend needs a certain gun or if you want to be generous, replace a New Gun with an Old Gun your holding, then replace New with Old once again, so you can drop the New Gun for your teammates to enjoy.)

Replayability is exactly like those previous three games I mentioned earlier. In GR, you have set Worlds that you must progress through various Areas, each Area containing separate Sections. There are 4 Worlds, each World has 4 Sections, with 1 final Boss Section afterwards, and each Section can have anywhere between 1-4 Areas. Each Area has a chance to contain cracks in the wall that, when shot with any weapon, can open a portal to a Vault, leading you to a secret puzzle Area that allows you to fight / wavedash your way to extra Power Scrolls. It's easy to see which Areas you've been through in past Journeys before, but sometimes you go through a different doorway and the new Area is from a different part of the sequence from the previous Journeys. Much like Enter the Gungeon, you might be in the same Chamber as before, but the rooms are spread out and connected differently every time, with different chests, secret rooms, shop items, and boss(es).

To combat this challenge, you have Weapons and Power Scrolls. Weapons range from a starter revolver, to a grenade launcher, to a wooden crossbow, to a tiny dragon that spits fire, to a black hole launcher, to a power glove that shoots a beam of lightning, each with unique and varying stat bonuses that all tie in to a big giant message of, "If you keep me and build around me, everything will cease to exist and nothing can stop you." Combine the weapon perk of, "Land 3 consecutive crits, gain 200% Lucky Hit Chance." with a Power Scroll that states, "Bonus 200% Crit Damage, but -50% damage when not hitting a crit." so you can literally take a weapon doing 50 damage per tick, and reach crazy highs of roughly 2k damage per tick, all the while extra bonuses of elemental damages and bonuses from the Goblet. It's absolutely nutty, but hurts like ripping off a wax tab when something nukes you out of existence and ends your Journey.

TL;DR - Shoot, Loot, Doot, Brute?, Cute, is fun, eat bun, can't wait for more this review is done.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I have played this game nonstop for three days and have no inclination of stopping. The game play loop of this rogue-lite is extremely addicting and only get better with time, becoming even more fast paced and fun after multiple runs and upgrades.

Despite being early access, I have only encountered two major 'bugs'.
 - Sometimes during Lu Wu's charge attack, the player can backpedal and prevent Lu Wu from attacking, keeping him charging until the player can kill the boss or messes up the backpedal. This may not be much of a bug, but it was most likely not an intended feature.
- Only twice in my 37 hours of play so far, have I experienced massive lag down to around 7 FPS that lasts until I die or pause the game for a significant amount of time. The rarity of these FPS drops make me unsure of the cause, but they did seem to worsen if i faced the direction of where I spawned in the stages of the 3rd area.

Again, despite these few gripes, I love this game and would recommend it to anyone who loves upgrade progression, fast paced first person shooters, and a good challenge (still have not beaten the final boss).

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
[b] [u] A FIRST IMPRESSION REVIEW [/u]

I don't leave reviews for many games, but I felt like I had to leave one for this game. At the time of writing this I put a bit over an hour into the game and while that's not a lot of time every minute of it was pretty enjoyable so I decided to list a couple of the pros and cons that I've found so far.

[list] [u] Pros: [/u]
[*] A lot of the guns can be useful, with different inscriptions on guns each run, the same weapon can be completely different from an earlier run you had.
[*] Even for being in early access there is quite a bit of different passives that really give the game it's "rogue-like" feel.
[*] The gunplay feels fun, while the guns don't pack the boom and effects of a game like DOOM or Destiny, it's still fun in it's own right.
[*] Going back to the guns, I've had a few runs where I just had a hell of a time choosing between some of the guns because I just couldn't decide between a gun with really good inscriptions that I liked using, or trying out a new gun that seemed really cool and could've been really sick with some of the passives I had.
[*] It's co-op though completely capable of being played solo.
[/list]

[list] [u] Cons: [/u]
[*] With the developer being located in Hong Kong, the English is hit or miss sometimes, though this isn't really a big deal.
[*] There is only two characters to play at this time, though I imagine more will be added later on.
[*] You may not understand what passives and abilities quite do at first with the wording being a bit strange, but this can be easily figured out by just playing around with it a bit.
[*] There is items you can get to fix this, but the starting moving speed in my honest opinion is very slow, which can make fighting the first boss and dodging attacks from enemies harder, though I'm sure with more time I can overcome this.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Gunfire Reborn is the rare gem that feels like it shouldn't be nearly as addictive as it is.  Generaly roguelite shooters make the mistake of being afraid to have powerful synergies in their builds.  This is understandable from a design pov because shooters don't feel good when success is balanced by back end numbers more than by twitch skill.  Reborn instead allows for interesting and fun builds to change your play style.

The Good:
Visual design is unique and interesting.
Enemies feel fair for the most part.
Levels are well crafted for the game play that's here.
Weapons feel good and the ammo economy is surprisingly well balanced.  You cant use nothing but your rocket launcher but running out of ammo and being stuck with you pea shooter is rare if you don't use two guns that share an ammo type.
Game is entirely able to be played solo.
KB/M controls are very smooth and totally rebindable.  Indie games and even sometimes AAA studios have an infuriating habit of making WASD unchangeable but not here fellow EDSF peeps you're all good here!

The Bad:
Localization and translation is very poor and needs to be addressed quickly.  I'm aware these kinds of things don't ultimately effect game play but the game struggles with some item and skill descriptions because the English grammar is almost indecipherable.  In addition to that poor grammar just gives the game an amateurish vibe it doesn't deserve. The game play here isn't amateur.  This is a professional game that's quite impressive and it shouldn't be held back by poor translation.

The Meh:
Game desperately needs a bunch of cosmetic customization.  It's a roguelite playing a pre-made character but it's also MP and cosmetic progression is a must if the game wants to have a long tail (no pun intended...ok maybe a little).
The dash ability needs a bit more range.  You don't want your dash over powered of course but you want it to feel impactful there's a significant CD on the dash so it seems reasonable to allow it to have a bit more oomph.
Movement speed is quite slow.  Like very very slow.  This is unusual for a game like this.  There are progression items and scrolls to improve it but it feels a bit too slow at default and I don't think it's necessary.

An absurd value here and well worth supporting.

There are some bugs and some delay when you are fighting the bosses but they will get fixed. 

In other words this game may be an early access but it's tons of fun and it's worth it 100%. Developers steal themselves selling this game for only 10 euro.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I did not expect to enjoy this game as much as I do already, and am very excited to see how it develops in the future. 

It's a fantastic first-person rogue-lite FPS. Solid style, tight controls, varied levels, and an impressive variety of weapons really sells this as an already well thought out game. I only hope this game gets the love and attention is so sorely deserves. 

I hope my friend gets this soon so I can try out the co-op with him, but the solo experience has been *incredibly* solid. No crashes, no apparent bugs (minus a few jank clips into geometry and weird enemy pathing), and solid performance with no real hits to FPS count. 

Absolutely a game I can recommend, and I will keep dipping in and out to see if I can find my way to the end.

PS thanks to Woolie on youtube for recommending this game in a video
