title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is mechanically similar to Dead Cells: you go through levels, die, progress your character, and repeat.; similarly, there are finite weapons with varied modifiers. 

In terms of gunplay, it's pretty similar to Shadow Warrior 2 but less bullet spongey. It's an FPS and you shoot and dash; you also click on people and you click on their heads. Enemies *will* feel bullet spongier during co-op play as the game scales enemy health based on the number of players. 

The enemy design is pretty good too - it feels like you actively need to know what the enemies are and what they do. The first stage doesn't really do this justice, but the second and third are really fun.

And the bosses. Man, the bosses. The first boss is somewhat generic but still action packed. The second boss shocked me. And the last boss was just a pure moment of 'oh shit'. The boss design was an unexpected surprise.

There's only 3 stage types throughout the game (at the time of writing); however, the second two stage types really feel more open and varied than the first.

Sometimes runs are dictated by RNG drops and you can get screwed over pretty early, but usually that's shown pretty early on and runs aren't always that long.

Also the game has some poor English translations at the moment. Still, these translations don't detract from the overall experience and I don't think I ran into a gameplay related issue due to faulty translation. 

TL;DR: A really enjoyable roguelite that's pretty damn cheap. Still in early access but I've had a couple hours of enjoyment thus far. Really hope to see more heroes, bosses and stages.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This is an addictive mix of FPS loot and shoot with rouglike aspects with a permanent progressive leveling system that gives you advantages along each playthrough to help you get closer to beating bosses and eventually beating the game. I have yet to beat the game, though I can say with each death and each progression I am having genuine fun with the game. Of course, I do have some gripes about somethings, but I am sure it is either designed intended or that this game is still early access.

The Story:

I believe there isn't necessarily a story but there are some small hints as to explain the reoccurance of enemies. As for the characters, you play as a roaming feline who goes by Crown Prince, accompanied by his demolition gun happy partner Ao Bai as they proceed to fight their way through trials and challenges with the ability to never truly die and find out what is the root cause of this phenomena.

The GOOD:

-There are currently two characters to play with, each with their own hero abilities but a permanent progressive system. Ao Bai is unfortunately level locked at 30 (meaning you are stuck with the Crown Prince until level 30). Bright side is that Crown Prince's progressive system get's carried over to Ao Bai. the only thing you need to unlock wtih Ao Bai is his hero abilities.

-A permanent progressive system. With each death, learn a little more to help you combat the challenges. Enemies drop Soul Essence which are the currency used to level up your hero, giving them helpful advantages with each playthrough. Heroes have their own abilities to unlock, but keep universal abilities when unlocked first time around. You don't lose your abilities on death, but add into the stuff you find throughout your dungeon runs.

-Loot and Shoot. While it may feel like a hero shooter, this is a rouglike game, meaning that with the weapons and items you find will give you plus or negative advantages through your runs. Upon death, you do not keep these weapons (aside from the hero's starting weapon) or items and must find them again with progressive advancing.

-Co-op: This game allows matchmaking and invite co-op. While there are only two heroes currently (with some more planned) you can join up with buddies to run the dungeons together or when you hit level 10, you can join in lobbies and help out struggling players.

- Devs listen: The devs are humble and very attentive to player problems. There is so much passion and care into this game and the devs are open to hearing problems and feedback and will work to fix the issues. Great for a healthy playerbase and some integrity that some companies aren't really known for.

Now for the BAD:

-Enemies hit like trucks. It almost makes me feel like this game was intended to be a bit of a movement shooter as well and while you have the ability to dash out of the way, if you get hit, say good bye to your shields and your health. I don't find this much of an issue, but it will bring frustration to those that progress a little further. I have a gripe with a certain group of enemies. Aside from the bigger ones that tend to rush you down, there are some that keep back and have all the movement to them and weapons that home in on you, breaking your shields and then downing you without so much problems. I feel that the homing snipers need to be actual shot your can avoid and the homing ones being later into the game rather than right off the bat. They are the only enemies I have an issue with. Cover excluded.

-I don't find this as a bad thing, but it can be a turn off to most players for whatever reason. Levels are procedurally generated. Each playthrough will have different rooms in a dungeon stage, complete with a boss at the end. While I find it refreshing to keep interest, some players feel it is bland and not unique to games to have procedural generated content. It makes no sense to me, but that's something that I feel should be pointed out.

-Some enemies will ignore collision with their shots. Even when you take cover, some enemies shoot through the cover and either nick you or you come close to being hit. I've had this happen with the sniper enemies more than anything else. 

-Bosses have the health pool of a raid party. Upon being intimidating at first glance, you'll notice that the first boss has a health pool that you can't help but feel you need an entire raid party to deal with. Bosses hit like trucks and it takes some doing to defeat them. You can beat them solo depending on what you have currently, but with the game in early access, there are some issues that bosses end up doing that screw you over more than intended. In the end, the bosses are designed for four players to take on and while it is doable with single player, I feel bosses should be scaled on solo runs with the progression that you made in your leveling.

- Translations: While you can understand most things, this isn't a game with english as it's primary language. Translations are from Cantonese to English and may sound off when reading item descriptions. The devs are actively working on making them understandable so if something sounds a little off, just know that they are working on fixing the translation.

To sum up, this game is pretty addictive and while I have yet to gather friends to play it, I find that the game does have its' heart in the right place of where it wants to go with a passionate dev team behind it. The game is a rouglike hero shooter with loot and shoot to scratch that replayability itch with challenging bosses and dungeon runs. There is even an elite mode where they are tougher and numurous if you feel that you got too powerful for the game and want greater rewards.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This is a pretty fun game for $12. The movement is reletively slower than some other roguelike games, but it makes up for it with the rewarding feedback of headshots. This review is written as of 5/30/2020 in Early Access stages of the game. Take what I say with a grain of salt. Or with the whole damn salt shaker.

Pros:
- I haven't encountered any game breaking bugs, or even some small bugs for an early access game.
- I love this kind of art style, and it works well with a game like this.
- Lots of guns for an early access game! Of coarse you don't get to keep them after you die, hopefully you can find another on another run, but there are a lot of weapons for an early access game like this.
- Skill tree in the rogueLITE is cool. I like roguelikes, but I hate not being able to hold onto any progression what-so-ever. So the skill tree helps me get my progression fix. 

Cons:
- There are only 2 characters! I am hoping to see more characters in the near-ish future of this games development cycle. 
- Some of the buff's you can get while you play don't feel too impactful, But I didn't get too far into the game to notice some of the buffs even working. (only got a little bit beyond 1st boss).
- Some of the indiana Jones sections (rolling rocks) are a little overwhelming when it comes the number of rocks it spawns. 
Suggestions for Dev's if they read this
- Work with your multi-lingual community to get other languages in the game. Also to fix some of the "broken English" that I've been noticing. 
- Add some characters soon! I'd love to see some more characters added. 
- I hope you don't end up under chinese rule. I want to see more work like this come from your studio, and that could be in jeopardy if chinese controlled. 

Liberate Hong Kong, Revolution of our time!
- Felan, Some American.

review:
Got this game on the recommendation of Woolie but really not enjoying it.

The movement is slow and floaty. Dashes take you a pitiful distance meaning you often can't do anything meaningful about your situation. Enemies quickly turn into bullet sponges that take a dozen headshots to kill (you can hear your shots hitting the weak spot). Maybe it's more fun with more people or when you overcome a certain level of grind but until you do, you're stuck replaying the same content with the same weedy weapons.

Graphically it's polished in its blocky, low poly style. Everything works. I just sadly don't enjoy it.
developer_response: Hi, thanks for your helpful suggestion, we will think about what adjustment to make and try our best to meet your expectation!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I haven't had the chance to play this game much so far but it is very fun.

The only real complaint I have is that in the middle of a fight it is kinda difficult to tell that you are taking damage. Specifically, I find that I rarely notice that my shield is down. I realise that when it brakes there is a noise and it creates a breaking effect on the screen but I found that in a fight I don't notice it. I think that the current noise of your shield breaking mixes in too easily with the other sounds in the game and makes it hard to notice. I think having a more distinguishable sound will greatly improve this issue. I also think that having a noise that lets the player know that the shield is recharging would help as well. There may be one but I didn't notice it.

Apart from that small issue, I think that the game is really fun and I look forward to seeing how it progresses in the future.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
New Review After Update - 5/10 - For 2020 it's bad graphics feels like it could have been made 15 years ago, combine that with mediocre gameplay.  It is fun to kill a little time but winds up being quite simple and repetitive.  Its an interesting mashup roguelite and FPS .  I think with some refinement, a bit more guns, characters, some balancing and a bit more content it could be really fun.

Old Review - 1/10 - Unplayable currently due to lack of Vertical Inversion for the mouse.  No self-respecting PC FPS game does not have inverted axis support, it's like the authors have never played a popular FPS game before.  I really want to play this game, but I'm an old school PC gamer which uses inversion.  I am eager to try this game out when they do add this support.  If you're like me and read this, don't waste your money (yet) until they add this support.  I will update my feedback once they do add it.
developer_response: We have added Mouse Inversion function in our latest update, we hope you will like it. Feel free to contact us for any other problems. Thanks for your feedback!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
It's exactly as it looks from the gameplay you can find online, except with some rare game breaking bugs.

My run just ended because i was walking next to a wall towards the entrance to the next room. A shotgunner in said room shot me through that wall without any line of sight and one-shot me.

Had a blast until then, though !

Game doesn't run super smooth, music gets repetitive, balance might be a bit off (i'm just 4 hours in, can't say for sure yet), but all of that is to be expected this early in development.

Guns are varied, well designed, sound great and look awesome, feel amazing to reload etc...
Upgrades are also varied and complement each other to form weird builds and it's lots of fun to find all those combinations. I just wish we had more control over our upgrade path because most things just randomly drop or come from chests with a choice from 3 items of a category which might contain 8+ items, so sometimes you're just gonna have bad runs because you only find the weaker ones early on.

You can't be carried by your gear however, as all upgrades improve your guns/grenades/abilities which still require you to land them properly and even have special conditions like requiring you to land headshots to benefit from them, which is great !

Game is hard however. As said previously, you can get destroyed insanely fast by enemies. It's intended to push you to use proper placement, prioritize targets, manage resources and all to survive. A side effect of that is that sometimes weird AI behavior or unfair room/enemy spawn combinations can (rarely !) end a run instantly.

I trust those issues will get fixed soon, and the game is so cheap anyway that you won't regret purchasing it.
The game also has poor translations (devs are apparently based in Hong Kong), but since i bought the game (yesterday) they already updated it to fix some spelling and wording mistakes, so that too will improve with time.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
A great addition to the growing indie developed FPS genre. Gunfire Reborn, at release of Early Access has relatively few bugs and hours of engaging gunplay. I experienced the game solo and with one friend in Co-Op mode, and got through nearly to the second boss after a few runs.  I am a little concerned about how crowded the first stages will feel with a full party of four players, as even with two we sometimes were feeling cramped. Some balancing issues will need to fixed in later patches, including the viability of some upgrades and weapons feeling really lackluster.
I am excited to see where the development of this game leads, and would like to see a roadmap of what is planned in advance.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Today I woke up to see Gunfire Reborn, a game I had never heard of, on the front page of steam for about $10

Today I spent 7 hours straight playing Gunfire Reborn blowing my expectations out of the water

Best way I could describe the game in simple terms is a randomly generated combat gameplay of borderlands down to elemental weapons and character specific action skills, meets the looting and progression of dead cells with stacking item modifiers and using a special currency dropped by enemies for permanent unlocks. And if that sounds fun to you, what do you have to lose with a maximum pricetag of $12? Also did I mention it's multiplayer too? Because it is so bring a friend or 2 and it's damn fun!

Some cons would be a few balance issues with some guns feeling like trash, movement speed is pretty slow especially when carrying anything that isn't a pistol, a few enemies being a bit too unforgiving killing you from max health in less than a second or you asking yourself "wait what even killed me?"(looking at you longbow men and bird bandits). And maybe a bit shy of content at only 2 playable characters and a fairly small pool of overall weapons which quite a few of them are pretty trash as stated above. Surely these will be ironed out with balance and new content updates in the future so hopefully some day the cons part of this review will become irrelevant.

Now if you'll excuse me, time to start another run

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
[h1] Summary [/h1]
A really fun loot-and-shoot that shows a lot of promise. It takes elements from all of your favorites in the rogue-lite, loot-and-shoot, and broader competitive FPS genres and melds them, quite successfully, into one title. At $11.99, this is a steal, especially if you have friends you can play it with. 

I purchased the game in the infancy of its Early Access period. If the team forges a good relationship with the community, there is the potential for this game to truly be an all-time legend in the Early Access program. 

For an Early Access game, it runs remarkably well. So far, I've only run into one bug with a boss resetting his position during combat--nothing run-ending; just annoying. The game is stable and playable. 

[b] Pros [/b]
+ Easy-to-play/hard-to-master core mechanics.
+ Permanent upgrades between runs in addition to randomly-rolled weapons, skills, and talents that appear in each run. There is a healthy amount of variety that should always lead to each game truly feeling like a "New Adventure."
+ Challenging, but not frustratingly so. Combat with each individual enemy matters. The bosses, though quite tough, are very dynamic encounters.
+ The game launched with 60+ weapons, 100+ skills, a massive permanent upgrade tree, and three unique ascension trees for each character. 
+ The ability to unlock challenge levels within each level to risk it all for better gear. 
+ The weapon variety is fantastic, allowing for different types of play patterns. 
+ Weapon tooltips give a lot of information, showcasing the level of complexity and depth in making your build. (Initially, this will be a lot of information for you to get on the fly, but you'll get used to it and come to appreciate it.)

[b] Cons [/b]
- A forgettable soundtrack. 
- Not much diversity in level design. You'll quickly feel like "I've been here before." 
- There are definitely some translation/localization issues. Usually, it's harmless, but there are some tooltips that are confusing. 

[b] Mehs [/b]
- Currently, there are only two characters. One of them is locked behind quite a few hours of grinding. I attribute this to the Early Access stage. I wouldn't hold it against the game, but I felt it prudent to mention this to perspective buyers.

The upgrades of Risk of Rain, the guns of Borderlands, and the format of Doom make for a spectacular combination that will provide you with endless amounts of fun.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
The game has serious potential but I do not recommend it until some serious changes are made. I don¬¥t know why everyone is avoiding commenting on the serious flaws of the game. 

The structure of the game is that of Risk of Rain, where you have a run that progressively gets more difficult as you progressively get more powerful. The first sequence, however, is almost impossible to complete even for someone with thousands of hours in shooters like myself. 

Even on the first stage in the first map, getting hit by one attack from an enemy does between 1/4 and 1/2 of your total health, and that's just one monster. On the third level you run into a spear throwing enemy whose attacks can be difficult to dodge when you're paying attention to other enemies or if they rush you, and their attack literally does 1/2 of your health. In this game, the only way to regain health is to either buy a health pack that you CAN ONLY BUY ONCE and that only heals 30% OF YOUR HEALTH. And you only run into this vendor once or twice per 6 stages. Otherwise you can very rarely get an enemy to drop health but this has happened to me maybe twice in over an hour of playing this game. 

The biggest problem is the scaling of the enemies. They get incredibly strong incredibly fast and you are not at a stage to counter them. Maybe later in the game when you have done a ton of runs and have progressed through their leveling system that increases your base stats might you have a chance. Otherwise, getting hit ensures defeat. The only way to have a chance is to have serious RNG luck on your side. If you don't get a good enough weapon or good enough scroll drops, you have no serious chance of making it very far which is a disappointing development flaw. 

The first boss is basically impossible. I've beat him 1/5 times, losing on runs where I had a strong kit of weapons and scrolls simply because he is way too freaking powerful. Everytime you die to him, the game mentions that you have a dash and can avoid his abilities, but the dash has a 3-4 second cooldown and when the dude pushes on you, you have no way to dodge his flurry of attacks especially since for his rock throw, the dodge doesnt even get you out of the AOE damage so you physically cannot dodge the ability unless you have a certain scroll of you manage to position yourself behind a pillar to block the attack which is hard to do when he runs so much faster than you and is basically on top of you the entire fight. 

One attack from the first boss almost kills you so if you are missing any health at all, you're instantly dead. Are you kidding me? How is that a fun mechanic within the first 10 minutes of the game? And on top of that, there arent health pots so if you get hit once and dont die and manage to regain your shield, the next time you get hit you're dead. To make matters worse, he has so much health and goes to regenerate his shield shortly after you break it, so it takes such a long time of wearing him down before you can kill him. Additionally, these pillars people mention that you can use to avoid his damage randomly break, letting through the remaining damage of that attack without you having any way to avoid it. I have also had this boss kill me by jumping through (not over or around) but through the pillar which is absurd.

The only way I was able to kill this boss was by getting a lucky scroll that gave me three dashes which allowed me to successfully stay so far away from him he couldnt kill me easily. Yet he still killed me once and I only beat him thanks to the revive mechanic that works once.

All in all, I am incredibly disappointed with this game because it has so much potential and frankly feels so good from a gun and abilities stance to play but there are serious developmental flaws with the leveling and scaling of the game.
developer_response: Thanks for your feedback, most of issues you point out do exist, and we will fix them and optimize the game in the following update. Please give us more time.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
i echo the words of most others: Replayability of Risk of Rain 2, mechanics of Borderlands, and gameplay of Doom. that isnt an exaggeration. Rogue-lite aspects are finding weapons (which are all creative as hell. for example, wrist mounted tiny dragon that acts like a flamethrower,) upgrades to your core abilities and elemental damage at the end of every arena, and scrolls that buff you and occasionally have downsides. Its a rogue-LITE because there is permanent progression in the from of talents. Stuff like ammo capacity, health/shields, and some special ones like getting a free weapon at the start of each run or the ability to shoot purple walls to unlock secret dungeons.

The Borderlands in it comes with the elemental damage mechanic, general gunplay, weapon stats, and the enemy health. There are multiple elements that work with one another for beeg damage (for example, corrosive damage + fire damage = explosion.) all weapons drop with random stats and modifiers, and once you buy the upgrade for it, intrinsic perks (for example, pistols can drop with a 25% chance to instakill on headshot.) Each enemy is unique, and have the health pool of an enemy from BL (hard to explain, but thats what it feels like.) There are bosses at the end of each level which require 4 stages to get through, and in all of its glowy fashion, they die in a lootsplosion.

The Doom comes from the arena to arena combat, with a heavy emphasis on staying mobile and dodging whenever you can. A bit unforgiving at times, but wheres the fun in easiness?

TLDR; this game is the bastard child of some of the genre respective greats of our time and is incredible. plus, early access, meaning more content!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is going to be big.

Lets get to the reason why you will love this game, and get addicted. 

- Replay Value - Think of all the amazing roguelites, risk of rain, binding of isaac this game will keep you coming back, some runs gives you lemons and you need to make lemonaid.
- Fast paced 
- High frames per second and optimized 
- Quick thinking skills needed, make sure you put your quake hat on.
- Variety, no run is the same and you unlock new things as you go along.
- Weapons are soooooo satisfying to shoot, the sound and feel you will love it. 
- Great art style
- Devs are listening and communicating well, write to them in game, literally send them feedback inside the game.
- Challenging until you work out the mechanics and still you will be hard pressed in some places because of the randomness.


If you love shooters like borderlands and like the satisfaction shooting interesting weapons, the reload sounds, the way the guns feel, this game will make you smile, you need to use your awareness skills, situational perception, using pillars and the map to guard yourself as well to dodge things.

Mechanics, your hero has a special and a grenade slot, and it's different for each hero this will only get better the more heros they add, you also have dash on a small cooldown to dodge attacks which you will need to do a lot.

The items you are given mid run are random and you can get god runs or get really bad luck and need to work hard, but even things like your basic dash can be buffed by random items you pick up, reducing its cooldown or % chance to refresh it on use, those types of things. Items have elemental damage on them or other interesting effects so each run you kind of need to make a build as you go with what you find, there is also things such as in slay the spire, where you give up certain health to get special items. There's weapon crafters you meet mid game to spend money on to buff your current weapon or a shop keeper that sells you things you might want, again.. all random.

It's so far really fun, it's cheap and you have nothing to lose but you WILL have fun. Good Luck! Happy fragging.

Additional info 

- Headshots, if you got good aim you will do well, everytime you hit the head you will get a sound to tell you.

- Shoot vases on the floor, you could get health if you're low, but it's rare.

- There is an ingame timer on the top left of the screen to see how fast you are going if you're into that sort of thing, this game will be huge with speed runners.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
I'm a big roguelike fan especially for the fps roguelikes, Ziggurat, Strafe, Eldrich, heavy bullets etc. Gunfire Reborn might be the best fps roguelike I've ever played and I've only beaten the first boss so far. It just plays soooo smooth and feels so good, all the guns are fantastic. It is also really unique both in it's aesthetic and systems. 

The combat is unlike anything ive played before, your character is very slow to begin with and dodging becomes about careful timing. Your character is also very underpowered to start with and makes you earn every little boost, picking up a double dash ability is a huge deal in this game. But even being slow and underpowered with only the starting gun you and your enemies are already satisfingly leathal. Each enemy explodes into different kinds of pickups upon death and progression is constant. 

There is a novel mechanic where by you gather a secondary currency during the run which can be used to buy permanent upgrades for future runs OR can be used to revive you on death. 

This game is quite difficult but grinding to level up is great because of the clever progression system and the fact that the game is just so crunchy and juicy to play.

review:
This game has good potential. In it's current state, it is extremely playable. Very few bugs that really don't affect gameplay a great deal. This game feels like it is in early access due to the amount of content and how polished it is. The only real issue (that isn't a big issue) is that the text appears to be translated to English and reads a little weird sometimes... easily understandable though.

Buy this game, support the devs, get more content. This game has a future.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Great game. It really is. Just a few things i'd suggest though.
Please for the love God (or of any deity you worship). Please adjust enemies with homing projectiles.
Make some enemies stagger on headshots/crits.
Allow the player to be more mobile. Maybe double jumps and or starting with 2 dashes instead of 1.
Fix enemies hitboxes. headshots tend not to register sometimes.
And most importantly. Buff the wild hunt shotgun.
This is just my opinion though. I only had 6 hours of play time when I made this post.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
[b]Gameplay: [/b]  
You can select one of the hero‚Äôs, each with his/her‚Äôs different strength and weaknesses
You have to shoot your way through different stages until you meet a boss.
Along the way you collect coins, ammunition, Guns from killed enemies or chests, coins can be used for upgrades at vendors.
Each enemies has different combat styles and the AI is not to bad in attacking you and trying to avoid of getting hit.
With progression in the game you also earn Talent points, these can be used to further boost your abilities.
[b]Graphics: [/b]
Good graphics and animations are great and a perfect mix between cartoon and realism.
[b]Sounds: [/b]   
Pleasant background music and punchy sound effects, but nothing special to it.
[b]Features: [/b]
A very extensive talent tree to help you progress
A armory that shows all available weapons and the stats for each one
Player information give you a nice statistic on your gameplay
Multiplayer
[b]Things I did not like: [/b]
The ‚Äúdash‚Äù feature take really time to get used to in order to doge attacks or enemy fire.
It‚Äôs a very short dash and on a pretty long cooldown if you in a middle of a fight (I know, it‚Äôs just a few seconds but it feels like an eternity)
Boss fights take a long time to get used to and once you died, you start at the beginning of the level and need to clean all again before try to kill the boss again, the grinding can get a bit tiresome, but it does mix it up and each run is a bit different.
Some balance features, if you run in group and your team members die, the game does not balance and adjust that you maybe suddenly play alone and not with your friend anymore.
[b]In a summary [/b]
Gameplay 	8/10 
Graphics 	       8/10
Sounds		6/10

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Vaguely feels like a stylized roguelike DOOM(2016) 
-This game is extremely promising, ive been having a blast, its very polished.
-Gunplay is almost perfect,  weapons feel weighted and impactful
-Art direction is stylized and very appealing, enemies and bosses are varied and memorable with pretty environments to go with
-considerably challenging in a good way. every death feels like my fault. (15 hours of runs to reach what I assume is the current final boss twice , havent beaten him yet tho)
-tons of loot to grind for and look forward too , the build possiblities are really fast with the different things weapons can roll with.
-----------------------------
Only thing I can say is to up the base movement speed by about 15%-20%. the enemies should also still be able to track the player same as they do at the original speed, i just think the game could use an overal slight speed buff.
or perhaps movement speed should not vary based on weapon size, tho realistic, the games movement feels best when using the "shuriken" Kunai .

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
If you could imagine Risk of Rain 2 and Nuclear Throne walked in to a bar one evening, totally unsuspecting of one another.  But they catch each other's eye from across the room.  The unlikely suspects strike up conversation and have a few drinks.  The night goes by and they decide to go home together, WHAM BAM GUNFIRE REBORN.

Seriously, its a great mix of progression and rogue-like/lite elements that plays clean and satisfying for the state of development that it is currently in.  

I've had a good amount of gameplay with minimal hiccups or bugs.  The guns feel good, and there is a ton of replayability.

However, keep in mind that this is clearly in early development but shows lots of promise in my opinion.  With good support, this game will be much much more.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is Immortal Redneck, with Risk of Rain 2 and Hades influences.  I see people mentioning Borderlands, but the guns aren't procedurally generated, which means that each and every one is unique, but designed by someone.

At its core, the game runs like Immortal Redneck.  You choose a character with its own abilities (right now limited to a cat and a dog), get a basic starting pistol, and you're off to the races, fighting through different temples collecting cash until you inevitably die, and go back to the beginning to upgrade and start again.

The Risk of Rain 2 part comes in with the co-op and items that you get.  I understand Immortal Redneck also had items (scrolls), but those could be positive or negative, and these are pretty much all positive buffs to your character, which is more in-tune with Risk of Rain 2's standard chests (not the Lunar pods, though).  Level progression feels more similar to RoR as well, with each level culminating in a boss before you travel to the next biome.

The Hades influences are very evident in the goblets (these would be boons in Hades) which allow you to upgrade one aspect of your character at a time, be it elemental, through your magic orb, or through your grenade.

I don't have a ton of time in the game, but I bought it today and these are simply initial impressions.  If you're a fan of rogue lite games at all, I'd say this is a worthy buy.  It's $10 at the time of posting this, and definitely worth the money.

If the game changes for the worse or better, I'll update this review accordingly, but at the time of writing, I'd say this is worth your money.  It even has co-op for up to 4 players, which I have not tried yet, but plan to later today.  Considering that you could buy four copies for $40 and have a good time with your friends, this is one to consider.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is tons of fun! I've been playing tons almost since launch! I highly recommend it, especially if you enjoyed playing Borderlands with friends. It has a slightly similar feel to it, but it is definitely unique in many ways with the talents you unlock from chests and all of the different enemies you encounter. It's really awesome to discover new guns with different enhancements on them. Gunplay is very satisfactory and you find different items on each run. No run feels the same. Only thing I would suggest is later on adding more characters and more bosses as the game goes on. I have also experienced a glitch where I can't see my friends' gun textures, they show up as black silhouettes, but that's to be expected just a few days after launch. So far my friends and I have reached boss 2 but been unable to beat it. It's nice and challenging but the little rewards you get at the end of each run definitely keep you playing and continuing to do runs! 
TLDR: Great gunplay, amazing for playing with friends, rewarding and doesn't feel super upsetting when you die, would love more characters and more bosses to be added as the game matures! Anyone complaining about the difficulty of the game is just mad they can't beat it in 2 runs. Games are supposed to be a little challenging!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is extremely fun and I hope they do more with it. It's sad to see the negative reviews based around a function that was immediately added to the game and people complaining about difficulty. This is supposed to be a challenge and you can feel it the deeper you go. The more you play, the more talents you get, the further you go next time.

I simply wish the descriptions were better in some cases, but that doesn't ruin the game.

Going forward I hope to see more characters and the like, but if this is it then that's fine. The money was still well spent and worth every cent.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This is like FPS Risk of Rain with Deep Rock Galactic graphics, if you're familiar with those two.

Although as far as I know, RoR does not have persistent passives, where Gunfire Reborn [i]does[/i], so you feel like you are a little stronger after each death.

The shooting mechanics seem good to me, though I'm not an FPS specialist.
A few notes:
Passives/Talents are small, permanent boosts to your character.

Occult Scrolls are big buffs you can find on a given run, but which only affect that run (until Game Over).

There is an active dodge on a ~3s cd.  You can dodge in any direction, including forward for a small speed boost.  Occult Scrolls can affect this.  I found one that was -50% cd.  Another one I found added additional charges to the dodge.  In short, the game has a dodge and knows it, and it expects you to use it.

Headshots/Weakpoints on every enemy.  Usually it's the head, although some tanky enemies have it on their backs.  These ones usually charge you, though, giving you an opportunity to sidestep and shoot them in the back.

Guns have a wide variety, skirting sci-fi and fantasy, although most weapons operate in a satisfying, conventional way.   No guns that produce spiders or that teleport you or that fire projectiles that bounce endlessly around the room.  Or at least, none that I've encountered.   Most just fire a projectile that either hits or explodes.  The most exotic weapon function I've seen so far is with one particular lightning rifle, which fires energy rounds, and has a rclick secondary which spawns a blue orb which increases your damage if you shoot through it. 

You start with a pea shooter with infinite ammo which automatically increases in power to match your least powerful aquired weapon, so it never becomes obselete and you always have it.  You move fastest when you have this "initial weapon" equipped, similarly to how some games have you move faster with a melee weapon out.

Other than your initial weapon, you can only carry two guns, and you lose both on Game Over.

Other than the infinite ammo your starting weapon uses, there are three types of ammunition--Normal, Large and Special.  Every gun you find on any given run will use one of these types, and it will affect the capacity of that weapon.  In general terms, you can carry a lot of Normal, a moderate amount of Large, and a small amount of Special ammo.   There are passives which can increase the max you can carry, and some Occult Scrolls play with ammunition as well.   For ex, I've seen Scrolls which give a chance to double the ammo consumption of a secondary attack while increasing the damage, and one which causes ammo you find to go directly into your magazine without reloading, and another which will refill the weapon you have out with any type of ammunition you encounter rather than the specific type it uses.

There are grenades.  The ones you start with on the Crown Prince character are low damage dot grenades, but if you keep selecting buffs during a run to empower your grenades, they can become very destructive.  They are easy to aim, as they have an obvious telegraph, and they explode into a green AOE pool which harms enemies but not you.  You start off being able to carry 3, but there are passives which can increase this to 8, and there are scrolls which can more than double that.

There is a signature power on a short cd (guessing ~20s?  can b affected by passives/scrolls) that you use with E.  On the Crown Prince character, this makes your character throw a purple orb in a straight line which stuns enemies in a small radius where it impacts.   Shooting enemies frozen in this way increases damage.  Again, there are passives and scrolls which can affect the function of this ability in several different ways, including removing the stun and increasing the damage, increasing the power of the next shot after using it, increased area of effect, and so forth

There are four damage types--Normal, Fire, Electric and Corrosive.  Weapons can either apply the damage type on hit, but some only apply the elemental debuffs for Fire (burning) Electric (+dmg taken) and Corrosive 

Weapons can spawn with mods that increase their damage against enemies suffering from these status effects--sometimes on weapons which don't actually produce them, so there may be situations where it is desireable to apply elemental effects with one weapon and finish them with another.

There are shopkeepers who sell healing, grenades, ammunition and a selection of weapons, and smiths/enhancers who will upgrade weapons you have.

Once you finish a boss, the game saves and you can resume at the beginning of the next area, so you don't have to do an entire run in one sitting.

That's all I can think of.  Good game.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
So, 30 hours in, and i'm just going to post my review of this that I left in the community section, that has improvement recommendations. TL;DR It's an amazing game that needs a bit of work, but is AMAZING so far. 

Hi, i've been playing this with a friend, we're both fans of rogues, i've about 800 hours in Binding of Isaac Rebirth with 100%, and nearly finished Gungeon 100% before checking this out.

So, these are my thoughts about the game so far. Keep that in mind, these are opinions. First off, if the dev is reading this, please do not nerf anything in this game. Don't nerf the bosses, the enemy HP scaling in coop, nothing. Most people I guarantee are used to playing something like borderlands where the game hands you a free win and haven't played something like Binding of Isaac where you are going to die. A lot.

Here is why coop is not broken, or impossible, or whatever. Four players means four times the scrolls. You can drop scrolls. This means with two cat and dog characters, you can make the perfect elemental builds for each of them, about 70% of the time. If you're putting points into crit damage, you understand how busted elemental stuff can be paired with max crits, and with four characters doing elemental/grenade damage, it gets crazy.

There is no '100% win' method, because it's a roguelike, it's not supposed to have one. It's supposed to be punishing, RNG oriented, and designed for replay value. That being said, the more you level up, the less RNG there is. Making the shopkeeper's stuff free, and increasing his inventory, you're nearly twice as likely to get good scrolls.


So... What should be fixed?

Is the game perfect? No, it's not. The low hanging fruit is the translations, which are being addressed. I think there are weird spots in the jumping puzzles that aren't mandatory to be fixed, but should be. You can do all of them without jumping boosting scrolls. My friend and I also have a strange, game breaking texture glitch that's occurred rarely. It isn't game breaking, but it's pretty distracting. I can't say what triggers it.

Meta guns. The lightning gun, the flame thrower, the prism (kunai), the bone worm, these four are very very meta weapons, and they are pretty easy to proc if you want to spawn with them after unlocking them. It's up to the devs to either make the other guns as good, or to just leave them meta, but there's really no point in only having a few viable weapons, since it's so easy to get them, and braindead to farm ammo for them. I am missing four weapons, I can't say how good the rest of the weapons are, I also play as the cat, while my friend plays as the dog, but he seems to agree that the weapons we use are the best. If you get the hawkeye perk, the bow is one of the best one shot weapons in the game, but it's definitely an idealist's weapon.

Scroll rarity/worthless scrolls --

One of the most confusing choices to me was the rarities in which each scroll is in, and why some are even in the game. Of course, I get that some have to be bad, it's normal, but why in this manner? Here's an example : Brutal Gloves. They give you a raw 35% damage buff, and REMOVE CRITS. Crits are the lifeblood of the game, you will not beat the game without them. Raw damage will get you nowhere, and every time I see someone accidentally grab this item, they drop it. So why isn't it a curse? Then, here's an opposite example : Final Judgement! One of the BEST scrolls in the game! It kills enemies at -20% HP, dealing 1,000,000 damage once they reach that threshold, and kills bosses at 10%, which sounds small, but is huge! What's the issue? Final Judgement is a NORMAL scroll. WTF? Why isn't it at least a rare? There are legendaries that are worth less than FJ. Not to mention, the legendaries kind of suck.

Deflection shield makes you take 90% more damage up close, and the opposite when you're far away. 99% of builds are going to be pretty close up, and in world 3, enemies pull you close and encourage you to come closer. It's not a very good item. Should it be changed? No, I think it's a okay item, just not legendary.

There are lots more examples of this, like Gormet being a normal, or "Against the Flow" not just being a curse item (because it sucks), but I don't want to get into that, or only sound negative. I do have an opinion on scrolls that were done perfectly -- the curse scrolls. They're pretty balanced, they're worth taking a chance in getting, none of them are really run-ending, and best of all, they are removable!

As far as tips go, I can only really speak for the cat. You need to be focusing your early upgrades on elemental effects, you need corrosive ready by boss 2, then you need ranged by boss 3. Remember to always search for Vaults and "sacrifice chests" (the red ones, that's what my friend and I call them) and if you're playing coop, SPEC INTO INVINCIBLE REVIVE! It's a great ability, and you can't die while reviving! It's not nearly as broken as it sounds, but it's essential for the third boss in coop. Singleplayer and coop are equal, but the players all need to carry their weight. i don't recommend playing this in matchmaking, just because you want to always trade with your teammates, and this game requires cooperation and strategy.

All in all, I think this is a great game, it could pass for a full game, let alone early access. No DLC BS, just a great rogue, fun as hell too. If this is really you guy's first game, it's sick. I love it so far. I can't wait to see more classes, and please add customization! Time trials would be fun, challenges a-la binding of isaac, maybe a random weapons run or a survival mode to grind souls. I think it's great, and it's changed my views on Early Access.

That being said, i'm playing this game quite a bit in two player, and my friend and I are always down to drag someone onto the battlefield with us, as long as you're a team player. Here's my discord if you want to play.

https://discord.gg/XPXFCCk

That being said, is the game hard in rogue terms? That's hard to say. I personally think it's pretty balanced, but I could easily see the other side of the coin.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Game is pretty good Borderlands-ish Rogue like FPS with a progression system that stays after each run. During the runs you get random upgrades /weapons/scrolls/powers but they are lost after you die or win. Will fill the review out more after I play more. But so far I'm really impressed. Also there is a four person cooperative mode that scales for the number of players when the game starts.

9/10 balls of yarn , 8.5/ 10 Meow's

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is surprisingly stable and polished for being a new Early Access title. I'm not even a huge fan of Early Access or rogue-likes, but I wanted to give this a chance because the gameplay loop and graphics looked good. 

I wasn't disappointed at all. The controls feel tight and the challenge is there. It's definitely meant for you to play through this multiple times to unlock permanent passives to make your next run easier. The closest game to this would be Immortal Redneck which costs about 2 Gunfire Reborns.

The graphical style is also nice. Colorful! I love colors and games that just have a drab brown and green palette are boring to look at.

My only (very minor) gripe with this is the translations to English. A handful here and there aren't completely clear, but for the most part it's not too bad.

I'd easily recommend this to anyone that like first person shooter rogue-likes. It's more polished than more expensive games I've played and it also has online co-op. This came out at a great time for me while I'm waiting for PSO2 to get here.

This is honestly a heavily inspired Borderlands model, So you'll see a lot of similarities. It's a great game, very fun and enjoyable. Can be very difficult at the start as well.

8/10 - Would be better with; Less bugs, More playable characters, Cosmetic unlocks, Wider variety of guns to unlock, More maps/Bosses to play through. However; For a $10-12 game... It's very much worth it.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Incredibly satisfying gameplay, most of the guns feel good (on first use, at least), and the game runs so smoothly it's unreal. Easy to grasp and interesting progression systems both for individual runs and permanent benefits. Enemies are varied enough to keep your attention; and while the bosses may seem overwhelming at first, with a few tries under your belt and a half-decent build, they become a fun but challenging (and sometimes hectic) ebb and flow. Keeping you moving dodging attacks and mobs, cycling weapons for max [b] DEEPS [/b], and [i] hopefully [/i] reviving your friends.
I do very deeply recommend getting some buddies to play with, while the game is very enjoyable on its own, having more people generally means an easier time. Enemies scale up with each additional player, but players can effectively trade weapons and scrolls (in-game modifiers ranging from downright harmful to I AM BECOME DEATH), meaning you can customize builds and create truly ridiculous combos.

The ONLY issue I've had is the few bugs that have been encountered. That being said, this game JUST came out on Early Access and is still very early in development. This is actually the first game I've been invested enough in to do a proper bug report, which has been made incredibly easy with the "feedback" button in the escape menu.

Gunfire Reborn is a gem, and I really can't recommend it enough. I'm so damn excited to see how the developers bring it along.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Hi,

Only played the game for a little bit but I have enjoyed every moment. I picked up this game without any research and had no idea what to expect. This is a fun, enjoyable and chilled game to play either on your own or with friends!

The idea behind the game is to make your way through the levels, killing enemies, unlocking areas, upgrading weapons, upgrading abilities, looting a variety of weapons and killing the end boss to progress to the next level. If you die you go right back to the start and the dungeon you are in changes 'route' so in theory no playthrough should have the same 'route/setting'. You can buy items and upgrades from NPC that are located in the level (which is a nice addition). 

There is a good amount of weapons in the game that have different stats which allow for fun playthroughs. The weapon system is similar in my opinion to Borderland weapons (with the different stats changes etc). All the weapons dropped in game are random.

There is a skill tree that you can upgrade via essence you get from defeating enemies and you can level up your abilities and stats by collecting in-game items (also in game items can boost your characters etc). Skill tree is fun and I would have to unlock all abilities to say whether they work or not etc.

I have no got all the way through the game yet (died on the 2nd phase ha) so not sure how many 'full levels' there are right now.

I would pick this up and just have fun, it's cheap and it offers decent replay value (the levels are pretty hard on solo, not sure if the game increases difficulty based on more players).

These are things I would love to see in the game (some may already be in the game or some may be on the 'upcoming' patches etc).

More maps - (places such as Snow settings, swamp settings, village settings, castle settings, Mountain settings)
Melee weapons - (would love to dual wield swords, use axes, spears, shields etc)
Armour - (I'd like to be able to equip items that boost your hero, head gear, body gear, foot gear etc)
More hero's in the game (more abilities for the hero, at the moment we only have one main ability and a second ability)
Wave defence - (I'd like parts of the game to make you defend an area, you can buy defences such as barries, auto turrets etc to help you and depending on how you perform in the wave defence you get better rewards etc)
Pets - I'd like to have companions that could maybe join you and give you buffs ( would help people playing solo perhaps?)
PVP (I'm not sure how to title this ha, I think it would be cool if you could compete with your friends or other people to see who can get through the levels first? The winner get's cool weapons/items, adds a new aspect to the game).

Hope you guys enjoy the review and grab this game!

Here is some gameplay that shows the game in all its glory!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PAiFjTpGunk&feature=youtu.be

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
Cute, fun and lots of replay value for solo and coop players alike!

The content currently available in the game isn't massive as of yet. However, for ONCE an early access game releases with a very solid foundation and no confusion of what it wants to be or trying to be, top it off with decent optimization and very fluid and smooth gun play. Imo, this makes the price well worth it. 

I wish the dev team a ton of success and I can't wait to see what else they add to the game in the coming months!

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game is an absolute blast! Gun-play and movement is generally fast-paced and feels very good, though there are some situations which make you feel pretty slow. The amount of varying synergies between all the items and abilities in the game is incredible. Most weapons feel good to use; I think there's only one weapon I currently dislike and more than a handful that I adore.

The maps get old really quick, especially since you go through them in the same order with generally little variation in everything but drops. I believe the roguelite nature of the game would be slightly more enjoyable if a certain ability that allows you to store your talent points was unlocked or available from the start. The two current heroes don't seem equally balanced, as one doles out way more damage at the cost of semi-useful crowd-controlling abilities. However, it does require a bit of progression to unlock the second hero, so perhaps there will be "side-grade" heroes in the future.

Overall, I'm inclined to say that the current state the game is in seems worth the current price of admission. Core gameplay is repetitive as expected, but the already large amount of variation in scrolls and weapons combined with the slick controls makes it enjoyable to replay. With more maps, tile variation, heroes, and perhaps game modes, I can see this being a pretty solid FPS roguelite similar to Dead Cells.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review: Surprisingly good so far, the translations as of right now can be a bit iffy but the gameplay feels great and is a mash up of a first person shooter, Rogue-lite, and Borderlands/Diablo style loot system where guns can drop with varying rarities and bonus stats. The Rogue-lite aspect comes in via build defining passives through scrolls and goblets as well as an overarching progression tree that you spend what you've earned at the end of each of your runs on. Even as it is right now I would say it's pretty worth it if there's more things coming down the line for this game.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
This game has a lot in common with Immortal Redneck (they are both FPS roguelite games, after all), but it does have several of it's own takes on the formula.

Even in the initial Early Access release everything is well polished and solid.  The basic combat all feels really good, there are nice variety in weapons, and I didn't run into any bugs in the first few hours.  

I hope that they keep updating, adding new worlds, enemies and weapons.  Even so, it's already worth the $10 launch price if the concept interests you.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
it's the first time i see a roguelike/fps game like this one and its not bad at all, it is a Great if i say so my self, the game has  good mechanics and awesome gameplay but also this game is not going to give you countless of hours of entertainment, yet, the game is still in early access so dont expect much more, but it still going to give you good amount of time for you to learn the game and enjoy it to the last bit.
as i said the game still in development so it lacks some features, but if it is weapons you seek you will find a good variety of them, enough to make the game look fresh everytime you start a run.
Two of few issues i encountered was a tiny little bit of delay between you and the player you're playing with, the hitboxes on you're character and the dash when you're fighting a boss (at least the 1st).
I sincerely recommend you to play this game with friends but if you don't have any and dont want to be all by your self you still have match making, yes this little game has matchmaking but only if you're level 10 thats the shittiest part.
if you're doubting buying this game just try it out you have nothing to lose if you dont like it you can always refound, i strongly recommend anyone that likes roguelike games to try it out.

title: Gunfire Reborn
review:
What a pleasant surprise! 

This is a great little game that feels well-polished, especially for being in early access. There are about 30 weapons which you can unlock by doing a variety of small challenges. On top of that, this game has a great progression system which you can slowly work on unlocking to grant you passive perks. Apparently, there is four-player co-op which I have not yet tried, and another character that can be unlocked. 

I am very excited to see what the future holds in store for this game!

title: Gunfire Reborn

Okay first off. Great game for 10.43$ I was looking for a fun game to play and stumbled across this one. Great so far. lemme list why
-Rogue like
-Multiple weapons/ randomized
-Feels pretty polished for early access game and I'm only 40 mins in.
-Controller support
- Stable frame rate which is rare for games in early access.
Buttt there are some cons.
-Enemies feel repetitive
-Rooms feel same, Almost all have same linear layout
- Only 2 heros.
-Not that many guns
So I'd rate this a 6.5-7 out of 10 which is good but there is room for improvement which is promising because again this game is in early access.
